column2: AUSTIN, Tex. -- I've done my share of griping about the prevalence of branding all over South by Southwest, which, good economy or bad, is absolutely everywhere. On banners behind, beside, below and underneath bands as they play. On credential laminates, posters, T-shirts, tote bags, cars, trucks and monitor screens. Even the key card for my hotel room is an advertisement for a music tech company. As visual pitches, they verge on predatory, crowding their way into your every line of sight whether you like it or not. Like the bands, the sponsors at South by Southwest go all out for attention.

Professor and Dean Emeritus at Columbia Law School. Service Sunday, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to the Alzheimer's Association.

THOUGH some might beg to differ, Joseph Szabo regards Jones Beach as ''the best place to be in the summertime.'' Mr. Szabo, a photographer and former high school teacher, whose iconic images of Long Island teenagers have inspired the likes of Bruce Weber, Terry Richardson, Sofia Coppola and Juergen Teller, spent three decades strolling the sand there, candidly shooting its rather remarkable sunbathers. The oft-amusing results, which have been compiled into a book, are replete with big hair, big muscles, barely-there swimwear and exuberantly oiled skin -- not exactly ''Wish You Were Here'' postcard material, but just as intriguing. ''Jones Beach'' by Joseph Szabo, $35, available April 1 from Abrams.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, March 6th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. NAMED for the seminal 1981 collection in which they were first introduced, Vivienne Westwood's buckled Pirate boots have gone on to become a classic, worn by every groovy style icon from Madonna to Kate Moss. As the fashion blogger Garance Doré put it, they are ''the official footwear of the coolest girls I know.'' Not surprisingly, they are also some of the hardest to come by -- or, at least, were. Once available only at Vivienne Westwood shops (the closest? London), they are now being sold on Net-a-porter. The online retailer has three styles: black suede with black leather straps; black suede with tan leather straps; and a tan suede with tan leather straps that, alas, has already sold out. But the site promises that more stock is on its way. Vivienne Westwood Pirate boots, $510 at netaporter.com.

THOUGH some might beg to differ, Joseph Szabo regards Jones Beach as ''the best place to be in the summertime.'' Mr. Szabo, a photographer and former high school teacher, whose iconic images of Long Island teenagers have inspired the likes of Bruce Weber, Terry Richardson, Sofia Coppola and Juergen Teller, spent three decades strolling the sand there, candidly shooting its rather remarkable sunbathers. The oft-amusing results, which have been compiled into a book, are replete with big hair, big muscles, barely-there swimwear and exuberantly oiled skin -- not exactly ''Wish You Were Here'' postcard material, but just as intriguing. ''Jones Beach'' by Joseph Szabo, $35, available April 1 from Abrams.

MERRILL--Marion, age 80, passed peacefully at home March 18th while she was surrounded by family and loved ones. She was the proud wife of 50 years to Robert Merrill and mother to David Merrill (Nancy Castle) and Lizanne Merrill (Samy Brahimy) and grandmother to Gracie Brahimy, Jesse Merrill and Clara Brahimy. Marion began her music studies in Michigan with her father, making her first piano recital appearance at the age of five, in Detroit. She was a scholarship student at the Julliard School with contemporaries such as Van Cliburn, Leontyne Price and Charles Wadsworth. Upon graduation, she had an active concert and TV career throughout the United States. She gave up her own career after her marriage to devote herself to raising their two children and give musical support to her husband. Marion did return to music and served as a full time piano accompanist to Robert Merrill. The couple performed with great public and critical acclaim throughout the world. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to the Robert Merrill Voice Scholarship fund at the Julliard School 60 Lincoln Center Plaza or call 212-799-5000 ext 692. Services were held privately.

Cambodia will turn 14 sites used by the murderous Khmer Rouge regime into tourist attractions. Among them are ammunition warehouses and the homes that were used by leaders of the Khmer Rouge, the regime that killed upward of 1.7 million Cambodians during its rule from 1975 to 1979. The sites are mostly found around the jungles near Anlong Veng, a former Khmer Rouge stronghold 180 miles north of the capital of Phnom Penh and home to many killing fields. A focal point will likely be the cremation site of Pol Pot (above), the Khmer Rouge leader who died under house arrest in 1998 near the Chong Chom border crossing to Thailand.

8 P.M. (Discovery, Animal Planet) LIFEOprah Winfrey narrates this 11-part nature series, which explores the adaptability and diversity of life on earth -- culling among the 30 million or so animal and plant species here -- from the spectacular to the downright bizarre. Images were captured in high definition using equipment like a ''yogi cam,'' which can track smoothly alongside migrating reindeer and elephants, and an intricate cable rigging that enabled crews to ''fly'' a camera through thousands of monarch butterflies. The survey begins with ''Challenges of Life,'' which explores survival strategies like those of the stalk-eyed fly, which inflates its head to impress females; Kenyan cheetahs who band together to hunt large prey; and monkeys in Brazil that use tools resembling a hammer and anvil to crack nuts. ''Reptiles and Amphibians,'' at 9, shows a pebble toad escaping a tarantula by bouncing down a rock face; a basilisk lizard running on water; a chameleon snatching its prey with its tongue; and the savage hunting techniques of the Komodo dragon. (Above, a sengi on the move.) 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE A discussion of the health care bill gets going with Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin; Representative Deborah Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida; and Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas. It continues with Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina; Representative Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland; Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky; and Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, and with Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

MCLAREN, one of the most successful teams in Formula One history, has spun off a company to sell road cars. That company, McLaren Automotive, introduced on Thursday its first entry, the MP4-12C, a two-seat, midengine supercar powered by a twin-turbocharged V-8. The car goes on sale in the first half of 2011. According to reports, the 12C has a top speed of more than 200 miles per hour. The Associated Press said the starting price would be $191,127.

Singapore isn't lacking for high-end lodgings, but the Las Vegas Sands hopes to top them all with its new Marina Bay Sands Resort, which features a dizzying array of luxury offerings. The resort, which has its ''preview opening'' set for April 27, followed by a grand opening on June 23, is said to cost $5.4 billion. So what does $5.4 billion get you? The dazzling 55-story complex (rendering above), designed by Moshe Safdie, will include three hotel towers (with 963 rooms total) connected by a single rooftop Sky Park, a museum, shops and a Vegas-style casino.
WILLIAMSBURG CONDO $1,295,000

Correction Appended It was a bright, warm, blue-skied December afternoon in Central City, New Orleans, and in this neighborhood of humble shotgun houses and overgrown empty lots, a convoy of white trucks and trailers idled incongruously while unmarked police cars blocked intersections nearby. On any other morning, a police presence would have meant more bad news: in a city that has one of the highest homicide rates in the United States, this neighborhood -- roughly a mile from the French Quarter -- has a murder rate that, in recent years, has hit quadruple that of the city as a whole. This morning, however, the 20 drivers, as well as 80 other crew members who hefted and humped a boggling array of gear at the tumbledown corner of Second Street and South Liberty, had anything but murder in mind: they were six hours into a day of filming the third episode of ''Treme,'' David Simon's new HBO drama -- co-created by the seasoned television writer and producer Eric Overmyer -- which is set in post-Katrina New Orleans and will make its debut on April 11. The production was only two scenes into the six on the call sheet; at that pace, they were looking at a 15-hour marathon -- yet another in the 11-day ultramarathon that shooting an hour of episodic television on location can demand. As the novelist George Pelecanos, a staff writer on ''Treme,'' told me of the years he spent on set as a writer-producer on ''The Wire,'' Simon's breakthrough series: ''If you got out with a 12-hour day, that was the luckiest day of the series. Try doing that for seven months straight. Only young people can do it. You don't see many people in their 50s carrying around lights.''

East After picking up the first N.C.A.A. tournament victory in CORNELL's history and the first for the Ivy League since 1998, the Big Red may try to get greedy against WISCONSIN. Years of watching Princeton's backdoor offense has caused many to equate the Ivies with low scoring, but Cornell averages 75.4 points, compared with the Badgers' 67. Tenth-seeded MISSOURI of the Big 12 takes on No. 2 WEST VIRGINIA of the Big East, which has only three remaining teams in the tournament. The Big East led all conferences with eight berths. Four of the Big 12's seven teams are still alive.

VERDONE--Sarah. Cherished wife of Tucker Viemeister and mother of Josephine and Louisa, died on March 11, 2010 at the age of 45. Surrounded by those who loved her, Sarah died peacefully at home after an extraordinarily brave battle with cancer that ended her all-too-short time with us. Sarah gave every ounce of herself to living throughout her illness supported by countless friends and her loving sisters and brothers: Michael Verdone, Anne Kane, Garrett Verdone, Susan Jankolovits, Moriah Sterling, Therese Wilson. Her absence will not only be felt by those who knew her intimately and cared for her deeply, but also by those who read her pithy reviews and commentaries on art, design, fashion, food and travel. A great beauty, generous, funny and deeply empathetic, Sarah was a writer who kept family at the center of her life. Tucker's love and commitment, Josephine's grace and Louisa's spirit sustained her in life and will continue to bear witness to her memory.

GORDON--Irving S. 81, died peacefully at home after a valiant 17 year struggle with Lymphoma then Myelodysplasia. An early leader in the development of dry cargo grain shipment, he was widely respected in the international shipping world for the duration of his 50 year career. He was always involved in Zionist then Israeli affairs, was an amateur biblical archaeologist and Egyptologist, and an award-winning master craftsman. Ever a man of extraordinary generosity of spirit and great personal strength, he is survived by his loving wife, of 61 years, Adina, his children Mark and Miriam, his grandchildren Josh, Jena, Adam, and David, his daughter-in-law Nancy, son-in-law Bruce (Medoff), grand daughter-in-law Laura and many loving nieces, nephews, and other cherished relatives. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Lymphoma Research Foundation and the Gordon-Gindi Fund at the JCC, Tenafly, NJ. Service 11:30am Sunday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

I started noticing them a few years ago. They were stuck onto the rear windows of cars and S.U.V.'s, white oval stickers reading ''OBX.'' It was puzzling to me. What was OBX? An exclusive private school? A secret society? These letters were all over Bergen County, and inquiring minds (my own) wanted to know -- what was OBX and how could I get some? When I finally figured out the code -- the abbreviation is for the Outer Banks of North Carolina -- I began to notice other oval stickers: LBI, DRB, MTK, all representing cool beach towns I had never visited. But at least other lucky drivers had been to Long Beach Island or Delray Beach or Montauk, probably on a regular basis. Perhaps a few even have an amazing second home in DRB or OBX.

LORENC--Irene. New York lost one of its greatest fans on March 13th - Irene Lorenc. Born on April 6, 1946, Irene was a child of Holocaust survivors, escaping with her family from former Czechoslovakia from religious and political persecution, building a new life in freedom for her family in Germany. No obstacles were ever too high for her to overcome for her family. Her powerful love, intelligence and commitment will shine forever in her family in New York and Munich. Beautiful wife of Karel Lorenc, loving mother of Edith and Jonathan Fassberg, Misha and Tom Fechtner and Tommy Fechtner and the most devoted grandmother to Ron, Yael, Gil, Sarah, Emily and Simon. Her courage, intelligence and love was extraordinary. She was laid to rest in peace in Prague next to her parents. Her boundless generosity and love will live in us forever. With love forever, her family.

JAGUAR executives are probably sitting around sighing and saying, ''It was nice while it lasted.'' They would be referring to the fact that Jaguar, in a tie with Buick, was at the top of last year's Vehicle Dependability Study from J. D. Power & Associates. It was a particularly sweet victory for Jaguar and Buick because they had edged Lexus from first place, where it had ruled for the previous 13 years. But in this year's Vehicle Dependability Study, released Thursday, Jaguar plunged to 23rd place.

CAIGAN--Linda, was born in Albany, NY in 1933 to Kate and Joe Mandelbaum. She is survived by her daughter Emily (and Khem) and son Peter (and Nancy), by her grandchildren Tuli, Gage, Lindsay, and Ali, by her in-laws Dr. Herbert I. Cohen and Amy S. Cohen, and by her nephews Jay and Lee Buck. Her husband, Robert A. Caigan, died in 1978, and her sister, Joan Buck, died in 1966. Linda earned her BA from Cornell and her MSW from Columbia. She was a social worker at WJCC and Phoenix in the 60s. In the early 70s she co-founded and worked at the Hallen School for children with learning disabilities. In the 80s, as head of Family Life Education for WJCS, she lead workshops and groups. For the past 15 years she was practicing as a mental imagery therapist and helped to develop the alternative care programs at White Plains Hospital. Linda died peacefully on March 12 and the funeral was on March 14. Contributions in Linda's honor may be made to America Institute for Mental Imagery (AIMI), 16 E. 96th Street, 1A, New York 10128. Email petemusic@aol.com for information about a memorial service to be held in Manhattan in April.

THE French handbag designer Jerome Dreyfuss has opened his first store in the United States, a month ahead of his wife Isabel Marant's adjacent shop in SoHo. It's a big, bright, open space, designed to look like a Modernist cabin: all white tiles and polished wood, with chirping bird sounds and a modular Ron Arad Do-Lo-Res sofa. Like his slouchy, insouciantly chic handbags, the space, as Mr. Dreyfuss sees it, could use some wear and tear. ''I don't like when things are too new, too clean,'' he said. ''Go ahead, stomp around in your heels.'' Along with his colorful spring collection, shoppers will find a few past favorites that are exclusive to the store, like the Twee (pictured) in gray python, brushed to feel like suede; and, later this year, his new capsule collection of leather jackets, thoughtfully designed so each style can be worn in different ways. ''I'm having fun making women smile,'' he said.

REMEMBER when a poster with a little French street waif or a pair of cat's eyes was enough to sell a Broadway show? Now, with advertising trying to stand out on television, the Internet and mobile devices, choosing the right Broadway campaign often means finding a look that is flexible enough for different platforms, and one that also catches attention quickly. For the coming revival of ''La Cage aux Folles,'' Sonia Friedman, one of the producers, hung poster candidates on her office walls for a week, then asked herself, ''Do I want to live with this for the rest of my life?''

GROSSMAN--Bella S.,daughter of Henry and Celia Seidenberg, in her 105th year. A true renaissance woman, loving, caring, smart, admired, respected and passionate in her beliefs and values. Beloved wife for 50 years of the late Jacob, dear sister of Edith and the late Zipporah, Pearl, and Ethel, devoted mother to Bob and Annamae Grossman and Ruth and Jess Karter; incredible grandmother of Michael and Marcia, Philip and Rhonda, John and Sonia, Linda and Larry, David, and Amy and Ron; cherished great-grandmother to Melissa and Scott, Lisa, Andrew, Kara, Melissa, Michelle, Kimberly, Max, Elizabeth and Katherine, proud great-great-grandmother to Jacob and Emma. She will also be greatly missed by the children and grandchildren of her wonderful friend and companion of 17 years, the late Harold Ruthizer as well as by the very many nieces, nephews and friends who loved her dearly. She was a wonderful role model for all those whose lives she touched being both educator and mentor professionally as well as personally. NEEDHAM, James W.,78, died peacefully after a long illness March 13, 2010 in New York City. The son of W. Reuel and Cecilia Coad Needham, he was born in Ithaca, NY and grew up in Southern California during World War II. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard, majoring in poker. Upon graduation from Stanford Business School he worked for Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in the treasurer's department. He began his Wall Street career at White, Weld and was Chief Financial Officer at the time of its sale to Merrill Lynch, where he then worked in international investment banking. In 1985 he joined Florence Fearrington, Inc. as Chairman. He retired when the firm was sold in 1997 to U.S. Trust Company of New York. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Florence, his daughter Elizabeth (Peter Mark) of Old Greenwich, CT, his son John (Justine) of Littleton, CO, and four grandchildren, Ethan and Kathryn Mark and Cecilia and Evelyn Needham. Jim was a collector of antiquarian natural history books, a longtime member of The Grolier Club and the consummate bookman. He was a benefactor of several institutions, among them Harvard where he endowed two Chairs, including one in Book Conservation. For many years, he served on the Harvard University Library Visiting Committee. There will be a reception in his honor at The Grolier Club on Easter Monday 5:30-7:30pm.

''Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,'' by Jane Austen and Seth Grahame-Smith, captivated readers and unleashed a whole new genre. Grahame-Smith's follow-up, ''Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter,'' hit bookstores this month, to be followed this spring by ''Jane Slayre'' and ''Android Karenina.'' As publishers run out of 19th-century classics to ransack, can these more contemporary titles be far behind?

WARREN--William, 73, died March 17, 2010 in Rancho Santa Fe, California. The cause of death was Alzheimer's disease. A true man's man, yet loved by women, Bill had a wonderful wry sense of humor. Well known for his five-alarm chili, he loved nothing better than cooking for the Sunday football gang. Bill, with his beloved wife Bobbi at his side, enjoyed the best life had to offer - travel, entertainment, sports, golf and his favorite spirit, Johnny Walker Black. If there were ever a song for Bill, it would be "My Way". His family, many friends and business associates will miss him terribly. After graduating from Alfred University, Bill became a titan of the reinsurance business, ultimately becoming the Chairman of National Reinsurance Co. Over his many years in the business, he was admired and loved by all those he worked with. Born April 29, 1936, in Peekskill, New York, he was the only surviving child of Mildred and Alfred Warren. His brother Al is deceased. His marriage to his first wife Jean, with whom he had three children, ended with her death. Bill is survived by his wife of twenty four years, Bobbi, his daughters Wendy, Carol and Elaine, and a plethora of stepchildren and grandchildren who all loved him and were loved by him. Donations in his memory can be made to the Burnham Institute for Medical Research in La Jolla, CA.

CAVE HOME, FESTUS, MO.In 2003, Curt and Deborah Sleeper and their two children were living in a cramped Missouri ranch house when they saw an eBay offering for three acres with an empty sandstone cave. They planned to build on the land, but they soon began to imagine the benefits of living like bears. The former sandstone quarry offered 15,000 square feet of naturally insulated space -- ample room for a pool table and even a basketball court -- and would eliminate the family's heating and cooling bills. The Sleepers lived under tents in the rear of the cave while they built the house themselves. They did laundry in buckets while Curt drafted the architectural plans; the family hammered, sanded and laid tile together. The finished home feels ''very private, very peaceful and nurturing,'' Deborah says. ''The inside of the house feels like you're outdoors without the discomfort of hot or cold.'' There are some unique challenges to living in the cave: three industrial-size dehumidifiers are needed to pump out roughly 60 gallons of water every day (which are redirected to an outdoor irrigation system), and the bare walls shed sand. The Sleepers have placed large umbrellas or interior roofs over areas like the kitchen that need to stay sand-free -- not least of all for the couple's 1-year-old son, Wes. WATER-TOWER APARTMENT, ESSEN, GERMANYA decade ago, the architects Arnim Koch and Michael Dahms were working on a project for the municipal utility of Essen, Germany, when they became enamored with a stately 1905 water tower in a wooded area to the south of the city. The tower had become obsolete, and the architects pooled their money to purchase it. The pair set about designing eight floors into the tower's base, which are now home to two rental apartments, a real estate agency and a communications business. Thomas Kalthoff, a young financial adviser, lives on the fourth and fifth floors of the converted tower with his girlfriend, Katharina, and his cat, Oskar. ''I see my apartment as a nice counterbalance to my work life,'' Kalthoff said. ''My daily work is not so surprising.'' Dahms and Koch's design recalls the building's industrial past but also reshapes it. Custom-designed cabinetry accommodates the tower's sloping walls, which narrow as they rise toward the former water tank. There are exposed concrete interiors but also floor-to-ceiling windows that offer sweeping views from Kalthoff's apartment when storms roll in. ''The most pride we take,'' Koch says, ''is that we were able to breathe life into something that had no use.'' PHOTOGRAPHS BY LARS TUNBJORK FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES

Davey Johnson, a former Mets manager, is a senior adviser to the Washington Nationals. He returned to Manhattan last week to promote a new MSG Network series, ''The Lineup: New York's All-Time Best Baseball Players.'' FIERTZ--Beverly Fowle, South Woodstock, VT. Married to high school sweetheart, raised three sons, resided 20 years in Germany and Switzerland, earned a law degree at age 55, and served on numerous Woodstock, VT area community boards, Bev Fiertz lived life fully during her 78 years that concluded on Monday, March 8. She successfully fought various ailments over the past years, but unexpectedly died at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center during heart surgery. The daughter of Margaret and Edwin Fowle, Bev was born in Flushing, NY on May 6, 1931, and grew-up in Manhasset, NY. A proud member of Manhasset High School '49, she graduated from Wheaton College (MA) in 1953. In 1954, she married Alden Fiertz, whom she had met in 9th grade French class. After she gave birth to three sons, the family moved from Ramsey, NJ to Duesseldorf, Germany in 1968, to Lausanne, Switzerland in 1972 and then to Geneva in 1979. Later, frustrated by the exploitation of several female friends by the legal system, she decided to fulfill a long-standing desire to become a lawyer even though it had been 30 years since she attended college. Bev graduated in 1986 from Vermont Law School, the first of ultimately many senior students. She always appreciated the warm reception from her classmates, despite their differences in age and experience. After passing the Vermont Bar Exam on her first try, Bev worked for Vermont Legal Aid before opening her law practice in South Woodstock, VT with a focus on serving low-income victims of domestic abuse. In addition to being an avid skier and tennis player, she enjoyed painting and sculpting. She was also an intrepid traveler, who visited all seven continents, and was fluent in both French and German. She particularly enjoyed her three visits each to the Arctic and Antarctica. She was dedicated to each of the communities she lived in and volunteered on many boards. These included such roles as President of the American Women's Clubs of Duesseldorf and Lausanne, a six year Trustee of Wheaton College, appointed Chair of the Vermont Human Services Board by Governor Dean, Chair of The South Woodstock Fire Department, Secretary of the Ottaqueechee Health Foundation, and as member of the boards of The New Hampshire Charitable Foundation-Upper Valley Region, the Faulkner Trust, and Woodstock's Thompson Senior Center. She proudly represented Wheaton College at the recent inauguration of Dr. Jim Yong Kim as Dartmouth College President. Her beloved husband Alden survives Bev, as do her sons Carey of Salisbury, CT, Randy of Bethesda, MD, and Stuart of London, England, and their wives Kim, Carol and Tina. She leaves behind seven grandchildren: Charles, Henry, Maggie, Katja, Callie, Mimi, and Louisa, and sister Janis Bigelow of Cotuit, MA, brother Bruce Fowle of New York City, and their families. A celebration of Bev's life is planned for a later date when her treasured garden is in bloom. Memorial contributions may be made to either an educational fund being established in her name at The Upper Valley Haven, 713 Hartford Avenue, White River Junction, VT 05001 or to the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation of Vermont, 137 Elm Street, Montpelier, VT 05402.

THE NEWS A plan to build new housing for Jews in disputed East Jerusalem mutated into one of the most serious conflicts between the United States and Israel in two decades. BEHIND THE NEWS The proposal for 1,600 new housing units, unveiled the previous week during a visit by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., met with sharp criticism from the Obama administration, which insisted that it be abandoned. The United States wants Israel to commit to substantive negotiations with the Palestinians. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the housing plan was not negotiable.

Pop Growing up in Benin, ANGÉLIQUE KIDJO didn't hear only African music. From America there were soul and Santana; from India there were Bollywood musicals. Her father loved jazz. They all had an effect on the music she would make herself , with her strong, wide-open voice riding African-rooted but thoroughly international arrangements. (Eventually Santana would record one of her songs: ''Adouma.'')

There is the television set. There is the Web. And there are television shows on the Web. But the Web on the television set? Some say television is a ''lean back'' medium, unsuited to the forward-curving spines of this Web-surfing epoch. But The New York Times reported last week that Google and Intel have joined the effort to marry the two media, teaming up with Sony to develop Google TV. The idea: You'll be able to curl up on a living room couch, Google your blind date, watch an endless stream of cat videos from YouTube and then tweet your friends about it all as easily as you now switch from ESPN to HBO to the Travel Channel. Perhaps one more step on the way to Google ubiquity. Click.

Classical They have laid down their arms, made peace and colonized each other. The parties here are traditional proponents of big-boned, rich, Romantic performances on one side and period-performance practitioners on the other -- musicians who play replicas of the instruments used when old music was composed and who seek to adopt the earlier style of playing. Now conductors and orchestras often incorporate whiffs of period practices, like swifter tempos, less vibrato and smaller ensembles for the music of Mozart, Haydn and others. The period guys have become less dogmatic and more flexible.

Art This year the first days of spring coincide nicely with ASIA WEEK, a once-a-year flowering of art at Manhattan auction houses, fairs, galleries and museums. At the Asia Society and Museum ''PILGRIMAGE AND BUDDHIST ART'' explores a tradition that dates from the first century A.D.: journeying to the sites of major events of the Buddha's life. It will include ritual objects and travel accessories, like reliquaries and prayer wheels, that have never been seen in public. Through June 20, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400, asiasociety.org.

AT first glance ''How to Train Your Dragon,'' the new action-adventure film from DreamWorks Animation based on the whimsical children's book by Cressida Cowell, does not seem to share much with the Coen brothers' ''No Country for Old Men'' or M. Night Shyamalan's ''Village.'' But a closer look reveals some similarities. From washed-out landscapes to minimally lighted rooms, the Nordic locations in ''Dragon'' feel more lived in and rough edged -- more realistic -- than one typically finds in animation. This comes from the influence of an outsider, the Oscar-nominated cinematographer Roger Deakins. Best known for his work on ''A Beautiful Mind,'' ''The Shawshank Redemption'' and Coen brothers' films, Mr. Deakins had little experience working in animation, save for some consulting on ''Wall-E.'' But as the co-directors of ''Dragon,'' Dean DeBlois and Chris Sanders (''Lilo & Stitch''), were thinking of a way to distinguish their film from other animated work, they decided to bring in someone who could see light in a different way. Below Mr. Deakins, Mr. DeBlois and Mr. Sanders discuss how they achieved the film's look.

CHRISTY--Arthur H. Slipped away from us on March 12, 2010, at the age of 86. He was the beloved husband and friend of his dear wife, Gloria Garvin Christy, and one of two sons of Francis T. and Catherine Damon Christy. He was born in Brooklyn and educated at Poly Prep, Deerfield Academy and Yale. Joining the Navy during WWII, he became the youngest commander of a commissioned ship, the SC1038, which was active in the Pacific theater. Graduating from Columbia Law School in 1949, he eventually entered public service as the Assistant Attorney General of New York in the Saratoga County Investigation. In 1953 he was appointed an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, participating in the successful prosecution of mobster Frank Costello. In 1955 he became Chief of the Criminal Division of the office, later the Chief Assistant and then was appointed United States Attorney in 1958. His last case was the successful prosecution of Vito Genovese, alleged head of the Mafia, on drug charges. Entering private practice, he practiced first with his father in Christy, Frey & Christy, and then formed the firm of Christy & Viener in 1976. In 1979 he was named the first Special Prosecutor under the Ethics in Government Act, investigating allegations made against Hamilton Jordan, then Chief of Staff to President Jimmy Carter. Christy was active in leadership roles of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the Community Service Society, the New York Heart Association and the Brooklyn Hospital. A scrimshander, he carved over 150 pieces and presented the engraved teeth to friends. Admired by all who knew him, he is survived by his son Duncan and his children Elizabeth and Ethan; his daughter Alexandra and her husband David Coggeshall and their children Catherine ("Cassie") and Walker; and stepdaughters Nicola Hesse and Debbe Rush.

ERICKSON--Nancee, passed away on Friday, March 12th, 2010 at her home in San Francisco, CA. She is survived by her beloved husband John, her two sons Nelson and Justin, her daughter-in-law, Betsy, her mother Marilyn Singer, her two brothers Richard and Donald, sisters-in-law, Martha, Lori and Mary, her three nieces, Edie, Zinnia and Arden, as well as by her cousins, godchildren and numerous loving friends throughout the world. Nancee was a loving wife, a devoted mother, a wonderful friend, and an elegant hostess, always with an endearing smile, warm heart, and quick wit. She delighted in bringing people together to build new friendships for herself and others. Nancee's artistry and personal contributions have had a deep and lasting influence on the communities where she lived. She will long be remembered for her contributions. Born in San Francisco on Veterans Day, 1947, Nancee and her brothers were raised in Portland, OR. Always with a great fondness for the fine arts, Nancee graduated with a degree in art history from Scripps College in Claremont, CA. She took this passion to Boston, MA, where she pursued a doctoral degree through programs at Harvard and Boston University and taught art history courses to college-level students. She met her husband John in Boston, and soon after their marriage in 1972 they began a life together in San Francisco where she continued her doctoral studies at Stanford University. In addition to being a full-time mother, homemaker, and gourmet chef, Nancee devoted her time, creativity, and imagination to a number of social and cultural causes in San Francisco, on Nantucket Island, and elsewhere. Nancee became deeply involved with community organizations, including the Junior League and Enterprise for High School Students (EHSS), a city-wide youth development agency that guides teens in exploring career interests, finding and retaining jobs and experiential learning. Together with her good friend, Toby Rose, Nancee co-founded the San Francisco Fall Antiques Show in 1981, establishing the show as the major fundraising event for EHSS. The San Francisco Fall Antiques Show continues today as the oldest continuously operating international antiques show on the West Coast. Aside from her work with EHSS, Nancee also held board positions with the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, Fort Mason Center, and the Town and Country Club. Nancee was also committed to educational causes. She involved herself deeply in her sons' schools, was an active member of Achievement Rewards for College Sciences (ARCS), and was a champion for special education programs. Most recently, Nancee devoted much of her time to the Children's Theatre Association of San Francisco. Nancee delighted in cultivating new artistic talents. She was a gifted needleworker, teacher and collector of fine decorative arts. Her elaborate pieces adorn her home as well as the Christmas trees of friends and family. Nancee also wove beautiful lightship baskets during her summers on Nantucket. Her passion for the arts led her to work closely with the Nantucket Historical Association (NHA) to create the 1800 House, which is at the heart of the NHA's educational program, a program dedicated to celebrating and reviving Nantucket's rich tradition in historic decorative arts and crafts. Nancee endeared herself to many during her short yet fruitful life. Although she is no longer with us, her impeccable taste, vibrant spirit, and resplendent personality will continue to touch and inspire the lives of everyone from her immediate family to those she met while walking her beloved golden retrievers on the shores of Crissy Field in San Francisco and the Tuppancy Links on Nantucket Island. The care and love she showered on her husband and sons will be missed. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on Thursday, March 25th at Grace Cathedral and also during the Summer on Nantucket. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Nantucket Historical Association with a specific designation to the 1800 House (P.O. Box 1016, Nantucket, MA 02554; 508-228-1894). Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco (Golden Gate Park, 50 Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive, San Francisco, CA 94118; 415-750-3546); Achievement Rewards for College Scientists (ARCS Foundation, Inc. NCC, P.O. Box 29405, San Francisco, CA 94129; 415-561-6537); or The Children's Theatre Association of San Francisco (CTA, P.O. Box 29006, San Francisco, CA 94129; 415-248-2677).

With cash in shorter supply across much of the economy, more people have turned to a form of commerce that existed before cash was invented: bartering. Craigslist started a barter category on its site in 2001 and is now posting about 200,000 new barter ads a month. That's up 10 percent from February of last year, which in turn was up about 100 percent from February 2008, according to its chief executive, Jim Buckmaster. (He explained that the ''stupendous'' growth rate had cooled along with the worst of the economic crisis.) But the appeal is clear: via bartering, consumers can use their time, skills and possessions instead of money to obtain goods and services like piano lessons, dental work and dog training -- and to meet new people along the way.

TAMPA, Fla. - Kevin Towers wears a National League championship ring from 1998, with ''SD'' on the face, a reminder that he built a World Series team as general manager of the San Diego Padres. But the wounds from losing that series, to the Yankees in a sweep, remain. Towers, who officially joined the Yankees on Tuesday as special assignment scout, spotted Tino Martinez in the clubhouse and reminded him that the 2-2 pitch from Mark Langston should have been a strike. There was no mistaking the reference: With two out in the seventh inning of Game 1 of the World Series, with the scored tied, Martinez took a 2-2 pitch from Langston down the middle. Umpire Rich Garcia called it a ball, and Martinez crushed a grand slam on the next pitch. The Padres never recovered.

Film The setup of Bryan Poyser's viciously amusing comedy ''LOVERS OF HATE'' suggests Sam Shepard's ''True West'' dragged into the bedroom and stripped of mythic connotations. Two brothers -- Rudy (Chris Doubek), a bitter deadbeat would-be novelist who is about to be divorced, and his younger brother, Paul (Alex Karpovsky), a successful author of a ''Harry Potter''-like book franchise -- reunite during Paul's latest book tour. Paul has always had eyes for Rudy's wife, Diana (Heather Kafka), and, after an uncomfortable dinner filled with lies and game playing, Diana invites herself to Paul's borrowed mountain chalet in Park City, Utah, where they pounce on each other. Unbeknownst to them Rudy steals onto the property, spies on them and tries to sabotage their idyll with nasty tricks.

BROPHY--Ira N.,88, died peacefully on March 17, 2010, surrounded by his wife of 64 years, Betty (Cohen); his daughters Susan, Melissa, and Nancy; his sons-in-law Jesse Spilka and Matthew Cooper, and his grandchildren Molly and Sam. Ira lived a rich, full life that included work, family, travel, photography, good food, music, politics, and public service. A graduate of Queens College and WWII veteran, Ira spent his early years as a marketing/sales executive before transitioning to a career in public service in 1971. His efforts for the NYC Office of Economic Development and Public Development Corporation to assist the printing industry and small businesses and develop a manufacturing center at the Brooklyn Army Terminal gave shape to the idealism that fueled his lifelong dedication to progressive politics. He also served as Congressman Jerrold Nadler's Campaign Treasurer; was the 1976 Democratic candidate for the NYS Senate in Nassau County's 8th District; and served as Board President of the South Shore Child Guidance Ctr in Freeport, NY. Funeral on March 21, at 10am, at Boulevard Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be directed to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee; Museum of Jewish Heritage in NYC; or South Shore Child Guidance.

LYING ON KUNMING LAKE AT THE SUMMER PALACE IN BEIJING, FEB. 18, 2010 Feng Xiwen, 22, a fourth-year medical student from Chengdu, Sichuan. ''This is my last winter break before I graduate, so I came to Beijing with a few friends. I really love traveling, and always do it during my school vacations. Sometimes I skip school to do it but don't tell my parents. I've been to Qinghai, Guangxi, but never to Beijing, because I thought it was too boring, with nothing to see. I came because I recently saw a movie called 'Summer Palace,' and there was the most beautiful scene, really short, set at the lake in the Summer Palace. So I decided I really wanted to come row a boat in this lake. I didn't know it was going to be frozen over! I came with a friend, who got lazy and went to find coffee. I trudged down to the lake by myself, got mud all over my shoes, and just lay down. The ice really stabbed into my back. On the train ride back to Chengdu, I decided I don't want to be a doctor anymore. It is a very difficult profession, and I didn't think it through clearly when I decided to go to medical school. I want to work in the film industry. You get to work everywhere in the world.'' As told to Xiyun Yang

PRITZKER--Margaret M. (nee Winsch) of New City and formerly of Larchmont, NY, passed away Thursday, March 11, 2010 at nearly 84 years of age, after a brief illness. She was born in Berlin, Germany in 1926, and survived World War II and the bombing of Berlin. She met her husband, Henry, while he was stationed in Berlin as a member of the United States Army. They were married March 24, 1956, and she came to the United States shortly thereafter. Subsequently, she worked several years in the laboratories of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, prior to raising a family. Margaret enjoyed opera and classical music, and was an avid reader and a student of history. Together with her husband she traveled the world. She was also a tireless volunteer, giving her time to Boy and Girl Scouts, Beth Emeth Synagogue in Larchmont and other organizations. She always will be remembered as a devoted wife to Henry, mother to son Daniel and daughter-in-law Kathleen, and daughter Debra. She truly loved her role as "Oma" to her grandchildren, Jonathan, Rebecca and Shannon Pritzker, and Alexis Browne. A memorial service was held on Friday, March 12, 2010 at Hellman Memorial Chapel, Spring Valley, NY. Shiva was observed at the home of Dr. Henry A. Pritzker. If desired, donations in her memory may be made to a charitable organization of your choice.

KATMANDU, Nepal -- Former Nepalese Prime Minister Girija Prasad Koirala, a pivotal figure in establishing Nepal's fragile democracy who also helped broker an end to the country's Maoist rebellion, died Saturday in Katmandu. He was 86. Nepalese leaders declared Sunday to be a national holiday, to allow public mourning of Koirala's death, and also ordered that the national flag be flown at half-staff. Koirala died at the home of his daughter after being in frail health.

CAVE HOME, FESTUS, MO.In 2003, Curt and Deborah Sleeper and their two children were living in a cramped Missouri ranch house when they saw an eBay offering for three acres with an empty sandstone cave. They planned to build on the land, but they soon began to imagine the benefits of living like bears. The former sandstone quarry offered 15,000 square feet of naturally insulated space -- ample room for a pool table and even a basketball court -- and would eliminate the family's heating and cooling bills. The Sleepers lived under tents in the rear of the cave while they built the house themselves. They did laundry in buckets while Curt drafted the architectural plans; the family hammered, sanded and laid tile together. The finished home feels ''very private, very peaceful and nurturing,'' Deborah says. ''The inside of the house feels like you're outdoors without the discomfort of hot or cold.'' There are some unique challenges to living in the cave: three industrial-size dehumidifiers are needed to pump out roughly 60 gallons of water every day (which are redirected to an outdoor irrigation system), and the bare walls shed sand. The Sleepers have placed large umbrellas or interior roofs over areas like the kitchen that need to stay sand-free -- not least of all for the couple's 1-year-old son, Wes. WATER-TOWER APARTMENT, ESSEN, GERMANYA decade ago, the architects Arnim Koch and Michael Dahms were working on a project for the municipal utility of Essen, Germany, when they became enamored with a stately 1905 water tower in a wooded area to the south of the city. The tower had become obsolete, and the architects pooled their money to purchase it. The pair set about designing eight floors into the tower's base, which are now home to two rental apartments, a real estate agency and a communications business. Thomas Kalthoff, a young financial adviser, lives on the fourth and fifth floors of the converted tower with his girlfriend, Katharina, and his cat, Oskar. ''I see my apartment as a nice counterbalance to my work life,'' Kalthoff said. ''My daily work is not so surprising.'' Dahms and Koch's design recalls the building's industrial past but also reshapes it. Custom-designed cabinetry accommodates the tower's sloping walls, which narrow as they rise toward the former water tank. There are exposed concrete interiors but also floor-to-ceiling windows that offer sweeping views from Kalthoff's apartment when storms roll in. ''The most pride we take,'' Koch says, ''is that we were able to breathe life into something that had no use.'' PHOTOGRAPHS BY LARS TUNBJORK FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES

ARONSON--Grambs, died March 2nd, age 94. Artist and illustrator of much acclaim, her late husband, James Aronson was a journalist and Hunter College professor. Grambs was loved and will be missed by her devoted family and friends.

BOYER--Marjorie Duncan Nice. Emerita Professor of History, York College, CUNY, died September 28, 2009. A specialist in travel in medieval France, her book, Medieval French Bridges: A History, was published by the Medieval Academy. She was born to Leonard Blaine Nice and Margaret Morse Nice in 1912. She met Carl B. Boyer in graduate school at Columbia. They married in 1935. She completed her PhD in History in 1958. Preceded in death by her husband, she is survived by four sons, nine grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Memorial service to be held June 19, 2010 at 11am, Durham Church, Durham, PA.

In 1956, the Austrian-born photographer Inge Morath traveled to Iran on assignment for Holiday magazine. She wanted to photograph the entire Silk Road, from southern Europe to the South China Sea, and thought of Iran as "a good start." James Levine will miss what would have been his final appearances with the Boston Symphony Orchestra this season, withdrawing from three weeks' worth of performances because of continuing problems with his back, the orchestra said on Monday. Mr. Levine, the conductor and music director of the Boston Symphony and the Metropolitan Opera, missed the opening of the Carnegie Hall season and key dates at the Met last fall when he pulled out to undergo an operation to repair a herniated disk. In March he canceled planned appearances at the Berlin Staatskapelle on the recommendation of his doctors, who said he should not travel while they adjusted his medication as part of his recovery from that surgery. In recent years, Mr. Levine has also had a cancerous cyst removed from his kidney and had rotator-cuff surgery to repair damage from an onstage fall.

Once, there was a spot, for one brief shining moment that was known as Camelot. And even though that spot was declared, in another context, by a different King Arthur, to be "a silly place," that kingdom and its knights are now set to make a serious return on television. On Monday, the Starz cable channel said that it was preparing a new series called "Camelot," based on the version of the Arthurian legend recounted in Thomas Malory's "Morte d'Arthur." Starz, which has recently found a hit in its sword-and-sandals adventure series "Spartacus: Blood and Sand," said "Camelot" will be written by Chris Chibnall, of the supernatural British dramas "Life on Mars" and "Torchwood," and produced by a team that includes Graham King ("The Departed," "Gangs of New York") and Morgan O'Sullivan and Michael Hirst (both of the Showtime period drama "The Tudors"). The 10-episode series is expected to begin production in June with episodes to start showing in 2011. No cast was announced -- Starz said in a statement that it was seeking "fresh talent combined with established faces" -- and no word if this "Camelot" will feature musical numbers with "footwork impeccable."

AUSTIN, Tex. -- The death on Wednesday of Alex Chilton, the singer and songwriter for the Memphis band Big Star, turned a reunion concert into a memorial. Mr. Chilton, who was 59, had his commercial peak when he was 16, singing "The Letter" with the Box Tops before he founded Big Star. While Big Star is regularly categorized as power pop for its obvious Beatles touches, its music also had Memphis twang and soul. Mr. Chilton's songs used subtle musical twists that only added to the yearning and stubbornness in his songs: starting in one key but suddenly sliding into another, deliberately making tempos and meters fluctuate. They were the kind of songs other songwriters admire.

Fresh from her performance at the South by Southwest Music Festival in Austin, Tex., Karen Elson will appear tonight at Le Poisson Rouge in her first solo show in New York. Ms. Elson, a former model, is known for attracting a seriously hip crowd when she sings with the Citizen Band, and tonight is sure to be no different. Go to check out the fabulous folks and their clothes and stay to listen. Ms. Elson will be performing songs from a forthcoming album, "The Ghost Who Walks," produced by her husband, Jack White.

From Agnanti Restaurant in Astoria to Zuzu Ramen in Brooklyn, Choice Eats covers the food scene in New York from A to Z, literally. Foodies will be gathering tonight at the 69th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue at 26th Street, for the Village Voice's third annual festival. The tasting event features bites from more than 50 restaurants and delicacies from more than 35 countries, including Cambodia, Vietnam, Italy, Brazil, Tunisia and Russia. Plan strategically and head straight to the eateries that will likely draw the longest lines, like Motorino, Del Posto and Fatty Crab.

Sondheim fans who missed the all-star birthday tribute to the composer at Avery Fisher Hall last week can breathe a sigh of relief. There are still plenty of opportunities to celebrate the dean of musical theater's big 8-0, starting with an event today. Five years ago, Symphony Space held a 12-hour marathon of Sondheim's work. The composer himself attended the session along with a lineup of Broadway's best, including Neil Patrick Harris, Elaine Stritch, Patti LuPone, Donna Murphy, Angela Lansbury and many more. Today, Symphony Space Live (symphonyspacelive.org) will feature the program from start to finish with "Wall to Wall Sondheim," with music from "Sweeney Todd," "Sunday in the Park with George," "Into the Woods" and more. Prove your devotion and listen to the whole thing.

'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' New York City Opera The New York City Opera's fortunes may still be uncertain, but during the current short season this resurgent company has done everything right. Building on the momentum started by its much-discussed fall productions of Hugo Weisgall's ''Esther'' and Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' on Friday night the company revived its popular version of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' at the David H. Koch Theater.

Edmund Dinis, a former prosecutor who lost his bid for re-election in Massachusetts after his handling of the case against Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the accidental drowning of Mary Jo Kopechne on Chappaquiddick Island in 1969, died March 14 in Dartmouth, Mass. He was 85. His death was confirmed by Henry Arruda, the manager of WJFD-FM, the Portuguese-language radio station in New Bedford, Mass., that Mr. Dinis had owned since 1975.

Liz Carpenter, who spent much of her life working the corridors of power in Washington as a newspaper reporter, an aide to Lyndon B. Johnson when he was vice president and press secretary to Lady Bird Johnson during her years in the White House, died on Saturday in Austin, Tex. She was 89. The cause of death was pneumonia, her daughter, Christy Carpenter, said in a telephone interview on Saturday. She said her mother had been admitted to University Medical Center Brackenridge in Austin on Wednesday.

Apple has hired Richard DeVaul, a veteran of the wearable computing field and co-founder of Aware Technologies, a company focused on creating fitness and health products. According to Computerworld, Mr. DeVaul will be a senior prototype scientist at Apple. According to Mr. DeVaul's LinkedIn page, he received a Ph.D. in media arts and sciences from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While there, he worked on a project called ''The Memory Glasses,'' which offered real-time memory support that could ''improve your performance on a memory recall task by a factor of about 63 percent without distracting you.''

KATMANDU, Nepal -- Girija Prasad Koirala, a former Nepalese prime minister and a pivotal figure in establishing Nepal's fragile democracy who also helped broker an end to the country's Maoist rebellion, died Saturday in Katmandu. He was 86. Nepalese leaders, in announcing his death, declared Sunday, the day of his funeral, to be a national holiday, to allow public mourning of Mr. Koirala's death, and they also ordered that the national flag be flown at half-staff. Mr. Koirala died at the home of his daughter after being in frail health.

SPOKANE, Wash. -- Michigan State's chances for another springtime march deep into the N.C.A.A. tournament were as broad as the smile on Tom Izzo's face midway through the second half of Sunday's game against Maryland. The fourth-seeded Spartans were beating fifth-seeded Maryland by 16 points and getting help from all corners of their roster in the absence of the injured point guard and team leader Kalin Lucas.

In addition to ''Repo Men'' and ''Hot Tub Time Machine,'' three movie soundtrack albums will be released on Tuesday: ''Brooklyn's Finest,'' ''Greenberg'' and ''How to Train Your Dragon.'' The top 10 albums partly reflect the taste of adolescents, who flocked to the ''Glee'' TV series and the ''Twilight'' movies. Like the soundtrack for ''Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel,'' ''Repo Men'' and ''Hot Tub Time Machine'' contain mostly songs from contemporary rock, R&B and rap artists, with a sprinkling of pop classics like David Bowie's ''Modern Love'' and the Mamas and the Papas' ''Dream a Little Dream of Me.'' NEEDHAM, James W.,78, died peacefully after a long illness March 13, 2010 in New York City. The son of W. Reuel and Cecilia Coad Needham, he was born in Ithaca, NY and grew up in Southern California during World War II. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard, majoring in poker. Upon graduation from Stanford Business School he worked for Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in the treasurer's department. He began his Wall Street career at White, Weld and was Chief Financial Officer at the time of its sale to Merrill Lynch, where he then worked in international investment banking. In 1985 he joined Florence Fearrington, Inc. as Chairman. He retired when the firm was sold in 1997 to U.S. Trust Company of New York. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Florence, his daughter Elizabeth (Peter Mark) of Old Greenwich, CT, his son John (Justine) of Littleton, CO, and four grandchildren, Ethan and Kathryn Mark and Cecilia and Evelyn Needham. Jim was a collector of antiquarian natural history books, a longtime member of The Grolier Club and the consummate bookman. He was a benefactor of several institutions, among them Harvard where he endowed two Chairs, including one in Book Conservation. For many years, he served on the Harvard University Library Visiting Committee. There will be a reception in his honor at The Grolier Club on Easter Monday 5:30-7:30pm.

NEW ORLEANS - Having just attentively watched Kentucky Coach John Calipari's postgame news conference after his team's 90-60 blowout of Wake Forest on Saturday night, the Wildcats super fan Ashley Judd was already game-planning for the round of 16. With top-seeded Kentucky (34-2) was set to face the winner of Sunday's game between No. 12 seed Cornell (28-4) and No. 4 Wisconsin (24-8) in the East Region on Thursday in Syracuse, she asked a Wildcats official which team Kentucky would rather play. He told her that Cornell was the preferred opponent because it is difficult for a team to comeback if they fall behind early to Wisconsin, which plays a slow and deliberate style. (Cornell defeated Wisconsin, 87-69.)

Charlie Gillett, who turned his youthful zeal for rock 'n' roll into an influential career by writing one of the first serious rock histories and, as a disc jockey in London, helping to discover talents like Dire Straits and introduce the new genre of world music, died on Wednesday in London. He was 68. The British Broadcasting Corporation said he had suffered from an autoimmune disease and died of a heart attack.

BEIJING -- The local authorities in northeastern China recently took control of a 10-year-old zoo where 11 rare Siberian tigers starved to death, and they are sending experts to try to save the remaining 20 or so tigers, three of which are in critical condition. The zoo, which is in Shenyang, the capital of Liaoning Province, is fast becoming a symbol of the mistreatment of animals in China, with allegations of misspent subsidies, bribes and the deaths of at least dozens of animals.

FORD--George C.,88, of Princeton, NJ died on March 18, 2010. Born in New York City to George Fudakowski and Leonida Krajewska Fudakowska, and raised in Greenwich, CT. He was a graduate of The Edgewood School, Swarthmore College ('43) and Harvard Business School ('48). Mr. Ford began his career as an electrical engineer at Curtiss-Wright in Caldwell, NJ. Changing fields to finance in 1948, he joined Reaction Motors in Rockaway, NJ. In 1952, he became comptroller of the Piasecki Aircraft Corporation in Philadelphia. From 1958 through 1979, he held a variety of top positions at Research-Cottrell in Bedminster, NJ, the pollution control equipment manufacturer, including head of strategic planning and president of Research-Cottrell International. In 1980, he established George C. Ford & Associates, a management consulting firm which focused on strategic analysis of the U.S. markets for electric power for major suppliers to the electric utility industry. He retired in 2006. He is survived by his wife of 35 years Nancy Shannon Ford of Princeton; five children from a previous marriage to Barbara Mott Patton: Greta F. Hayton of San Ramon, CA, Paul F. Ford of Berkeley, CA, Thomas M. Ford of Princeton, Edward G. Ford of Cooperstown, NY, and George W. Ford of Pennington, NJ; brother Thomas I. Ford of Chattanooga, TN; five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held 2:00pm Tuesday, March 30th at Trinity Church, Princeton, NJ.

GROSSMAN--Bella S.,daughter of Henry and Celia Seidenberg, in her 105th year. A true renaissance woman, loving, caring, smart, admired, respected and passionate in her beliefs and values. She will also be greatly missed by the children and grandchildren of her wonderful friend and companion of 17 years, the late Harold Ruthizer as well as by the very many nieces, nephews and friends who loved her dearly. She was a wonderful role model for all those whose lives she touched being both educator and mentor professionally as well as personally. Services, Wednesday, March 24 at 12:30pm at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY

There are 9.2 quintillion possible outcomes to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. Yahoo has built a tool to use the wisdom of many to determine which of those results are most likely. Called Predictalot (apps.yahoo.com/-vU1ZXa5g), it is a prediction market that lets users bet on any outcome. It then continuously recalculates the odds of each outcome based on people's bets.

It seems safe to describe Andrew Hessel, above, as an unbridled optimist. After all, he is selling $20 shares in a journey toward a personalized cure for breast cancer, which he says could be feasible in the next few years. Mr. Hessel is the managing director of the Pink Army Cooperative. This is a Canadian organization that has set out to reduce the cost of cancer treatments, while also making them more effective by embracing a new wave of synthetic biology technology. The group hopes to build a relatively cheap virus in its labs that could be tweaked on an individual basis to hunt and kill breast cancer cells.

Stewart L. Udall, an ardent conservationist and a son of the West, who as interior secretary in the 1960s presided over vast increases in national park holdings and the public domain, died Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. The last surviving member of the original Kennedy cabinet, he was 90. Mr. Udall had been in failing health after a fall last week, according to a son, Senator Tom Udall of New Mexico.

(Showtime) NURSE JACKIE Season 2 opens with Jackie Peyton (Edie Falco) seeking redemption from her indiscretions by renewing her commitment to Kevin (Dominic Fumusa, above with Ms. Falco) and their daughters (Ruby Jerins and Mackenzie Aladjem) and spending a lot of time in the All Saints chapel. (BBC America) TOP GEAR Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond and James May do their part to save the planet by building an electric car with batteries from a milk float, a delivery vehicle common in Britain. They then tour Oxford before submitting their creation to the new-car testing process. Later the men head to the track for a battle of the continents, with North America represented by the Chevrolet Corvette ZR1 and Europe by the Audi R8 V10. Michael Sheen of ''Frost/Nixon'' is the star in a reasonably priced car.

Tyler Cowen has a thoughtful post analyzing how the health care bill might evolve. The following part of his argument tracks, to some extent, with the more optimistic of the scenarios I sketched out yesterday:

"... Generations of conservatives have complained that the so-called mainstream media have been biased against them. Well, get ready, Republicans, for déjà vu all over again. The coverage through November likely will highlight the most extreme attacks on the President and his law and spotlight stories of real Americans whose lives have been improved by access to health care ... The louder Republicans yell, the more they will be characterized and caricatured as sore losers infuriated by the first major delivery of candidate Obama's promise of "change." ... But fighting back against a supposedly hostile press is old hat for the GOP. A far greater challenge will come from a new quarter. Large segments of the American business community are going to present a formidable ally for Obamacare, either with outspoken support or notable silence. From businesses that have been crushed by rising health care costs, to pharmaceutical companies cleverly co-opted by the White House early on in the process, to the doctors' organizations (including the American Medical Association) that endorsed the final product, to, yes, even the vilified insurance companies - none of these entities are going to join the charge to reverse the new reality of U.S. health care, and many will make it clear that they are resigned to or actually in favor of the apparently inevitable conclusion."

Henry Conway stepped into the British consciousness out of a white horse-drawn carriage, dressed like Beau Brummel, completely upstaging Paris Hilton (whose party it was supposed to be). The fact that he had been involved in a financial scandal that cost his Tory father his seat as a member of Parliament made the tabloids apt to pay attention: London's Evening Standard gave the picture its front page. But as Conway, 27, himself observed in a different context in his fashion column for SuperSuper magazine, "Where there's muck, there's brass." After dark, the event promoter socializes with the likes of Princes William and Harry at his Thursday-night wheeze at Mayfair's hip Mahiki Club. And he will soon debut a Friday party cheekily called Royal Jelly at Bungalow 8. He is also the co-author of a book on the history of knitwear and appears as a fashion expert on highbrow arts programs like the BBC's "Newsnight Review." "I am a slightly old-school cultural commentator," Conway says over the phone from London, not before mentioning he's just had an appointment with "Victoria Beckham's facialist." But he doesn't see a conflict between his roles as budding public intellectual and private party host. "I think you do have to experience life to be able to judge it and pass judgment on it."

California to Consider Smoking Ban on Beaches | Smoking on 64 state beaches and 278 parks may be banned if California lawmakers sign a smoking bill into law. Violators will receive a $100 fine. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has not said he will sign the bill, which faces one more vote in the State Senate. But enforcement could be difficult, because the parks system has no money for additional staffing or warning signs, said Roy Stearns, a spokesman for the state parks system. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

During Holy Week, multitudes descend on the Vatican, and therefore Rome. Beginning on Palm Sunday (March 28) and continuing until Easter Sunday (April 4), the already numerous springtime visitors will be joined by tens of thousands of pilgrims, eager to participate in the liturgical calendar's most important events. Crowds at St. Peter's Basilica and the adjacent Vatican Museums are inevitable, but with a bit of planning, avoiding the throngs is possible.

It's Asia Week, "a once-a-year flowering of art at Manhattan auction houses, fairs, galleries and museums," writes Karen Rosenberg. Today, take advantage of the offerings first by checking out one of the many related exhibits, like "Humor in Japanese Art," which showcases satirical paintings, prints and sculpture at the Ukrainian Institute of America, or "Pilgrimage and Buddhist Art," at the Asia Society and Museum, which "explores a tradition that dates from the first century A.D.: journeying to the sites of major events of the Buddha's life. It will include ritual objects and travel accessories, like reliquaries and prayer wheels, that have never been seen in public." The show will help prepare you for "The Buddha," a new documentary that will be shown on PBS on April 7. The film by David Grubin is narrated by Richard Gere and features interviews with the Dalai Lama and notable Buddhists like the poets W. S. Merwin and Jane Hirshfield, as well as Robert Thurman and others.

"The Soviet-born singer and pianist Regina Spektor, from the Bronx, sings obtuse but plaintive folk songs about love and truth," writes Amanda Petrusich. Ol' Blue Eyes is the musical inspiration for the latest Broadway production from the choreographer Twyla Tharp, who previously took on Billy Joel ("Movin' Out") and Bob Dylan ("The Times They Are A-Changin.") Her latest show, about four couples in various stages of love, features original master recordings of Sinatra's voice, a live band and some big names from the dance world, including Holley Farmer, an alumna of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. Go now, when the dancers are at their most energetic.

PACKMAN--Elliot L.,65. Beloved husband of Lee, cherished brother of Laurie (predeceased) and Mimi (Stuart L. Schreiber). He will be remembered by his family and friends as a gentle, loving, gracious man, and by his patients as a dedicated dentist for thirty-six years. Contributions may be sent to The Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (pancan.org). Services will be held Wednesday, March 24, 11:30am, at Frank E. Campbell Memorial Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue.

Services will be held on Wednesday, March 24 at 11:30am at Ballard-Durand, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Donations: Sound Shore Stars, Inc. Special Olympics.

The landmark health care overhaul passed by the House will provide medical coverage to tens of millions of uninsured Americans and will have an impact on nearly everyone who already has insurance. Readers, understandably, have questions about it all. On Monday, Ron Lieber, Tara Siegel Bernard, Jennifer Saranow Schultz and Natasha Singer of The New York Times answered readers' queries online. Here are edited versions of the questions and answers:
DACK--Jacqueline. We are deeply saddened to lose our dear friend and extend heartfelt condolences to the loving family. Helen Berlin and Helen Halper

HELLER--Rabbi Zachary I. of Newton, MA on March 22, 2010. Husband of Lynne (Epstein). Father of Rabbi Joshua Heller and Dr. Miriam Heller Stern. "Saba" of five. "A Rabbi's rabbi." Senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Bayonne, NJ for 29 years and Associate Director of the National Center for Jewish Policy Studies for 12 years. He lectured internationally and published four books.

GOLDSTEIN--Howard E.,April 23, 1931 - March 21, 2010. Howard Goldstein grew up in the liquor industry. His father and grandfather started Standard Food, a noted distributor of brands like Seagrams and Bacardi. Howard managed and built Standard Food Wholesalers which was sold to Herman Merinoff of Charmer. Later he started his own import company, Wellington, which he sold to Bell's Scotch. Howard had been an industry innovator with his numerous launches of successful brands like Finlandia Vodka, Aguardiente Crystal, Boucheron, Barbella (which is named for his wife Barbara and the Italian word Bella for pretty) and finally Hpnotiq Liqueur. Outside of his achievements, within the liquor industry, he is most known for his charitable activities. Howard was a vice president of the National Committee for the Prevention Child Abuse and was honored at the White House for his contributions. Anonymously he sent the children and parents of the local Ronald McDonald House to the circus every year. He is survived by his brother Stewart, his sister Rhona, his beloved wife Barbara, and his children Elizabeth with her husband Eric and daughter Josie and his son James with wife Rachel.

CHRISTY--Arthur. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society of New York (CSS) mourn the loss of a Trustee, friend, and ally in our fight against poverty in New York City. Arthur Christy served as an active leader on the CSS Board from 1963 to 1979, and again from 1980 to 1988. He remained a loyal supporter until his passing. Our deepest sympathy goes to his family. David R. Jones, Pres. & CEO Community Service Society

JACOBSON--Leslie A. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Storm King Art Center mourn the passing of Leslie A. Jacobson, long-time trustee, stalwart supporter, and cherished friend. His astute guidance and wise counsel for more than three decades contributed immeasurably to Storm King's establishment and emergence as a world-renowned institution. In 2003, the law firm Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson established the Leslie A. MONROVIA, LIBERIA -- When darkness comes to Congo Town, women in crisp uniforms take the streets, patrolling with Kalashnikov rifles and long, black hair tucked into baby-blue caps. The brisk sergeant in command, Monia Gusain, matter of factly calls them ''my men.'' But the stern Indian women facing her are actually wives and mothers who wage peace for a living on the rutted dirt roads of Liberia.

Gay men and lesbians are barred from taking part in many clinical trials that deal with sexual functions and occasionally from other studies as well, researchers are reporting. Writing in last week's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, the study's authors say that the scientific rationale for the exclusions, if any, is not at all clear. ''Researchers should be held to careful scientific reasons,'' they add, ''when they develop exclusion criteria that are based on sexual orientation.''

DECAMINADA--Joseph Pio, of Scarsdale passed away on March 21, 2010. Mr. Decaminada was born on October 17, 1935 in Gebo, Wyoming. He was a retired insurance company executive for the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company beginning as Corporate Secretary and working his way to Senior Executive Vice President Secretary. Mr. Decaminada held a BA magna cum laude from St. Francis College Class of 1956; a JD from St. John's University Class of 1959; business management studies at Harvard University 1978-1979. He received the CPCU Designation 1965; was named Man of the Year Recovery Forum 1978; recipient of the Brotherhood award, NCCJ, 1991; the Angelo-American fellow, BD Cooke & Partners, Ltd., London, 1966. Memorial Society CPCU (National President 1984-1985, Distinguished Service Award 1989, Eugene A. Toale Memorial Award New York Chapter 1974). Mr. Decaminada was the past chairman of the board of directors CPCU-Harry J. Loman Foundation, Motor Vehicle Accident Indemnification Corporation, New York. Property Insurance Underwriting Association, Insurance Federation of New York. He contributed articles to profit journals board of directors, chairman of the board at the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, NY, a member of the Knights of Columbus for 52 years, and a Decorated Knight of Malta. He was an active member of Sacred Heart Church in Hartsdale. Mr. Decaminada is survived by his wife of 51 years Genevieve, his son Joseph and his wife Eileen and his four grandchildren Chelsea, Joseph, Amanda and Eric. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY 10583 (914) 725-1137. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10am, Sacred Heart Church in Hartsdale. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

So Monday was the day the five-minute grace period started. That gave time-pressed drivers in New York five extra minutes to move their cars after alternate-side regulations take effect. 10:30 P.M. (MSG) THE LINEUP: NEW YORK'S ALL-TIME BEST BASEBALL PLAYERS Who is the greatest center fielder ever to grace a New York team? How about pitcher? Shortstop? The debate will rage through this new 10-part series, which presents nominees for each spot on the diamond -- starting Tuesday with the catcher -- as well as for manager, culled from the Yankees, Mets, New York Giants and Brooklyn Dodgers. Fran Healy will moderate a panel with Gary Carter, the Hall of Fame Mets catcher; Sparky Lyle, the former Yankee bullpen ace; Will Leitch, a contributing editor to New York magazine and baseball aficionado; and Steve Hirdt, executive vice president of the Elias Sports Bureau. Drawing on a list of players from each position, the men will determine the top five, discuss the merits of each and name the winning player to the official lineup card. The series also features interviews with Yogi Berra (above), David Cone, Dwight Gooden, Darryl Strawberry, Willie Randolph, Andre Dawson, Bucky Dent, Wade Boggs, Davey Johnson, Tony Kubek, Rusty Staub, Don Zimmer, the boxing historian Bert Sugar, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the actors Charles Grodin, Steve Schirripa and Michael Rapaport. Fans can make predictions online at msg.com/lineup and receive points and weekly prizes for each correct pick, with a grand prize bestowed for the most correct choices over all. 7 A.M. ''When I came here, the owner of the team was Warner Communications and it wanted to bring the best; it was like show biz,'' Beckenbauer said Saturday during a pregame news conference at the new Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., which was sold out for a match against Santos F.C. of Brazil in the stadium's debut. ''It was unique in the whole world. Maybe not the best team, but the most spectacular.

The premise of my Thursday column -- that the proportion of people living in poverty has stagnated since the 1970's -- is sometimes contested by conservatives. They note that since the poverty threshold was devised in the 1960's, a range of programs have been introduced to alleviate poverty: free school lunches, food stamps, earned income tax credits, and so on. None of those safety net programs are counted in determining whether someone lives below the poverty line, and so -- the argument goes -- the proportion of people living in poverty is hugely overcounted.

With millions of jobs disappearing in this recession and more people taking early retirement, Social Security is expected to pay out more in benefits in 2010 than it takes in in payroll taxes, an event that wasn't expected until 2016. This effect may be reversed as the recession eases, but this tipping point reminds us of where things are headed. With more baby boomers retiring, by the end of this decade outlays will exceed revenues every year regardless of the condition of the economy. By 2037, Social Security's surplus, currently at $2.5 trillion, will be exhausted.

Overview | What do science museums have to offer? How can visiting a science museum complement classroom curriculum and reinforce science standards? What can students get out of a trip to a science museum? In this lesson, students reflect on the exhibits, learning experiences and purposes of science museums, then prepare for and visit a local science museum where they engage in an open-ended scavenger hunt. Afterward, they develop scripts for a museum guide to use with visitors or generate ideas for their own science museum.

Steve McQueen, the hard-driving, hard-living existentialist hero of a generation of action movies, would have been 80 years old today. McQueen, an avid and accomplished motor racer, died in 1980 of a heart attack after surgery to treat mesothelioma, a form of cancer associated with inhaling asbestos fibers. Early racing suits, his motorsports contemporaries have noted, were dipped in a chemical solution that contained asbestos to make them fire-retardant.
