It doesn't take a mountain of fashion magazines or even a slim volume of Roland Barthes to understand that a mere outfit can be profound. Just look back at your wardrobe over time. (Thanks, Facebook, for making this painfully easier.) The prom dress in which you lost your virginity, the hideous interview suit for the job you never got - clothes become shorthand for experiences, and powerful triggers of memories. The universality of "I dress, therefore I am" is what propelled Ilene Beckman's 1995 memoir, "Love, Loss and What I Wore," to the best-seller list, and then to a Broadway play by Nora and Delia Ephron. Now comes the photographer Jeannette Montgomery Barron's series of photographs and written recollections, "My Mother's Clothes." A group of still lifes depicting the wardrobe of her late mother, the prominent Atlanta socialite Eleanor Morgan Montgomery Atuk, "My Mother's Clothes" will be on display in July at Jackson Fine Art in Atlanta and published as a book in March 2010.

Not long after Terry Herbert found the Staffordshire Hoard, a collection of more than 1,500 pieces of gold and silver Anglo-Saxon treasure, in a farmer's field in Britain, Mr. Herbert, an out-of-work metal detectorist, said, "I've had people go past and go, 'Beep, beep, he's after pennies.'" Now we know that Mr. Herbert's discovery is worth just a bit more than that. On Tuesday Britain's National Heritage Memorial Fund gave a grant of £1.285 million (about $1.9 million) to two museums that will keep the treasure, having raised a total of £3.3 million (about $4.9 million) to keep the collection intact, The Guardian reported. The Birmingham and Stoke-on-Trent museums will pay that money to Mr. Herbert and Fred Johnson, the farmer in whose field the hoard was found, having raised donations from around the world in a campaign that began in January. David Starkey, the historian who started the fund-raising campaign, told The Guardian, "This is by far the most important archaeological discovery in Britain since the Second World War." He added, "Frankly they'd have been demented not to give the money."

This week an unusual arrival is on the upper reaches of the Billboard album chart: gospel music. "Here I Am" (Verity) by Marvin Sapp, a veteran singer and preacher from Grand Rapids, Mich., reached No. 2 in its first week, with 76,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It is the first time that a gospel album has been in the Top 10 since November 2008, when "The Sound" from Mary Mary reached No. 7, according to Billboard. It credits the sleeper radio success of Mr. Sapp's 2007 song "Never Would Have Made It" with the new album's sales. ("Thirsty," the album that contained "Never Would Have Made It," peaked at No. 28.)Also on this week's chart, Lady Antebellum's "Need You Now" (Capitol Nashville) returns to No. 1 for a fourth time with sales of 93,000, bringing its eight-week total to just under 1.5 million. Ludacris's "Battle of the Sexes" (Def Jam), last week's top seller, dropped two spots to No. 3 with 61,000. "The Edge" (Razor & Tie), a compilation of 32 songs by hard rock bands like Jet, Korn and Godsmack, opened at No. 4 with 53,000, and "The Fame" (Interscope) from Lady Gaga is No. 5 with 48,000 sales in its 73rd week of release.

Tuberculosis cases in the city, which had a troubling increase in the early 1990s, continued their steady decline in 2009, falling by 15 percent from 2008, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said. I've been looking at the April issues, the month for taxes and shaping up and being sexy (in 60 seconds!), and I'm feeling strangely energized, if not entirely hopeful about the future of magazines. I enjoyed Alexandra Jacobs's piece about Polyvore in the style issue of The New Yorker. (I also was excited to see the piece on Brunello Cucinelli; interesting business, with annual sales of more than $200 million, reports RebeccaMead, and I know a lot of women who like the clothes, expensive though they are. But I was bored reading about him.) One thing in the Polyvore piece that amused me was the description of the company's office, the atmosphere of tact and friendliness - unlike magazine offices which, as Ms. Jacobs noted, "are widely perceived to be snake pits." But looking at clothes and brands and trends on a computer screen is a different experience, isn't it? Magazines are diva pits, flesh-and-blood places, and they are probably less so today than 10 or 20 years ago, and of course that outsized feeling and passion for clothes is what helps stir the imagination of designers and editors alike. I guess things are thinning out now, and not just magazine pages. Polyvore is a useful site for people, but it does, as Ms. Jacobs's reporting suggested, reflect a remote, blunt, user-friendly time.

Yes, the executive order that Stupak accepted as cover for his pivotal health care vote is probably meaningless. And yes, the health care bill, as passed, effectively tilts public policy in a more pro-choice direction: The fact that women are required to write a separate check for abortion coverage means that public money isn't literally paying for abortion, but it doesn't change the fact that federal dollars are being spent in ways that make it much easier to obtain abortion-covering insurance. (And that's without getting into the tangled issue of community health centers.) But what struck me most, at the end, wasn't the folly of Stupak's decision to compromise his pro-life principles by voting "yes," but the extraordinary loneliness of his position before he folded.

You may see Oprah Winfrey next week on her syndicated talk show, but you won't be seeing the broadcasting queen in a Philadelphia courtroom. On Tuesday Ms. Winfrey settled a defamation lawsuit filed by the former headmistress of a school she set up in South Africa, who had said that the talk show host had defamed her after a sex-abuse scandal there, Reuters reported. Nomvuho Mzamane ran the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa at its founding in 2007 but left after students there said they were being abused by another staff member. After Ms. Winfrey held a news conference and said that Ms. Mzamane had ignored the students' complaints, Ms. Mzamane said Ms. Winfrey had defamed her and made it difficult for her to find another job. A statement from lawyers representing both women said the dispute had been settled "peacefully to their mutual satisfaction" and both women had withdrawn their complaints, according to Reuters. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. A trial was scheduled to begin on Monday in federal court in Philadelphia, where Ms. Mzamane was living when she filed the suit.

Here are some highlights from Wednesday's edition of The New York Times:

State Begins Releasing Inmates | In recent weeks, California has started an effort to reduce its inmate population of 167,000 by 6,500 this year. Some prisoners may be released early for completing drug or education programs. Part of the plan includes changing how the state handles parolees, many of whom, at the moment, return to prison on technical violations, according to criminal system experts. California is the only state that places all prisoners on parole at release, but now hundreds of low-level offenders will be released without close supervision from their parole officers. The effort represents a "seismic shift," said Joan Petersilia, a criminologist at Stanford Law School and a longtime scholar of the state's prisons. The prison system costs the state $8 billion annually, about 11 percent of the state budget. [The New York Times]

By the time you read this, David de Rothschild will be floating somewhere in the middle of the Pacific Ocean on the Plastiki, a 60-foot catamaran made primarily from used plastic bottles. Assuming, that is, all goes as planned. ''The boat only averages five knots,'' he says with a laugh about the ambitious 11,000-mile itinerary. ''That's about six miles an hour.'' But the 31-year-old heir to the Rothschild banking fortune is no stranger to adventure. Having visited some of the most beautiful places on the planet - in 2005 he trekked across Antarctica via the South Pole - he now travels to some of the most blighted, sharing his stories and spreading awareness through his Web site, adventureecology.com. In 2007 he took a team to Ecuador to explore the effects of oil drilling. The Plastiki expedition will take him and his crew to the Eastern Garbage Patch, an island of trash in the Pacific Ocean twice the size of Texas. ''The list of problems is big,'' he says optimistically, ''but the list of solutions is even longer.'' More...

Marilyn Monroe, Joan Crawford, Marlene Dietrich and Queen Elizabeth II all wore them. We're talking about Delmans, the salon shoe line founded by Herman Delman in 1919. Today at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology shoe lovers can take a guided tour through "Scandal Sandals and Lady Slippers: A History of Delman Shoes," which explores the company's history and its greatest era of success in the 1930s through the 1950s. Around 50 shoes, dating from 1926, are presented along with period advertisements. A pair of "suede, instep strap sandals from circa 1939 performs a similar function. Boasting red, white, green, and blue color sections, four tiny bows are sequenced delicately down the vamp while a narrow ankle buckle strap, oval toe, and triangular heel maintain the shoe's elegant silhouette."

Does just reading the word plantain make your mouth water? Then Pilar, the tiny Cuban restaurant that opened this fall in Brooklyn, is your spot. "Accompanying nearly every entree are sticky-sweet maduros, made with plantains so ripe, their peels are almost black. The spongy flesh is browned until lightly caramelized," writes Ligaya Mishan. There are also crisp tostones, "slices of green plantains that have been fried, flattened and fried again." Even the grilled cheese "gets a helping of the fruit, between gooey layers of Cheddar and Gruyère." If that sounds like too much, go for the subtle cream of plantain soup. "It proved an unexpected delight, the sweetness of the fruit sublimated into an earthy broth." The kitchen is headed by Ricardo Barreras, who runs Pilar with his wife, Lizbeth Moreno. Mr. Barreras grew up in Miami and his parents are from Camagüey, Cuba. "In scale and in spirit, Pilar recalls Cuba's paladares, small family-run restaurants often operated out of private homes. The cooking takes time, so be prepared to linger."

PARIS -- The European Union's highest court on Tuesday gave Google broad latitude to sell advertising spots to rivals of trademarked brands when users do searches for names like Louis Vuitton. But it also said that the search engine might have to do more to protect brand owners from infringements. In a case brought by the luxury goods company LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the European Court of Justice said Google should not be required to block sales of brand names as advertising keywords. However, the judges said advertisers, or Google, could be liable for trademark violations in individual cases.

Anderson Cooper, the CNN anchor, has drawn attention for his plans to turn a former West Village firehouse into a private residence. Preservationists want landmark designation for the building; a man whose son worked at the firehouse and died in the Sept. 11 attacks wants Mr. Cooper to restore a memorial plaque; and an architect working on the renovation sued Mr. Cooper, saying she fell through the hole where the fire pole had been. While Mr. Cooper's vision for the firehouse, a 9,000-square-foot building at 84 West Third Street, is unusual for its ambition and the attention it has drawn, it is not without precedent.

Brett Yormark, the Nets' chief executive, knows his team is dreadful. At 7-63 -- with a chance to succeed the 9-73 Philadelphia 76ers of 1972-73 as the most futile team in N.B.A. history -- that is a hard conclusion to avoid. Fans cannot help but express their misery. During the fourth quarter of the Nets' loss to Miami on Monday night, Chris Lisi, of Middletown, N.J., put a bag over his head, an act that Yormark, of all people, might have found to have potential.

The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed adding the oil and gas sector and facilities that inject carbon dioxide into the ground to the greenhouse gas sources that are required to report their annual emissions to the government. The agency already requires 31 industries to track and report emissions. The new rule, if accepted after a public comment period, would also try to track emissions of methane and fluorinated gases, which have a much more powerful impact on the atmosphere than carbon dioxide does.

Gilbert Arenas of the Washington Wizards is scheduled to be sentenced on Friday for a felony count of carrying a pistol outside his home without a license. In preparation, both sides filed court memorandums on Tuesday. Prosecutors recommended that Arenas serve three months in jail, according to The Washington Post. Arenas pleaded guilty on Jan. 15 to storing four unloaded guns in the Wizards' locker room at the Verizon Center, and using them in a joke with his teammate Javaris Crittenton. As part of his plea agreement, prosecutors filed only a single gun possession charge. The Post reported that the Assistant United States Attorney Christopher R. Kavanaugh was seeking a jail sentence because Arenas provided inconsistencies in his dealings with prosecutors and showed little remorse other than how the incident impacted his career. ''If any other individual without fame, power and the wealth of this defendant, brought four firearms into the District for the purpose of a similar confrontation, the government would seek their incarceration and the court would almost certainly give it,'' Kavanaugh wrote, according to The Post.

MARTINO--Angelina S.,a former longtime resident of Riverdale, NY, died March 22nd in Greenwich Hospital, Connecticut. Martino on December 23, 1943 in New York City on the eve of his departure to serve in World War II. A former parishioner of St. Gabriel's and St. Margaret's churches in Riverdale, she worked for many years as a medical secretary for the Neurological Institute at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Following her retirement, Mrs. Martino was an active member of the Leisure Club at St. Margaret's Church and a volunteer with the auxiliary at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. Along with her husband, she enjoyed traveling and cherished spending time with her children and grandchildren. Mrs. Martino's loving husband of 60 years, Samuel died in November 2003. Surviving are her children, Donna (Peter) Martino of Englewood, NJ; Edward (Peggy) Martino of Greenwich, CT; and the Hon. Michael (Antoinette) Martino of Tuckahoe, NY; six grandchildren, Michael Christopher and Stephanie, of Tuckahoe; Mark, Michael Keith, Maggie and Annie, of Greenwich; and a sister, Lucy of California. A brother, Celidonio and sisters, Frances and Anne also predeceased her. The family would like to acknowledge and thank the doctors, nurses, and staff at Greenwich Hospital for their kindness, professionalism and care during these past weeks. Friends may call on Thursday from 4 to 8pm at Gallagher's Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, CT 06830. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11am, Friday at St. Michael's Church, North Street, Greenwich. Donations in Mrs. Martino's memory may be made to the St. Joseph's Auxiliary at St. Joseph's Hospital, 75 S. Broadway, Yonkers, NY 10701.

KLEMM--David Robert, President of Klemm Real Estate in Washington Depot, CT, passed away peacefully early Saturday morning in Palm Beach, FL, after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in South Bend, IN on January 12, 1938, he attended the University of Notre Dame, and graduated from Indiana University, where he was President of Beta Theta Pi fraternity. After retiring from an illustrious career in radio broadcasting, he moved to Washington, CT in 1977 where he and his wife, Carolyn, began Klemm Real Estate which became Litchfield County's premier luxury real estate firm. David served as President and Director of Marketing for the firm's five offices and forty agents until recently when he handed stewardship over to his two sons. Mr. Klemm is survived by his beloved wife Carolyn Viccari Klemm, his son Peter R. Klemm and daughter-in-law Christina Klemm, his son Graham T. Klemm and partner Matthew Lynn, and adored granddaughter Natalie Klemm. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather who was intelligent, honest, articulate, good humored and a great communicator. Although a private man he had countless friends and colleagues who admired his great dignity and the integrity of his life. There will be a private family graveside service.

DEAN--Kenneth Bass On March 21, 2010, passed away leaving behind Susanne, his beloved wife and best friend of 60 years. He is also survived by his cherished sons and their wives William, Kenneth, Barbara, Jonathan and Claire, as well as six adoring grandchildren Alexander, Scott, Patrick, Casey, Elizabeth and Madeline, two devoted sisters Gloria Mayer and Nancy Dayton and his faithful friend Zorro. Born in Brooklyn, NY on December 22, 1925, Ken proudly attended Union College and joined the Navy during WWII where he rose to the rank of Lieutenant JG. After the War, he followed in his father's footsteps and joined W. E. Dean & Company as a commercial real estate broker in lower Manhattan. At that time, lower Manhattan consisted of tea and coffee warehouses and ship chandlers eventually evolving into the financial capital of the world. In the mid sixties he merged with Cushman & Wakefield, Inc. where he continued a very successful career and was often referred to as "Mr. Downtown." He resided in Garden City, NY with a summer home in Quogue, NY before retiring in 1994 to Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Quogue. Ken loved life, the New York Jets and enjoyed golf, biking, swimming, fishing and spending time with family and friends. Loved by all who knew him, his courage, spirit and enthusiasm will never be forgotten. Details for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Ken's family respectfully requests that donations be made in his memory to The ALS Association, 42 Broadway, New York, NY 10004 or ALS Research Fund, 1120 NW 14th St., Miami, FL 33136. Services entrusted to Aycock Funeral Home, Jupiter, FL. Online condolences may be made at aycockfuneralhomejupiter.com

Memorial Society CPCU (National President 1984-1985, Distinguished Service Award 1989, Eugene A. Toale Memorial Award New York Chapter 1974). Property Insurance Underwriting Association, Insurance Federation of New York. He was an active member of Sacred Heart Church in Hartsdale. TENNITY--Marilyn S. A native Californian and a philanthropist of science and arts, died on March 18, 2010 at her home in Indian Wells, California. Born December 26, 1919, she was 90. The cause was cancer. Mrs. Tennity was the widow of Dr. Charles F. Swift, who died in 1959, and William P. Tennity, a mechanical engineer who died in 2003. The Tennitys moved from Los Angeles to Indian Wells in 1980 when Mr. Tennity retired. They helped to construct an African Village and animal preservation center at The Living Desert, a wildlife botanical park in the Coachella Valley near Palm Springs. Mr. Tennity chaired the building committee for the expansion of the Eisenhower Medical Center and the Tennitys became co-founders of the McCallum Theatre along with Bob and Dolores Hope, and Gerald and Betty Ford. The Tennitys spent summers in Santa Barbara where they supported the Natural History Museum and Lobero Theatre: they also participated in the expansion of the Memorial Hospital at McCall and at Syracuse University. Marilyn was born in Los Angeles in 1919, just after her father recovered from influenza during 1918 epidemic while he was serving with an artillery training company in World War I. After living 10 years in Los Angeles, Marilyn moved to New York City where her father was transferred during the Great Depression to participate in the nationwide expansion of the United Parcel Service delivery business, founded in 1907 in Seattle. Marilyn's father, George D. Smith, would become CEO and Board Chairman (1962-1972). Her family lived in Manhattan's Tudor City during Prohibition where she remembered speakeasies and gunfire in the streets. After moving to Jackson Heights (Queens), Marilyn met neighbors, bandleader Benny Goodman and Lamont Cranston, radio voice of "The Shadow". After a decade in New York City, the family moved to New Rochelle where she met her first husband, Charles Swift, a classmate from Syracuse University. At Syracuse, Marilyn graduated with a degree in psychology, volunteered for the Red Cross, and was a member of Gamma Phi Beta sorority. Marilyn and Charles became the parents of five children; the oldest, Geoffrey, died as a young child. She and Charles returned to Marilyn's birthplace in Los Angeles, where they raised their four children until Charles' death in the late fifties. Marilyn remarried to William Tennity who became father to Marilyn's children, living in Southern California and Idaho. After Mr. Tennity died, Marilyn divided her time between Indian Wells, Santa Barbara, and McCall, Idaho. Marilyn Smith Swift Tennity is survived by four children: James Swift of Bellingham, Washington; Peter Swift of Charlotte, Vermont; Nancy Furlotti (Mrs. Alexander) of Los Angeles; and John Swift of Cayucos, California; a brother, George Smith of San Francisco; eleven grandchildren; and one great-granddaughter.

Last week, a group of art-world heavy hitters (editors, writers, curators, etc.), led by the peripatetic London-based Swiss art dealer Ivan Wirth, were gathered around a large table in the back room of his New York gallery, Hauser & Wirth on East 69th Street, gazing with rapt attention at fragmentary objects that were close to nothing. Hauser & Wirth represents the estate of the sculptor Eva Hesse (1936-70), and assembled on the table were essentially outtakes from her studio- delicate, insistently handmade studies in papier-caché (a version of papier-mâché), cheesecloth and bits of adhesive. Not quite works in their own right, they were still riveting in their suggestion of themes that had preoccupied Hesse throughout her decade-long career (cut short by her death from brain cancer at age 34): plasticity, an engagement with ephemeral materials, the elusive and incomplete nature of memory, and a redolent corporeality.

For Americans accustomed to traveling in Europe, leaving a few extra coins on a dinner bill has finally developed into a reflex. But remove us from the Continent and all kinds of tipping head scratchers present themselves. What's a customary gratuity for scuba guides in Costa Rica, cooks for an Andean trek or doctors and nurses in Romania (if you press their flesh with a few bills, they'll press yours)? Beyond the exotic, travelers remain flummoxed by such courtesies as tipping the chambermaid (do so during your stay, not just on departure) and how much to give the concierge ($5 to $10 per request, more if it's challenging, and as much as $150 at a luxury hotel, if you've really put him to the test).

One of four designs by Frank Gehry for the Eisenhower Memorial has been chosen by the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission for a four-acre site at the base of Capitol Hill in Washington, the commission announced Thursday. Mr. Gehry was selected in March 2009 after a competition through the General Services Administration's Design Excellence Program, which asked him to create several options. In making its selection, below, the commission said it considered aesthetic and thematic issues, environmental impact and estimated construction costs. Still subject to final approval, the memorial will be between Fourth and Sixth Streets SW, south of Independence Avenue. Groundbreaking is planned for August 2012, with an opening scheduled for Memorial Day 2015.

A new report shows just how striking the changes in the real estate market have been in New York in recent years. The report, by New York University's Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy, reveals that the city gained a remarkable number of new housing units, and then watched the market fall faster than at any time in recent history.In a 140-page report released on Thursday morning, Furman Center researchers found that the city gained 170,000 new housing units from 2000 to 2008. But by 2009, the building boom ground to a halt. Building permits being issued dropped by 90 percent from 2008 to 2009. The city issued fewer permits for new housing units than any time since 1992.

I recently became aware of fascinating efforts by Adam Nieman to help society appreciate environmental challenges in fresh ways by visualizing volumes that are otherwise abstractions. In 2003 he created the image above, illustrating the volume of the world's oceans and atmosphere (if the air were all at sea-level density) by rendering them as spheres sitting next to the Earth instead of spread out over its surface. To my eye, this helps powerfully convey the finite nature of these shared global assets. In general, I think there's great merit in conceiving and testing new ways to communicate visually on the keystone issues of this blog (energy and climate, population and consumption, the relationship between humans and other life). Click here for his globe showing all the world's land types as "islands" (and note how tiny the urban islet is).

In my first hour in Toronto, I ate these things: stewed rabbit, blueberry-buckwheat pancakes, crisp ribbons of translucent guanciale and billowy mounds of smoked ricotta. And this was all just the first dish. Brunch at Hoof Café - the new offshoot of Grant van Gameren and Jen Agg's Black Hoof, across the street - is a decidedly meat-focused affair. Stranger than this strange assemblage, which also included more blueberries and some syrup and - why not? - candied celery and which seemed to suggest the chefs were smoking more than cheese, was the fact that it all sort of worked. Not brilliant, but sweet and smoky and meaty and an oddly comforting way to begin the first meal of the day. The lines out the door should have tipped me off: Toronto is in the throes of a serious love affair with all things meaty.

In 1986, Daimler-Benz commissioned the pop artist Andy Warhol to make a series of paintings to celebrate the automaker's centennial. The plan was for 80 works, and the subjects would be 20 of Daimler's most important cars, including the Benz Patent Motorwagen of 1886, the first car ever built. But Warhol died on Feb. 22, 1987, of a heart attack shortly after gall bladder surgery. At the time of his death, he had completed only 35 silkscreens and 12 large-scale drawings. They were his last works.

Lorin Maazel, the venerated maestro who ended his term as the music director of the New York Philharmonic last year, will not be sitting on his laurels for very long. On Wednesday, the City Council of Munich voted unanimously to approve Mr. Maazel's appointment as chief conductor of the Munich Philharmonic Orchestra, the orchestra said on its Web site. His appointment will be effective with the 2012-13 season. In a statement, Christian Ude, the mayor of Munich, said the orchestra had succeeded in signing up "one of the world's pre-eminent conductors" who will "motivate and inspire excellence." Mr. Maazel, who was a highly visible figure in Munich when he served as the chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony, added in his own statement that "the quality of the orchestra is unsurpassed," and that following in the footsteps of previous conductors like Sergiu Celibidache, who conducted the Munich orchestra until his death in 1996, "represents a challenge" that he will take on "with joy."

Even before he opens his mouth, you can tell that the central character in Martin McDonagh's "Behanding in Spokane" is bonkers. Of course, it's kind of a giveaway that he's being played by Christopher Walken, that master interpreter of psychos. But look closely at what he's wearing, and how he's wearing it. Everything is at least secondhand, and nothing really fits, including that big black coat and those oversize, way-too-short pants. Yet his clothes seem as much a part of him as his skin, or a carapace for an armadillo. This guy lives in those duds and probably has for a long, long time.

Voters to Decide on Legalizing Marijuana | For the second time in 40 years, voters in California will decide whether to legalize marijuana, after a ballot initiative -- which proposes to legalize pot and allow it to be sold and taxed -- qualified to be on the November ballot, state officials announced Wednesday. Supporters turned in 694,248 signatures from every county except Alpine. Officials in Los Angeles County, where the signatures were submitted Wednesday night, estimated 523,531 signatures were valid. To qualify for the November election, the ballot needed 433,971 signatures. Richard Lee, an Oakland marijuana entrepreneur, has spent $1.3 million to put together the campaign. "We're one step closer to ending cannabis prohibition and the unjust laws that lock people up for cannabis while alcohol is not only sold openly but advertised on television to kids every day," he said. [The Los Angeles Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

More than a week ago, Tyler Cowen kicked off an irresistible blogospheric listing exercise: In this case, the theme is "10 books which have influenced your view of the world." You can find Matthew Yglesias's list here, Will Wilkinson's list here, Matt Continetti's here, and many more at this link. My own follows below. Note that these are not my 10 favorite books, nor the 10 best books I've ever read, but the books that quickly came to mind - I was following Cowen's "go with your gut" admonition - as having shaped my writing or pushed me in one intellectual direction or another over the years. As an experiment, I've also tried listing them in rough chronological order, starting with the books that influenced me as a child and working my way upward (or downward, perhaps) toward adulthood. And like many people, I've cheated and gone over 10 - in my case, by doubling up on a few that share an author or a theme.

"The English were wary of the Continental taste for opera in the 17th century," writes Allan Kozinn, "but they liked the idea of adorning plays with music. What composers and theater producers came up with is a curious compromise that Roger North, a writer at the time, called 'semi-opera.' " He goes on to say that "the staging of Purcell's 'Fairy Queen' that opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening makes a powerful argument for the hybrid form." Jonathan Kent directs this production of the 1692 adaptation of Shakespeare's "Midsummer Night's Dream," which features William Christie conducting his ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, and is the centerpiece of the new BAM Opera Festival. Go to listen to the music and look out for the masques, or mini-dramatic interludes. They "are freewheeling and almost vaudevillian in spirit," Mr. Kozinn writes, especially the "Masque of Seduction" — "presented at one point by an army of choristers in bunny costumes, offering what appeared to be a quick tour of the Kama Sutra."

Think of it as Twitter with pictures. With a miniature wearable camcorder called the uCorder, you can document every mundane aspect of your life, from tying your shoes to going into the subway. The uCorder is about the size of a stick of gum. You can attach it to your belt, put it on a lanyard around your neck or slip it into a shirt pocket. Additional flash memory can be added to either of the two models, the $80 IRDC150 and $100 IRDC250, which come with 1GB and 2GB of memory, respectively, giving you either 36 or 72 minutes of video. The larger-capacity model can also double as a Web cam, using the included mount.

I'VE long been a pack rat when it comes to saving financial documents. I have a file cabinet full of old cellphone and credit card bills, brokerage firm and bank account statements and health insurance benefit forms. When my husband accused me of saving too much, I realized that there wasn't much reasoning behind my recordkeeping. So I decided to find out what financial documents people needed to keep and in what form -- as we fully enter the age of electronic statements -- and what can be purged now.

SHANGHAI -- The trial of four employees of the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto ended here on Wednesday, but a verdict had not yet been reached. The four are charged with accepting millions of dollars in bribes from Chinese steel companies and stealing commercial secrets. The defendants face 5 to 15 years in prison. A three-judge panel is expected to rule in days or weeks on the case, which is being closely watched by foreign companies operating in China.

EVEN economic oracles would have trouble predicting their retirement needs with a high degree of precision. But most Americans face that task anyhow, without having the slightest idea about what the future holds. Using sophisticated calculators and other tools can help, but they're only as good as the assumptions you feed into them -- about future earnings, how your portfolio will perform over time, the inflation rate, your tax bracket and more.

MOST of us would like an answer to this question: Am I on the royal highway toward realizing my long-term financial goals -- building up savings for the children's education and for retirement, for example -- or am I bumping along a back road that ends far short of my goals? Your tax return can provide clues for answering that question. So, before filing away a copy of your 2009 return, spend some time reviewing it. Even if you want professional advice, review the return first. ''The client who gets the best advice is often the one who raises the best questions,'' said Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and certified public accountant. He and two other accountants who specialize in personal finance offered pointers for going through the return, the topics to consider and the questions to ask.

FEW things in our financial lives could be as tedious yet as important as reviewing the policies that insure what we own. Hours spent poring over pages written in arcane language can seem totally wasted. So we don't do it. But avoiding the issue does not make it go away. Without going through your policies annually, how will you know if all your assets are actually covered?

To be a modern American consumer is to be plagued by a never-ending, guilt-inducing stream of undone tasks. There's the nagging feeling that you don't have the most cost-effective plan with the cable company and the vague sense that the money in your bank account could be earning more interest. Perhaps that flexible spending account reimbursement keeps slipping down your list of things to do, and you know in the back of your mind that you could save some money by raising your insurance deductibles.

YOU probably get an annual physical. Your doctor will ask about your concerns, take your blood pressure and 30 minutes later you're out of the paper gown and off to work -- maybe with a new prescription for Lipitor. A similar annual checkup takes place in another type of practitioner's office: financial planners. But instead of analyzing your good and bad cholesterol levels, a planner may evaluate your good debts (mortgage) and bad debts (credit card). And instead of testing your reflexes, they may look at your savings and assess your ability to respond to a financial emergency.

Funeral services to be held today March 25th at 2pm, Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey.

If you want to liberate the videos, music tracks and photos trapped on your PC and bring them to your home theater, you need a media player that can handle all types of files. I've been trying out a Seagate FreeAgent Theater+ media-streaming device for a few weeks now, and it certainly fits the bill. The media device can stream a very wide variety of video, music, and photo formats from your PCs and attached hard drives, U.S.B. keys, and network-attached storage devices.

van ITALLIE--Nancy Lindberg. With great sorrow, the family of Nancy Lindberg van Itallie announces her death on March 22, 2010. An editor for 40 years of trade books, travel guides, human rights and international relations journals. Nancy, beloved wife of Michael, and cherished mother of Jessica and Jason, is profoundly mourned and will be greatly missed by her family and many friends. Memorial Service: Saturday, March 27, 1:30pm, Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue.

FOR people who enjoy guidance in their workouts, a heart rate monitor can be a cheerleader and a scold. It can, for instance, be programmed to sound an alarm when the wearer's heart rate falls below or above the desired zone. These monitors, which double as sports watches, typically gauge exercise intensity by measuring the user's heart rate with a chest strap. The more basic models tend to have just a few functions -- say, a tracker for burned calories -- while the higher-end monitors let athletes compile all sorts of data about their workouts. To some users, tracking and analyzing their results can be an inspiration.

The secretary of state's office announced Wednesday that a measure to legalize, regulate and tax the sale of marijuana had qualified for November's ballot. The measure would essentially place marijuana on a similar legal level as alcohol, allowing Californians over 21 to possess up to an ounce of the drug and to grow it for personal use. Backers say the law could raise more than $1 billion in tax revenue, but opponents have warned that it would lead to wider abuse of the drug. Medical marijuana has been legal in California since 1996.

SPIELBERG--Dr. David, died March 22, 2010. David was a talented musician, physicist and computer programmer with a brilliant comic personality. He was husband to Janet, father to Alex and Tony, grandfather to Natalie and Miranda, and uncle to Bette and Jessica. He is greatly missed. To honor him, do a good deed.

WINSTRAL-MILLER--Phyllis. The sun has set on the life of Phyllis Winstral-Miller of New York City and Harborside, Maine. She died peacefully at home in Manhattan, surrounded by family and friends on March 23, 2010. She was the beloved wife of Jonathan S. Miller, the cherished stepmother of Beth and son-in-law Fred Felleman and Jennifer and son-in-law Cary Antill. She is deeply mourned by grandchildren Brandon Miller, Sam, Greg and Maggie Antill, by her brother Len and sister-in-law Helen Winstral, by sister-in-law Barbara Henley and Ernest Henley and nephews Davis and Alan Henley and Adam and Jonathan Winstral. Phyllis was preceded in death by her parents Rae and Harry Winstral of Miami Beach, FL. This beautiful, highly competent woman was fiercely and lovingly involved with all in her family, and was the most loyal of friends. Phyllis worked for 30 years as an assistant to the chairman of James Felt Realty Services. She was a passionate sailor, gardener, collector, reader, and companion to her husband, truly a "woman for all seasons". The family thanks her amazing friend and caregiver, Elieze Charles, for the love and skill that cushioned the last difficult year of Phyllis's life. A Memorial Service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street on Sunday March 28 at 2:30 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Alzheimer's Association, 160 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. - The postseason schedule change announced by Major League Baseball on Wednesday is specific to one day. The off day that had been scheduled between Games 4 and 5 of the League Championship Series has been eliminated. The new schedule does not condense the postseason. The World Series is still scheduled to start Wednesday, Oct. 27, because Fox wants only one scheduled weekend, not two, and does not want to broadcast a game on Friday night. The last three games of the World Series will still drag into November.But even a small change was a welcome one, and a tangible sign that the Special Committee for On-Field Matters, formed by Commissioner Bud Selig in December, is making a difference. In a statement, Selig said more announcements will be coming.

THIS should be a golden age for banks that want to persuade people to ditch their checking accounts and start fresh elsewhere. Fees became so high that the federal government stepped in to regulate overdrafts. Interest rates have fallen so low that many banks refuse to pay interest to many checking account customers.

Anyone of a certain age remembers the old commercials with an elderly woman shouting ''I've fallen and I can't get up!'' But what was the subject of many a joke among college-age young adults is no laughing matter. If you care for aging parents you know, or will soon find out, that falling and its subsequent physical complications can literally become a matter of life and death.

Dwight Gooden, the former pitching star who has battled drug and alcohol problems, was arrested Tuesday and faces several charges, including driving while under the influence of drugs, after an accident in Franklin Lakes, N.J. The police said Gooden, who lives in Franklin Lakes, struck another car on Old Mill Road and drove away. He was apprehended not far from the accident scene after someone called 911. He was driving with a child in the car and among the eight charges filed against him was endangering the welfare of a child. The police did not identify the child, but Gooden has a 5-year-old son.

Most people know that power chargers for electronic devices draw electricity when plugged into the wall even when they aren't charging something. But short of unplugging every wall wart not in use, what do you do about it? AT&T is introducing a new charger in May called the AT&T Zero that senses when the phone it is charging is unplugged from it and shuts down so that it has no ''vampire draw.'' The price was not announced.
DANIELS--Evelyn. Dearest lady, dearest friend, we will miss you. Helen and Irwin

BUTTS--R. Freeman. The community of Teachers College, Columbia University, mourns the passing of one of its great minds, the education historian and philosopher R. Freeman Butts, who retired as William F. Russell Professor in the Foundations of Education. A proponent of an integrative approach to the study of education and its interaction with cultural and social conditions, Professor Butts served as Associate Dean of International Studies and directed the College's Teachers for East Africa and Afghanistan projects. He also focused on issues of civic and public education, writing memorably in the late 1950s that "education is not only deeply embroiled in some of our most bitter public controversies, but... has become one of the central issues in the alignment of political, economic, and social forces in present-day America." Susan Fuhrman President John W. Hyland, Jr. William Rueckert Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Teachers College, Columbia University

McGRAW--Harold W.,Jr. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the most esteemed members of the Library family, Harold W. McGraw, Jr. A devoted Trustee for three decades, a generous benefactor, and a great friend, he was deeply dedicated to the cause of education overall and to The New York Public Library in particular. We are grateful for his tireless work in the corporate philanthropic community on the Library's behalf and for his own generous support of our Science, Industry and Business Library, among many other endeavors. We are proud that one of the Library's most beautiful spaces, the McGraw Rotunda, honors his family name. We offer our deepest sympathies to his son, Library Trustee Harold McGraw III, and to all of his family and friends. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

EAST West Virginia's point guard, Darryl Bryant, broke a foot in practice Tuesday and will not play against Washington. His replacement, Joe Mazzulla, below, has started only 7 of 109 career games and is shooting 38 percent this season but is averaging 20 percent more assists and 28 percent fewer turnovers per 40 minutes than Bryant. The Huskies have played only one other game outside the Pacific time zone (and lost, at Texas Tech). Cornell starts four seniors, who have compiled an 88-31 record and won three Ivy League titles. Kentucky starts three freshmen and no seniors and has four potential 2010 N.B.A. lottery picks.

BALDINGER--Marilyn (Lyn), died March 23 at home in Sarasota, FL. Formerly of New York City and Woodbury, CT. Lyn was 81. Married to Stuart for 61 years she also leaves son Scott and his wife Paula, son Mark and his three children Jessica, Max, and Samantha, daughter Robin, her husband Rod Dorman and their two sons Brett and Kirk, her dear brother Samuel Laitman, and sister-in-law Rita B. Singer, all of whom she loved and was loved by in return. For 61 years she was my lover, companion, and best friend, my partner in life. For all who knew her she was a friend who cared in good and bad times. She had a lovely smile, a gentle manner and in every way was a gracious and elegant lady. Her love of animals is reflected in her last request to her family. That any remembrance of her be expressed as a donation to your local Humane Society. Services will be private.

There are two veteran doormen who work directly across the street from each other at the western end of 86th Street near Riverside Drive. Well, Karl Rove isn't one to let a downpour dampen his parade. "Democrats are celebrating victory," the Republican strategist wrote in The Wall Street Journal after President Obama signed the health care reform package. "The public outcry against what they've done doesn't seem to bother them. They take it as validation that they are succeeding at transforming America. But we've seen this movie before and it won't end happily for Democrats."

My colleague Jesse McKinley has a fascinating article today about how legal-marijuana advocates are promoting the fiscal virtues of their cause. Not coincidentally, another banned substance was legalized in the wake of major economic upheaval: alcohol, during the Great Depression. The "Noble Experiment" known as Prohibition ended in 1933, when a legalized alcohol market promised more job opportunities and additional sales tax revenues for governments under stress.

As Rod Nordland and Timothy Williams write in The New York Times, the secular coalition led by former Prime Minister Ayad Allawi won the most seats in Iraq's parliamentary elections, narrowly edging out the incumbent Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who angrily denounced the results as fraudulent.

If the bunny in the book looked anything like this, it's no wonder Alice went headlong down the rabbit hole. The jewelers Soraya Silchenstedt and Candice Pool (their line is called Finn) made this 18-karat-gold and diamond pendant for a friend who wanted them to replicate the stuffed animal belonging to her 5-year-old. "She was a bit sad at the time," Silchenstedt says, "so it had to be really beautiful." The resulting piece, inspired by the mask Candice Bergen wore to Truman Capote's Black and White Ball and photos of rabbits gamboling in the snow, contains 3.5 carats of sparklers of various sizes that are meant to represent snowflakes. Call it bling for the hippity-hop set. It's $9,875 at Barneys New York.

Coming to South by Southwest in search of a record deal seems so last-century. While the festival used to serve a key A&R purpose in showcasing bands for labels, it long ago evolved into more of a showcase for already-established acts to show off their wares. But further down the totem pole from Hole and Stone Temple Pilots, upstart acts still come. The Brooklyn singer-songwriter Alina Simone, who released an album of Russian punk songs in 2008, was back for her fourth South by Southwest because, she said, "something weirdly good" always seems to happen there. In years past, she picked up a nice write-up in Billboard magazine and found a manager.

Directors at Credit Suisse borrowed a bit more money from the generous Swiss banking giant last year, the bank's annual report shows. Nine directors accounted for about $23.7 million in loans (based on the current exchange rate of 93.4 cents to the Swiss franc), up from the seven directors who owed about $22.2 million at the end of 2008, according to the annual report, which was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

The company that managed Axl Rose's career in Guns n' Roses for much of the last two years has sued him to collect what it says is $1.9 million in unpaid fees. Front Line Management, whose founder and chief executive is Irving Azoff -- who is also executive chairman of Live Nation Entertainment, which merged with Ticketmaster last month -- filed suit in Los Angeles Superior Court on Thursday, saying that Mr. Rose is in breach of an oral contract that obliged him to pay Front Line 15 percent of his gross earnings as a performer. The suit says that Mr. Rose has not paid the management fees on recent concerts in Asia, South America and Canada, which grossed $12.5 million. A spokesman for Mr. Azoff declined to comment further on the suit, and representatives for Mr. Rose -- including his new manager, Doc McGhee -- did not respond to inquiries.
The proposed overhaul of American financial regulations should reduce the extent of risk-taking by the biggest banks and may bolster their credit ratings, Fitch Ratings said Friday, Reuters reports.

Hockey news away from the N.H.L. has been somewhat more uplifting lately. Echoing the gold medal Olympic clash, rival teams of U.S. and Canadian servicemen in Afghanistan have squared off in a street hockey games, part of a morale-boosting tour for Canadian troops that runs through this weekend. The pianist Lang Lang was the headliner at a concert designated as a benefit for Unicef at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, and was joined onstage for one song by Wyclef Jean, one of the prime movers behind the Hope for Haiti Now concert and telethon and the resulting album. The artist Shepard Fairey has become a museum darling but is still close enough to his street-art roots to have been arrested, jailed overnight and sentenced to two years of probation last year in Boston for pasting his work on buildings before a retrospective at the city's Institute of Contemporary Art. Now - as he prepares for a May exhibition at Deitch Projects in New York, that gallery's final show as its owner, Jeffrey Deitch, closes the business to take over the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art - Mr. Fairey is planning to put up street art the polite way, by asking building owners.

It's all about . . . Back to the land, starting with our cover story on Hawaii's Big Island, an off-the-grid wonderland where Mother Nature went a little bit nuts. Then we head down under to Australia to commune with the cane toads in the awe-inspiring Top End, and to Lake Powell, a no less jaw-dropping corner of the American West. We check in with the urban refugees yearning to buy the farm (for a weekend), pay a visit to the schnapps makers of the Austrian Alps, and get to know the environmental adventurer David de Rothschild. Not that we've entirely forgotten the charms of city life: There's a stop in newly energized Bordeaux, France; a wander through the half-closed doors and shadowy lanes of Palermo, Italy; and a rip-roaring meet-and-greet with the movers and shakers of Beirut. And because you can't go back to the land if you don't take care of it, there's T's first-ever guide to eco-tripping.

You can't buy these shoes without knowing the story behind them. Sure, they're elegant, in an Old World, spaghetti Bolognese, "Where's Michael?" kind of way. "But what's with those specks of paint?" someone might ask you. "What kind of an animal would paint while wearing full-grain Italian calfskin shoes?" Although there are many expensive men's shoes that now bear his name, Salvatore Ferragamo (1898-1960) designed only one style for men in his lifetime, and you're looking at it. Andy Warhol owned a pair and, naturally, he painted in them. And then Warhol died. And then, in 2006, the Ferragamo family bought those paint-specked Warhol shoes at an auction. And now, authorized copies are available for $990 at the Ferragamo flagship store on Fifth Avenue in New York. Call (212) 754-5200.

And for the residents of Wilton, N.H., an economically depressed town with a population less than 4,000, it's the biggest thing to happen all winter. Adam B. Ellick and Stefania Rousselle produced this video on how a group of racers, many of them unemployed, find a way to lift their spirits in dismal times. You ride along with the drivers, and in teeth-rattling glory, experience the grueling joy of this unlikely competition. (E.O.)

Marijuana Proposal Appeals to Need for Green | Proponents of the ballot measure to legalize marijuana in California won't dwell on the drug's safety or social acceptance. Instead, they will focus on money: They say that taxing its sales could raise $1.4 billion and ease the $20 billion state deficit. The measure, which qualified for the November ballot on Wednesday, would allow licensed retailers to sell up to one ounce at a time, a transaction that would be subject to tax. "We need the tax money," said Richard Lee, founder of Oaksterdam University, a trade school in Oakland for marijuana growers. Mr. Lee backed the ballot measure's successful petition drive. "Second, we need the tax savings on police and law enforcement, and have that law enforcement directed towards real crime." Some are not so sure. "We just don't think any good is going to come from this," said John Standish, president of the California Peace Officers Association. [The New York Times]

Australians call the northernmost chunk of their continent the ''Top End,'' a breezy moniker, as though Australia were a boiled egg sitting upright in an egg cup waiting tobe cracked open with a silver spoon. Just how much Top End there is is open to debate, the kind that gets worried out with maps drawn in the dust. While I was there last September, I saw dust maps that gave the Top End most of Australia north of the Tropic of Capricorn - about a third of the continent. Others included only Cape York and the rather wind-swept-looking peninsula that includes the roistering town of Darwin, the capital city of the Northern Territory.

An Awkward Time For a Wish to Come True | Three years ago, Gary P. Delagnes made a prediction to the members of the police union he heads: That in July 2010 the San Francisco police would be members of the "highest-paid major police department in the country." But the police are reaching their long-awaited economic summit when the city is in an economic abyss. Gerry Shih reports that with a  record $522 million budget gap facing the city, some in city government are pushing for the police to give up the 4 percent raise scheduled to take effect July 1 or to face layoffs that could result in a $17 million savings. Despite recent sharp cuts in controversial overtime payments, total police compensation has been rising for the past five years, city data show. In 2009, 52 members officers and members of the command staff took home more than $200,000, with one retiring deputy chief taking home more than $500,000. "When I sit down with my constituency," said Supervisor David Campos, who was on the police commission before running for district office, "the feeling I get is they want the police, but they don't want the police being the best compensated in the country when we're shutting down gyms and pools."

"Growing up in Benin, Angélique Kidjo didn't hear only African music," Jon Pareles writes. "From America there were soul and Santana; from India there were Bollywood musicals. Her father loved jazz. They all had an effect on the music she would make herself, with her strong, wide-open voice riding African-rooted but thoroughly international arrangements." She "now applies her grown-up style to songs she learned from Miriam Makeba, Aretha Franklin and Curtis Mayfield, among others; the guitars and drums often have an Afropop lilt." Tonight listen to these songs as well as others from her new album, "Oyo." She'll be at Town Hall.

"Birdemic: Shock and Terror" is a would-be thriller about avian rampage. Directed and written by James Nguyen, the movie was made for just $10,000 as a tribute to Mr. Nguyen's favorite director, Alfred Hitchcock. "Since 'Birdemic' was discovered at the 2009 Sundance Film Festival — where Mr. Nguyen brought it anyway and showed it in bars after it was rejected by the festival's selection committee — it has become a cult hit on the midnight movie circuit," Dave Itzkoff writes. "Crowds in Austin, Tex., Phoenix and Los Angeles have thrilled to its stilted dialogue, substandard production values and young heroes who defend themselves with coat hangers." The movie has "spawned a discussion about why, of all the Z-grade movies that are made each year, this particular one should find favor with audiences. What has made Mr. Nguyen a latter-day anti-genius to rival Edward D. Wood Jr., whose 1959 horror dud "Plan 9 From Outer Space" became legendary for its countless defects?" Find out tonight and Saturday when IFC Center screens the movie at midnight.

Milton will remain forever cherished deeply within the hearts of those that knew and loved her.

LUND--Theresa M. Died at home in Jupiter, FL, on March 17, 2010 at the age of 69, after a seven year struggle with PSP (Progressive Supranuclear Palsy). During that time she was an inspiration to all who knew her or came in contact with her. Theresa, known to her children, grandchildren and friends as Tzippi, lived a full and fascinating life. She was married for nearly 50 years to Peter A. Lund, the former CEO of CBS. After meeting in the fifth grade and growing up together in Minneapolis, MN, the two of them, along with their sons, Mark and Tim, began an odyssey that included 13 moves and some wonderful adventures. Tzippi was eclectic in her interests and pursuits. As they moved about the country she was, at various times, a yoga instructor, travel agent, banker, hotel sales agent, photographer and small business entrepreneur. She was an avid hiker and with her good pals she trekked in Nepal, hiked portions of the Appalachian Trail, the mountains of Vermont and Colorado and at one point walked across England. In between trips she was a skier, golfer, tennis player, bridge player and still found time to read two or three books every week. But, clearly her greatest accomplishment was the way she handled the last seven years of her life. From the time she was diagnosed with PSP until she died, she never complained. Even during the past several years, when she couldn't talk or move anything except the fingers of her left hand, she would signal yes when asked if she was happy. A truly remarkable woman who was a gift to the wonderful group of friends who were part of her life until the very end. Theresa is survived by her husband, Peter; her two sons, Mark of NBC in New York and Tim of Arnold Advertising in Boston; and her seven grandchildren, Connor, Kelly, Jack, Maxwell, Olivia, Nathan and Charlotte; and her two sisters, Kathy and Patti. A Mass of Christian Burial will be Celebrated 10am, Monday, March 29, 2010 at St. Patrick Catholic Church in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Memorial contributions may be made in Theresa's name to, CurePSP, Foundation for PSP/CBD and related brain diseases, Executive Plaza III, 11350 McCormick Road, Suite 906, Hunt Valley, MD 21031.

van ITALLIE--Nancy Lindberg. With great sorrow, the family of Nancy Lindberg van Itallie announces her death on March 22, 2010. We are proud to say that Mr. McGraw's commitment lives on in his son. Sanford Weill, Chairman JD Hoye, President National Academy Foundation

SACKLER--Mortimer. Colum- bia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Dr. Mortimer D. Sackler, who, along with his family, has been a devoted friend to our institution and Department of Psychiatry. His vision and generous support of the Sackler Institute for Developmental Psychobiology has been invaluable to our growing understanding of the complex processes underlying brain development and mental illness. The recently established Mortimer D. Sackler M.D. Prize for Distinguished Achievement in Developmental Psychobiology will honor his legacy in perpetuity. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Theresa; his children, Ilene Sackler Lefcourt, Kathe A. Sackler, MD, and Mortimer D. Sackler, Jr.; and the entire Sackler family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University Jeffrey A. Lieberman, MD Lieber Professor of Psychiatry Chair, Dept. of Psychiatry
FRIEDMAN--Doris. Farewell to our brave and beloved cousin. May she rest in peace. Irving & Muriel Gerstein and family

KING--Spencer Frederick. We mourn the unexpected loss of our beloved son and brother, Spencer, age 34, who died February 23rd, 2010 in Atlanta, GA. Born in New York on August 26th, 1975 to Olga C. Duke and Joseph P. King (deceased), he graduated from The East Woods School in Oyster Bay, NY, Avon Old Farms in CT and the College of Charleston. He is survived by his mother, Olga C. Duke, his stepfather, Tony Duke, Jr., his sister, Cristina King Kloss, and her husband, Bill Kloss, his half sister, Milena R. Duke and his stepbrother, Anthony Duke, III and his wife, Dana Duke. His beloved niece, Mackenzie Kloss, and nephew, Harrison Kloss, will especially miss him, as will all his aunts, uncles and cousins in the Cabrer and Nevares families. Spencer's sense of humor, his penetrating smile, charisma and deep love for his family, as well as, his ability to fix anything, his love of motorcycles and passion for flying helicopters will always be missed and never forgotten. A funeral service in Palmas del Mar, Puerto Rico, followed by the spreading his ashes at sea, was held on March 2nd. A celebration of Spencer's life will be held on Saturday, April 17th, 2010 at the Creek Club, Locust Valley, NY, 1:30pm.

McGRAW--Harold W.,Jr. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of one of the most esteemed members of the Library family, Harold W. McGraw, Jr. A devoted Trustee for three decades, a generous benefactor, and a great friend, he was deeply dedicated to the cause of education overall and to The New York Public Library in particular. We are grateful for his tireless work in the corporate philanthropic community on the Library's behalf and for his own generous support of our Science, Industry and Business Library, among many other endeavors. We are proud that one of the Library's most beautiful spaces, the McGraw Rotunda, honors his family name. We offer our deepest sympathies to his son, Library Trustee Harold McGraw III, and to all of his family and friends. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

McGRAW--Harold W.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Darien Library mourn the loss of a steadfast and generous supporter, esteemed leader, thoughtful mentor and beloved friend. Harold W. McGraw, Jr. served as Trustee from 1951 to 1957 and 1968 to 1974. He was President of the Library Board from 1953 to 1957 and from 1970 to 1972 and was named an Honorary Trustee in 1977. His leadership of the capital campaign for construction of the first Darien Library in 1957 caused a fellow trustee to remark that Harold McGraw "almost single handedly got the library built." In 1972-74 he led the campaign to expand the building by constructing a new children's wing, which was named in honor of the McGraw family. He was Honorary Co-Chairman of the capital campaign that resulted in construction of the New Darien Library, whose opening was celebrated on January 10, 2009, his 91st birthday, with thousands of visitors singing "Happy Birthday" to him. Harold seldom visited the new building without stopping by the McGraw Children's Library, named in his honor. His support of the engagement, education and entertainment of children was unwavering; it reflected his commitment to the important role of public libraries from the beginning to the end of the life of each person in the community. To his family, especially Sue, Terry and Robert, we express our sorrow for their loss, tempered only by our belief that his great good kindness, his generosity and his unwavering friendship to so many have set an enduring example of all that is best in human nature. To the memory of Harold W. McGraw, Jr., generous with his support, advice, leadership and, above all, friendship-we pledge that we will never forget the lessons he taught us, and we promise that the Darien Library will always reflect his enduring values of intelligence, common sense, enterprise, commitment and integrity.

Jim Marshall, a photographer whose images of Jimi Hendrix, the Rolling Stones, Johnny Cash and others in the 1960s and '70s helped define their subjects as well as rock 'n' roll photography itself, was found dead on Wednesday morning in a Manhattan hotel. He was 74. He had been found unconscious in his room by security personnel at the W Hotel on Lexington Avenue and was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The cause was not immediately known. An autopsy by the medical examiner was inconclusive, and results of toxicology and other tests were not expected for at least a week, a spokeswoman said.

"You don't really think about Curious George saving the day, as the title of the new exhibition at the Jewish Museum puts it. A 'good little monkey,' he is called in the classic series of picture books by Margret and H. A. Rey, but he was no savior. He was a mischief-maker, an innocent, born in the jungle and lured into the strange world of humans," writes Edward Rothstein. "But as the exhibition points out, at least outside of the books' frames, Curious George really did save the day, and more than once. In early September 1939, just after World War II began, the Reys — a husband-and-wife team of German Jews living in Paris — sought refuge at Château Feuga, an old castle owned by some friends in southern France. At such a time, Hans A. Rey wrote in a letter, 'it feels ridiculous to be thinking about children's books.' But that is what they were doing, prolifically, including a book about a monkey named Fifi, who later became known as Curious George." Make an early trip to the museum to find out more about the history of the couple and their beloved creation and to get there before Passover begins. The museum closes at 2 p.m. on Monday and stays closed for the first, second, seventh and eighth days of the holiday.

The idea for my Sunday column, about why boys fail, arose in part when Sheryl and I were on book tour peddling our book "Half the Sky." We would talk about how women in poor countries were being left behind, and so often some member of the audience would say something like: But why are boys in this country lagging?

In 1900, an American man could expect to live on average until he was 45 years old. By 1940, that life-expectancy number had jumped to 62 years, while for women the average number increased from 51 years to 66 years.

Original source documents are the lifeblood of journalism, but rarely are documents associated with news stories seen by the general public. Reporters want to share this material, but the means of doing so - PDFs or Flash-based readers - simply fall short. They are cumbersome and difficult to navigate, search or share. SACKLER--Mortimer D. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Mortimer Sackler, an esteemed Benefactor of the Museum since 1976. Through the generosity of Dr. Sackler and other members of his family, the Metropolitan Museum established The Sackler Wing Galleries (for Asian art), The Sackler Gallery for Egyptian Art, and The Sackler Wing, which houses The Temple of Dendur, the full-scale monument that was built ca. 15 B.C. and was a gift to the United States from Egypt in 1965. Dr. Sackler also endowed The Dr. Mortimer D. Sackler and Theresa Sackler Gallery in the European Paintings Galleries and donated funds for related acquisitions. His benevolence has enhanced many areas of the Museum and will be appreciated by visitors for generations to come. We extend condolences to his entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

LEVINE--Gloria, an accomplished merchandiser of women's high fashion clothing in Westchester for most of her life, died peacefully on March 25, in Lenox, MA. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Levine, nee Schulman, was born into a Westchester fashion family. Her mother and father owned and operated an elegant women's specialty store, L.A. Schulman, Inc. in White Plains which they founded in 1926. She succeeded her parents at L.A. Schulman in the late 1950's and successfully turned the shop into one of the finest fashion stores in the metropolitan area. Preceding her joining the family business, she worked for a junior dress manufacturer in NYC starting as a sketcher and within two years becoming lead designer. Gloria is predeceased by her husband, Samuel Levine in 1978 and by her daughter Lisbeth, a cancer victim, in 1984. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Gussie and Peter Greer, three siblings, Naomi Barry, Phyllis Schain and Lowell Schulman, and four randchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gloria's memory may be made to Hospice Care of the Berkshires, 877 South St., Pittsfield, MA 01201.

A judge on Friday blocked the closing of 19 schools for poor performance, finding the city engaged in ''significant violations'' of the new state law governing mayoral control of city schools. Bloomberg's signature education policies, means the city will have to start over in making its case to close the schools, this time, the judge wrote, with ''meaningful community involvement.''

EAST Kentucky may not be the best team left in the field, but it would be hard to argue any team has been better. The top-seeded Wildcats' victory against Cornell on Thursday showed them at their dominating best - in a 30-6 first-half run - and at their precocious worst, when a sloppy second half by their freshman-heavy lineup let the Big Red stay close. DeMarcus Cousins was a handful for Cornell, and he probably will be for West Virginia, too. But the Mountaineers' biggest concerns are injury-related. The loss of point guard Darryl Bryant (broken foot) leaves them thin in the backcourt against Kentucky's John Wall and Eric Bledsoe, and the star forward Da'Sean Butler injured his right hand in a fall against Washington. Butler packed his hand in ice after practice on Friday.

Tulips were as important a part of the Dutch Golden Age as canal houses. They were treasured as possessions, speculated upon as commodities and revered as subjects for artists. Though so-called "tulipmania" has died down, aspects of the obsession continue. Every spring, Dutch crowds and tourists flock to the Keukenhof gardens to take in endless fields of flowers, and the flowers are the subject of a small ongoing exhibition at the Rijksmuseum (Stadhouderskade 42; 31-20-674-7000; www.rijksmuseum.nl), simply titled "Tulips in Amsterdam."

IN 1986, Daimler-Benz commissioned the pop artist Andy Warhol to make a series of paintings to celebrate the automaker's centennial. The plan was for 80 works, and the subjects would be 20 of Daimler's most important cars, including the Benz Patent Motorwagen of 1886, generally considered the first car ever built. But Warhol died on Feb. 22, 1987, of a heart attack shortly after gall bladder surgery, having completed only 35 silkscreens and 12 large-scale drawings. The pieces belong to the Daimler Art Collection and are now on display at the Albertina Museum in Vienna. It is the first time, says the German newspaper Der Spiegal, that the collection has been shown together since an exhibition at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan in 1988.

LONDON -- Harry Carpenter, a popular sportscaster for the BBC who was hailed as the voice of boxing in Britain and who announced some of the sport's biggest fights, died on March 20 in London. He was 84. The cause was complications of a heart attack that he had last summer, his family said.

Crocuses in New York parks have formed a patchwork of color. In Times Square, early daffodils brighten an island. Women have shed winter boots for the comfort of flat shoes. In New York, the comfort factor drives fashion. Across the Atlantic in Paris earlier this month, the difference between the two cities was clearly seen in the choice of footwear. In the French capital, it's all about status and taste, regardless of discomfort. I saw women change to flat shoes after attending a show. The interior of the show tent was black and the lighting almost nonexistent; no one could see your face, let alone your feet. Back in New York, a French bulldog succumbed to the comfort of flat booties on a rainy day.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Business of Game Quells Thrill,'' March 22: New York Gauchos Coach Russell Smith's criticized the recently fired Norm Roberts for being too laid-back as the men's basketball coach at St. John's. In my experiences in intercollegiate athletics, a majority conduct their business as did Roberts.

ON a recent afternoon at an airy recording studio here, Usher Raymond IV leaned back in a chair and sang along as ''There Goes My Baby,'' a slow-burning ballad from his forthcoming album, ''Raymond v. Raymond'' (Jive), played over the sound system, occasionally picking up an unlighted cigar, which he rolled in his mouth. When the song ended, this 31-year-old singer, who records under his first name, motioned for an engineer to shut the sound system off and launched into an explanation of the tune's origins.
