DEAN--Kenneth Bass On March 21, 2010, passed away leaving behind Susanne, his beloved wife and best friend of 60 years. He is also survived by his cherished sons and their wives William, Kenneth, Barbara, Jonathan and Claire, as well as six adoring grandchildren Alexander, Scott, Patrick, Casey, Elizabeth and Madeline, two devoted sisters Gloria Mayer and Nancy Dayton and his faithful friend Zorro. Born in Brooklyn, NY on December 22, 1925, Ken proudly attended Union College and joined the Navy during WWII where he rose to the rank of Lieutenant JG. After the War, he followed in his father's footsteps and joined W. E. Dean & Company as a commercial real estate broker in lower Manhattan. At that time, lower Manhattan consisted of tea and coffee warehouses and ship chandlers eventually evolving into the financial capital of the world. In the mid sixties he merged with Cushman & Wakefield, Inc. where he continued a very successful career and was often referred to as "Mr. Downtown." He resided in Garden City, NY with a summer home in Quogue, NY before retiring in 1994 to Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Quogue. Ken loved life, the New York Jets and enjoyed golf, biking, swimming, fishing and spending time with family and friends. Loved by all who knew him, his courage, spirit and enthusiasm will never be forgotten. Details for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Ken's family respectfully requests that donations be made in his memory to The ALS Association, 42 Broadway, New York, NY 10004 or ALS Research Fund, 1120 NW 14th St., Miami, FL 33136. Services entrusted to Aycock Funeral Home, Jupiter, FL. Online condolences may be made at aycockfuneralhomejupiter.com

RYSKAMP--Charles A. The Board of Trustees of The Frick Collection and Anne L. Poulet, Director, wish to express their profound sorrow at the death of Dr. Charles Ryskamp, Director Emeritus. Mr. Ryskamp served with extraordinary distinction as Director of the Frick from June 1987 until September 1997, and continued to serve as an advisor until very recently. During his tenure at the Frick, the institution underwent profound evolution. He expanded the special exhibition program, developed new gallery spaces, enhanced the publications program, strengthened the Collection with new art works, and built broader-based support among existing constituencies, while making countless new friends for the Frick. His tireless efforts to stabilize the finances of the Frick Art Reference Library ensured its enduring presence in the world of art history research. His deep knowledge of literature and art informed every aspect of his leadership of the institution, where his commitment to scholarship and connoisseurship remain the touchstones of our mission. Previously seen as a staid and static museum, Mr. Ryskamp found ways to energize the institution without losing sight of its high standards and unique place in the art world. His tireless, ever-engaging, larger-than-life persona drew a widening audience into the Frick circle, and set the course for expanding our outreach to a broader visitorship. He will be remembered for his passionate love of art, for his dedication to ensuring the strength and stability of the institution, as a gifted connoisseur, and for his wisdom, warmth and marvelous wit. He will be deeply missed. Margot C. Bogert, Chair Anne L. Poulet, Director

LONDON -- Harry Carpenter, a popular sportscaster for the BBC who was hailed as the voice of boxing in Britain and who announced some of the sport's biggest fights, died on March 20 in London. He was 84. The cause was complications of a heart attack that he had last summer, his family said.
The New York Times Style Magazine spring 2010 logo.

Besides being a dictator, a political thorn for the West and a Dr. Evil-like figure of pop culture ridicule, the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il is also a film buff. Other dictators have taken an interest in cinema as a propaganda tool -- Stalin exploited Sergei Eisenstein and Hitler hired Leni Riefenstahl -- but Mr. Kim has gone further. The Dear Leader, as he is called, is the author of the textbook cum manifesto ''On the Art of the Cinema.'' He has been known to function as a hands-on mogul in the state-run film industry, rewriting scripts and nurturing pet projects. In 1978 -- while running the propaganda department under his father, Kim Il-sung, the country's founding president -- he even arranged the kidnapping of Shin Sang-ok, a South Korean director, whom he tasked with improving the quality of North Korean movies.

Television Through its first 10 episodes last September the good-natured ''10 THINGS I HATE ABOUT YOU,'' descended from ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' was the smartest, funniest and sweetest of the tween and tween-plus shows battling for young audiences on ABC Family, Nickelodeon and the Disney Channel. It returns on Monday (ABC Family, 8 p.m.) with the squabbling Stratford sisters, Bianca (Meaghan Martin) and Kat (Lindsey Shaw), each caught up in a crisis: Bianca needs to destroy the evidence of her kiss with the ex-boyfriend of Padua High School's queen bee, Chastity (Dana Davis), while Kat needs to sneak into school during her one-day suspension to take a crucial exam. Ms. Martin remains the high point of the excellent ensemble, though at 18, she's threatening to age out of her younger-sister role. With its sharply written but traditional sitcom humor, ''10 Things'' is like a lower-budget ''Glee,'' without the songs and the sometimes nasty edge.

A new group of yachts is catering to the boating crowd's appetite for adventure and design. The 105-foot Necker Belle catamaran (virginlimitededition.com; $88,000 a week), refurbished last year by Sir Richard Branson, has a wine cellar, an outdoor movie theater and a three-person submersible for exploring reefs and wrecks. Reflecting the new emphasis on exploring remote waters, Cape Race (right; mvcaperace.com; $2,000 to $3,000 per person per week) is a converted fishing trawler -- outfitted with six generous cabins and a mahogany-paneled saloon -- that can cross the Atlantic twice without refueling. And the Panthalassa (camperandnicholsons.com; $200,000 a week), a 184-foot ketch with off-white interiors by Foster & Partners, has an oval stairway that brings sunlight to the lower level, where staterooms are paneled in leather and bathrooms tiled in black marble. MICHAEL CANNELL

Midwest Tennessee's win over Ohio State was probably the best preparation it could have hoped for before facing Michigan State. Wayne Chism and Brian Williams were overpowering inside against the Buckeyes, but the Spartans can spread defenses with their 3-point shooting, and they make rebounding a point of pride. The Spartans went to the Final Four last year, and taking them out this time will not be easy.

THE Columbia is a tall yellow-brick condominium at the corner of Broadway and West 96th Street, populated by many families and professionals. On weekday mornings, the lobby bustles with kids scurrying to school and grown-ups hurrying to work. Lately, though, there has been an addition to the hubbub: Contractors, lines of them, waiting for authorization to ascend the elevator to the apartments they are in the process of renovating. Men with tool belts used to be a common sight around condo and co-op buildings in a city that was renovation-mad. But when the economy collapsed and the real estate market tanked, the contractors, along with the carpenters, plumbers, electricians, floor guys and stone guys, seemed to fade away.
To the Sports Editor: ''The Glory Days of Football'' (March 26) states that in 1930, the St. Mary's College football team was perhaps the first sports team to be honored at the White House.
MENELL--Marion. There is an empty space in my heart where my special Aunt Marion, my second mother, always dwelled. Phil and I will miss her terribly. Ilene and Phil

The unlovely term ''vernacular architecture'' describes some of the most unusual buildings ever created, from Mongolian yurts to Irish sod houses. Many (like a treehouse 148 feet above the West Papuan rain forest) lie at the frontiers of the imagination, while others (like a shanty in Manila held together with urban waste) we'd prefer to forget. The forthcoming book ''Buildings Without Architects'' (Rizzoli, $23) presents them all as works of grass-roots ingenuity, pegging modish key words like ''sustainable'' to ancient buildings, most of which were made of stuff that's been around since prehistoric times. STEPHEN HEYMAN

ZIPORA FRIED is not afraid of repetition. As an artist, Ms. Fried, who was born in Israel and grew up in Vienna, is best known for her large, labor-intensive drawings covered in silvery thickets of rapid pencil strokes. One drawing can take weeks to complete. Now she has turned her manual skills to making a dizzying array of Austrian-style dumplings in New York. A schnitzel's throw from Schiller's, Kinski, as her new cafe is called, serves seven kinds of sweet and savory dumplings, called knödel (the schupfnudeln, or potato noodles, are divine), as well as Viennese coffee and pastries, and such all-day breakfast fare as kaiserschmarren, or the emperor's pancakes, made with egg whites, powdered sugar and plum preserves. Heaven! Kinski, 128 Rivington Street; (646) 270-9733. Weekdays, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.; weekends, 11 a.m. to midnight. STEVE PULIMOOD

Butler's run to the Final Four may be unlikely, but basketball fans in Indianapolis with long enough memories recall the Bulldogs playing on the same stage as Big Ten and other major-conference teams in the 1950s and '60s. And in those days before ESPN - heck, in those days when no one on our block had a color TV - a Butler fan could watch the Bulldogs about as often as he could see Indiana and Purdue. Butler had only about 2,000 students then and played in the Indiana Collegiate Conference. But it had a renowned if now widely forgotten coach, Tony Hinkle, and a fieldhouse that was the largest basketball arena in the country when it opened in 1928.
KORN--Jay. The world is a sadder place now. Our hearts are broken but your spirit will see us through. We love you and will miss you always. Mira, Gil, Alison, Greg, Evan and Julie

Boats have a unique capacity to make you feel close to nature, but they also have a unique capacity to pollute it. A few carriers, however, have set a course for sustainability. Disney Cruise Line's laundry facilities use water generated by their air-conditioners -- some 50 tons a day. And the heat produced by the ship powers evaporators that turn 1,000 tons of seawater into potable water daily. disneycruise.disney.go.com.

Just as bushy beards and Hunter boots have captured the pastoral fantasies of the urban fashion tribe, a taste for field and stream is driving the travel avant-garde. Nowadays, rural pleasures -- whether it's picking your own asparagus or indulging your inner ranger -- have given rise to a new breed of back-to-the-land destinations.

For travelers 66 years or older, Tourism Ireland is offering a Golden Trekker Pass: four days of unlimited free train travel on Irish Rail. The Irish Rail route map covers most of Ireland, from Cork to Dublin, to Galway to Dundalk, the last stop in the Republic of Ireland. The pass is not available for travel in Northern Ireland.

IT says something (not good) about the state of foreign film distribution in the United States that the Portuguese director Pedro Costa has become one of the most exalted figures in world cinema without having a single one of his creations open in a commercial theater here. Instead his work has been disseminated through not-for-profit institutions like Anthology Film Archives (which presented a Costa retrospective in 2007) and the New York Film Festival (which showed his newest film, ''Ne Change Rien,'' a documentary about the French actress and singer Jeanne Balibar, in the fall). Which makes it all the more remarkable that the Criterion Collection is releasing ''Letters From Fontainhas,'' a generously appointed boxed set that contains Mr. Costa's trilogy filmed in the Fontainhas district of Lisbon -- ''Ossos'' (1997), ''In Vanda's Room'' (2000) and ''Colossal Youth'' (2006) -- as well as two of his short films, a feature-length documentary on his work and a huge repository of written and audio-visual commentary from an international assembly of artists and scholars.
BRUDNER--Matthew. We will miss our dear friend who was a mench and a gutte neshumah. Our hearts go out to the Brudner family. Hope and Jeffrey Halpert

THE calendar says spring has sprung. But inside the typical city apartment, one that lacks skylights and glassy southern exposures and unlimited views of blue sky, spring does not arrive on autopilot. Many New Yorkers must actively invest in spring by adding a few hardy houseplants that can make it anywhere, like a dim walk-up in Hell's Kitchen or a tiny railroad apartment in the Bronx. Harriet Beecher Stowe contended that caring for houseplants was a way of girding one's moral fiber, but the plants can gird one's morale as well. Try a blooming lily (perhaps a clivia) or a mini-cyclamen, which will blossom for months if the room temperature stays below 70 degrees.

By recording their ninth victory Friday night, the Nets avoided becoming the worst team in N.B.A. history. But after losing to the Bulls in Chicago on Saturday night, they still have a chance to finish in a tie for that distinction with the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers if they do not record a victory in their last nine games. The poor season will at least give the Nets a shot at taking Kentucky's John Wall with the first pick in the draft. It is just that -- a shot. In its history, the league has gone through a variety of ways to determine how the top pick is selected. Since 1993, the team with the worst record has had a 25 percent chance of securing the first pick. In the 25 lotteries, the league's cellar-dweller has come away with the No. 1 overall selection only four times.

KLEMM--David Robert, President of Klemm Real Estate in Washington Depot, CT, passed away peacefully early Saturday morning in Palm Beach, FL, after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in South Bend, IN on January 12, 1938, he attended the University of Notre Dame, and graduated from Indiana University, where he was President of Beta Theta Pi fraternity. After retiring from an illustrious career in radio broadcasting, he moved to Washington, CT in 1977 where he and his wife, Carolyn, began Klemm Real Estate which became Litchfield County's premier luxury real estate firm. David served as President and Director of Marketing for the firm's five offices and forty agents until recently when he handed stewardship over to his two sons. Mr. Klemm is survived by his beloved wife Carolyn Viccari Klemm, his son Peter R. Klemm and daughter-in-law Christina Klemm, his son Graham T. Klemm and partner Matthew Lynn, and adored granddaughter Natalie Klemm. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather who was intelligent, honest, articulate, good humored and a great communicator. Although a private man he had countless friends and colleagues who admired his great dignity and the integrity of his life. There will be a private family graveside service.

Q.My niece will be studying architecture in Rome for the coming fall semester, and we would love to combine a trip to Rome and possibly Florence while visiting her with her parents. Could you suggest reasonably priced but nice hotels in both Rome and Florence and a possible itinerary for three days in Rome and two in Florence? We'd take the train to Florence from Rome. Pamela Castellano,Huntington, N.Y.

THE NEWS Police officials in Philadelphia said they would increase curfew enforcement, reduce student privileges on mass transit and take other steps to curtail ''flash mobs'' of teenagers. BEHIND THE NEWS The sudden gatherings of people linked through social-networking sites or text messages began benignly but have turned raucous lately, with crowds of youths sprinting down city blocks and sometimes brawling, vandalizing property or assaulting bystanders. ''It was like a tsunami of kids,'' said a deliveryman who was beaten when he tried to keep a rowdy flash mob from invading a pizza shop.

CHURCHILL--Jonathan Hand, 78, died peacefully at his Manhattan home on March 26, 2010, from complications of Lewy body disease. Born in New York City, he was the son of Mary Hand Darrell and John Dwight Winston Churchill, and a grandson of Judge Learned Billings Hand and of the American author, Winston Churchill. After graduating from Harvard College and Harvard Law School and serving in the U.S. Army, he practiced law in the City. He was a member of the Century Association, the American Law Institute, the New York City Bar Association and the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club. He is fondly remembered on Martha's Vineyard and elsewhere as an avid sailor who took great pleasure cruising and racing his 1926 Q boat "Taygeta" and the 1979 trimaran "Moxie". He navigated "Moxie's" record-breaking win (64 hours, 48 minutes) in the 1987 Newport Bermuda Multihull Race. He is survived by his wife, Judith Gaebel Churchill, as well as three step-brothers, Norris Darrell, Jr., Richard W. Darrell and Cass Canfield, Jr. A memorial will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Central Park Conservancy (centralparknyc.org) or Sail Martha's Vineyard (sailmv).

One of France's most traditional cities, Bordeaux is loosening up, with an infrastructural face-lift and experimental new restaurants and boutiques. WHY IT'S HOT: A young generation of winemakers, restaurateurs and fashion designers, along with British expats and Parisian transplants seeking a slower pace, has given Bordeaux an unstuffy new profile. Mayor Alain Juppé sandblasted the city's sootyfacades and installed 27 miles of tramway with an all-underground power supply.

NOAH BAUMBACH'S new movie is called ''Greenberg,'' but it is equally -- maybe even more so -- the story of Florence Marr. Roger Greenberg, the title character, has the more familiar face by far; he's played by Ben Stiller, a big movie star sliding comfortably into a small, sharp movie. But Florence's face is the first one we see. She wanders into the frame pulling a large, slow-moving dog and is then captured in close-up as she negotiates Los Angeles traffic on the way to her job as the household assistant of a well-to-do family with a house in the hills. That face, its soft jaw and wide gray-green eyes topped by untameable dirty-blond hair, is not likely to be recognized by most viewers. Greta Gerwig, the 26-year-old actress, screenwriter and filmmaker who plays Florence, has appeared mainly in the kind of low-key, low-budget, socially networked features that I will try, from this moment forward, not to call mumblecore. ''Greenberg'' is obviously a breakthrough for her -- even if Mr. Baumbach, whose four previous features include ''Kicking and Screaming'' and ''The Squid and the Whale,'' is not exactly Michael Bay -- though not necessarily a departure.

COMMON wisdom holds that there was a magical time long ago when, whatever your seat assignment, flying was first class. But when did it all end? Last week, Marie Force, the archivist at the Delta Heritage Museum in Atlanta, published an online gallery of photographs of Delta flight attendant uniforms from 1940 to the present. ''Delta was one of the more conservative airlines,'' Ms. Force said. ''We didn't have hot pants.'' Still, for almost 40 straight years, the airline's female flight attendants (something called ''stewardesses'') turned heads with overseas caps (the '40s), stiletto pumps (the '50s), A-line topcoats (the '60s) and bell-bottoms (the '70s). Then, in the '80s, Delta took a style nosedive with doofus sweater vests and horse-bow cravats. The uniform at right, in service from 1950 to 1956, required only an eye patch to transform a Delta attendant into a sexy pulp villainess, like Angelina Jolie in the retro-futurist flop ''Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow.'' More period uniforms are at deltamuseum.org. STEPHEN HEYMAN

BRAUSE--Ruth. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Ruth Brause, beloved mother of Louis and mother-in-law of Ruth Brause. Ruth, Louis, and the Brause family are dear friends who are greatly admired for their extraordinary generosity, profoundly strengthening the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and beyond. We extend our sympathies to Ruth, Louis, and the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Lauber of Little Egg Harbor, NJ. Memorial service to be held on Saturday, May 1 at 11am at St. Paul's-onthe-Green in Norwalk, CT. Burial will be private. Contributions to Animals in Distress, 238 Danbury Road, Wilton, CT 06897 would be appreciated.

KALTENBACHER--Pauline Seidel, died in her 95th year, on March 24, 2010. Devoted wife of the late Richard S. Kaltenbacher and daughter of the late Joseph Seidel and Bertha Montegue Seidel. Polly lived in St. Louis, Boston, South Orange, Highland Beach and Martha's Vineyard and had an unmatched zest for life. She is survived by Carol and Philip Mehler, Nancy and Edward Strauss, and Joseph and Gail Kaltenbacher. Loving and generous grandmother to Amanda and Mark Tamis, Rick and Melissa Mehler, Arthur and Elizabeth Jacobson, Elizabeth and David Kaufman, Thomas and Traci Jacobson, Jason and Edie Kaltenbacher and Eric Kaltenbacher, as well as great-grandmother of Isabella, Harry and Ricky Tamis, Hannah Rose and Samuel Mehler, Zoe, Samuel, Grace and Rachel Jacobson, Chloe Jacobson, and Willa and Oliver Kaufman. Proud graduate of Wellesley College, class of 1936. Donations in her memory can be sent to: Development Office, Wellesley College, 106 Center St., Wellesley, MA 02481 or Martha's Vineyard Hospital.

Virgin America is going to Disney World. The airline today announced new daily nonstop flights to Orlando from Los Angeles and San Francisco beginning in August. One-way fares will start at $149 and $199 respectively. The three-year-old airline also announced plans for its first international destination, with direct flights to Toronto from Los Angeles and San Francisco, pending a decision by the Department of Transportation. Three more destinations are also in the works for 2010.

When you own a 150-acre farm, having a change of heart about how you do things is a slow, costly process. When you're a third-generation rice farmer in rural Louisiana -- a state with just 23 organic farms -- deciding to try to grow brown rice without pesticides or chemical fertilizers is enough to get you certified not organic, but insane. Fifteen years ago, Kurt and Karen Unkel of Kinder, La., decided the risk was worth it. ''I started this because I could not see the future in conventional farming,'' Kurt told me when I visited him last month. Back then, he and his brother were farming 2,000 acres. But ''it got to where you could plow 100 acres and you wouldn't find one earthworm.'' As he spoke, he turned over the soil in his experimental vegetable garden, sending earthworms squirming back toward the ground. ''And as I learned about the nutrition, there just wasn't no stopping. You're dealing with life!''

LeBLANG--Milton. May 17, 1921-March 26, 2010. A loved and respected man. His life made the world a better place. Services at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Road, Great Neck, NY, Sunday, March 28, 12pm.

TAKING THE PLUNGE, VICTORIA FALLS, ON THE BORDER OF ZIMBABWE AND ZAMBIA, AUG. 1, 2009 Hazel Aslin, 17, a high school student from Wimpole, England, bungee jumps off the Victoria Falls Bridge near Livingstone, Zambia. ''As soon as I knew I was going to Zambia, I thought, 'Yeah, I'm definitely bungee jumping.' It was my first time doing it, but, at first, I wasn't scared at all. Even as I stood on the bridge, I was watching other people do it, and still the nerves hadn't hit me. Then, there's a kind of platform you go onto to get harnessed up. And as soon as I stepped on that platform, I was absolutely petrified. Before you jump, it's really beautiful. You've got the falls behind you and you can see the rapids below you and this deep gorge. But when you're actually jumping, it all flies past. I was really worried that there was going to be a massive jerk -- that it would hurt or something -- but I realized I couldn't even feel whether I was going up or down. It all just kind of merged into one.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Does the Ending Need Rewriting,'' March 24: Committing a foul during a basketball game is a rule violation. If a college player incurs five fouls, he or she is removed from the game.

Theater Playwrights Horizons has been on a hot streak lately, with one acclaimed production after another making this new-play incubator fertile again. Next up, on the small stage where Annie Baker's ''Circle Mirror Transformation'' became a sell-out sensation last fall, and hot on the heels of Bruce Norris's ''Clybourne Park,'' is the latest play from Kia Corthron, whose previous works include ''Breath, Boom'' and ''Force Continuum.''

During Holy Week, multitudes descend on the Vatican, and therefore Rome. Beginning on Palm Sunday (March 28) and continuing until Easter Sunday (April 4), the already numerous springtime visitors will be joined by tens of thousands of pilgrims, eager to participate in the liturgical calendar's most important events. Crowds at St. Peter's Basilica and the adjacent Vatican Museums are inevitable, but with a bit of planning, avoiding the throngs is possible. St. Peter's Basilica and Square will host Papal Masses, audiences and celebrations throughout the week. Tickets to the events are free, but must be secured well in advance through local dioceses or from the Prefecture of the Pontifical Household (39-06-6988-4857; www.vatican.va). Reserved tickets are required for Holy Thursday Mass, Good Friday Mass and Saturday's Easter Vigil - all at the Basilica. Those hoping to grab a spot at the outdoor Masses on the Square on Palm Sunday and Easter Sunday, 9:30 and 10:15 a.m., respectively, should arrive well ahead of time.
BRUDNER--Matthew. We are all saddened by this terrible tragedy. Our thoughts and prayers are with you all. We love you, Helene and Al Kaplan Mona and Dan Morello

ADAM GOLDSTEIN, better known as DJ AM, was a disc jockey to the stars. He worked on albums for Madonna and Will Smith. He dated Nicole Richie and Mandy Moore. And as if that weren't enough fodder for the tabloids, he appeared on a reality TV show as a recovering addict. He was found dead last summer, in what was ruled an accidental overdose.

LUND--Theresa M. Died at home in Jupiter, FL, on March 17, 2010 at the age of 69, after a seven year struggle with PSP (Progressive Supranuclear Palsy). During that time she was an inspiration to all who knew her or came in contact with her. Theresa, known to her children, grandchildren and friends as Tzippi, lived a full and fascinating life. She was married for nearly 50 years to Peter A. Lund, the former CEO of CBS. After meeting in the fifth grade and growing up together in Minneapolis, MN, the two of them, along with their sons, Mark and Tim, began an odyssey that included 13 moves and some wonderful adventures. Tzippi was eclectic in her interests and pursuits. As they moved about the country she was, at various times, a yoga instructor, travel agent, banker, hotel sales agent, photographer and small business entrepreneur. She was an avid hiker and with her good pals she trekked in Nepal, hiked portions of the Appalachian Trail, the mountains of Vermont and Colorado and at one point walked across England. In between trips she was a skier, golfer, tennis player, bridge player and still found time to read two or three books every week. But, clearly her greatest accomplishment was the way she handled the last seven years of her life. From the time she was diagnosed with PSP until she died, she never complained. Even during the past several years, when she couldn't talk or move anything except the fingers of her left hand, she would signal yes when asked if she was happy. A truly remarkable woman who was a gift to the wonderful group of friends who were part of her life until the very end. Theresa is survived by her husband, Peter; her two sons, Mark of NBC in New York and Tim of Arnold Advertising in Boston; and her seven grandchildren, Connor, Kelly, Jack, Maxwell, Olivia, Nathan and Charlotte; and her two sisters, Kathy and Patti. A Mass of Christian Burial will be Celebrated 10am, Monday, March 29, 2010 at St. Patrick Catholic Church in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Memorial contributions may be made in Theresa's name to, CurePSP, Foundation for PSP/CBD and related brain diseases, Executive Plaza III, 11350 McCormick Road, Suite 906, Hunt Valley, MD 21031.

MENELL--Marion. My sister always cared, my sister always shared, my sister was one of three, my other sister and me. Now I am only two, but I know what to do, I will always cherish her love, she would do the same for me too. So long Dear Marion. Morty Howard

Johannesburg's Arts on Main complex, with its stylish mix of tenants, has quickly become a culture hub since it opened last summer, bringing life back into the heart of a neglected central business district. The project, the brainchild of the 27-year-old developer Jonathan Liebmann (who's currently converting a nearby factory into a hotel in time for this summer's World Cup), occupies five redone warehouses around a central courtyard (below right) on the corner of Main and Berea Streets. The complex's anchor is the studio of the celebrated South African artist William Kentridge, whose presence has helped draw an elite group of chefs, designers and gallery owners. Canteen: Locals and tourists alike flock to this cafe (above left) for gastropub-meets-game-reserve fare (think ploughman's platters and springbok carpaccio) courtesy of the British chef Richard Rust. The walls display work by the complex's residents, and a rooftop bar holds film screenings. 011-27-83-399-9740; entrees $6 to $12.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week are Nell Irvin Painter, the author of ''The History of White People''; Pamela Paul on Laurie Abraham's adventures in group couples therapy; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Paper Cuts The Book Review's blog covers books and other forms of printed matter.

THE stereo died with a wheeze, the lights clicked out, and suddenly there was only darkness and the sound of the wind rustling through palm trees. The air was soft and warm, fluid against the skin. Stars began to rise against the inky blackness around them. The moon poured down. This was Gran Roque, the tiny main settlement of Los Roques national park in Venezuela, an archipelago of coral, mangrove and sand that lies less than 100 miles north of Caracas in the Caribbean Sea. It was a weekday night in the middle of winter, at the start of one of the blackouts that has plagued the mainland and these islands for months.

Starbucks has lately found itself in the middle of a debate between advocates of ''open carry'' gun rights and of gun control; the former have held armed meet-ups at several of its locations, and the latter have demanded that the coffee chain prevent this from happening. Seeking to duck these fresh salvos in the long debate over how firearms fit into American life, the company has issued a statement that such matters ought to be worked out ''in the legislatures and courts, not in our stores.'' Well, sure. But drawing a line between official institutions of lawmaking and the daily sphere where citizens move about is not so easy. And one thing the pistols-and-Frappuccino moment has demonstrated is that this is acutely true for a business with an image carefully devised to blur the line between public space and commercial space. Fans of more-expansive interpretations of the Second Amendment see it as their right to bear arms while going about their routine business, which usually means carrying a concealed weapon. It also turns out that a surprising number of states grant the right to carry an unconcealed weapon. The catch is that private businesses are often allowed to ban guns from their premises, making it difficult, as a practical matter, to run errands while outfitted like Wyatt Earp on the way to the O.K. Corral. Starbucks, as it happens, does not impose such rules in its many thousand square feet of space in states that happen to have open-carry laws. The meet-ups seemed calculated to inspire a showdown, and that's what happened. Peet's and California Pizza Kitchen were also picked as meet-up spots by the open-carry crowd in the San Francisco Bay Area, and these companies responded by promptly instituting no-gun rules. When Starbucks demurred, the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence organized an online petition inviting you to ''Tell Starbucks: 'Keep Guns Out.' ''

KING--Spencer Frederick. We mourn the unexpected loss of our beloved son and brother, Spencer, age 34, who died February 23rd, 2010 in Atlanta, GA. Born in New York on August 26th, 1975 to Olga C. Duke and Joseph P. King (deceased), he graduated from The East Woods School in Oyster Bay, NY, Avon Old Farms in CT and the College of Charleston. He is survived by his mother, Olga C. Duke, his stepfather, Tony Duke, Jr., his sister, Cristina King Kloss, and her husband, Bill Kloss, his half sister, Milena R. Duke and his stepbrother, Anthony Duke, III and his wife, Dana Duke. His beloved niece, Mackenzie Kloss, and nephew, Harrison Kloss, will especially miss him, as will all his aunts, uncles and cousins in the Cabrer and Nevares families. Spencer's sense of humor, his penetrating smile, charisma and deep love for his family, as well as, his ability to fix anything, his love of motorcycles and passion for flying helicopters will always be missed and never forgotten. A funeral service in Palmas del Mar, Puerto Rico, followed by the spreading his ashes at sea, was held on March 2nd. A celebration of Spencer's life will be held on Saturday, April 17th, 2010 at the Creek Club, Locust Valley, NY, 1:30pm.

Q.A friend and I will be spending the weekend in Nicaragua at the end of April. We want to travel with a guide/translator who can help us navigate street food and local living along with volcano/kayak/canopy options. Is there any reasonably priced tour in which we can work with a local guide and create our own itinerary? Elyse Pasquale, New YorkA.For private tours, Gregory Dicum, in his article ''The Rediscovery of Nicaragua'' (Dec. 17, 2006), suggested Tours Nicaragua (toursnicaragua.com; 505-2265-3095). The company's general manager, Richard Leonardi, in an e-mail message, quoted an average cost of $175 to $230 a person per day (based on double occupancy) for a fully guided tour that features a custom-designed itinerary, English-speaking guide, hotels in each location, daily activities and private transportation. Frommer's (the Travel section's online content partner) also lists Explore Nicaragua Tours (505-2250-1534). I spoke with Zobeyda Manzanares, a company representative, who quoted $75 (plus tax) a person per day, for a tour of Granada that ends at the Mombacho volcano, and includes an English-speaking guide.

WASHINGTON -- Just a few months into his first term in 1993, President Bill Clinton went to Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the protector of Senate rules, to ask permission to use a fast-track budget process known as reconciliation to enact a bold health care overhaul. The president did not get the senator's consent, and he did not get a health care law, either.

Williamsburg Is the New Williamsburg Should you find yourself wandering the streets of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, these days, you might be reminded of another Williamsburg, the restored historic village in Virginia. With shops like the Brooklyn Kitchen, where you can learn how to pickle vegetables and butcher your own pig, and Rye, where you can sip an old-fashioned at the 100-year-old oak bar, the neighborhood hasn't quite returned to colonial times -- but chances are your server will have facial hair and woolens that would do an 18th-century blacksmith proud. There are glass blowers (Michael Anchin Glass Company), perfume makers (CB I Hate Perfume) and illegal urban beekeepers who've set up shop in East Williamsburg with that same can-do spirit that got us to the New World in the first place. While you might not hear the resounding fife and drums of our founding fathers, the bars on Bedford Avenue are jammed with Bunyan-bearded hipsters who look as if they moonlight in a fiddle band. And the spirit of Patrick Henry lives on in these Brooklynites, whose call to arms is ''Give me bike lanes or give me death!'' KATHLEEN EGAN

Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl has recruited one McDonald's all-American: Scotty Hopson, a 6-foot-7 sophomore guard. Pearl said the joke in the program was that ''Scotty is the McDonald's all-American, the rest of the guys just eat there.'' But Hopson, who was supposed to be a dynamic scorer, has played only one dynamic offensive game in the postseason, making 7 of 9 shots in the Volunteers' second-round victory over Ohio. In the Midwest Regional semifinal against Ohio State, he was 1 of 5 from the field.

MARSHALL--Jim. Leica Camera is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, supporter and music photography icon. A revered photographer, Jim Marshall was one of the few artists who was uniquely capable of capturing the musical energy that emanated from the greatest musicians of the 20th century. His exceptional personality and reverence for his subjects coupled with unparalleled access allowed him to encapsulate timeless memories. It is an honor to have worked alongside one of the greatest photographers of all time. We wish to extend our deepest sympathy to Jim's entire family. With heartfelt condolences, Leica Camera

BACK in the 1940s, when ''mall'' was just a word for shady promenade and downtown Haverstraw was still a shopping hub for Rockland County, the sturdy old brick building that houses Union Restaurant and Bar Latino was a clothing store called Pressler's. It's safe to say the Presslers would not recognize the place today. Where gabardine once hung, there are lanterns, stucco arches, stained glass, local artwork. Where tailors fitted the local swells with blue serge suits, waiters regale the swells of another era with pitchers of tangy, tequila-infused sangria and plates of first-rate rack of lamb. Perhaps the only thing that hasn't changed is the pressed-tin ceiling.

SYRACUSE -- After West Virginia's loss at Connecticut on Feb. 22, West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins sat his team in a circle in the locker room. Huggins has broken a few chairs and made some power forwards blush with his language over the years, but that day he calmly reminded the Mountaineers of their potential. The theme of that speech was about ''being special,'' and what this team means to the state of West Virginia.

Wan Chai, one of the oldest districts in Hong Kong, has been quickly gentrifying. To tap into the area's remaining authentic culture, check out the Wanchai Livelihood Place, an organization started by a group of local residents to preserve and celebrate the neighborhood's distinct identity. The Livelihood Place (852-2835-4376; www.wclive.net) offers a blend of exhibitions and tours that delve into the neighborhood's history. ''Hong Kong changes so quickly,'' said Kevin Lee, the organization's photo and design editor. ''Our hope was to preserve reminders of our heritage, especially for the local youth. The fact that we have been attracting foreign tourists as well is a pleasant surprise, so we have recently been developing more English-language materials.''

HIS WANDERLUST By the time you read this, David de Rothschild will be floating somewhere in the middle of the Pacific Ocean on the Plastiki, a 60-foot catamaran made primarily from used plastic bottles. Assuming, that is, all goes as planned. ''The boat only averages five knots,'' he says with a laugh about the ambitious 11,000-mile itinerary. ''That's about six miles an hour.'' But the 31-year-old heir to the de Rothschild banking fortune is no stranger to adventure. Having visited some of the most beautiful places on the planet -- in 2005 he trekked across Antarctica via the South Pole -- he now travels to some of the most blighted, sharing his stories and spreading awareness through his Web site, adventureecology.com. In 2007 he took a team to Ecuador to explore the effects of oil drilling. The Plastiki expedition will take him and his crew to the Eastern Garbage Patch, an island of trash in the Pacific Ocean twice the size of Texas. ''The list of problems is big,'' he says optimistically, ''but the list of solutions is even longer.''

COBB--Margaret Gallatin died peacefully at home in New York on March 24 at age 102. A lifelong Francophile and Claude Debussy scholar Mrs. Cobb was appointed in 1972 to head the newly founded Centre de Documentation Claude Debussy in St. Germain-en-Laye (outside Paris). It was here that she gathered an extensive body of primary source material which is now located in the Bibliotheque Nationale of France in Paris. Among her many publications which centered on the literary influences on Debussy are The Poetic Debussy, Debussy's Letters to Inghelbrecht, and the co-translation of the Marcel Dietschy biography A Portrait of Claude Debussy. In 2002, she was honored by the French government with the title of Officier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. At the time of her death she was working on a book on Debussy's letters with quotations from the poetry Jules Laforgue. An avid collector of Debussy letters she donated over 100 to Morgan Library where she was a Fellow. Prior to opening the Centre, Mrs. Cobb was an editor for thirty-five years at McGraw Hill and editorial consultant there for the Larousse Frenchnglish dictionary. She will be greatly missed by her surviving family, her son Dr. Oliver E. Cobb (Pamela) of Seattle and her daughter Jean Gallatin Crocker of New York, five grandchildren, Amy C. van Daalen (Anthony) and Alder H. Crocker of Connecticut, Alison G. Herber (Paul) of Seattle, Dr. Pamela Faulks (Craig) of McLean, VA, and Henry E. Cobb (Wendy) of Salt Lake, and ten great-grandchildren. A family graveside service was held in Southampton on March 27.

TORONTO -- Henrik Lundqvist has saved the Rangers countless times in his five years in the N.H.L., never more often than this season. But a soft goal he allowed late in the third period of what turned out to be a 3-2 overtime loss here Saturday night cost them a critical point in their desperate chase for the last playoff position in the Eastern Conference.

JORGE PARDO For a trippy take on our trademark ''T'' (''Buzz Off,'' Page 83), we called on the Cuban-born artist Jorge Pardo. Pardo has been known to make art that works -- as in clocks, chairs, lamps and even a sailboat (far right). His hilltop house in Los Angeles was first conceived as an exhibit for the Museum of Contemporary Art. He travels widely for work, recently visiting London, Madrid and Mérida, on Mexico's Yucatán peninsula. A virtual exhibition of Pardo's genre-bending oeuvre -- sculptures and paintings rendered in photomural wallpaper -- continues through May at the Irish Museum of Modern Art in Dublin, and another Pardo show opens May 6 at the Friedrich Petzel Gallery in New York.

Hans Backe, the new coach of Major League Soccer's Red Bulls, is an itinerant soccer lifer. He has zealously followed the game in a coaching career that has lasted nearly 30 years - taking him from his native Sweden to Norway, Denmark, Greece, England, Mexico and now the United States. Direct, open and loquacious, in stark contrast to many dour European coaches, Backe, 57, has recently worked as an assistant to Sven-Goran Eriksson. After stints at Manchester City and with the Mexican national team, Backe followed his fellow Swede back to England for a brief spell as the manager of Notts County in League Two.

CLARK--William Judkins, 85, passed away March 20, 2010 in Denver, CO after a lengthy and graceful battle with Alzheimer's disease. He was born in Savannah, GA on July 21, 1924 to parents Reuben Grove Clark and Katherine Judkins Clark, and raised in Albany, NY. A graduate of the Woodberry Forest School and Yale University, where he sang with the Whiffenpoofs and was a member of Skull and Bones, he was a pilot who saw combat in the Pacific with the Army Air Force in WWII. His business career included significant roles at Owens-Corning Fiberglas and CIBA-GEIGY, and he was a real estate entrepreneur in Pawley's Island, SC. Generous with both time and resources, he is remembered with love by friends, family, and the many who felt his warmth and charity. He is survived by his beloved wife of 59 years, Mary Thompson Clark, and his brothers Reuben and Holland. He is also survived by his three children: William Judkins Clark Jr., Catherine Clark Shopneck, Mary Clark Talbot, all of Denver, six grandchildren: Fraser, Adam and Will Clark, Andy and Chris Shopneck and Betts Talbot and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in the auditorium at Parkplace in Denver, CO on Tuesday, April 6th at 3pm. Funeral services will be held at the St. Augustine's Chapel on the Vanderbilt University Campus, Nashville, TN, Saturday, April 17 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for any donations to be sent to Yale University or the Alzheimer's Association.

Hamburg is getting a lot of eco-buzz: it's a darling of the Web site treehugger.com and will be Europe's Green Capital in 2011. Surrounded by rivers and nature preserves, it's navigable by bike, canoe, fuel-cell hybrid bus and solar-powered ferry. But what's really driving the city forward are its enviro-minded chefs, designers and shop owners.

SINCE its opening in 2005 the Baryshnikov Arts Center has been resolutely multidisciplinary in its programming. Still, the building is named after a man who is synonymous with dance, and it was something of a surprise to learn three years ago that Mikhail Baryshnikov had asked the Wooster Group, the venerable experimental theater collective, to take up residence in a newly acquired and still-to-be-renovated theater in the building in Midtown Manhattan. The Wooster Group, known for collages of high and low culture that make extensive use of technology, has long been housed in and identified with the Performing Garage on Wooster Street in SoHo, though it has occasionally ventured to St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn and elsewhere. But the group moved into a new era when the Baryshnikov Center's 238-seat Jerome Robbins Theater finally opened this month with preview performances of ''North Atlantic.'' (The show runs through April 25.)

Film Released nearly 30 years ago, Jean-Jacques Beineix's ravishing thriller ''DIVA'' could hardly seem more contemporary. With its wanton appropriations from every corner of movie history and its unapologetic, un-self-conscious embrace of pure style as a cinematic vocabulary, it anticipated any number of modish but less entertaining films, including Mr. Beineix's follow-ups, ''The Moon in the Gutter'' and ''Betty Blue.'' (Many critics loved ''Diva'' at the time, but not all; Vincent Canby of The New York Times called it ''empty though frightfully chic-looking.'') The plot, which in part involves a surreptitiously recorded opera recital and Taiwanese crooks who want to pirate the recording, also resonates with our times. And the famous motorbike chase, through the arcades of the Rue de Rivoli and down into the Paris Métro, has been copied so many times that you have to remind yourself how surprising it was on first sight. 11 a.m. Friday to next Sunday, IFC Center, 323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-7771, ifccenter.com; $12.50.

KEMP--Harvey Gilbert, Jr.,MD, former chief of cardiology at St. Luke's Hospital Center, died at New York Hospital on March 24, 2010, after a short illness. Dr. Kemp was professor of clinical medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and founded the current Division of Cardiology at St. Luke's Hospital Center, where he was in charge from 1970 to 1990. During his medical career, he also was a founding fellow of the Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions. He was the author of numerous scholarly papers on Cardiology. Graduating from Johns Hopkins University Medical School in 1959, Dr. Kemp finished his Osler internship at Johns Hopkins and then served in the US Air Force in Wiesbaden, Germany, as a medical officer from 1961-63. Returning to the United States, he completed his medical residency at New York Hospital and was chief resident from 1964-65. Following the completion of his studies, Dr. Kemp went to the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston as a fellow, working with Dr. Richard Gorlin until 1970. At this time he was recruited by St. Luke's Hospital Center in New York City to establish their cardiology division and act as its chief. Dr. Kemp was a fellow of the American College of Cardiology, the New York Academy of Medicine, and was a member of the American Heart Association, and the New York State Cardiac Advisory Committee. He was active in the New York Clinical Society and the Medical Strollers. Aside from his medical career, he was a member of the New York Holland Lodge and The Union Club, where he served as a Governor from 1992-1995. Dr. Kemp is survived by Barbara, his loving wife of 30 years; two sons, Christopher and Alexander, of Los Angeles, CA, and their respective wives Beth and Winnie; three step-children, Elizabeth Sundell of Nantucket, MA, Malcolm Chace of Providence, RI, and Barbara Ulehla, Wilton, CT, and nine step-grandchildren. Services will be held on Friday, April 16th at The Church of the Incarnation at 11am, followed by a reception at The Union Club, 101 Park Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the American Heart Association at 122 East 42nd St., New York, NY 10036.

RYSKAMP--Charles. We are deeply saddened by the loss of Charles Ryskamp, our beloved colleague and friend. Charles has been associated with the Yale Center for British Art since its inception, as a result of his long friendship with Paul Mellon, the Center's founder. We cherish especially Charles's recent involvement in the life of our institution. He took special pleasure serving as teacher and mentor to Yale undergraduates. We will miss his remarkable energy and enthusiasm, his generosity, as well as his wit and wisdom. We are grateful for his time among us and all that he gave to our community. Amy Meyers, Director, the staff and students at the Yale Center for British Art New Haven, Connecticut

THERE once lived a hideously blue-bearded man who slit the throats of his half-dozen wives, stashing their corpses in the basement of his castle one by one. So goes the legendary folk tale ''Bluebeard'' (''La Barbe Bleue''), published by Charles Perrault in 1697 to become an enduring European bedtime story.

For years, Woody Johnson was known as the reclusive billionaire owner of the Jets. He ran one of the most secretive organizations in football, the headquarters lined with a barbed-wire fence. So this month, when Johnson verbally slapped the N.F.L. over a clandestine coin flip and invited HBO's cameras into training camp with full access, his behavior seemed so out of character. Except that it was not.

9 P.M. (NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC) BREAKOUT Some of the most high-profile prison escapes in recent history are the subject of this new series. Each week it includes interviews with prisoners who made it over the wall and the law-enforcement teams that subsequently captured them. In this episode the subject is a convicted armed robber, George Rivas, above, who in 2000 escaped from a prison in Texas with six other inmates (they were called the Texas Seven), and ended up a few weeks later in southern Colorado, where he and two escapees were captured near the trailer park where they had been staying. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS President Felipe Calderón of Mexico is a guest.

ECO-ISTE/ ($(4$) k st) /n. / A neologism combining 'ecologist' and 'egoiste' to indicate a person devoted to her own green agenda, irrespective of the downside. Often used to describe a style-conscious individual who wears her do-gooding heart on her Balmain sleeve, e.g., She's such an eco-iste. She thinks that recycling her grandmother's vintage Vuitton luggage somehow cancels out her carbon footprnt from chartering that private jet to Brazil. FEral/ (fer$(4$) el) / adj. / Of or like a wild animal; savage. Can describe animals, as in, ''Australia's Kakadu National Park is teeming with feral beasts like horses and buffalo that threaten the natural habitat,'' as well as humans, e.g., He's gone totally feral since he returned from that farm stay in Costa Rica. He's grown a Zach Galifianakis beard and is no longer heatng his loft.

A few years ago, it was enough not to wash the towels every day. But it takes much more for hotels to earn their green stripes these days: those towels are now organic cotton, for starters, and the water to wash them is filtered and reused. Toilets are low flow, cleaning products are sulfate-free, hybrid cars meet guests at the airport, gardens are organic, and everything is recycled. Of course, it's the rare hotel that actually does it all. But what if one did? Herewith, the hypothetically perfect eco-hotel. A green roof like the one at the Hilton Baltimore reduces storm water runoff and keeps the building cool. Looks good, too.
TRENT--Bertram J. March 28, 2007 - 3 years today. Forever loved, forever missed. Geraldine, Bruce and Michael

STYLE MAP MADRID If Salamanca is the city's Upper East Side, then Las Salesas is its West Village. A breeding ground for independent and avant-garde designers, the neighborhood is being infiltrated by international brands hoping to catch some of the low-wattage cool. (Enter Marc Jacobs.) But the narrow streets around the Plaza de las Salesas aren't paved with all the big-name labels just yet. The area still has a healthy regard for homegrown design. JEFFRIES BLACKERBY 1. LeFreakOlé: Anabela Lubisse's colorful clothes made from vintage fabrics nearly burst out of this tiny boutique. A native of Mozambique, Lubisse evokes an African-dance-hall style with fringed knit tops, paper-bag pants and pins fashioned from tiny Whitney Houston album covers. Argensola 20; 011-34-91-319-5310.
A Consumption Surtax To the Editor:

Look for luggage made from repurposed and recycled materials, like Heys's recycled ABS plastic EcoCase, which comes in a rainbowof colors ($370 for a rolling three-piece set; shop.heys.ca); Endstar's line of bags made with Bionic Yarn, a recycled-plastic fiber; and Killspencer's packs and duffel, which cleverly use reworked military truck tarps and other materials (killspencer.com).

When Julie Gilhart gets behind something, you can be sure it's going to be both stylish and sustainable. Take this silk dress by the Paris-based label E2. Fashioned from vintage Balmain scarves, it possesses qualities close to the heart of the women's fashion director of Barneys New York. ''For one thing, it's not mass-produced,'' Gilhart says. ''Whenever possible, I like to know who a designer is, what they stand for and where their things are made. This is not just 'fashion consciousness' -- it also adds a sense of story, romance and culture to the clothes you buy and wear.'' She refers to Michèle and Olivier Chatenet -- the husband-and-wife team behind E2 -- as futurists. ''They sense what people will want and incorporate it into their collections,'' she says. ''Every piece they make is one of a kind and utilizes pre-existing fabric, but somehow they make it feel new.'' The clothes are also practical for this inveterate traveler. ''The pieces pack easily and are well suited for numerous occasions.'' That's perfect for Gilhart, who is planning a surfing vacation at Nihiwatu Resort on Sumba Island in Indonesia. SANDRA BALLENTINE

VISIT NoLIta early enough on a weekday, before all the boutiques stir to life at 11 or even noon, and you might feel as if you had traveled back in time 75 years. Weathered walk-up tenement buildings cast shadows over the side streets; homeless men trudge through on their way to the Bowery; pizza shop workers settle in for a day at the ovens. But even in its quiet moments, there are signs that this neighborhood, framed by Houston, Lafayette and Kenmare Streets and the Bowery, is now something very different. A woman strolling past St. Patrick's Old Cathedral does so in Chanel flats; a trash pile on Prince Street includes a white leather handbag in like-new condition.

THERE are low-budget films, there are micro-budget films, and then there is ''Breaking Upwards.'' It may be hard to imagine how someone could make a feature-length romantic comedy in New York City for just under $15,000, but Daryl Wein and Zoe Lister-Jones managed to do it. The making of ''Breaking Upwards,'' which opens Friday both at the IFC Center and on cable through video on demand, is almost a tutorial in how a do-it-yourself ethos can overcome the tough economics of the movie business. And that is not simply because the couple collaborated on the script, played the lead roles and produced the film together, with him also directing and her in charge of tasks ranging from writing the lyrics for the songs to cooking meals for cast and crew.

DeSILVER--Mrs. C. H. Died peacefully at home on March 9, 2010 in Irvington-On-Hudson, NY. She was 79. Collette was wife to the late C. Harrison DeSilver, Architect, and is survived by her three children, Albert Flynn DeSilver, Serena Ray DeSilver, and Margaret DeSilver-Scallan, who gave her three grandchildren, Finn, Gillian, and Flannery. Collette lived a full and colorful life as a dancer for the Ballet Ruse de Monte Carlo in New York, as an assistant curator of antiquities at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, a curator at the New Canaan Historical Society, and as an assistant editor to Jason Epstein at Random House. Collette was also an elegant Boston debutante, coming out in the autumn of 1950. She studied in Rome and Paris, lived in Kenya and South Africa, and traveled extensively through out the world. She will be remembered for her wonderful charm, exquisite humor, and great kindness to all she encountered.

Attention, Chopin fans: On March 1, the 200th anniversary of the Polish composer's birth, a new permanent exhibition opened at the Chopin Muzeum in Warsaw. Designed by the Milan firm Migliore + Servetto Associated Architects, the installation displays some 500 items, from musical manuscripts to the composer's cuff links. In contrast to the setting, the 16th-century Ostrogski Castle, the exhibition design (which won a 2008 competition) is the last word in high tech, offering what the architects called a ''system of emotional landscapes and soundscapes'' that appeals to all the senses. Ico Migliore, a partner in the firm (which won awards for its communication design for the 2006 Olympics in Turin and for an exhibition in Milan for T, among others), explained that each of the thematically organized galleries embodies a different visual and technological approach.

McGRAW--Harold W.,Jr. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Darien Library mourn the loss of a steadfast and generous supporter, esteemed leader, thoughtful mentor and beloved friend. Harold W. McGraw, Jr. served as Trustee from 1951 to 1957 and 1968 to 1974. He was President of the Library Board from 1953 to 1957 and from 1970 to 1972 and was named an Honorary Trustee in 1977. His leadership of the capital campaign for construction of the first Darien Library in 1957 caused a fellow trustee to remark that Harold McGraw "almost single handedly got the library built." In 1972-74 he led the campaign to expand the building by constructing a new children's wing, which was named in honor of the McGraw family. He was Honorary Co-Chairman of the capital campaign that resulted in construction of the New Darien Library, whose opening was celebrated on January 10, 2009, his 91st birthday, with thousands of visitors singing "Happy Birthday" to him. Harold seldom visited the new building without stopping by the McGraw Children's Library, named in his honor. His support of the engagement, education and entertainment of children was unwavering; it reflected his commitment to the important role of public libraries from the beginning to the end of the life of each person in the community. To his family, especially Sue, Terry and Robert, we express our sorrow for their loss, tempered only by our belief that his great good kindness, his generosity and his unwavering friendship to so many have set an enduring example of all that is best in human nature. To the memory of Harold W. McGraw, Jr., generous with his support, advice, leadership and, above all, friendship-we pledge that we will never forget the lessons he taught us, and we promise that the Darien Library will always reflect his enduring values of intelligence, common sense, enterprise, commitment and integrity.

For years, hotel designers used traditional motifs mainly for contrast -- by mixing Louis XIV and Le Corbusier, they seduced trend-seeking travelers with eye-catching compostions. But period promiscuity may be giving way to a new faithfulness. These days, arch has gone back to being a noun, as hoteliers go for real historicism, creating (or recreating) grande dame properties that serve their nostalgia straight up. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

Alix E. Gerz and George S. Matysik Jr. were married Friday evening at the Glen Foerd mansion in Philadelphia. Mayor Jayne Young of Lansdowne, Pa., officiated. Ms. Gerz, 29, is keeping her name. She is the marketing manager at the Free Library of Philadelphia Foundation. She graduated summa cum laude from Temple University, where she also received a master's degree in history.

The prominent American poet Ai, whose work -- known for its raw power, jagged edges and unflinching examination of violence and despair -- stood as a damning indictment of American society, died on March 20 in Stillwater, Okla. She was 62 and lived in Stillwater. The cause was pneumonia, a complication of previously undiagnosed cancer, said Carol Moder, head of the English department at Oklahoma State University, where Ai had taught since 1999.

It's been shown that conventional sunscreens contribute to coral bleaching. So if you're headed somewhere reef-y, your resort may ask you to wear a biodegradable, mineral-based sunscreen (made with titanium dioxide or zinc oxide). Soléo Organics' sunblock (soleousa.com) scores highest in the Environmental Working Group's Skin Deep database.

Though it was once known as the Paris of the Middle East, ''Beirut never truly lost its sheen,'' says Gordon Campbell Gray, the British hotelier who finally opened Le Gray last November, having forged ahead even through the 2006 Israel-Hezbollah war. The Lebanese capital surely has a touch of Parisian glamour, but it also has a dash of Berlin (bullet-pocked buildings after a civil war that lasted from 1975 to 1990) and Miami (flashy night-life zones choked with Ferraris and S.U.V.'s). There's a burgeoning gallery scene, world-class shopping -- from avant-garde boutiques like IF to big-ticket designers like Marc Jacobs and Dior -- and five-star hotels like the new Four Seasons and Le Gray. ''The Lebanese have a spirit for living for the day, and it permeates every aspect of their life,'' Campbell Gray says. ''You really understand this when you head back to a Western city.'' MAURA EGAN LE GRAY

RYSKAMP--Charles. The Trustees and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library deeply mourn the death of Charles Ryskamp, Director from 1969 to 1986. Through his leadership, the Morgan made outstanding acquisitions, mounted numerous superb exhibitions, and expanded its scholarly initiatives. Charles brought all his exceptional qualities to the service of the Morgan: erudition, taste, wit, and grace. He leaves an extraordinary legacy as a scholar, connoisseur, and eminent champion of art and culture. We shall miss him greatly. S. Parker Gilbert, President William M. Griswold, Director

The singular downtown artist David Greenspan has made a name for himself as an actor for hire in productions like the off-kilter musical ''Coraline'' last year and Target Margin Theater's 2006 extravaganza ''Faust.'' (The review in The New York Times called his Mephistopheles ''irresistible'' even though ''you know you shouldn't go near him.'') But he's also known as the cerebral playwright (and star) of sparely staged works like ''The Myopia,'' which the Foundry Theater presented in a critically praised revival this winter. Changing modes so regularly (he's now performing in Michi Barall's ''Rescue Me'' at the Ohio Theater), does he also change his approach? ''I CAN take any empty space and call it a bare stage. A man walks across this empty space whilst someone else is watching him, and that is all that is needed for an act of theater to be engaged.'' I encountered these lines from ''The Empty Space,'' by Peter Brook, as a college freshman. They struck a chord within me then and have remained a guiding principle in my work.

THE calendar says spring has sprung. But inside the typical city apartment, one that lacks skylights and glassy southern exposures and unlimited views of blue sky, spring does not arrive on autopilot. Many New Yorkers must actively invest in spring by adding a few hardy houseplants that can make it anywhere, like a dim walk-up in Hell's Kitchen or a tiny railroad apartment in the Bronx. Harriet Beecher Stowe contended that caring for houseplants was a way of girding one's moral fiber, but the plants can gird one's morale as well. Try a blooming lily (perhaps a clivia) or a mini-cyclamen, which will blossom for months if the room temperature stays below 70 degrees.

When it comes to sustainability, Brazil walks the walk: Eighty-À ve percent of its electricity comes from renewable sources, and it's a top producer of environmentally sensitive products like vegetable-dyed leather and Amazonian cocoa butter. Now tourism is also going green, with a wide array of new conservation initiatives and eco-lodges proliferating across the country. Here, a regional sampler.

I'VE been looking at the April issues, the month for taxes and shaping up and being sexy (in 60 seconds!), and I'm feeling strangely energized, if not entirely hopeful about the future of magazines. I enjoyed Alexandra Jacobs's piece about Polyvore in the style issue of The New Yorker (the March 29 issue, to be precise). I was also excited to see the piece on Brunello Cucinelli; interesting business, with annual sales of more than $200 million, reports Rebecca Mead, and I know a lot of women who like the clothes, expensive though they are. But I was bored reading about him. One thing in the Polyvore article that amused me was the description of the company's office, the atmosphere of tact and friendliness -- unlike magazine offices, which, as Ms. Jacobs noted, ''are widely perceived to be snake pits.''

WASHINGTON -- The agency that guards airline security inside the United States is likely to remain without a Senate-confirmed leader for months to come after President Obama's nominee for the position abruptly withdrew late Friday night amid questions from Congress about his work as a defense contractor. The nominee, Maj. Gen. Robert A. Harding, a retired Army intelligence officer, pulled out of contention for director of the agency, the Transportation Security Administration, just two and a half weeks after Mr. Obama submitted his nomination. Mr. Obama's first pick for the position also withdrew under fire this year, and the administration has not announced a third choice.

IF the bunny in the book looked anything like this, it's no wonder Alice went headlong down the rabbit hole. The jewelers Soraya Silchenstedt and Candice Pool (their line is called Finn) made this 18-karat gold and diamond pendant for a friend who wanted them to replicate the stuffed animal belonging to her 5-year-old. ''She was a bit sad at the time,'' said Ms. Silchenstedt, ''so it had to be really beautiful.'' The resulting piece, inspired by the mask Candice Bergen wore to Truman Capote's Black and White Ball and photos of rabbits gamboling in the snow, contains 3.5 carats of sparklers that are meant to represent snowflakes. Call it bling for the hippity-hop set. It's $9,875 at Barneys New York. SANDRA BALLENTINE

The rococo Versace Mansion in the heart of South Beach remains an icon of fascination. Or that's the hope, anyway, of Barton G. Weiss, a Miami restaurateur who has turned the late Gianni Versace's beachfront villa into a 10-room hotel. The hotel, called The Villa by Barton G., is modeled on a Roman palazzo filled with fountains, frescoes and stained glass, featuring a pool and terrace tiled in thousands of colorful mosaics. Gianni Versace's former bedroom has a nine-foot-wide bed, two balconies and - for those who don't pack light -- seven closets. Rooms start at $2,100.

Each week on the City Room blog, the editors select a New Yorker to answer readers' questions. Here are excerpts from last week's Q. & A. with Michele LoBianco, an independent career consultant, coach and facilitator, who teaches ''Recession Proofing Your Career'' at the School of Continuing and Professional Studies at New York University. Q. I am 45 years old and have practiced law for over 16 years. I've had a decently successful career in the law, but I feel I am getting burned out and yearn for something new. I am considering getting an M.F.A. in nonfiction writing. Your gut feeling: Is this a reckless economic act in these times? If I liquidate, I will have enough cash to sustain myself for at least three years with no other income. Scott

RYAN McGINLEY knows from adolescence. As the chronicler of (usually naked) misspent youth, the 32-year-old photographer has made a not-insignificant career out of capturing and exalting this most evanescent of states. In Mr. McGinley's art photographs -- as well as in his editorial work for fashion magazines -- the youthful vigor of his subjects is usually caught in color, in a dynamic interplay with the landscape. However, in ''Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere,'' his new exhibition of nudes at the Team Gallery in SoHo -- and the accompanying tome of the same name (Dashwood Books, $95) -- he ventures into the studio, photographing his coltish subjects in dramatic black-and-white, with lighting that brings to mind photos from the golden age of Hollywood. ''I wasn't interested in going the route of studio photographers who are about showing each pore, where you really see the grit and grime,'' Mr. McGinley explained. ''The world in my photographs has always been a fantasy.'' The show runs through April 17 at Team Gallery, 83 Grand Street. HORACIO SILVA

DAWSON--John Philip III, 81, of prostate cancer in New York City on March 21, 2010. Retired Professor of History at Brooklyn College, CUNY, born in Ann Arbor, MI, on November 28, 1928, the son of Law Professor John P. Dawson and Emma van Nostrand McDonald Dawson. Phil graduated from the University of Michigan in 1950 and received his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1961. He wrote Provincial Magistrates and Revolutionary Politics in France, 1789-1795 and other historical works. Former husband to Ellen Beale Greene and the late Evelyn Raskin. Survived by his wife, Kathryn Callaghan, children John Philip Dawson IV, Liza Dawson, brothers and sisters-in-law David and Beth Dawson, Peter and Joan Dawson, grandchildren Madeleine, Jack, Aminata and Aiche and nieces and nephews. Phil's commitment to social justice extended from his personal affairs to his political beliefs and professional work. Phil's contributions to his family, friends and community are unique and irreplaceable; his love and kindness will never be lost or forgotten. Memorial service will be held at 2:30pm, May 30, 2010, at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., New York.

WASHINGTON -- With the Obama administration looking to score another major legislative victory, an array of pro-business groups and fiscal conservatives are mounting a well-financed campaign to scale back or block altogether the Democrats' plan to overhaul regulation of the financial industry. By the time the campaign is over, opponents of regulation plans will probably have spent tens of millions of dollars to lobby Washington lawmakers, run advertisements and start petition drives. It is an effort that many of the players, from the United States Chamber of Commerce down to smaller splinter groups, see as vital to their economic survival.

LEVINE--Gloria, an accomplished merchandiser of women's high fashion clothing in Westchester for most of her life, died peacefully on March 25, in Lenox, MA. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Levine, nee Schulman, was born into a Westchester fashion family. Her mother and father owned and operated an elegant women's specialty store, L.A. Schulman, Inc. in White Plains which they founded in 1926. She succeeded her parents at L.A. Schulman in the late 1950's and successfully turned the shop into one of the finest fashion stores in the metropolitan area. Preceding her joining the family business, she worked for a junior dress manufacturer in NYC starting as a sketcher and within two years becoming lead designer. Gloria is predeceased by her husband, Samuel Levine in 1978 and by her daughter Lisbeth, a cancer victim, in 1984. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Gussie and Peter Greer, three siblings, Naomi Barry, Phyllis Schain and Lowell Schulman, and four randchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gloria's memory may be made to Hospice Care of the Berkshires, 877 South St., Pittsfield, MA 01201.

Butler's run to the Final Four may be unlikely, but basketball fans in Indianapolis with long enough memories recall the Bulldogs playing on the same stage as Big Ten and other major-conference teams in the 1950s and '60s. And in those days before ESPN - heck, in those days when no one on our block had a color TV - a Butler fan could watch the Bulldogs about as often as he could see Indiana and Purdue. Butler had only about 2,000 students then and played in the Indiana Collegiate Conference. But it had a renowned if now widely forgotten coach, Tony Hinkle, and a fieldhouse that was the largest basketball arena in the country when it opened in 1928.

WHEN General Motors unveiled the Personal Urban Mobility and Accessibility prototype last year before the New York auto show, it resembled little more than an enclosed wheelchair for two. ''We were the S.U.V. company, and we accept that,'' said Larry Burns, at the time G.M.'s vice president for research and development and strategic planning. ''We want to become the U.S.V. company -- known for ultra-small vehicles.''

Classical HELMUT LACHENMANN, a hugely influential contemporary German composer whose music draws upon the outer limits of tonality and timbre, turns 75 in November. This week two performing-arts organizations are getting a big jump on that festive event with concerts devoted to Mr. Lachenmann's oeuvre. On Tuesday members of the EAST COAST CONTEMPORARY ENSEMBLE -- Steven Beck, pianist; Bill Kalinkos, clarinetist; and Jeremiah Campbell, cellist -- focus on Mr. Lachenmann's solo and chamber works in a program that includes his ''Allegro Sostenuto,'' ''Dal Niente,'' ''Pression'' and ''Wiegenlied.'' 8 p.m., Good Shepherd Church, 162 West 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 877-0685, eccensemble.com; $20, $10 for students.

Caetano Veloso With a passing phrase in ''Falso Leblon,'' one of the more self-conscious tracks on ''zii e zie'' (Nonesuch), Caetano Veloso articulates the album's point precisely. ''Mas o meu samba transcende,'' he sings -- ''But my samba transcends'' -- just as his band sets up a broodingly buoyant groove. Mr. Veloso, an unimpeachable eminence of Brazilian popular music, must know he isn't straining with that claim. Due out in the United States on Tuesday, ''zii e zie'' features the same younger musicians as on his brittle, embittered rock album ''cê,'' from 2006: the bassist and keyboardist Ricardo Dias Gomes, the drummer Marcelo Callado and the guitarist Pedro Sá, who produced both albums along with Mr. Veloso's oldest son, Moreno Veloso. (On April 8 this same group will begin a brief cross-country tour at Terminal 5 in New York; caetanoveloso.com.br.)

By the time Britain's skinheads completed their devolution from hard-edged dandies to racist hooligans, their cherished Dr. Martens boots had gone viral. Now, Dr. Martens is marking its 50th anniversary. To celebrate, the company has commissioned covers of 10 "cult" songs from acts like the Human League, Buzzcocks, the Pogues and even the Cold War Kids. (Full details here.) As of November 2009, at least 139 cities in the United States had climate action plans, including Portland and Chicago. Oakland doesn't have one yet, but it does have a goal: by 2020, the city seeks to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 36 percent of what they were in 2005. That goal is more aggressive than those of either San Francisco or Berkeley, which both have climate action plans.

Thierry Marx is finally moving to Paris. The French chef and Bruce Willis lookalike, who has impressed diners who have made the trek to Cordeillan-Bages in Bordeaux with his inventive molecular fare since 1996 (read about it here), has always seemed too big of a talent even for the grand 18th-century chateau owned by the Lynch-Bages wine-making family. (Imagine if Thomas Keller were stuck in Yountville.) A year from now, he will be installed at the Mandarin Oriental in Paris, which is scheduled to open in 2011 on the rue Saint-Honoré. Whether he brings his two Michelin stars - or his signature dish of Aquitaine beef wrapped in plastic with burning cabernet vines - with him remains to be seen.

The visit from Paris was far less controversial, but the message nonetheless relatively radical.
