"Like many Western governments-like the United States, in fact-Spain has a clear path to recovery provided the economy grows at utterly implausible rates. The secretary of state for the economy now gives presentations to investors in London and Paris professing that Spain is 'determined to act' to reduce its deficit. But this is very much like American noises on the deficit: lots of declarations of will and idealism and very little concrete description of how to get there. Olli Rehn, the monetary commissioner of the European Union, has described the Spanish promise to cut the deficit to 3 percent of GDP in 2013 as wishful thinking. Standard & Poor's lowered its rating of the Bank of Spain's debt from Group 2 to Group 3 (which includes the United States) ... The Spanish debt crisis can be looked at in a lot of different ways. You can see the housing bubble, the labor market, the division of governmental labor between Madrid and the autonomous communities, or the lack of political will as the main cause. There are so many budget-cutting measures you may possibly have to take that a good case can be made for shutting down almost any aspect of the welfare state. The whole kit and kaboodle may be nearing the point of unsustainability. The system of state guarantees and welfare rights that Spain has erected may be the biggest bubble of them all. In that case, the wisest course for a politician may be to stay in the boat, hope you are wrong that you are going over the falls, and wait and see what you really have to do to survive."

Whatever Bartlett Sher had to teach Kate Whoriskey, she evidently learned it faster than anticipated: on Monday, the Intiman Theater in Seattle announced that its interim arrangement under which Mr. Sher (the director of Broadway's "South Pacific" and "Light in the Piazza," and the Metropolitan Opera's "Tales of Hoffman") and Ms. Whoriskey (who directed the Off-Broadway production of "Ruined" for Manhattan Theater Club) would share the title of artistic director, and Ms. Whoriskey would take over from Mr. Sher next year, was being accelerated. The theater has made Ms. Whoriskey its artistic director, effective immediately, and she will select its remaining plays for the season; Mr. Sher was named the theater's artistic director emeritus. "Working with Kate over the past months has affirmed for us that that we are ready now to move forward with her vision for the theater as the sole artistic director," the theater's board president, Kim A. Anderson, said in a statement. On Sunday, the producers of the Broadway revival of "The Miracle Worker" that Ms. Whoriskey directed at Circle in the Square theater said it would close April 4.

Closed since 2005 for a renovation project that has run years behind schedule, the Bolshoi Theater, the Moscow home of both the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, is now aiming to reopen in October 2011, Agence France-Presse reported. "We are assuming that the Bolshoi Theater's historic building will be opened on Oct. 2, 2011," the theater's deputy general director, Anton Getman, said, according to Agence France-Presse. "I will not risk naming an earlier date," he said, "but we must do all that is in our power to let the public in on Oct. 2, and we will," adding that performers and staff members might be allowed access to the building as soon as June or July. Before you get your hopes up, keep in mind the star-crossed history of the theater's $700 million restoration, which has taken nearly 5 years of its 185-year existence: originally planned to be finished in 2008, the repair work was delayed, and last year prosecutors opened an investigation into the possible embezzlement of funds intended for the project.

This is the kind of career-as-meta-gag that smart young writers dream of, but almost nobody can pull off. Cody, a Los Angeles resident (who in an earlier life was Brook Busey from Chicago), made her name with the Oscar-winning screenplay for "Juno." She followed up with the Showtime series "United States of Tara," a writerly tour de force about a suburban mom (played by Toni Collette) with multiple personalities, now in its second season. "It's safe to say that I need everything to be embellished, creatively or otherwise," says Cody, 31. "Just like I'm inclined to put on too much jewelry or get too many tattoos, I need my writing to be a little over-the-top.

Robert Plant still isn't reuniting Led Zeppelin, but he is digging deep into his past for the name of his next project. Coming off a highly successful collaboration with the bluegrass singer and fiddler Alison Krauss, Mr. Plant will next hit the road with a group called the Band of Joy, a name cribbed from the  1960s band from Birmingham, England, in which he performed with the future Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham. In a news release Mr. Plant said the lineup for the new Band of Joy would include the singer Patty Griffin, the instrumentalist and vocalist Darrell Scott, the bassist Byron House, the drummer Marco Giovino and the guitarist Buddy Miller. The band will begin a 12-city tour on July 13 in Memphis and conclude on July 31 in Miami; it is also preparing a new album on which Mr. Miller will serve as co-producer and that will be released by Rounder Records in the late summer or early fall.

Depending on how you look at it, the venerable Centre Georges Pompidou, designed by Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano, will get either a new sibling or a new rival next month, when a branch opens to the public in Metz, France. The Centre Pompidou-Metz's inaugural exhibition has blockbuster written all over it; the coyly titled ''Masterpieces?'' will feature some 800 of the world's most prized modern works, from Alexander Calder's ''Josephine Baker IV'' to Yves Klein's "Grande anthropophagie bleue (ANT 76).'' A TGV rail link makes the museum an easy 80-minute trip from Paris. And then there is the building itself. Conceived by Shigeru Ban and Jean de Gastines as a series of modules around a central spire, it is flamboyantly capped by an undulating lattice roof structure (made from 11 miles of glue-laminated timber beams) and sheathed in a fiberglass and Teflon membrane that gives the place an otherworldly glow when lit up at night. All the better for stealing the spotlight.

Does a documentary film adapted from a best-selling nonfiction work about the application of economic theories and models to unusual real-life situations stand any chance at the box office? Attendees of the Tribeca Film Festival will get an early chance to answer that nonacademic puzzler. On Monday, festival organizers said the film version of "Freakonomics," by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner (both are contributors to The New York Times), will be shown as its closing night gala on April 30. The film, making its world premiere at the Tribeca festival, includes segments directed by Alex Gibney ("Taxi to the Dark Side"), Morgan Spurlock ("Super Size Me"), Rachel Grady and Heidi Ewing ("Jesus Camp"), Eugene Jarecki ("Why We Fight") and Seth Gordon ("The King of Kong").

It's hard to believe the cocktail lounge that's opening in the Empire State Building today is brand new because it looks so right. At 3,500 square feet of brushed stainless steel, a generous curved marble bar, tufted banquettes, glass-topped tables and Art Deco chandeliers, it accommodates up to 150 people in sophisticated style in a former postal substation. "I feel like I'm giving the Empire State Building the cocktail lounge it deserves," said the owner, Mark Grossich, who also owns the Campbell Apartments in Grand Central Terminal, and the World Bar in Trump World Tower, among others.

I paid $10 to get rid of two old desktop computers, a non-working Apple TV, a couple of cellphones, a network-attached storage (NAS) drive, two ancient iPods, and a photo printer. How Much Medical Marijuana Is Too Much? | Police, prosecutors and defense lawyers have struggled with the question of how much pot a medical marijuana patient may possess since the California Supreme Court threw out a conviction and struck down a state law that imposed an eight-ounce limit. Instead, patients are entitled to a "reasonable" amount of the drug for their ailments, the court said in its January ruling. The ruling has resulted in a number of marijuana cases being dismissed; other trials ended in acquittals. Law enforcement agencies around the state are struggling with the aftermath of the ruling. "Gray is not a good color for the law," said Gerald Benito, the Shasta County district attorney, who dismissed a case this month. "It makes it very difficult for us to enforce the law - I think everyone is crying out for a clear line." [The Associated Press]

THORNTON--Angela. The staff of Worldly Things is saddened by the loss of our colleague. Angela's passion was for the stage, but when she was with us, her work ethic and "no nonsense get on with it" attitude were an inspiration for us all. We were lucky to be in her company and to enjoy her warmth and wit. She will leave a lasting impression with whomever was privileged to meet her.

BOISE, Idaho -- Barack who? Representative Walt Minnick of Idaho barely mentioned the president's name. Mr. Minnick was among 34 Democrats in the House who voted against the health care overhaul, and he has made sure his constituents back home know it. There he was at Boise State University on Saturday night, mingling at a dinner sponsored by the Idaho Freedom Foundation, a conservative group trying to stop the health bill from taking effect. A few feet away, Ron Paul, the contrarian Texas congressman and the event's guest speaker, was busy signing copies of his book ''End the Fed.'' Later, Mr. Minnick giggled with Mr. Paul as cameras clicked.

West Leave the tape measure in the tool box. BUTLER went round for round with top-seeded Syracuse and No. 2 Kansas State in the West Regional. So any notion of the Bulldogs as cuddly underdogs should be discarded. With the way they have played, a homecourt advantage and a hobbled Michigan State team as an opponent, the Bulldogs could well be favorites to advance to the national title game next Monday night. Butler won the West with dogged man-to-man defense, holding Kansas State to 38 percent shooting and forcing Syracuse into 18 turnovers.

CHURCHILL--Jonathan Hand, 78, died peacefully at his Manhattan home on March 26, 2010, from complications of Lewy body disease. Born in New York City, he was the son of Mary Hand Darrell and John Dwight Winston Churchill, and a grandson of Judge Learned Hand and of the American author, Winston Churchill. After graduating from Harvard College and Harvard Law School and serving in the U.S. Army, he practiced law in the City. He was a member of the Century Association, the American Law Institute, the New York City Bar Association and the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club. He is fondly remembered on Martha's Vineyard and elsewhere as an avid sailor who took great pleasure cruising and racing his 1926 Q boat "Taygeta" and the 1979 trimaran "Moxie". He navigated "Moxie's" record-breaking win (64 hours, 48 minutes) in the 1987 Newport Bermuda Multihull Race. He is survived by his wife, Judith Gaebel Churchill, as well as three step-brothers, Norris Darrell, Jr., Richard W. Darrell and Cass Canfield, Jr. A memorial will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Central Park Conservancy (centralparknyc.org) or Sail Martha's Vineyard (sailmv).

RYSKAMP--Charles A. The Board of Trustees of The Frick Collection and Anne L. Poulet, Director, wish to express their profound sorrow at the death of Dr. Charles Ryskamp, Director Emeritus. Mr. Ryskamp served with extraordinary distinction as Director of the Frick from June 1987 until September 1997, and continued to serve as an advisor until very recently. During his tenure at the Frick, the institution underwent profound evolution. He expanded the special exhibition program, developed new gallery spaces, enhanced the publications program, strengthened the Collection with new art works, and built broader-based support among existing constituencies, while making countless new friends for the Frick. His tireless efforts to stabilize the finances of the Frick Art Reference Library ensured its enduring presence in the world of art history research. His deep knowledge of literature and art informed every aspect of his leadership of the institution, where his commitment to scholarship and connoisseurship remain the touchstones of our mission. Previously seen as a staid and static museum, Mr. Ryskamp found ways to energize the institution without losing sight of its high standards and unique place in the art world. His tireless, ever-engaging, larger-than-life persona drew a widening audience into the Frick circle, and set the course for expanding our outreach to a broader visitorship. He will be remembered for his passionate love of art, for his dedication to ensuring the strength and stability of the institution, as a gifted connoisseur, and for his wisdom, warmth and marvelous wit. He will be deeply missed. Margot C. Bogert, Chair Anne L. Poulet, Director

JAFFE--Carolyn S. March 17, 1923 March 27, 2010. Early Saturday morning, Carolyn S. Jaffe passed in the way that she had lived with dignity and grace, surrounded by love. Beloved wife of the late Sidney, the love of her life, for 47 years. Cherished mother to Faye, Alice, Michael and James. Adored Grandmother to Lauren, David, Daniel, Benjamin, the late Noah, Jesse and Leigh and "Super Gaga" to Eden. She began her career as a chemist for General Aniline and Dye at a time when few women were in the profession. After a period as wife, mother and volunteer, she began her next professional endeavor as an educator which extended for over 20 years at PS130 in Manhattan. Carolyn inspired and enriched the lives of her students and colleagues with her passion for life, people and love of learning. She will be forever missed and remembered through the lives that she touched with her remarkable mind, charitable heart, formidable spirit, and her belief in social justice. Services will be held at I.J. Morris Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Avenue (Avenue L), Brooklyn, NY (718-633-0400). All are encouraged to join in a celebration of Carolyn's life held prior to the service at 10:30am at the chapel with funeral service to follow at 12:30pm. Passover precludes sitting Shiva. Carolyn was a champion of empowerment through education and a proud graduate of Hunter College High School, Hunter College, and Yeshiva University. In memoriam, donations can be made to the Hunter College High School Alumae/i Association (212-772-4079 www.hchsaa.org).

PEORIA, Ill. -- The youngest member of Congress came home this weekend to hugs. Hugs, then more hugs. ''Thank you for making time to do this,'' one woman said during her hug, as Representative Aaron Schock stepped inside a church gymnasium to shoot free throws for charity. ''And thank you,'' she added quickly, ''for your vote on health care.''

RYSKAMP--Charles. The trustees and staff of The Library of America are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime trustee and friend Charles Ryskamp. His love of books and profound knowledge of literature and art gave inspiration to us all. D. Ronald Daniel, Chairman Cheryl Hurley, President

In politics, as in sports, the thrill of victory sometimes pales alongside the agony of defeat. In 2010, Democrats remain on track to experience both. Achievement of their decades-long quest for comprehensive health care legislation left Congressional leaders and White House aides jubilant. It broke, at least temporarily, the psychology of failure that threatened President Obama's administration as it had burdened President George W. Bush's tenure.

RYSKAMP--Charles. Generous, madcap, irreplaceable Charles delighted in the simplest of pleasures: Sunday night dinners, ham sandwiches, students and young artists, books, sailing, Maine, needlepoint, spring bulbs, orchids, but most of all his friends. He was worldly, elegant, handsome, giggly, Jackie's escort, with a wicked sense of humor and an eyebrow raised at the world. His joie de vivre and grace under pressure are forever an inspiration. We adored him. A., A., T. and N.

McGRAW--Harold W.,Jr., The Norwalk Hospital Board of Trustees and the Norwalk Hospital Foundation Board of Directors mourn the loss of Harold W. McGraw, Jr., a steadfast and generous supporter of Norwalk Hospital. Mr. McGraw's support helped ensure that Norwalk Hospital continue to provide outstanding quality care for all of his friends and neighbors in our community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, Sue, Terry and Robert. Ervin Shames, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Norwalk Hospital David Lehn, Chairman, Board of Directors, Norwalk Hospital Foundation

WALSH--Philip C.,died peacefully at his home in Peapack, NJ, on March 24, 2010. Born on May 23rd, 1921, he was the son of Philip C. Walsh and the former Frances Prendergast. He was educated at The Newman School, Phillips Andover Academy and Yale University, where he majored in geology. He graduated in 1944 and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and to Sigma XI. He was a First Lieutenant in the 10th Armored Division of George Patton's 3rd Army, served as a Forward Observer in France and in Germany, and was awarded a Purple Heart and a Silver Star for gallantry in action. He married the former Alexandra Somerville Tuck on May 19, 1945, and moved shortly thereafter to Peru in the employ of W.R. Grace & Co. Returning from Peru in 1956, he settled in New Vernon, NJ, though his work would continue to take him to Latin America for the next 40 years. Following his academic interests he left Grace in 1971 to work in the mining industry with Newmont Mining. He would later serve as Vice-Chairman of St. Joe Minerals, Director of Cyprus Minerals Company, and Chairman of the Board of Foote Mineral Company, and was a Corporate Director of T. Rowe Price for twelve years. He was always involved in his community, and served on the Harding Township Board of Education, as the Police Commissioner of Harding Township, as a trustee of Morristown Memorial Hospital, as Chancellor of the American Association of the Order of Malta, and as Commodore of the Edgartown Yacht Club. He was also an active member of the Essex Hunt Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club, and the Somerset Hills Country Club. He was predeceased by his first wife and the mother of his six children in 1993, and was married to the former Peggy McDonnell in 1995. He often commented that he had been blessed to have married two wonderful women. He had an agile and quick mind, loved history, Shakespeare's sonnets, the New York Yankees, the Yale class of '44, Chappaquiddick, hiking in the White Mountains, sailing, writing poetry and, above all, his family. He was a wonderful guy, a friend to all, and was as good a father and husband as God created. We will miss him terribly. He leaves six children (Eugenie Flaherty of Philadelphia, PA, Philip of Miami, FL, Frances Cummings of Bedford, NY, Alec of Basking Ridge, NJ, Nicholas of Yarmouth, ME, and Elizabeth Lovering of Bedford, NY), eight step-children (Pia Pearce of Norwich, VT, Michael of Malibu, CA, Megan Kyle of Freeport, ME, Stephen of Pipersville, PA, Peggy Vance of New York City, Anna of Los Angeles, CA, Terry of Norwich, VT, and Andrew of Old Chatham, NY), 19 grandchildren, 27 step-grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A Mass of Funeral Liturgy will take place March 31, 11am at Christ the King Church, New Vernon, N. J. Contributions may be made to the Chappaquiddick Community Center (PO Box 2966, Edgartown MA 02539) or to St. Thomas More (The Catholic Chapel Center at Yale University, 268 Park St., New Haven CT. 06511).

The percentage of visitors who came back to the top sites in the week ended March 20 mostly increased from the same period last year. Repeat visitors, as defined by Hitwise, are those that return to a Web site within 30 days, and advertisers value them. The numbers can be deceptive. As a site like Facebook or YouTube, above, gains new users who return, the percentage of new users falls. Most of the popular sites saw a drop in the percentage of new visitors: Facebook saw a decrease of 57 percent, Windows Live Mail of 36 percent and Google of 2 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

SOLOMON--Milton D.,90, died on March 25 in White Plains, NY after a brief illness. Loyal and loving husband to Edith; proud father of Abby, Steve, Suzy and Ken; devoted grandfather of Jamie, Nicole, Reuben and Kieran and great-grandfather of Aishe and Abayome. He loved and will be missed by his son- and daughters-in-law Geoff, Sarah-Marie and Janice, and his nephews Robin and Larry Horn and their families; his cousins and many friends. A memorial will be held at the Multipurpose Center in Anthony Veteran Park, 11 Olympic Lane, Ardsley, NY, Saturday, April 10, 2010, at 1pm.

TAMPA, Fla. -- Lesson No. 1 for the Yankees pro personnel director Billy Eppler: in the land of pinstripes and Joba Chamberlain, leave yourself some wiggle room. One comment by Eppler about Chamberlain in a WFAN radio interview Saturday appeared to contradict the club's party line that no decision has been made about Chamberlain's future as a starter or reliever. When asked by the host Evan Roberts if Chamberlain might contend for a spot in the rotation in 2011, Eppler paused and said, ''I wouldn't consider that likely, no.''

BENNETT--Lewis R.,died peacefully March 26, 2010 after a long illness. Former Assistant General Counsel to the New York Power Authority. Golfer, sports enthusiast and NY Philharmonic volunteer. Lew faced his illness with courage and strength. Survived by first cousins Lee Bauer, Rick Bernstein, Linda Sikka, Lisa Schultz, Robert Bernstein, Alan Kraft, their families, and by dear friends Paul Chazan, Bruce Boyd and Alvin and Louise Becker.

LEVINE--Gloria, an accomplished merchandiser of women's high fashion clothing in Westchester for most of her life, died peacefully on March 25, in Lenox, MA. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Levine, nee Schulman, was born into a Westchester fashion family. Her mother and father owned and operated an elegant women's specialty store, L.A. Schulman, Inc. in White Plains which they founded in 1926. She succeeded her parents at L.A. Schulman in the late 1950's and successfully turned the shop into one of the finest fashion stores in the metropolitan area. Preceding her joining the family business, she worked for a junior dress manufacturer in NYC starting as a sketcher and within two years becoming lead designer. Gloria is predeceased by her husband, Samuel Levine in 1978 and by her daughter Lisbeth, a cancer victim, in 1984. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Gussie and Peter Greer, three siblings, Naomi Barry, Phyllis Schain and Lowell Schulman, and four randchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations in Gloria's memory may be made to Hospice Care of the Berkshires, 877 South St., Pittsfield, MA 01201.

The Blackfoot and Clark Fork Rivers began flowing freely in Milltown, Mont., on Friday after engineers removed a dam to allow for cleanup of sediment captured behind it. A century of mining 120 miles upriver from the dam left sediment of copper, zinc and other heavy metals at the site.

WASHINGTON - Congress has voted, President Obama will hold a last signing ceremony on Tuesday, and still, Americans are struggling to make sense of the health care debate - what it means for them and their families, for businesses and the economy, for states, for lawmakers in the November elections, for Mr. Obama and his presidency, for the nation's future, and in a most elemental way, for the future of civil democracy. People surprised by the visceral - and in some cases vicious and violent - reactions to approval of the legislation have not had the benefit of months of e-mail from readers of The New York Times and this blog. Passions often ran high in these messages.

RYSKAMP--Charles. The Trustees and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library deeply mourn the death of Charles Ryskamp, Director from 1969 to 1986. Through his leadership, the Morgan made outstanding acquisitions, mounted numerous superb exhibitions, and expanded its scholarly initiatives. Charles brought all his exceptional qualities to the service of the Morgan: erudition, taste, wit, and grace. He leaves an extraordinary legacy as a scholar, connoisseur, and eminent champion of art and culture. We shall miss him greatly. S. Parker Gilbert, President William M. Griswold, Director

Vasily Smyslov, the seventh world chess champion and one of the most successful and durable tournament and match players of the generation that came of age after World War II, died Saturday in Moscow. He was 89. The death was reported by the Russian television station NTV.

Of the three prominent New York metropolitan area college basketball jobs open, two have been filled with local coaches considered strong in the area. Seton Hall made a surprising move in hiring Iona Coach Kevin Willard, who won 21 games this season but was 45-49 in three years as the Gaels' coach. That came days after Fordham hired Hofstra Coach Tom Pecora, leaving St. John's as the final local program to fill a head coaching vacancy.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- Representative Alan Grayson could have headed straight for the sign that said ''Health Care Hero.'' Instead, he held back, smiling and bouncing in his zippered size 13 boots, letting the cheers crescendo like Bruce Springsteen before an encore. When Mr. Grayson, a first-term Democrat, reached the 75 supporters awaiting him at the airport here on Friday, he was unabashedly triumphant. ''It's not enough to be No. 1 in your military expenditures, it's not enough to be No. 1 in the number of countries around the would that you occupy,'' he said. ''We have to be No. 1 in health care.''

Cherie DeCastro, the last surviving member of the DeCastro Sisters, whose sultry ballad ''Teach Me Tonight'' sold millions of copies in 1954, died on March 14 in Las Vegas. She was 87. The cause was pneumonia, said Alan Eichler, her manager.

PORTLAND, Me. -- Even in Representative Chellie Pingree's liberal district in southern Maine, the celebration was tempered. At a reception and dinner here promoting gay rights on Saturday night, a revolving door of well-wishers -- mostly liberals and mainstream Democrats -- shook Ms. Pingree's hand and thanked her for backing President Obama's health care bill.

NEW ORLEANS -- Welcome to the Bizarro World of health care politics. In this world, a Republican congressman explains his vote against the health care bill to a disappointed constituency by pointing out that he voted for and still prefers the original House version -- which was, in many ways, more liberal than what eventually passed. And, he adds, do not forget that his votes have aligned with President Obama nearly 70 percent of the time.

VICTORY--A. Michael, died peacefully with his family at his side Saturday, March 27, 2010, after losing a courageous battle with COPD and multiple myeloma. He was a loving husband to wife Annemarie, adoring father to children Elizabeth and Christopher and doting grandfather to Emily and Whitaker. Born in London on November 3rd, 1934, he was painfully separated from his mother in the early years of World War II as a child evacuee. When his mother was able to locate him at the end of the war, they moved to Calgary, Alberta and eventually settled in Providence, Rhode Island. A committed and stellar student, Michael graduated Magna Cum Laude from Providence College and was admitted to Harvard Business School where he was honored as a Baker Scholar. He then moved to New York City to begin a career as an Investment Banker at Shearson Lehman, eventually branching out on his own to concentrate on the development of small businesses. Among his many accomplishments were the launch and eventual sale of Essence Magazine and board seats at such companies as SFN Group and Pueblo International. He considered himself a true New Yorker, a lover of the arts, particularly the opera. Michael will be remembered lovingly by all those who knew him as a caring and honest man with a unique sense of humor, who valued his friends and family above all else. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Father Martin's Ashley, 800 Tydings Lane, Havre de Grace, MD 21078.

SPARTA, Ga. -- A white man had just finished thanking Representative John Barrow for his vote against the health care bill when Walter A. Collins rose to respectfully disagree. ''I find your vote on health care very disturbing,'' Mr. Collins, 72, a black retiree, politely told Mr. Barrow, a centrist third-term Democrat. ''When you voted no, I really wanted to cry.''

GOLDBERG--Julius, 95 years young. Resident of Westbury, Boca Raton and most recently Great Neck. We mourn this man of great integrity, humor, kindness and warmth. Devoted husband to Feigy for 68 years, loving father to Ron and Amy, father-in-law to Eileen and Ernie, cherished Papa to Ari and Rachel, brother to the late Sarah. Beloved by his nieces and nephews and their families. Tirelessly dedicated to his family, synagogue and community. The family requests donations be made to the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation in his memory. Services to be held at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation on Thursday April 1, 11:30am. 21 Old Westbury Road Old Westbury, NY 11568

Scientists have known for decades that the human brain has trouble simultaneously processing more than one stream of information. A growing body of more recent research has reinforced the notion there are serious cognitive challenges posed by various kinds of multitasking.

New York City agreed Tuesday to pay tens of thousands of dollars to five cyclists who filed a lawsuit saying they were harassed during the monthly cycling group-ride Critical Mass -- including one man seen on videotape being shoved off his bicycle by an officer. As part of the settlement, the city will pay the cyclists a total of $97,751, with each plaintiff receiving $500 to $30,000 apiece and their lawyers receiving a total of $35,000.

This week's review is of Recette, on Greenwich Street at West 12th in the West Village. It's an ambitious restaurant in the space of a deeply casual one, with a menu that appears to embrace the small-plates trend. Really it's more complicated than that: The best way to experience Recette is to order a lot of snacks, and then a couple of other dishes per person, which creates a kind of modified three-course tasting menu for everyone and leads to some serious delights. And the pastry chef, Christina Lee, has much to commend her as well. Save room for s'mores, course number four.

It's not often that a prestigious art institution hosts an evening of face-melting noise music. Yet that is exactly what happened on Friday at the Whitney Museum when Ari Marcopoulos, an artist in this year's Biennial, was invited to curate the museum's "My Turn" program. The series uses artists' recent work as the jumping-off point - which in this case just happened to be ear-splitting cacophony.

Reproduced below is a chart from the John Jay Report on sexual abuse in the Catholic priesthood, commissioned by the U.S. Council of Catholic Bishops, showing the number of credible accusations of abuse across the last half-century. It's part of the basis for my column's claim that something in the moral/cultural/theological climate of the 1960s and 1970s encouraged a spike in sexual abuse, and also for my assertion that we've since seen the church come to grips with the problem, at least in the United States.

When I was pregnant, I made a vow that no matter how much poundage I piled on I would not devolve into one of those slovenly sweat-pants-wearing preggos that you see waddling down the street leaving a trail of Saltine crumbs. Making an effort, after all, is what separates us from the animals, and nowhere is this truer than during that distinctly mammalian experience of childbirth. Even when I could no longer see my toes, I could rest assured that they were freshly pedicured.

James Hill, a photographer with a deep knowledge of Russia, has brought an intimately impressionist eye to the day-after scene in the Moscow subway. (Slides 1 and 2.) These photographs, taken for The Times, are imbued with a sense both of sorrow and fear. An underground realm known for its sparkling tiles and chandeliers is rendered strangely dark and foreboding. "The mood of the city is evident on people's faces," said Maria Anzhaurova, 21, a student, at the Lubyanka station, the site of the first attack on Monday. "People are watching each other closely. It is clear that people are afraid, very afraid."

The Grammy Award-winning saxophonist Branford Marsalis announced on Tuesday that he will make his Broadway debut this spring as the composer of original music for the forthcoming revival of August Wilson's "Fences."

The Charleston Symphony Orchestra in South Carolina has canceled the rest of its season and suspended operations, saying it has run out of cash to pay its expenses, The Post and Courier of Charleston reported. The board president, Ted Legasey,  said in a telephone interview on Tuesday that the critical issue was a decline in fund-raising. He said that major gifts were down 60 percent from last season, creating a shortfall of about $400,000.  People who had purchased tickets for the final concert of the CSO's season, on April 17, are being offered refunds.

With an increasingly permanent network of lanes and legal access to office buildings around the city, the bicycle is becoming more entrenched as a mode of transportation. An entity no less mainstream than the United States Department of Transportation is on board, recently describing bicycles and pedestrians as "equals" to trains, planes and automobiles and encouraging further development of cycling infrastructure at the state and federal level.

Parenthood has brought with it a whole new vocabulary: technical terms for types of discharge, baby-related brand names that double as class signifiers, all kinds of goofy parent-speak that one can elect to adopt ("neck cheese," say, for the stink between a newborn's folds) or discard (see "neck cheese"). So when my friend Julie told me she was getting a princess cake for her daughter's first birthday, I shunted the term in and out of the revolving door of my mind, figuring she meant something pink and frilly and possibly topped with Barbie wearing a crown.

In 1978, he managed to fight off two ax-wielding assassins sent to kill him after he broke with Saddam Hussein's Baath Party.

Israel offers many good reasons to visit: breathtakingly diverse landscapes, endless historical and religious sights, and plenty of incredibly friendly and beautiful people. Recently the country added another feather to its cap of landmarks: its first museum devoted entirely to design. The project, in the Tel Aviv suburb Holon, is part of an ambitious plan to put the wealthy but otherwise bland municipality on the global culture map; in fact, an interesting group of international architects has already been invited to submit proposals for a new town hall on an adjacent lot.

You can burn it, bludgeon it or behead it, but a lucrative literary franchise just doesn't stay down. (Same goes for vampires apparently.) If you've admired the way the four volumes of Stephenie Meyer's "Twilight Saga" fit neatly on your bookshelf, you'd better make room for a fifth. On her Web site Ms. Meyer writes that she will be publishing a new work set in the "Twilight" universe, to be released by  Little Brown & Company on June 5. The novella, called "The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner," is told from the perspective of the title character, a newborn vampire who turns up briefly in the third "Twilight" novel, "Eclipse." Ms. Meyer said the story was originally written for "The Twilight Saga: The Official Guide" but was ultimately too long to include in that book. If the unsettling notion of newborn vampires keeps you from ever cracking open this book, know that one dollar from each copy sold will go to -- where else? -- the American Red Cross.

The Roundabout Theater Company's revival of Tennessee Williams's "The Glass Menagerie," starring Judith Ivey as Amanda Wingfield, will extend its run by two weeks through June 13, the theater has announced. Directed by Gordon Edelstein, the production had its start at the Long Wharf Theater and received rave reviews there and at Roundabout for Ms. Ivey's performance. The show is running Off Broadway at Roundabout's Laura Pels Theater.

Ryanair has suspended its on-board cellphone service after the Swiss company that provided the technology elected to terminate the contract, the airline said Monday. The service, which went live in February 2009, had enabled Ryanair passengers to make and receive voice calls and text messages on 50 of the airline's fleet of 230 Boeing 737 planes.

In an era of shrinking magazine and newspaper circulation and dwindling advertising revenues, among the hard hit professions is photojournalism. Long romanticized as a creative, exhilarating and peripatetic way of making a living, the life of today's photojournalists is one of financial struggle and social deprivation. There are just not enough lucrative assignments out there.

President Obama defended his health care program in an interview broadcast on Tuesday morning, portraying it as a "centrist approach" that Republicans are opposing mainly because they want "political benefit in November."

Last week, Reihan Salam predicted the appearance, among left-of-center writers, of "thoughtful, honest assessments of flaws in the Affordable Health Care for America Act that were largely overlooked" during the beat-the-Republicans phase of the debate. Now John Cassidy, The New Yorker's financial writer, has delivered an impressive two-part contribution to the genre. Cassidy supports the health care bill on moral grounds, but he has deep doubts about its fiscal sustainability. On this front, he makes two points that many right-of-center wonks have been hammering on for a while now. First, the individual mandate is "a bit of a sham," and lots and lots of people will probably just pay the modest fine (or dodge it) until they get sick, at which point they'll show up demanding their guaranteed insurance policy, sending costs skyrocketing. Second, the subsidies for the individual market are so much more generous than the existing tax deduction for employer-provided health care that employers will have an enormous incentive to offload their employees onto the new exchanges:

Inserting a new house into a once-industrial neighborhood isn't always an easy task. Designing something exponentially fancier than its surroundings makes no sense, but going the faux-former-factory route is just as bad. Luke Ogrydziak and Zoe Prillinger of Ogrydziak/Prillinger Architects, a 10-year-old San Francisco firm, navigated a graceful middle ground in their design for this 6,000 square-foot, three-story house and private art gallery in the city's South of Market district. Its plain, rugged materials, elegant proportions and openness to its surroundings make it an asset to its setting -but a suitably unobtrusive one.

I started Backup My Info! from my small apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. After signing up a few clients, I hired my first engineer who worked with me in my apartment. I worked from my bedroom desk, and he worked from my kitchen table. I removed all of the pictures from my walls and replaced them with white boards that we used for strategy sessions. My floors were lined with duct tape that I used to hide and secure the network cords that ran between the bedroom and the kitchen. That year, my revenue reached $20,000, which was less than half my engineer's salary. Looking back, I'm not sure how we did it. But necessity is necessity, right?

Here are some highlights from Tuesday's edition of The New York Times:

Debt Threatens the Future of States | California is among a handful of states showing signs of debt overload similar to the debt that took Greece to the brink. In California, the debt looks manageable on the surface - just 8 percent of the total economy - but that does not take into account the big unstated debts, like the shortfall in its biggest pension fund. If that is counted, the state's debt burden quadruples to 37 percent of the economic output, according to estimates. [The New York Times]

Renée Price, the director of the Neue Galerie, devotes almost as much time to the museum's shop as she does to the museum's exhibition program. Many of the uninsured are going to be unpleasantly surprised that new insurance options for them remain years away -- 2014, to be precise. That's the year insurers will have to take all applicants regardless of pre-existing conditions. Everyone earning less than 133 percent of the poverty line ($14,404 for a single person) will be eligible for Medicaid. People who aren't offered employer-sponsored insurance whose income falls between 133 percent and 400 percent of the poverty line, and who aren't already on a public program, will be offered subsidies to choose among negotiated insurance plans through state-organized insurance exchanges.

SNYDER--Murry A. Middlebury. Murry Abraham Snyder, 90, passed away peacefully on March 2, 2010 in Middlebury, Vermont. In 1961 he was featured in Life Magazine for his work with children who stutter. In 1962 he became director of the National Hospital for Speech Disorders in New York City. His accomplishments included many periodicals determining that stuttering was an emotional, not physical disorder. He continued his practice as a Clinical Psychologist in New York until his retirement to Vermont in 1988. Murry painted prolifically for over forty years of his life, even after macular degeneration deprived him of his sight. Many of his works feature the profound beauty that he always loved about Vermont. Survivors include his wife, Helen Snyder of Middlebury, his daughter Karen Snyder Kadish of Norwood, New Jersey and his two sons, Adam Snyder of Homewood, Alabama and Andy Snyder of Florence, Vermont, two daughters-in-law, Sue Buckingham and Christine Anderson. Murry was very close to his two grandchildren, Ethan Anderson Snyder and Caleb Snyder-Kadish. He was pre-deceased by his eldest son, David in 2002. A memorial service will be held at 1pm on Saturday, April 10th at Tossing Funeral Home, followed by a reception at the Chaffee Art Gallery in Rutland, Vermont. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

KEMP--Harvey G.,Jr., MD. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing our of our dear friend and former colleague, Harvey G. Kemp, Jr., MD, distinguished member of the Cardiology faculty from 1970 through 1994, who helped establish the Division of Cardiology at St. Luke's Hospital and continued to serve as Chief of Cardiology for the merged hospital system for many years. He was a deeply respected member of his profession and helped advance the field of cardiology both in New York State and nationally. To his wife Barbara, the entire Kemp family and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Frank J. Cracolici, President Louis Brusco, M.D., President, Medical Board Bruce Polsky, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Jonathan Steinberg, M.D., Chief, Division of Cardiology

Last season, fans hammered the Mets for not incorporating enough of the team's history into Citi Field. Now that the team has been working to fix the problem, some fans wonder if it should try a little harder when it comes to accuracy. To rectify complaints that the team spent more time paying homage to Jackie Robinson and the Brooklyn Dodgers than Tug McGraw and Mookie Wilson, the Mets added giant photos of stars from the team's pennant-winning years, team logos in the parking lots and orange-and-blue flowers in the gardens in front of the stadium.
BERNSTEIN--Martin B. Marti, we all loved you very much. Michael, Joyce and family

JACOBSON--Mary Jay. Peacefully, at home, after a brief illness. Mary, Muszka to her friends, grew up in Warsaw and came to New York with her parents in 1939. Her father, Dr. Leon Wulman, was a physician and director of the OSE, a Jewish relief organization. In New York she met and married Fred Jacobson, chief of the German desk of the Voice of America and a lyricist. The family moved to Germany in 1963, where Fred, still with the VOA, became a successful song writer, in German and English, under the name Fred Jay. Muszka was instrumental in her husband's career, in ways large and small. She was an exquisite hostess of parties in Berlin and New York and of countless guests at their house in Tuscany. Passionately devoted to friends and family, she had a knack for helping people and an instinct for novel solutions to life's problems. She was a wonderful teller of stories and anecdotes. After Fred's death in 1988, she established a yearly award in his name, the Fred Jay Prize, for German language song lyricists. Apart from promoting careers, this 15,000 Euro award became a major bash for the German music business, a party which bore the imprint of her personality. During these later years, she divided her time between Munich, Tuscany and New York, where her son, Dr. Michael Jacobson, daughter-in-law, Dr. Elizabeth Jacobson and beloved granddaughter, Annie live. They survive her and will miss her greatly, but feel she lives on in her friendships, in the memories of her friends and in her stories. Michael, Elizabeth and Anna Jacobson

SACKLER--Mortimer David. The Trustees, Director, and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation remember with gratitude Dr. Mortimer Sackler. His inspirational philanthropy lives on with us in the Sackler Center for Arts Education at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and in the continuing commitment of his family members to our institution. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to Theresa Sackler and Dr. Sackler's extended family.

WALSH--Philip C.,died peacefully at his home in Peapack, NJ, on March 24, 2010. Born on May 23rd, 1921, he was the son of Philip C. Walsh and the former Frances Prendergast. He was educated at The Newman School, Phillips Andover Academy and Yale University, where he majored in geology. He graduated in 1944 and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and to Sigma XI. He was a First Lieutenant in the 10th Armored Division of George Patton's 3rd Army, served as a Forward Observer in France and in Germany, and was awarded a Purple Heart and a Silver Star for gallantry in action. He married the former Alexandra Somerville Tuck on May 19, 1945, and moved shortly thereafter to Peru in the employ of W.R. Grace & Co. Returning from Peru in 1956, he settled in New Vernon, NJ, though his work would continue to take him to Latin America for the next 40 years. Following his academic interests he left Grace in 1971 to work in the mining industry with Newmont Mining. He would later serve as Vice-Chairman of St. Joe Minerals, Director of Cyprus Minerals Company, and Chairman of the Board of Foote Mineral Company, and was a Corporate Director of T. Rowe Price for twelve years. He was always involved in his community, and served on the Harding Township Board of Education, as the Police Commissioner of Harding Township, as a trustee of Morristown Memorial Hospital, as Chancellor of the American Association of the Order of Malta, and as Commodore of the Edgartown Yacht Club. He was also an active member of the Essex Hunt Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club, and the Somerset Hills Country Club. He was predeceased by his first wife and the mother of his six children in 1993, and was married to the former Peggy McDonnell in 1995. He often commented that he had been blessed to have married two wonderful women. He had an agile and quick mind, loved history, Shakespeare's sonnets, the New York Yankees, the Yale class of '44, Chappaquiddick, hiking in the White Mountains, sailing, writing poetry and, above all, his family. He was a wonderful guy, a friend to all, and was as good a father and husband as God created. We will miss him terribly. He leaves six children (Eugenie Flaherty of Philadelphia, PA, Philip of Miami, FL, Frances Cummings of Bedford, NY, Alec of Basking Ridge, NJ, Nicholas of Yarmouth, ME, and Elizabeth Lovering of Bedford, NY), eight step-children (Pia Pearce of Norwich, VT, Michael of Malibu, CA, Megan Kyle of Freeport, ME, Stephen of Pipersville, PA, Peggy Vance of New York City, Anna of Los Angeles, CA, Terry of Norwich, VT, and Andrew of Old Chatham, NY), 19 grandchildren, 27 step-grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A Mass of Funeral Liturgy will take place March 31, 11am at Christ the King Church, New Vernon, N. J. Contributions may be made to the Chappaquiddick Community Center (PO Box 2966, Edgartown MA 02539) or to St. Thomas More (The Catholic Chapel Center at Yale University, 268 Park St., New Haven CT. 06511).
CHURCHILL--Jonathan Hand. We mourn the death of our good friend and former partner Jonathan Hand Churchill. We will miss his wit, charm and good counsel. Carol Seabrook Boulanger and J. Portis Hicks

Expanding health insurance to 32 million more people will greatly strengthen our country's safety net. The reforms will also improve the health of many of those currently uninsured, addressing a national disgrace: the premature deaths of uninsured people who cannot get medical care. But inadequate health care accounts for just 10 percent of premature mortality. Even with these reforms, our populationwide health indicators will continue to trail those of other developed countries.

9 P.M. (LIFETIME) DOWN WITH LOVE (2003) A homage to the old Doris Day-Rock Hudson films of the 1960s. Barbara Novak (Renée Zellweger, above, with Ewan McGregor) is an author who has just completed a book that argues for professional and sexual equality for men and women. Catcher Block (Mr. McGregor), a men's magazine writer, decides to challenge himself by writing an exposé of Novak while simultaneously making her fall in love with him. In his review in The New York Times, A. O. Scott wrote: ''Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, the screenwriters, have shaken together a canny cocktail of period vernacular and deliberately labored double entendres, some of which extend for entire scenes. The best moments have a glorious, hectic artificiality, emphasized by split screens, gimmicky editing and the obviously cardboard three-quarter moon that bobs in the ersatz Manhattan sky.'' 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Usher performs, and the Iranian-American freelance journalist Roxana Saberi, who was released from prison in Iran last year, is a guest.

The new health care law is expected to extend coverage to as many as 32 million uninsured Americans over the next decade. Under the law, most Americans will be required to have health insurance by 2014 and the most affluent households will face higher taxes. Here, how the overhaul could affect those who have health insurance now and those who do not. If you're sick, you could get coverage three months from now.

PIANTINI--Carlos. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on March 26, 2010, of Carlos Piantini, a violinist with the Orchestra, 19561972. McGRAW--Harold W. Jr. The West Side settlement houses, including Greenwich House, Hartley House, The Hudson Guild and Lincoln Square Neighborhood Center, mourn the loss of an ardent supporter of the New York City's settlement houses and the services they provide. As the sponsor of the Harold McGraw Good Citizenship Award, which recognizes youth who have demonstrated academic excellence and civic involvement, Mr. McGraw made a lasting contribution to the improvement of young people's lives. The dramatic passage of health care reform was a historic turning point in the effort to repair a deeply broken system. But by itself, the legislation will not be enough to address the needs of many people of color, who face higher rates of infant mortality, chronic disease and disability, and premature death than white Americans do. The new law will help expand insurance coverage and improve access to health care providers in underserved communities, among other benefits. But the major reasons for the persistence of racial and ethnic health inequalities are socioeconomic inequality and differences in neighborhood living conditions -- both of them fueled by residential segregation. These are the issues that policymakers must tackle if we are to improve opportunities for good health for all.

CHALK--Shirley, beloved wife of the late Howard, mother of Robin, Russell, and the late Leslie, grandmother of Morgan and Spencer, sister, great-aunt and great friend died on March 14, 2010. A memorial service will take place at a later date.

RYSKAMP--Charles A. The Director, staff, and Advisory Council of the Princeton University Art Museum express their profound sorrow at the death of Charles Ryskamp, longtime member of the Council and former distinguished member of the Princeton faculty. During his tenure at Princeton and then his subsequent directorships of the The Pierpont Morgan Library and The Frick Collection, Charles Ryskamp exhibited a deep knowledge of both literature and art that left an indelible mark on all of these institutions, energizing public understanding of the past, educating and mentoring generations of students and museum professionals, and maintaining the highest of standards in both scholarship and connoisseurship. In his work with the Advisory Council, he was a loyal and steadfast presence reminding us of how a deep passion for art can manifest itself in a life and an institution, and how art can occupy the center of a great university. We shall miss his wisdom, his often irreverent spirit, and his insistence on the transforming power of art. James Steward, Director

LEON--Alexander. My family's heart goes out to the Leon family. Its a bit ironic that Alexander's funeral is on the day before passover. A great husband, father, and grandfather. My love and thoughts go out to the whole Leon family. The Arthur Pergament Family

RYSKAMP--Charles. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Charles Ryskamp, a devoted friend of our company for more than half a century. Charles was a distinguished member of the Met's board for more than 30 years, serving for much of that time as chairman of the Art and Archives Committee. The Met was privileged to be one of the many cultural institutions that Charles, a distinguished scholar and urbane gentleman, loved and supported with tremendous dedication. We will long remember his generosity, intelligence, charm, humor, and immense devotion to opera and the arts. His presence at the Met will be greatly missed by all his friends in our company. We extend our sincere condolences to his brothers and their families and to Charles's many other friends around the world. Christine F. Hunter, Chairman of the Board William C. Morris, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager

RYSKAMP--Charles A. The American Council of Learned Societies mourns the loss of Charles Ryskamp. In 2001, the Council and The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation established the Charles A. Ryskamp Research Fellowships in honor of his achievements as a scholar and as a leader of cultural and philanthropic institutions. RYSKAMP--Charles A. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation were the grateful beneficiaries for more than a quarter century of Charles Ryskamp's erudition, vast knowledge of the arts, literature and museums, and disarming wit. We are truly saddened by his passing. The Foundation's longest serving trustee (from 1974-2001), Charles helped set its course almost from the beginning. He educated successive generations about its history, was a discerning judge of those elements of the past worth keeping, and an eager proponent of new ideas and creative directions. In honor of his service to the Foundation and his devotion to assisting young scholars in the humanities, the Charles A. Ryskamp Fellowships were established in 2001 to make it possible for 15 of the most distinguished among them to pursue their research each year with sufficient resources and for sufficient time to help realize their promise. His continuing engagement with the Ryskamp scholars has been testimony to his own brilliance as a teacher and scholar. Anne M. Tatlock, Chairman, and Donald M. Randel, President

BERNSTEIN--Martin B. "The greatest truths are the simplest, and so are the greatest men." Julius Charles Hare. From humble beginnings to the height of success, Martin Bernstein was his own man. Strong, intelligent and honest, Marty knew how to work a deal while at the same time holding his family and friends above it all. He will be sorely missed by those who truly knew him. When Martin B. Bernstein stepped into a room, he always looked around with a twinkle in his eye. No matter the time, no matter the place, Marty had a smile and a ready handshake. He had a way of shining a light on you that made you feel as if you'd been friends for years, certainly wishing you had been. When I think of Marty, I think of his uncanny ability to engage people at the tables surrounding ours in a restaurant, or elsewhere; turning a formal affair into a friendly gathering. It is a rare man that is ready to share himself so willingly. I will miss his sound advice, I will miss the laughter, but mostly I will miss that twinkle. With our sincerest, heartfelt sympathy, Brian and Kathy Haynes

LONDON -- More than 200 years ago a German banker, Mayer Amschel Rothschild, sent his five sons to different European cities to guarantee the survival of the family's banking business. Perhaps the most attractive promise of reform is that if we lack or lose coverage, we'll have the security of knowing we can buy affordable insurance through the exchanges set up by the states. This promise won't be effectively realized, however, unless state and federal leaders charged with setting up the exchanges are pressured to keep private insurance premiums in check. After all, 99 percent of local insurance markets are ''highly consolidated,'' according to the American Medical Association, and in 24 states (up from 18 a decade ago), the largest insurer has more than 70 percent of the market. At a minimum, strong exchanges will be needed to encourage competition and transparency.

Several weeks ago on the hospital floor where I'm a nurse, we had a V.I.P. patient whose spouse expected, and got, the red-carpet treatment. The patient's spouse made many demands, but what struck most of us as particularly galling was the meal service both received. Day after day, meal after meal, a hospital employee wheeled a china-laden cart into that patient's room. It looked like room service at a fancy hotel. Each time one of these splendid repasts came to the floor, work would stop while we watched the cart roll past the large metal service container stacked with trays that held the other patients' meals.

In this week's Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein examines the iPhone hack that was a winner at the 2010 Pwn2Own contest, held last week at the CanSecWest conference in Vancouver. She speaks with Ralf-Philipp Weinmann, a researcher at the University of Luxembourg's Faculty of Science, Technology and Communication, who explains the basic strategy of the exploit. It took about 20 seconds, using the Safari browser, to seize control of the phone's text message database, though as Mr. Weinmann explains, other personal information, like contacts, photos and e-mail and even iTunes files, could also be vulnerable. And only a firmware update can patch the vulnerability, he says.

The trouble with an adjective like "timeless" is that it's bandied about so commonly, one is reluctant to use the word even when it truly applies - as it most certainly does in the case of this photograph by Bernat Armangue of The Associated Press, showing Ethiopian Orthodox Christians praying inside the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem. His work was last seen in Pictures of the Day on March 19, in a scene that was far more obviously contemporary: a Palestinian protester waving the flag during a clash with Israeli forces in Hebron. Another A.P. photographer, Rajesh Kumar Singh, has also caught a timeless moment, during the Kumbh Mela festival in India (Slide 4). But we don't want to overuse the word "timeless."

You think Karl Lagerfeld makes a trip to his safety deposit box every time he wants to change up his precious knuckle hardware? Of course not. Karl has his own walk-in safe. But not just any old walk-in safe. The world's most expensive walk-in safe, and he designed it himself. And you can have one just like it. The Narcissus, as the Dottling Safes model is called, is 1,600 pounds of steel-bodied, gleaming chrome-plated aluminum home security. It can be fully customized with watch winders, jewelry drawers or special compartments for whatever you value most. Glorious peace of mind? $340,000. Having the same safe as Karl Lagerfeld? Priceless.

A few follow-ups on the previous post. First, I would invite readers who are skeptical of the data pattern shown in the chart I reproduced to read the entire John Jay Report, as well as the National Review Board report that accompanied it, and (especially) the statistical addendum that John Jay put out in 2006. These are impressively thorough documents, and you may find that many of your objections are addressed in their pages. Where a subject like this is concerned, no statistical assessment is going to be completely dispositive, but I am persuaded that the John Jay/N.R.B. portrait of the pattern of abuse - the rise from the late '50s till 1980, and the drop-off since - is as rigorous as one can hope for at the moment. (In addition, the National Review Board report does an impressive job of addressing many of the cultural issues related to the crisis in an evenhanded and non-hysterical way.)

We're all familiar with the fashion crowd's fixation with black, but if you're also obsessed with watches, check out Black Limited Edition, a series of vintage stainless steel Rolexes turned into "Tron"-like collector's items. Alejandro Alcocer, a watch fanatic and design entrepreneur who has previously delved into skateboarding, catering and handbag design, followed the legend of a black watch supposedly released by Rolex in the late 1960s for the Royal British Army soldiers stationed in South Africa. It was thought that only 500 were made, but Rolex never confirmed their distribution and they became the holy grail of watch collecting. So Alcocer decided to make his own, with the help of a Pennsylvania-based company that had previously done contract work for the U.S. Army but had fallen on tough times. Aside from the dial and crystal, which remain in vintage original condition, the watches were transformed into matte black beauties using highly specialized chemical applications. Black is the new black, and I'm feeling for the Rolex redux.

Justin Bieber, the shaggy-haired, baby-faced Usher protégé, is barely 16, but he now has a No. 1 album on the Billboard chart. "My World 2.0" (Island), his first full-length LP, sold 283,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Billboard reported that Mr. Bieber is the youngest solo male artist to top its album chart since a 13-year-old Stevie Wonder reached No. 1 in 1963 with "Little Stevie Wonder/The 12 Year Old Genius." (Upon receiving the chart news on Wednesday, Mr. Bieber tweeted about how he was celebrating: "SCHOOL ... buzzkill"). Mr. Bieber's minialbum, "My World," released in November, rose five spots to No. 5 this week with 50,000 sales; together the two records have sold just under 1.4 million copies.

The Art Institute of Chicago has begun closing some galleries for one to two hours a day in an effort to close a budget gap, Carrie Heinonen, the museum's vice president for public affairs, said. The rotating closures are an experiment so far, but the museum projects being able to save $150,000 annually if they are continued, Ms. Heinonen said. She added that none of the most-visited galleries - like those displaying Impressionist paintings or famous works like Edward Hopper's "Nighthawks" or Grant Wood's "American Gothic" - had been closed and that the museum had received very few complaints. The closures were reported by Time Out Chicago.

According to Ver Bien Para Aprender Mejor (''See Well to Learn Better''), a program sponsored by the Mexican government, about one-tenth of the country's children do poorly in school simply because they can't see well. That's not just because glasses are expensive, but also because in Mexico they're often perceived as evidence of a handicap. In an attempt to address both problems, Ver Bien turned to the industrial designer Yves Béhar, who, as the creator of the One Laptop Per Child XO (the original $100 computer), has earned a reputation as a maker of inexpensive, attractive products for kids in the developing world. Béhar designed a set of split frames, which makes the glasses less costly to assemble in the field and lets kids customize them using a smorgasbord of color options. ''They're at the intersection of practicality and personal expression,'' Béhar says. With the help of Augen, the manufacturer, Ver Bien can keep the total cost - including an eye exam and shipping - at just $10. This year alone, it will give away 400,000 pairs. ''This is about using the very best not to make the most expensive product,'' Béhar says, ''but to make the most valuable product - and to make it efficiently.''

The new West Village eatery Recette, "is small and crowded behind its windows, loud in the way that little Village restaurants can become loud, the sort of place men go wearing blazers, then pull them off halfway through the meal, where women flush and everyone leans into the table to talk," Sam Sifton writes. The restaurant, run by Jesse Schenker, features "American food with Spanish flavors, cooked with French technique; small plates and high concept." Start with snacks, like codfish fritters or the charcuterie plate or, say, the tête de cochon. Then move on to pork belly cooked with a sherry-laced caramel or ocean trout with a dressing of smoked bacon. "The cooking at Recette is smart and imaginative, the food that results from it elegant and full of flavor. The wine list is deep and the service friendly and able, if sometimes overwhelmed. You may have to ask for water a couple of times. There will be the occasional crash of a dropped wineglass. It is casual, almost to a fault. But Recette is a very good restaurant."

"The Glass Menagerie" might bring to mind memories of overwrought high school productions. So too might "The Miracle Worker," about the life of Helen Keller, which did not fare well in its recent Broadway revival. A new production of "Menagerie" looks like it might have more luck. "Do not come to the Laura Pels Theater, where the Roundabout Theater Company's terrific new revival of Tennessee Williams's career-igniting play opened last week, looking for a standard dose of weepy Southern lyricism," writes Charles Isherwood. "Instead you'll find something unexpected, namely the fiercely moving and seriously funny play Williams actually wrote, in a production directed by Gordon Edelstein that's lightning-lit from within by the tough, compelling and first-rate Amanda Wingfield of Judith Ivey, giving what is surely the performance of her career."

ANDERSON--Richard Charles, died peacefully on March 26th at his farm in Chippenhook, Vermont. He is survived by his son Cass and loyal black lab, Ace. His beloved wife, true love, and best friend, Ingrid, died in 2006. Dick was born in Chicago in 1929 with a passion for advertising. Beginning as a mail boy at the Erwin Wasey agency, he went on to hold senior management positions at Young & Rubicam in New York and Chicago. He later joined Needham, Harper and Steers where he rose to executive vice president and chairman of that agency's board of management. Dick went to work full time for Lands' End, Inc. in 1984 where he was subsequently named chief executive officer and vice chairman of the board. Dick and Ingrid retired to their farm in Vermont in 1993 where they developed a herd of award winning Belted Galloway cattle. He taught others to look for the Big Idea in everything they did, and he led by example.

LIVINGSTON--Pamela Sullivan, 65, of Nantucket and New York City, died March 28, 2010, of complications from ovarian cancer. She leaves her husband of 40 years, Curtis, her children, Molly and William and her grandchildren, Liam, Morgan and Lizzie. Her sister, Priscilla Swift and brother, Robert Sullivan, Jr. also survive. She was educated at Sweetbriar College and Columbia University and had resided with her family in Chappaqua, NY and Arcadia and Pasadena, CA. Pam enlivened us all as the champion and center of her family, a gifted hostess, a dedicated librarian, an ever-curious researcher, a tireless volunteer, a good friend and true lover of life. We will all miss the spirit, joy and love she brought to everything and everyone she touched. Services will be private. Contributions may be sent to the Pamela Livingston Memorial Fund at the Nantucket Atheneum, One India Street, Nantucket, MA 02554. A commemoration is planned for this Summer on Nantucket.

8 P.M. (13, 49) TAVIS SMILEY REPORTS -- MLK: CALL TO CONSCIENCE On April 4, 1967, at Riverside Church in Manhattan, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (below with President Lyndon B. Johnson) delivered what is known as his ''Beyond Vietnam'' speech, a passionate indictment of United States involvement in the Vietnam War. He was assassinated in Memphis one year later. The program explores Dr. King's antiwar position in relation to the current American engagement in Iraq and Afghanistan, as Mr. Smiley interviews, among others, the civil rights activist and Princeton University professor Cornel West and the historian Taylor Branch, the author of a trilogy about Dr. King's life and the civil rights movement. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Guests include the country music singer Gretchen Wilson, who performs, and the chef Chris Kimball.

BERNSTEIN--Martin B. "The greatest truths are the simplest, and so are the greatest men." Julius Charles Hare. From humble beginnings to the height of success, Martin Bernstein was his own man. Strong, intelligent and honest, Marty knew how to work a deal while at the same time holding his family and friends above it all. He will be sorely missed by those who truly knew him. When Martin B. Bernstein stepped into a room, he always looked around with a twinkle in his eye. No matter the time, no matter the place, Marty had a smile and a ready handshake. He had a way of shining a light on you that made you feel as if you'd been friends for years, certainly wishing you had been. When I think of Marty, I think of his uncanny ability to engage people at the tables surrounding ours in a restaurant, or elsewhere; turning a formal affair into a friendly gathering. It is a rare man that is ready to share himself so willingly. I will miss his sound advice, I will miss the laughter, but mostly I will miss that twinkle. With our sincerest, heartfelt sympathy, Brian and Kathy Haynes

RYSKAMP--Charles Andrew, 81, died peacefully on Friday, March 26, of multiple myeloma. He is survived by his brothers Jim and Philip, sister-in-law Eileen, and several nieces and nephews. A scholarship fund will be established in his name at Princeton University, details forthcoming; in the interim, contributions may be made to any of the many institutions Charles loved. Alan Salz Angus Wilkie

ISLER--Alan, author and professor, died March 29, 2010 after a long illness. Born in London in 1934, Alan Isler emigrated to the United States at the age of 18. He served in the US Army from 1954 to 1956. He received his doctorate in English Literature from Columbia University and taught Renaissance literature at Queens College, CUNY, from 1967 to 1995. His first novel, The Prince of West End Avenue, won the National Jewish Book Award in 1994 and was nominated as a finalist in fiction by the National Book Critics Circle. In England in 1995, it won the Jewish Quarterly-Wingate Literary Prize and was a finalist for the Writers' Guild award. He is also the author of: Kraven Images (1996), The Bacon Fancier, also published as Op. Non. Cit. (1999), Clerical Errors (2002) and The Living Proof (2005). His work, noted for its wit and literary erudition, has been translated into more than twelve languages. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Ellen Isler, president and CEO of JBI International, the Jewish Braille Institute; his sisters, Fay Ruback, Dolly Gillin of Los Angeles and Ella Molin; four children, Adam, Eric, Joshua and Claudia; two stepsons, Adam and Ethan Gahtan; and eleven grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be sent to JBI International, 110 East 30th Street, New York, NY 10016. Services will be on Thursday, April 1, 2010 at 11am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at West 91st Street.

Generous, madcap, irreplaceable Charles delighted in the simplest of pleasures: Sunday night dinners, ham sandwiches, students and young artists, books, sailing, Maine, needlepoint, spring bulbs, orchids, but most of all his friends. He was worldly, elegant, handsome, giggly, Jackie's escort, with a wicked sense of humor and an eyebrow raised at the world. His joie de vivre and grace under pressure are forever an inspiration. We adored him. A., A., T. and N.

Your mother-in-law hates computers. Hates. Them. "Too old, too stupid," she says. She comes for a Christmas visit and you show her pictures from your daughter's kindergarten graduation. She watches with increasing interest as you scatter and scan the photos with a flick of the finger. She takes a turn and it goes well. Then you show her the YouTube video of the fall pageant. The satellite map of your childhood home. She takes a turn and this time she does not give it back. You leave her alone for an hour and come back to find her scanning recipes on Epicurious. "This isn't really a computer," she says. "It can't be. I actually might like having one of these around." Is that so? Merry Christmas, beloved, Luddite mother-in-law. We bought it for you.

Rockefeller Center remains the star of its own universe. Embodying John D. Rockefeller's vision of a "city within a city," the 19-building complex has its own post office (for outgoing mail only), postage stamp (issued in 2001, a 10-cent depiction of Atlas) and, according to the 2000 census, a lone resident (a man). "In Detroit, the incapacity of the government is actually an advantage ... There's not much chance a strong city government could really turn the place around, but it could stop the grass roots revival in its tracks ... In many cities where strong city government still functions effectively, citizens are tied down by an array of regulations and permits that are actually enforced in most cases. Much of the South Side of Chicago has Detroit like characteristics, but the techniques of renewal in Detroit won't work because they are likely against code and would be shut down the minute someone complained ... In most cities, municipal government can't stop drug dealing and violence, but it can keep people with creative ideas out. Not in Detroit ... The people in Detroit know that they are on their own, and if they want something done they have to do it themselves. Nobody from the city is coming to help them."

"Death has become banal," proclaims Leonor Scherrer, the daughter of the French couturier Jean-Louis Scherrer and the mind behind one of the ghastliest start-ups since the Grim Reaper: Leonor Funeral Couture. Scherrer is building a fashion line to outfit the bereaved that harks back to a time when "a widow's mourning dress was closely observed," as in Goya's painting of the Duchess of Alba. Her line even comes complete with its own fragrance, Maximilia, named after Maximilian Kolbe, the Polish friar who took the place of a condemned man at Auschwitz. Scherrer's lavish youth is a roman à clef waiting to happen: Catholic school, a caretaker named Guigui, her father's boutique on the Avenue Montaigne, which, she notes, was once called "L'Allée des Veuves" or "Widows' Way." Lately, she's been dabbling in music, and one of the tracks off her forthcoming album is a cover of Schubert's "Death and The Maiden." "For me, she represents France in all senses: the elegance, the aristocracy" - and, évidemment - "the darkness."

The New York Public Library's Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers has announced its 2010-2011 fellows, a group that includes the novelist Mary Gaitskill; the historian Annette Gordon-Reed, author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning "The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family"; and the New Yorker writer Larissa MacFarquhar. Other fellows include the fiction writers David Bezmozgis, Maile Chapman, and Wells Tower; David Sandlin, a graphic novelist; Geoffrey Brock, a poet; David Hinton, an essayist and translator of classical Chinese poetry; Michael Meyer, who is writing a book about a family's organic rice farm in China; and Matthew Stewart, who is writing a book about the role of Deism in the founding of the United States. The academics are Sara Lipton, who teaches medieval history at the State University of New York, Stony Brook; James Romm, a professor of Classics at Bard College; and Andrew McConnell Stott, who teaches English at the State University of New York, Buffalo.

Hours after the design for the tower that Anish Kapoor and Cecil Balmond will create for the 2012 Olympic Park in London was revealed, the work had already earned a few not-so-flattering nicknames, The Guardian reported, including the Colossus of Stratford and the Hubble Bubble. But the official name of the 377-foot, $29 million red steel structure is the ArcelorMittal Orbit, and when it is finished it will stand taller than Big Ben or the Statue of Liberty (though it will be several hundred feet shorter than its Parisian ancestor, the Eiffel Tower). Lakshmi Mittal, the chief executive of the steel company ArcelorMittal, is providing about $24 million for the cost of the structure, with the remaining amount coming from the Greater London Authority. Boris Johnson, the city's mayor, told The Guardian that while some people will say "we are nuts, we are barmy in the depths of a recession to be building Britain's biggest ever piece of public art," London's Olympic Park needed it to spark people's "curiosity and wonder."

LONDON -- Last year brought the centenary of the founding of Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. The  English National Ballet used the occasion for some spinoffs, like the premiere of David Dawson's "Faun(e)." Sadler's Wells Theater presented another spinoff, "In the Spirit of Diaghilev," which involved collaborations between artists and choreographers like Russell Maliphant, who made "Afterlight (Part One)." This week brought a spinoff of those spinoffs, "Ballet Russes -- Encounters," involving both the English National Ballet and Sadler's Wells. Inevitably, parts of it had nothing to do with Diaghilev at all.
