One of the most memorable classes I took in business school was an elective called "Management as Seen by the Arts." It was taught by Professor Culbertson, a character straight out central casting if ever there was one: Harvard-educated, bespectacled, gray hair and beard, slight paunch concealed by a tweed jacket with leather elbow patches. We read "Bonfire of the Vanities" and "Death of a Salesman," and we discussed how drastically the economic landscape had changed since the filming of "Norma Rae."

Judge Rules Wiretapping Without a Warrant Was Illegal | Vaughn R. Walker, the chief United States district judge of San Francisco, ruled that federal agents had eavesdropped illegally on an Islamic charity based in the United States. Judge Walker said that the Bush administration lacked the authority to act without warrants to intercept phone calls and e-mail messages between Americans and foreigners as part of an effort to prevent terrorist attacks. The ruling delivered a blow to the Bush administration's claims that its surveillance program, which Mr. Bush authorized shortly after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, was lawful. The intercepts, Judge Walker ruled, violated a 1978 federal statute requiring court approval for domestic surveillance. The organization monitored by the taps, in this case, was Al Haramain, a now-defunct Islamic charity in Oregon. Two lawyers representing it in 2004 were also tapped. The judge said the plaintiffs had been "subjected to unlawful surveillance," and said the government was liable to pay them damages. [The New York Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

When it comes to bespoke bicycles, Michael Maharam happily calls himself a dilettante. A lifelong collector of one-of-a-kind bikes from around the world, Maharam, of the New York textile company of the same name, recently made friends with a true expert - Sacha White, a master builder who owns Vanilla Bicycles in Portland, Ore. Together, they conceived an exhibition devoted to the work of craftsmen like White, who make a living cutting steel, welding and filing for weeks on end. (''You wouldn't want to be their manicurist,'' Maharam says.) The show, ''Bespoke: The Handbuilt Bicycle,'' which opens May 12 at the Museum of Arts and Design, collects 21 of the finest contemporary examples from America and abroad, from charming, Old World road bikes to aggressively styled titanium and steel mountain bikes. On the gallery's back wall, a set of drawings by the design firm 2x4 explains how bicycles are built. Maharam hopes the exhibition will open up the city's bicycle culture to more people. ''One reason bicycles have become so popular is because manufacturers are making the well designed and beautiful accessible to the masses,'' he says. ''This is the epitome of the well designed and beautiful.''

"Treme," the new HBO series from David Simon, about New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, doesn't begin until next Sunday, but you don't have to wait until then to see a work that explores disaster in the modern American city. Tonight, The Kitchen presents the world premiere of "Bellona, Destroyer of Cities." The interdisciplinary theater work is adapted and directed by Jay Scheib from Samuel R. Delany's science fiction novel "Dhalgren," and is set in a city after a cataclysmic event. It is the second part in Mr. Scheib's trilogy, "Simulated Cities/Simulated Systems," and features passages from the novel with original material, movement and live video. Performances begin at 8 p.m.

"Perhaps you've never heard of the choreographer Faye Driscoll. But if you're reasonably plugged into the contemporary arts scene in New York, chances are you've seen some of her work," writes Claudia La Rocco. " 'Loneliness,' her video flip-book dance, was part of the New Museum's 'Younger Than Jesus' triennial. She was a member of Doug Varone and Dancers, has performed with Yasmeen Godder and served as the choreographic assistant to David Neumann, when he created a duet for himself and Mikhail Baryshnikov." Those who want to get more familiar with her work should head to Dance Theater Workshop to see "There Is So Much Mad in Me." "The piece, which includes fine dancers like Tony Orrico and Lindsay Clark, is drawn in part from media images of people in extreme states and investigates their enduring need to be seen. What better time to catch a glimpse of Ms. Driscoll?"

BERNSTEIN--Martin B. We mourn the loss of our beloved husband, father, and grandfather, Martin B. Bernstein, who passed away on March 29, 2010 among his family and friends. Marty was a devoted and supportive husband and a kind and attentive father and grandfather who dedicated his life to our happiness. Despite a long and painful illness, he remained cheerful and true to his sweet spirit to the end. Marty was a graduate of Far Rockaway High School, the SUNY Maritime College and Brooklyn Law School. His public service included positions as an Assistant Attorney General of the State of New York, a Councilman of the Town of Hempstead, Long Island, and a director of the Long Island Power Authority. He was a successful real estate developer and investor, and long before recycling became a household word, he founded Ponderosa Fibres of America, once the largest producer of recycled pulp in the world. He went on to finance various ventures and served as a director on numerous educational and private boards, and worked tirelessly to give senior citizens in New York City better, safer lives. Marty's interests ranged from Saturday afternoons at the opera to following the exploits of Jack Bauer in "24". He was an avid bibliophile whose curiosity ranged from serious studies of World War II and the Civil War, to the big, contemporary novels of Philip Roth. He is also one of the few who read all twenty of Patrick O'Brien's AubreyMaturin books; still, he found time to read three newspapers a day as well as "The New Yorker" every week. He loved a round of golf and a game of poker with his buddies, and watching the New York Jets with his boys. Marty was the kindest, most compassionate, and generous of men who enjoyed numerous lifetime friendships. He sought to help anyone in need, and always had a good story or joke to share with friends and family. His goodness and love will be with us forever. Marty is survived by his wife of 26 years, Deborah, his sons Scott Bernstein, Nathan Bernstein and Paul Meyer, daughters Lori Chaiken and Michelle Salem, and their spouses, Bonnie Bernstein, Helen Bernstein, Janine Meyer and Steve Chaiken. He proudly leaves behind ten adored grandchildren: Mathew and Alyssa Bernstein, Rachel and Samantha Bernstein, Tucker, Karli, Hana Grace and Joseph Meyer, Jack and Katie Chaiken, and his beloved dog, Rufus.

BERNSTEIN--Martin B. The depth of the sadness at the passing of Mr. Bernstein cannot be expressed. The continued calling of him as "Mr. Bernstein" after 40 years, defines the respect he commanded. He was an advisor, mentor and friend. His bravado and demanding ways were always touched with kindness and caring. Only his close friends and associates understood the vastness of his kindness, guidance and generosity. His was a life to celebrate and admire. The comfort of his mere presence will never be replaced. His family and friends should understand how lucky we were. Farewell, Mr. B. Caridad and Brian Palumbo

Once, insider trading was considered a crime of opportunity -- a chance to profit from an unexpected tip. Today, regulators fearit has become a business model for some hedge funds on Wall Street. In the past six months, nearly two dozen people have beenaccused of participating in a complex marketplace where inside information was regularly bought and sold. Some defendantshave pleaded guilty; others deny the charges, saying they profited from dogged research, not illegal tips.This graphic shows how prosecutors described the flow of insider information in the Galleon case, and in other related cases in this continuing investigation.

TWO and a half years have passed since the credit crisis upset the markets, leading to the collapse of several major investment firms. By the fall of 2008, liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans were calling for financial reform. What had once been considered radical, requiring hedge funds to register with government regulators, for example, was now described as necessary. Financial reform was to be carried out quickly to restore confidence in the markets.

Native Union has created a line of handset adapters for mobile phones that can't quite decide whether they are retro or futuristic. Either way, many people are likely to find its Moshi Moshi02 line an improvement over shouting into a tiny mobile phone. What the company has done is to take an old-fashioned landline handset, added a bit of Euro-design pizzazz, and adapted it so you can attach it a mobile phone. Because you can get the earpiece snug against your ear and the mouthpiece close to your mouth, you will find that you won't have to repeat yourself as often or shout to be heard.

This is the time each decade when America takes stock of itself and counts heads. Residents are asked to complete their census forms as of April 1 if they want to be counted. Getting busy New Yorkers to respond has never been easy. And for those who find the whole exercise depressing because the 2010 forms (pdf), unlike past census inquiries, seek only the drabbest details of our lives as Americans -- how many people live at that location, ages of all occupants and whether households rent or own -- here's a tip.

THE image of the Big Three auto executives flying in their corporate jets to Washington in November 2008 to ask for billions in federal bailout money may still be fresh in most people's minds, but the fact is that business jet use has been falling sharply -- by double digits -- for the last two years. According to the Federal Aviation Administration, which tracks business jet use, the number of flight operations peaked at 4.8 million in 2007, then fell by 11 percent in 2008 and 19 percent more in 2009, to 3.4 million flights. (In February 2009 alone, business flight operations fell by more than 30 percent.)

CORPORATE buyers are intensifying their hunt for deals -- and they're becoming a bit bolder. More than two years past the start of the financial crisis, deal-making is continuing a steady ascent as companies seek to bolster their growth through mergers and acquisitions. And as their collective appetite grows, so too does their willingness to consider more aggressive international transactions or unsolicited bids.

Once, insider trading was considered a crime of opportunity -- a chance to profit from an unexpected tip. Today, regulators fear it has become a business model for some hedge funds on Wall Street. In the past six months, nearly two dozen people have been accused of participating in a complex marketplace where inside information was regularly bought and sold. Some defendants have pleaded guilty; others deny the charges, saying they profited from dogged research, not illegal tips. The federal government recently agreed to sell most of the 120,000 formaldehyde-tainted trailers it bought nearly five years ago for Hurricane Katrina victims for pennies on the dollar. How could it not have anticipated that the sale of those units - perhaps the most visible symbol of the government's bungled response to the hurricane - would result in outrage? And how can they sell them cheaply to middlemen who will then turn a profit selling them back to those who still remain without housing, post-Katrina?

From John Tozzi at BusinessWeek we learn that Bank of America will extend to small-business accounts the protections recently granted to individual consumers by the Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act of 2009. Between May and July, Bank of America will implement new policies for its two million small-business account holders that will end rate increases on existing balances, provide at least 45 days advance notice on rate changes for future balances, eliminate the over-limit fee, and set a grace period of at least 25 days between the statement closing date and the payment due date.

Lately, buns - sometimes holy - have been on everyone's minds, bodies and menus. As a nod to Good Friday, with apologies to anyone who's off leavened items this week, here's a guide to the Big Apple's best buns: sticky, cinnamon, hot cross and otherwise:STICKY BUNSLet's start at the very beginning with a small bakery on Madison Avenue at 83rd Street, William Greenberg Jr. Desserts. When I was a child, my father went here for schnecken. The German word for snail, its reference is the spiral shape of the thing. In fact, while I identify schnecken with this particular rich-doughed, cinnamon-filled, raisin-laden, pecan-topped, caramelized breakfast staple, the label is as generic as "danish," and can be used to describe any flattened, coiled, cinnamon-raisin pastry. Sadly, William Jr. sold his bakery a number of years ago and the goods don't taste the same. If you want to experience a sticky bun as I knew it, you can go two blocks down to E.A.T., where Eli Zabar has created something that rivals the Greenberg classic. Or else call Scarsdale, where William's son Seth continues to bake (and sell) his father's schnecken. Seth uses the same ingredients as his dad and has the original 1930s recipe cards to prove it. You can taste the sour cream and butter in the dough; the perfectly burnt brown sugar in the thick glaze.

Epatha Merkerson, who for nearly two decades has played that crime drama's hard-charging police lieutenant, Anita Van Buren, will leave the show at the end of its current season, The Hollywood Reporter said. Ms. Merkerson, an Emmy Award-winner for the HBO adaptation of "Lackawanna Blues" (not to mention the performer who played Reba the mail lady on "Pee-wee's Playhouse"), appeared in an episode of "Law & Order" in its first season, back when George Dzundza and Chris Noth were still the lead cops. She then joined the show as Lt. Van Buren in its fourth season in 1993. Since then Ms. Merkerson has appeared in more than 375 episodes of "Law & Order," and been on the show longer than any other cast member. The Hollywood Reporter said a deal to return "Law & Order" to NBC for its 21st season was not yet in place.

Plenty of artists are controversial in their lifetimes, but in most cases the dust settles. The choreographer Kenneth MacMillan died in 1992. Some of his ballets remain controversial for their subject matter: abusive sexuality, abnormal psychology and social dissidence were regular themes of his. Some of his ballets remain controversial for their style, which could include aspects of exaggerated and repetitious expressionism, sexual imagery in nonsexual contexts, acrobatic hyperextension, over-manipulative partnering and jerkily mechanical pure-dance routines. And almost every ballet he ever made remains controversial for its deficiencies of construction: individual dances are too long or too irrelevant, certain scenes are expressively unclear, overall organization has too many loose ends.

A few years ago, Ted Muehling journeyed to Vienna's venerable glassworks J. & L. Lobmeyr to research the butterfly-etched drinking set he was in the midst of designing for them. There he found an archive of flat files, filled with the stuff of a designer's dreams: pencil sketches on graph paper by Josef Hoffmann, graceful charcoal drawings of glassware by Oswald Haerdtl and renderings of complicated patterns and engraved borders by Adolf Loos. These rich supporting materials by Vienna's early-20th-century masters will be on view at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, alongside their delicate three-dimensional counterparts, beginning April 23 as part of ''Ted Muehling Selects: Lobmeyr Glass From the Permanent Collection.'' From a baroque, leaf-cut decanter by Ludwig Lobmeyr to the thin, attenuated muslin glass forms that have dominated the past half century, Muehling primarily chose pieces meant for celebration and ritual; the great thing about Lobmeyr, he says, is ''they may be opulent and insanely expensive, but for the most part the pieces are useful and functional drinking glasses.''

Say hello to "The Losers," at No. 10 on our paperback list. That series, written by Andy Diggle and illustrated by Jock (no last name -- think Madonna), is about members of a  special forces group who are betrayed by their handler and find themselves hunted by the C.I.A. The series ran 32 issues, from 2003 to 2006, but the run was long enough to garner interest from Hollywood. A film version of the comic is to open on April 23. Jeffrey Dean Morgan, Zoë Saldana and Chris Evans are part of the elite team, while Jason Patric plays their renegade handler, Max. "The Losers" are a reinvention of a group of DC Comics characters from the 1960s who had many adventures in World War II.

Even in 3-D, Alice in Wonderland has nothing on the Surrealists, who imagined spaces far trippier than any rabbit hole. Max Ernst drew a maiden trapped inside a giant zoetrope; Alberto Giacometti created rooms strung with a spinal column and other oddities; and Salvador Dalí's famous ''Dream of Venus'' installation, at the 1939 World's Fair, was an aquatic funhouse filled with topless women and a rubber cow udder. For the exhibition ''The Surreal House,'' which opens June 10 at London's Barbican gallery, the curators have worked with the architects Carmody Groarke to bring these dreamscapes to life, constructing a labyrinth of rooms and corridors that immerse visitors in the art, films and furnishings of the movement's original and contemporary practitioners. ''The idea is to radically alter the space so that you're not sure what's up, what's down or where it finishes,'' says Alona Pardo, an assistant curator at the Barbican. Rather than imagining surreal interiors, the sculptors Claude and François-Xavier Lalanne furnished them. Their zoologically inspired pieces are now on view at the Les Arts Décoratifs in Paris, including hippo-shaped bathtubs and a bed that resembles a can of sardines. The retrospective also includes pieces designed for Yves Saint Laurent's apartment, exhibited here for the first time.

Caravaggio's time to shinehas arrived in Rome, where his paintings have been collected from around the globe to mark the 400th anniversary of his death. And fittingly perhaps for a man often painted as a villain -- while the work of his rivals have long adorned the papal apartments and the Sistine Chapel -- his images of often shocking brutality and portraits of lascivious young men now fill the old papal stables at the Scuderie del Quirinale.

There is perhaps no better symbol of the Southern California lifestyle than the heat lamp, that industrial, propane-fueled pillar that magically appears on every restaurant terrace the moment the mercury dips below 70. As ubiquitous as cellphone towers - and as grimly utilitarian - the lamps are a not so subtle reminder that even L.A. is prone to the change of seasons. Sort of, anyway. Kindle Living aims to give the heat lamp an image makeover by reimagining it as an actual lamp. The three models currently in production come complete with pleated shades, curvaceous bases (to hide unsightly propane tanks) and an array of colors, like black - perfect for that post-Oscar bash - or pale pink for a poolside sweet 16. And true to form, the Kindle Glow, with its translucent shell, offers not just warmth but mood lighting. Now if only it provided cellphone reception.

It may not warrant a special designation from the United Nations, but Saturday is International Pillow Fight Day. Leave your jammies on, grab a soft, non-feather pillow, and head to Union Square for the fifth annual event. The fight, which is timed to coincide with other fights around the world, is hosted by Newmindspace, which produces "interactive public art, creative cultural interventions and urban bliss dissemination." Participants must swing lightly and clean up their mess. All leftover pillows will be donated to two Manhattan no-kill animal shelters to make bedding for puppies and kittens. The fight kicks off at 3 p.m.

"Even before you see his eyes, you're aware of the force of his gaze. Portraying the artist Mark Rothko, Alfred Molina sits with his back to the audience at the beginning of 'Red,' John Logan's intense and exciting two-character bio-drama, which opened on Thursday night at the Golden Theater," writes Ben Brantley. "Yet the set of his neck and shoulders makes it clear that he is staring hard and hungrily, locked in visual communion with the object before him. That's an abstract painting, copied from Rothko, and it is indeed very red and very dramatic. But it is Mr. Molina's stare that invests it with real drama." The show, set in a New York studio on the Bowery in the late 1950s, follows a new assistant as he is initiated into the aesthetic of the artist. " 'Red,' which arrives as fresh, yes, as paint from its recent premiere at the Donmar Warehouse in London, initially registers as a visceral exercise in art appreciation. Fortunately though, it turns out to be more a study in artist appreciation, a portrait of an angry and brilliant mind that asks you to feel the shape and texture of thoughts."

EDWARDS--Manho Chou, 75, died February 18, in Washington, DC. Born April 4, 1934 in Hangzhou, China. Eldest of six children of a Chinese air force officer and regional magistrate serving in the Kuomintang government under Chiang Kai-shek. During the war with Japan, her family lived in Yunnan, Chungching, and Chengdu. Her private memoirs describe the severity of Japanese bombings in the countryside. She and her siblings would blow out candles and hide under beds when the bombs fell. She recalled American relief planes dropping packages of Klim powdered milk, Gerber's cookies and small black scissors. She kept a pair as a memento. Her family had prominent members including her uncle, the major poet Zhu Ziqing. As her family fled the Communists in 1949, Mao Zedung praised her uncle in a famous anti-imperialist speech titled "Farewell, Leighton Stuart," referring to the last US envoy. Another maternal uncle was Zhu Wuhua, China's first Harvard Ph.D. in physics and president of Shanghai Jiaotong University. Her family resettled in Taiwan, where she met Robert Randle Edwards, a young US Navy officer from Alabama who had studied Mandarin. When they wed, her husband was threatened with discharge for marrying "an aborigine." In 1961 they moved to Massachusetts and then New York, where her husband was a law professor at Columbia University. She received a BA from Columbia in 1981. A person of many talents, she enjoyed music, cooking and writing. She suffered from surgery-induced hypoparathyroidism and was an advocate for fellow victims. Survivors include her husband and three children, Lee, Sue, and Jon.

Donations in his memory may be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering.

ISRAEL--Fred, died March 28, 2010, at his home in Somerset, New Jersey. He was a beloved husband, father, and grandfather. He was a Holocaust survivor and a hidden child during World War II. Fred Israel was born on January 22, 1941 to Benjamin Israel and Ida Kuflick Israel in a displaced persons camp in Belzen, Belgium. Fred immigrated to the United States in January 1948 and lived in Bronx, New York. Fred attended Stuyvesant High School and graduated from The City College of New York. During Vietnam War, Fred served in the United States of America as a member of the Bronx National Guard. Fred was currently employed by Citibank as a senior systems analysis for the past 20 years. He married Sarah Timmerman Israel on January 17, 1971. They have four children, Rachel and her husband Isaac Zetooney, Aaron Nathan Israel and his wife Stefani, Daniel Saul Israel, and Helene Rivkah Israel and two grandsons, Morris Zetooney, and Benjamin Israel. Fred was buried March 29, 2010 at the Floral Park Cemetery located in Monmouth Junction, New Jersey. Donations can be made in Fred's honor to the following: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, SW, Washington, D.C. 20024, Attn: Sara Eigenberg/Fred Israel Hidden Child Fund. Services were handled by The Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Inc., Edison, NJ.

9 P.M. (13, 49) BILL MOYERS JOURNAL At the time of his murder in Memphis, on April 4, 1968, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had expanded his campaign for racial equity to include the problem of economic inequality. In commemoration of the 42nd anniversary of Dr. King's death, Mr. Moyers discusses the plight of poor and working-class Americans who are falling behind economically and what the nation can do to help them realize the vision of Dr. King, above. The guests include Bryan A. Stevenson, a longtime advocate for social justice and a faculty member at the New York University School of Law, and Michelle Alexander, a legal scholar, civil rights advocate and the author of ''The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness.'' 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW The chef Katie Lee prepares Easter dinner.

TAMPA, Fla. - Two days after Pat Venditte's first switch-pitching appearance in a major league exhibition game, Venditte found himself back in the Yankees' clubhouse at Steinbrenner Field, summoned as an extra pitcher for the trip to Dunedin, Fla., to play Toronto. He sat in an empty locker, alone, waiting quietly before boarding the team bus. All of a sudden, Curtis Granderson approached him with a fresh white baseball and a pen. Granderson wanted an autograph. ''You serious?'' Venditte said, a fair question considering it was April 1. But Granderson is too nice a guy to pull that kind of cruel trick on somebody.

DALLAS--Anna C.,on March 30, 2010 at age 97. Devoted mother of Arthur T. Dallas, Patricia Ferrari, Rita Keane and Claire O'Neill; loving mother-in-law of Ann Dallas, Robert Ferrari, Michael Keane and Declan O'Neill. Beloved Oma to ten grandchildren and Grand-Oma to 15 great-grandchildren. Predeceased by her husband, Arthur Dallas. Anna was the center of our family, a warm, gentle person who lit up the room with her smile. She was everyone's Oma. Family will receive friends at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave., New York, Sunday, April 4, 5-8pm. Funeral Mass Monday, April 5, 11am, Epiphany Church, 22nd St. and Second Ave., New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Anna Dallas to Monastery of St. Clare, 70 Nelson Ave., Wappingers Falls, NY, 12590.

LEON--Alexander, 90, born and raised in the Bronx, former resident of Brooklyn and Queens, who lived for over twenty years on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, died on March 28, 2010 from pneumonia after a valiant struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. Born June 15, 1919, Alex graduated from NYU in Accounting, was a WWII veteran and worked, until he retired, as an appellate conferee for the IRS, where he was widely admired for his integrity, dependability, and incisive intelligence. He survived the deaths of his adored, oldest nine year-old son Harold, first beloved wife Henrietta, doting sisters Betty and Tillie, and loyal brother-in-law Sam. He is deeply missed by his beloved wife Lee, sons Marty and Irv, daughters-in-law Linda and Nancy, grandchildren Lena, Ari, and Sam as well as many extended family members. The family expresses deepest gratitude to George Bashaleishvili, his devoted home health aide, Dr. Hassan Khouli, his attending physician providing compassionate care at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, and Rabbi Elliot Cosgrove of Park Avenue Synagogue who officiated at his funeral on March 29, 2010. He will always be remembered as New York's Number One Yankee fan, a dedicated family man through and through, and a composer of songs for and about those he loved. Cherished by all fortunate to have known him, he was a husband, father, grandfather, and uncle who gave and gave to others until there was no more left to give. The Leon Family of New York City and Ann Arbor, Michigan

Thursday, April 1, 2010, was Census Day, the day of the population count that will serve as the national reference point for the next 10 years. While the official census delves into people's private worlds -- their lives behind closed doors -- The New York Times took a census of a different sort, one that captures New Yorkers in their everyday glory, filling the very public canvas that defines the city. Taking a page from the venerable Harper's Index, and a few from ''A Day in the Life of America,'' this flash census took a snapshot of gathering points in each of the five boroughs: a food court, a ferry, a cafe, a park, a bus.

DANCIS--Joseph, M.D. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the sudden passing of Joseph Dancis, M.D. Dr. Joseph Dancis, former Chairman of the Department of Pediatrics, joined the faculty at NYU following his postdoctoral work. He was promoted to professor in 1962 and appointed Chair of the Department of Pediatrics in 1974, a position he held until 1989. His vision for the future of pediatrics, commitment to research, and his mentorship of a generation of pediatricians has had an indelible effect on the character of the School of Medicine's Department of Pediatrics and the field of pediatrics. In his honor, the department's annual Dancis Day is dedicated to presentation of resident, fellow and young faculty research. As a nationally recognized expert, Dr. Dancis' influence has been felt far beyond the School of Medicine. He wrote scores of peer-review papers, was an expert on inherited metabolic diseases and the physiology of the placenta. In all his roles, he thought like a scientist, deliberate and purposeful. In 1983, he was elected President of the American Pediatric Society and subsequently, in 1986, received its most prestigious award, the Howland Award, recognizing a career of accomplishment in academic pediatrics. His prodigious works in the field of inborn errors of metabolism are broadly referenced to this day in the medical literature. Dr. Dancis received a bachelor's degree from Columbia College in 1934 and graduated from St. Louis University School of Medicine in 1938. He completed residency training at Bellevue Hospital and subsequently pursued research training in protein and nucleic acid chemistry at NYU and Sloane-Kettering. A colleague and generous supporter of the Department of Pediatrics, Dr. Dancis will be deeply missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his daughter Dale Dancis, of New York City and his son, Dr. Andrew Dancis of Philadelphia, and three grandchildren. Kenneth G. Langone Chairman, Board of Trustees NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman, M.D. Dean & CEO NYU Langone Medical Center Catherine S. Manno, M.D. Pat & E. John Rosenwald, Jr., Professor and Chair Department of Pediatrics

Well-armed squads of gunmen for drug cartels mounted coordinated attacks on two army garrisons in northern Mexico on Wednesday in what appeared to be a new tactic, the Mexican Army said. Squads of men armed with grenades, armored cars and assault rifles tried to blockade garrisons in Reynosa and Matamoros at around 11 a.m. They were repulsed and suffered casualties, but a brazen attempt to bottle up military patrols in their barracks had not been seen before in the 3-year-old conflict. The region has been ravaged in recent weeks by conflict over turf between the Gulf Cartel and its former allies, the Zetas.

STONE--Natalie Gordon, died peacefully on April 1, 2010 in Palm Beach, FL. She was 93 and she was a mensch! Born in Arlington, MA on January 27, 1917, Mrs. Stone graduated from Wellesley College in 1938. In 1941, she married the late Myron K. Stone. She is the mother of Elizabeth Webb, Pamela Ancowitz and Randall Stone, grandmother to eight grandchildren and great-grandmother to four. Her brother Melvin Gordon and his wife Ellen Gordon survive her. She was life-long supporter of Wellesley College, an enthusiastic member of the Democratic Party, worked for many Jewish organizations, and a big supporter of the arts. For Wellesley, she founded the Wellesley Club of the Palm Beaches. As a Democrat, she was very proud to be on Nixon's so-called Second Enemies List. She was Vice President of the Jewish Federation of New York. In Palm Beach, she was the founder and first chairman of the Cultural Society, Kravis Center. She was also a board member of the Florida Stage. Services will be private. Contributions may be given in her name to one of her passions: Wellesley College, The Democratic Party, UJA Federation, or arts organizations.

"Shannon Plumb," Ken Johnson writes, is a "terrific comic performer. She makes mock television commercials in a flickering, silent-movie style and adds rousing soundtracks of jazz, rock, folk and country music. Portraying a student with attention deficit disorder, an absurdly bewigged model for a shampoo ad, a patient suffering side effects from a stop-smoking pill and other characters, Ms. Plumb is hilarious. Comparing her to Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton might sound like a stretch, but it's not." Tonight IFC Center is presenting "An Evening with Shannon Plumb." The artist and filmmaker will be there to present a sampling of her films and participate in a discussion.

The important American baritone Thomas Hampson, artist-in-residence with the Philharmonic this season, presents "A Guide to German Romanticism," part of the orchestra's Insights series tonight at 6:30 at the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center. "Mr. Hampson will discuss iconography, metaphor and imagery in German lieder," writes Anthony Tommasini. "He knows what he is talking about, having sung the repertory throughout his career, lived for an extended period in Vienna and done important scholarly work on the songs of Mahler. His comments will be illustrated with music, for which he will be joined by the pianist Craig Rutenberg."

As part of the 2010 New York Fornés Festival, presenting an array of work by the playwright, director and theatrical pioneer Mariá Irene Fornés in honor of her 80th birthday, there will be a rare revival of her play "And What of the Night?" at the Cherry Lane Theater tonight. Ms. Fornés, the theater historian Marc Robinson wrote recently on the ArtsBeat blog, "is among the most important contemporary playwrights, with more than 40 plays that helped establish an American version of absurdism (in her plays of the 1960s) and that codified a spare, lyrical form of realism (in her work of the 1980s). Through her influential teaching, she has also been the godmother to an enormous number of other Hispanic playwrights."

A Major Shift | San Francisco public health doctors have begun to advise H.I.V. patients to start taking antiviral medicines as soon as they are found to be infected, rather than waiting - sometimes years - for signs that their immune systems have started to fail. The controversial city guidelines, to be announced next week by the Department of Public Health, may be the most forceful anywhere in their endorsement of early treatment against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

My mother-in-law, Dorothy, is showing me the red spiral notebook that's almost as precious to her as my husband's baby pictures. Inside, in Dorothy's distinctive script, is a list of every book she has read since 2007. For some people waking up in the middle of the night is a terrible curse; unable to drift back to sleep, they're confronted with a big gaping hole that represents hours of lost time. For my mother-in-law, that time is a gift. At 87, she is acquiring the education she never had by working her way through the canon of great literature. She has now read close to 100 books, including every single novel by Anthony Trollope, Charles Dickens, Jane Austen, Edith Wharton, Henry James and Thomas Mann.My mother-in-law discusses her newfound passion with the enthusiasm of a young girl, although she can also be a very tough critic, writing "VG" for "very good" in the margins next to her favorites. Thus far, only a handful of books have received the top prize. Though she "loves" Mr. Darcy, especially after seeing the Masterpiece Theater version with the dashing Colin Firth, she didn't award Jane Austen a single "VG." "I can't explain it," she says. "I like her a lot and I wish she'd written more - was she sickly? I can't remember - but she just doesn't hold a candle to Thomas Mann (three 'VG's'). Everybody should read 'Buddenbrooks.' Where were those books when I was growing up?"

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The Mets intended to wait until Saturday's exhibition final against Baltimore in Sarasota to make their final cuts. Instead, they let six players go after Friday's 4-2 loss to Tampa Bay, cutting pitchers Nelson Figueroa, Bobby Parnell, Kiki Calero and Elmer Dessens; infielder Russ Adams; and outfielder Chris Carter. Carter had a great spring, hitting .393 with four homers, and Manager Jerry Manuel nicknamed him the Animal for his work ethic. Still, Carter lost out as a left-handed bat off the bench to the veteran Frank Catalanotto, a Long Island native.

Michigan St. vs. ButlerSaturday, 6:07 p.m.TV: CBS Cue the ''Hoosiers'' theme music. Butler, playing a few miles from campus and winner of 24 straight, will be the crowd favorite. Michigan State knows the feeling. Last year, the Spartans made it to the championship game as the de facto home team in Detroit. Can Tom Izzo get them back to the title game? A lot will depend on how Korie Lucious, playing for the injured Kalin Lucas, handles a tenacious Butler defense. Or will the Bulldogs, behind a baby-faced star (Gordon Hayward) and a baby-faced coach (33-year-old Brad Stevens) continue a run that would make Jimmy Chitwood and Norman Dale proud?

RUDDICK--Dorothy Cole, an artist, died Tuesday, March 23 in New York City at the age of 84. She was married to Bruce Ruddick, a psychiatrist and poet who died in 1992. She lived in New York City and spent summers with her family in Amagansett, New York. Mrs. Ruddick attended Radcliffe College and Black Mountain College in North Carolina, where she studied with Josef Albers. Upon graduation, she moved to New York where in the early 1950s she drew for Flair, the Fleur Cowles magazine, and Mademoiselle. She also designed textiles for the design firm Knoll, where her colleagues included Isamu Noguchi, Harry Bertoia, George Nakashima, and Eero Saarinen. Her work is in the collections of a number of museums including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Museum of Modern Art, New York. She had one-person exhibitions at numerous New York galleries including the Fishbach Gallery and the Richard York Gallery. Her last project, designed with her daughter Margie Ruddick and WRT for the Durst Organization, is a living sculpture in the Urban Garden Room at Bank of America Tower's 60-foot high street-level atrium space at One Bryant Park, New York. Mrs. Ruddick is survived by her daughters Abby Cole Ruddick of Jakarta and Bali, Indonesia; Lisa Ruddick of Chicago; and Margie Ruddick of Philadelphia; and by three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on April 13th at 6pm at the Fifteenth Street Friends Meetinghouse, 15 Rutherford Place, New York City.

DANCIS--Joseph, M.D.,died suddenly on March 30th at the age of 94. A past chairman of the Department of Pediatrics at NYU School of Medicine, he was especially committed to promoting and mentoring research in the pediatric department. Dr. Dancis wrote scores of peer-reviewed papers and was elected president of the American Pediatric Society in 1983. In 1986, he received the Society's most prestigious award, the Howland Award, recognizing a career of accomplishment in academic pediatrics. His prodigious works in the field of inborn errors of metabolism are broadly referenced to this day in the medical literature. A Brooklyn native, Dr. Dancis entered Columbia University at the age of 15 and then attended the St. Louis School of Medicine where he graduated at the age of 22 as a member of Alpha Omega Alpha, the medical honor society. He became a medical investigator at a time when the tools for this activity were just being developed. His research was eclectic, touching on varied topics and delving into the biochemistry of a patient problem. In each of his various research areas, pursued over many years, he interacted closely with patients, patients' families, and a broad array of close collaborators and colleagues. His research and work developed answers that helped define the metabolic pathways underlying human disease. A loving husband, father and grandfather, Joseph Dancis will be deeply missed.

It's not food, shelter, sex or even the world's greatest computer, but Apple has always had a knack for navigating the space between need and desire, and so when the iPad, a fashionably tardy debutante with a flair for the grand entrance, finally made its curtsy yesterday, people did wonder. You first adopters, of course, might even now be reading this by sliding, spreading and tapping your fingers on a cool glass plane using the mouseless, keyless, buttonless gadget. But it will be months before the big questions are answered: Will iPad kill the laptop? Save the newspaper? Lure people to the e-book? Is there an app for an oracle?

ACTING on an impulse last month, Faran Krentcil dipped her shoulder-length curls into a bathtub filled with Virgin Snow, a pale lavender tint, in the hope, she said, of emerging a ''rock 'n' roll fairy princess.'' The 32-year-old digital director at Nylon magazine got her wish and then some, her lilac fading within days to an otherworldly gray. A mistake? Sure, but no matter. During New York Fashion Week, Ms. Krentcil stood out like a beacon. ''More people took notice,'' she said. ''I got photographed a lot.''

Kwazulu-Natal, South Africa, July 18, 2009 ''This summer, I participated in a high school summer program in South Africa. Our program, Global Awareness in Action, focused on public health and H.I.V./AIDS. We worked with an N.G.O. in KwaZulu-Natal called Amangwe Village that runs a crèche, or preschool, for H.I.V.-infected/affected children. There, we met Lindiwe, a teacher. We were fortunate enough to stay once with Lindiwe's family, all 30 or so of them. Four generations live in a few round houses on top of a hill, including Lindiwe, her father and his multiple wives. The next morning, a few of the grandchildren including Ntumfa (in white) and Hippo (in orange) took us on a hike. Suddenly, we were in the midst of rolling hills covered in tall, pale grass. We hiked for over two hours. To be alone in such a vast and humbling place was more than any of us could absorb. Being there together as friends, not as foreigners and locals, made it that much better.''

A brief article on March 14 about an automobile show at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta, which includes cars once owned by Clark Gable and Steve McQueen, referred incorrectly to the actors' preferences in cars. They both owned Jaguars; it was not the case that they had completely different tastes in cars. (As the article noted, Mr. Gable owned a big, lavish 1935 Duesenberg and Mr. McQueen owned the sleek Jaguar XKSS -- both of which are in the Atlanta show. But Mr. Gable was one of the first Americans to own a Jaguar XK120, a predecessor to Mr. McQueen's XKSS.)

When it comes to vacations, what entices adults doesn't always appeal to those with toddlers and teenagers in tow. So Luxurylink.com, which offers discounts on high-end hotels, started FamilyGetaway.com last month. Like its sister site, it offers deals and auctions, only they're geared for families. Among other things, the site highlights ''family-friendly'' features in an easy-to-see sidebar that appears once shoppers click on a particular hotel. For example, parents interested in the Sheraton Algarve Hotel on Portugal's southern coast can immediately see that it has babysitting, a teenagers' club, a children's pool and a playground on the premises. The listings are vetted by the company.

LIVINGSTON--Pamela Sullivan, 65, of Nantucket and New York City, died March 28, 2010, of complications from ovarian cancer. She leaves her husband of 40 years, Curtis, her children, Molly and William and her grandchildren, Liam, Morgan and Lizzie. Her sister, Priscilla Swift and brother, Robert Sullivan, Jr. also survive. She was educated at Sweetbriar College and Columbia University and had resided with her family in Chappaqua, NY and Arcadia and Pasadena, CA. Pam enlivened us all as the champion and center of her family, a gifted hostess, a dedicated librarian, an ever-curious researcher, a tireless volunteer, a good friend and true lover of life. We will all miss the spirit, joy and love she brought to everything and everyone she touched. Services will be private. Contributions may be sent to the Pamela Livingston Memorial Fund at the Nantucket Atheneum, One India Street, Nantucket, MA 02554. A commemoration is planned for this Summer on Nantucket.

THAU--Diane Rita. The beautiful and beloved Diane Rita Thau, 68, of Pacific Palisades, California, died at home surrounded by her family after a four year battle with Ovarian Cancer. Diane was one-of-a kind. Her beauty, humor and class could light up a room, ignite a conversation and even make a stranger feel like a lifelong friend. She always had a twinkle in her eye, adventure in her soul and boundless love in her heart. She graduated from NYU and went on to earn a Masters degrees in Arts and Sciences from Columbia University and from The College of New Rochelle. Diane's love of children and passion for education lead her to a career specializing in Early Childhood Development and learning disabilities. Her distinguished career spanned over 30 years, practicing in both New York and Los Angeles. Diane was a beautiful woman, a devoted wife, a loving mother and grandmother, a treasured friend and a respected teacher. Her grace, generosity, kindness, and friendship will be missed by all who knew her.

ZIEGLER--Alvin M. Beloved husband of Roslyn for 62 years, cherished father of Sharon, Brian and daughter-in-law Andrea, loving and proud grandfather to Jerri, Carly and Ali. Graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School and The City College of New York. Club Champ of Tam O'Shanter Golf Club. We will love him and miss him forever. May he rest in peace in golf heaven.

DRUCK--Judith, a beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother died on April 3rd, after a life of almost 97 years. She was a woman of great courage, love, determination, and independence. She is survived by her children, Susan Salzhauer and Stephen Druck, her seven grandchildren, and her many great-grandchildren. She loved them all, as well as her husband Maurice who she continued to love every day of her life. GG, as she was fondly named by great grandchildren, was an inspiration for generations of her family, and for many blessed to know her. May her memory continue to be a source of blessing, courage, and inspiration. Funeral will be graveside for family on Wednesday. For Shiva information call: 212-334-8710.

Spring started in New York with heavy rains. Standout umbrellas included one printed with Venetian canals, a scene reminiscent of parts of the Northeast, and an automobile print, unfurled in time for the automobile show. Tourists ducked under vinyl ponchos the color of Easter eggs. By Wednesday, nature had taken a full turn, and glorious spring sights were everywhere. The magnolia trees at the Frick mansion were in bloom, for many a signal of the end of winter. Other signs included people sunbathing in the parks, straw hats, the bare leg replacing black stockings and leggings, pussy willows and forsythia in full bloom, sparrows bathing in the fountain at Gramercy Park, and a few dandies strutting in their Easter finery.

INDIANAPOLIS - Tom Konchalski, the editor and publisher of High School Basketball Illustrated, called St. Anthony High Coach Bob Hurley in his apartment Thursday to wish him a Happy Easter. Before speaking with Hurley, whom he has known for more than four decades, Konchalski reached his wife, Chris, who informed him that Bob would be inducted into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame on Aug. 13. ''What took them so long?'' Konchalski said.

MEESON--John Hamann, age 73, of Elizabeth, NJ passed away on March 20, 2010 at Northern Metropolitan Nursing Home after an extended illness. John was born on August 19, 1936 in Summit, NJ, and was the only son of the late John (Jack) and Claire Meeson. He graduated from Middlebury College in Vermont and was in the Army Reserve for several years achieving the rank of 2nd Lieutenant. He worked for many years as a Computer Programmer, most recently at Metro Creative Graphics. He enjoyed trains, photography and was a baseball fan. John is survived by two sons, Daniel Meeson and his wife Suzanne Lampe of Stratford, and John Meeson Jr. and his wife Dawn of Trumbull and their sons Eric and Kevin. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on April 8th at Black Rock Congregational Church, 3685 Black Rock Turnpike, Fairfield, CT. Donations may be made to Bridgeport Rescue Mission, 1088 Fairfield Ave., Bridgeport, CT 06605

BIERMAN--Jacquin David, 1915-2010. Born in Harlem on January 19, 1915, passed away in Miami Beach on March 23, 2010, at the age 95. A product of the New York City school system who graduated first in his class at NYU, and obtained his law degree from Yale, where he was an editor of the Yale Law Quarterly, Mr. Bierman began his career with the chief counsel's office of the IRS in Washington. While there, in the legislation and regulations division, he worked on many critical projects, including the excess profits tax regulations, which helped pay for WWII. In 1947, Mr. Bierman left the chief counsel's office for private practice. He became a partner in both the national accounting firm of J.K. Lasser & Co. and its legal advisor, the law firm of Chase & Bierman.He loved the arts and literature and represented many arts-oriented organizations and individual artists. He later became Of Counsel to Schwartz, Burns, Lesser & Jacoby, which in turn represented MCA and Universal, among others. Mr. Bierman also personally represented certain artists and organizations such as Simon & Schuster and the controversial science fiction writer, L. Ron Hubbard, during Hubbard's development of Dianetics. During Mr. Bierman's career, he was a prodigious writer and lecturer. Among many other works, he co-authored "Income Tax Differentials" with William J. Casey, former director of the CIA. He taught at the NYU Law School and was instrumental in developing the NYU master of laws program in taxation. He was a major force and frequent chairman at the NYU Practising Law Institute, NYU's continuing legal education program for tax lawyers. Mr. Bierman also founded the Hawaii Tax Institute. While still in New York, he served Of Counsel to London, Buttenweiser & Chalif, and to Helen Lehman Buttenweiser's and Ephraim London's successor firm, London Buttenweiser. He was undoubtedly one of the pre-eminent tax lawyers of his day. In 1977, at age 62, he moved to Florida, and began a second career. He became a professor at the University of Miami School of Law, where then Dean Soia Mentschikoff appointed him director of the graduate law program in taxation. At age 67, the IRS asked Mr. Bierman to return as professor-in-residence to spend a year studying and making recommendations with respect to the "Underground Economy." In this capacity, he analyzed and helped draft numerous regulations. Returning to Miami at age 77, Mr. Bierman began his third career by enrolling as a student at the University of Miami and earning a master's degree in mental health counseling. At age 81, as a mental health counselor, he spent a number of years counseling troubled youths in Miami's Liberty City. Until he was 90, he guided a large number of young people into useful and productive lives. Mr. Bierman was a religious man and a major philanthropic force in the Miami Beach Jewish community. Among the many beneficiaries of his philanthropic efforts were the Talmudic University, the Ascent Institute, and a Jewish women's homeless shelter. The endowed chair in taxation at Yale Law School bears his name. Mr. Bierman was an avid bongo player, art collector, reader, skier, painter, and collector of early American pressed glass goblets. He loved science fiction, owned a cattle ranch, enjoyed fishing, and was a wine connoisseur. As a tax lawyer, as a professor of taxation, and as a social worker, he achieved lasting success and changed lives. He will be deeply missed by many. Mr. Bierman is survived by his wife Gloria and their four children, Adam, Joshua, Douglas, and Robin Tennant. He is also survived by his first wife Irma and their three children, Alfred, Michael, and Louise Oshatz. In addition, he is survived by seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.
LADD--Catherine Macdonald, March 30, 2010. Married to the late Daniel Ladd and mother to the late Daniel Ladd Jr. Survived by her granddaughter, Catherine M. Ladd.

WHILE Paris Fashion Week initiated several trends, it also proved that some things simply don't get old. Like fedoras. Off the runway, quite a few chic women -- including two photographed in Paris last month (above left) -- were seen sporting the chapeau. Among them, the actress Clémence Poésy (above right), who was spotted at Balenciaga in a version by Maison Michel (net-a-porter.com has a similar style for $330); and the models Ruby Aldridge, Carmen Kass and Magdalena Frackowiak (who is shown top right), all of whom walked right out of the Kenzo show in hats from the fall collection. For one that is truly your own, check out the French millinery shop La Cerise sur le Chapeau (lacerisesurlechapeau.com), which lets you choose the color of the hat, ribbon and wrap. The hats, about $175, require one to two weeks to make.

BEN-ZVI--Yehiel. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Tel Aviv University and the American Friends group are deeply saddened by the loss of our valued colleague, Yehiel Ben-Zvi, Vice President of Tel Aviv University. Under Yehiel's guidance, Tel Aviv University attained a place of prominence in higher education in Israel, establishing a world-wide network of Friends Associations, supporters and benefactors. His wise counsel and warm friendship will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bella, Ofer, Orly, Daniel and the entire Ben-Zvi family. LEON--Alexander, 90, born and raised in the Bronx, former resident of Brooklyn and Queens, who lived for over twenty years on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, died on March 28, 2010 from pneumonia after a valiant struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. Born June 15, 1919, Alex graduated from NYU in Accounting, was a WWII veteran and worked, until he retired, as an appellate conferee for the IRS, where he was widely admired for his integrity, dependability, and incisive intelligence. He survived the deaths of his adored, oldest nine year-old son Harold, first beloved wife Henrietta, doting sisters Betty and Tillie, and loyal brother-in-law Sam. He is deeply missed by his beloved wife Lee, sons Marty and Irv, daughters-in-law Linda and Nancy, grandchildren Lena, Ari, and Sam as well as many extended family members. The family expresses deepest gratitude to George Bashaleishvili, his devoted home health aide, Dr. Hassan Khouli, his attending physician providing compassionate care at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, and Rabbi Elliot Cosgrove of Park Avenue Synagogue who officiated at his funeral on March 29, 2010. He will always be remembered as New York's Number One Yankee fan, a dedicated family man through and through, and a composer of songs for and about those he loved. Cherished by all fortunate to have known him, he was a husband, father, grandfather, and uncle who gave and gave to others until there was no more left to give. The Leon Family of New York City and Ann Arbor, Michigan

WITH magazines folding at an accelerated clip, now would seem an inauspicious time to introduce a title. Penny Martin, the editor of The Gentlewoman, a new twice-a-year style guide and sister publication to Fantastic Man, thinks otherwise. ''The best magazines have always come out of a recession,'' she said. ''The Face, i-D, Blitz -- they all launched in 1980, after the winter of discontent. Strangely enough, this doesn't feel odd at all.'' Of course, it helps that The Gentlewoman, a stylish, thinking gal's read infused with a certain retro charm, is unlike any other women's magazine out there. While the real roadrunner doesn't beep like its cartoon counterpart, contrary to Virginia Heffernan's column (''Beep!''), there is an animal that beeps: the human. Since the inception of the Warner Brothers Road Runner more than 60 years ago, its ''beep beep'' (some think it's ''meep meep'') has been supplied by human voices, the Looney Tunes artist Paul Julian's being the first.Pleasantville, N.Y. EDWARDS--Manho Chou, 75, died February 18, in Washington, DC. Born April 4, 1934 in Hangzhou, China. Eldest of six children of a Chinese air force officer and regional magistrate serving in the Kuomintang government under Chiang Kai-shek. During the war with Japan, her family lived in Yunnan, Chungching, and Chengdu. Her private memoirs describe the severity of Japanese bombings in the countryside. She and her siblings would blow out candles and hide under beds when the bombs fell. She recalled American relief planes dropping packages of Klim powdered milk, Gerber's cookies and small black scissors. She kept a pair as a memento. Her family had prominent members including her uncle, the major poet Zhu Ziqing. As her family fled the Communists in 1949, Mao Zedung praised her uncle in a famous anti-imperialist speech titled "Farewell, Leighton Stuart," referring to the last US envoy. Another maternal uncle was Zhu Wuhua, China's first Harvard Ph.D. in physics and president of Shanghai Jiaotong University. Her family resettled in Taiwan, where she met Robert Randle Edwards, a young US Navy officer from Alabama who had studied Mandarin. When they wed, her husband was threatened with discharge for marrying "an aborigine." In 1961 they moved to Massachusetts and then New York, where her husband was a law professor at Columbia University. She received a BA from Columbia in 1981. A person of many talents, she enjoyed music, cooking and writing. She suffered from surgery-induced hypoparathyroidism and was an advocate for fellow victims. Survivors include her husband and three children, Lee, Sue, and Jon.

Three teams in the American League have it all, and their identities are no secret. The Yankees, the Boston Red Sox and the Los Angeles Angels have lots of money, deep reservoirs of homegrown talent and passionate fans who seem to scrape up every ticket every night. It is no coincidence that those teams have each made four playoff appearances in the last five seasons. The Oakland Athletics won the American League West in 2006, the same year the Detroit Tigers won the wild card. The Tampa Bay Rays won the East in 2008. Otherwise, the West division has been property of the Angels, and the wild card and East division have gone to the Yankees or the Red Sox.

AS a 26-year-old woman living in Manhattan, I have zero tolerance for couples who exhibit very private affections in very public places. Although I try to look elsewhere, these amorous displays are hard to avoid. Everywhere I go, people are fondling each other as if the entire city were a cheap motel room. At a restaurant on the Lower East Side recently I was enjoying a friend's company when the man and woman next to us joined hands across the table. If it had stopped there, we could have just rolled our eyes and continued our conversation. Instead, they leaned in for a lengthy, passionate kiss that lifted them off their chairs. We skipped dessert and decided to cap off the meal at a nearby coffee shop -- only to watch another couple sit side by side in a lip lock while we sipped lattes.

McDADE--Innes Fergus, an actor, playwright and artist, passed away from cancer at age 63 on Sunday, March 21st in her home surrounded by loving friends. Innes performed at Harvard's Loeb Theatre in The Square Root of Love and What I Do, Do, Do Adore, Baby. At Penn State University, she received an MFA in Theatre Arts and performed in House of Bernarda Alba, Suddenly Last Summer, and The Seagull and others. In New York, she garnered great acclaim in The Boys Next Door and Off-Broadway Veronica's Room and The Sunday Promenade at The New Theatre of Brooklyn. Innes was a member of The Ensemble Studio Theatre and co-wrote the screenplay, Donuts, with her dear friend, Cecilia de Wolf. She earned an MFA in playwriting from Brandeis University, and wrote plays including A Treasury of Useful Information. Monologues written by Innes are published in the anthology, A Grand Entrance. Innes'collages, which she made from items she found in the trash, include pieces crafted from 100 year old hand written correspondence arranged in traditional quilt patterns. Her art is showcased in galleries, corporate offices and residences. Innes volunteered at the local elementary school, as an ESL teacher, and with the blind. She was a regular at Aram's Cafe in Belmont, MA where she made friends and did much of her writing. Innes' friends were numerous and represented every age and walk of life. Her loyalty, directness, wit, and wonder were an inspiration to all who knew her. She leaves behind her loved brother, Jared McDade, his wife Terrill, their sons, Thomas and Taylor, and countless friends devastated by her loss. A memorial service and celebration of her life will be held in the near future.

For the Cincinnati Reds, the last decade began with so much promise. They were coming off a 96-win season and had just added baseball's premier star, Ken Griffey Jr., with a new ballpark starting to rise. Yet after a winning season in 2000, the Reds endured nine losing seasons in a row. As a new decade dawns, that might be about to change. Walt Jocketty, who helped build championship teams in Oakland and St. Louis, has been the Reds' general manager for nearly two years, and his team may be ready to make a move.

GIESSEN--Professor Bill Cormann Giessen, born June 8 1932 passed away on Thursday March 25. Dr Giessen was a beloved Chemistry and Mechanical Engineering professor at Northeastern University for over 40 years. He received his ScD in Metalurgy from Goettingen University. He had 225 published papers and 15 patents on materials and alloys. In addition to his professional work, he did much to bridge the German and Jewish communities. He was the adored husband of Mary Carolyn Burns, father of Nora Giessen, grandfather of Fredrike and Bruno Giron-Giessen.

ART comes in many forms. For the West Coast artist Alex Israel, it's sunglasses. Freeway Eyewear is Mr. Israel's latest project, and, as with all of his work, it is inspired by Los Angeles. ''I was at an existential point in my career where I didn't know what to make,'' he said of the line's genesis. ''Sunglasses just stood out as a symbol of Southern California.'' Five of the styles are named after L.A. freeways (a sixth, called L.A. Rays, is a revival of a once-defunct brand); each takes a design cue from classic frames: The 15 is based on surfer shades from the 1950s; the 10 (above) is a nod to the '90s Wayfarer. To further boost the brand's SoCal vibe, Mr. Israel enlisted the graphic designer John Van Hamersveld, best known for his Day-Glo ''Endless Summer'' film poster, to create the logo, and the photographer Anthony Friedkin, who has been documenting Los Angeles since the '70s, to shoot the retro-beachy campaign (right).

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Midmajors Show They Deserve Better Deal,'' March 22: I hear rumblings that the N.C.A.A. is considering expanding the men's basketball tournament to 96 teams from 65 next year, and that people are concerned about its effect on the midmajors. What people should really be concerned about is what this proposed format will do to the regular season and the conference tournaments. These two account for a vast majority of the season, yet they will account for almost none of the excitement or buzz.

PILLSBURY--Edmund P. We mourn the death of Edmund P. Pillsbury, who served as Director of the Yale Center for British Art from 19761980. Ted oversaw the opening of the Center as a public institution in April 1977 and played an important role in the life of the Center in its formative years. His untimely death is a great loss for the art world, and we extend our deep condolences to his family, friends, and colleagues. Amy Meyers, Director and the staff of the Yale Center for British Art

Once again this year, the issue of executive pay is high in the public conciousness. Government bailouts of financial and auto companies have increased resentment over astronomical pay that can seem unrelated to performance. As Congress begins to consider financial reform, highly paid executives are likely to remain the targets of some serious tongue-lashings, if nothing else. Bills under consideration contain provisions for a greater ''say on pay'' by shareholders, and many companies moved on their own to adopt such provisions last year, though ''say'' generally refers to a nonbinding vote.

Opening Night The first opening game played at night was held in St. Louis on April 18, 1950. The Cardinals beat the Pirates, 4-2. Extra Innings The longest opening day game in history was a 15-inning game played at Cleveland Stadium on April 19, 1960. The Tigers defeated the Indians, 4-2. D.H. Debut Ron Blomberg of the Yankees walked in the first appearance of a designated hitter in 1973. Record-Tying Blast Hank Aaron Atlanta Braves, 1974 Hit his 714th home run, against the Cincinnati Reds, to tie Babe Ruth for the career mark. Three-homer Games George Bell, Blue Jays, 1988 Became the first player to hit three home runs in an opener - all of them coming off Bret Saberhagen of the Royals. Tuffy Rhodes, Chicago Cubs, 1994 Hit three straight off Mets pitcher Dwight Gooden. Dmitri Young, Detroit Tigers, 2005 He did it against the Royals. Seeing Double The first opening day doubleheader was between the Boston Americans and the Philadelphia Athletics in 1903. Boston won the first game, 9-4, and Philadelphia won the second game, 10-7.

BAUER--Helen Lucy Mattes, 100, of Wyckoff, NJ, on Tuesday, March 30, 2010 at home. Beloved wife for 66 years of the late Theodore J. Bauer, MD, in 2005. Originally from Iowa City, and a 1931 graduate of the University of Iowa, Helen accompanied her childhood sweetheart Ted on his postings with the U.S. Public Health Service. BAGHDAD -- The killers came at night, speaking passable English and wearing uniforms and carrying weapons that resembled those of the American military. By the time they left the village of Hawr Rajab on Friday evening, they had fatally shot or slit the throats of 25 members of an extended family, Iraqi officials said Saturday, in a chilling episode of violence reminiscent of the worst days of the country's sectarian warfare in 2006 and 2007.

ALL-NIGHTERS That first night without Chief, I found myself straining to hear him coming up the stairs, his arrival heralded by toenails on the hardwood, followed by the crash of the spare bedroom door opening as he strolled in to take his place on the rug. Circle, circle, plonk. But throughout the house, no sound, just the branches groaning in the wind and the aggressive plink of wind chimes outside the window. I was alone. Chief was gone for good. Now, months later, I'm awake and alone yet again, and, as in years past, worried about money. I pass the infernal deep blue hours haunted by memories of my dog, haunted by regret. When I ask myself, ''Was it worth it?'' and come up short, I then ask, is it so bad that my wildest indulgence was trying to keep someone I adored alive and happy just that much longer?
BERNSTEIN--Martin B. We will miss you sorely. You were one-of-a-kind. Love Elaine and Norman Fass

THE NEWS The Obama administration proposed scrapping a longstanding moratorium on offshore drilling along the East Coast and opening vast tracts there and in the Arctic Sea to oil and natural gas drilling for the first time. BEHIND THE NEWS While industry groups and some Republicans offered muted support, many environmentalists denounced the plan, which seemed tailored to help Mr. Obama's chances of passing his climate and energy bills. For example, it exempts waters off New England; Maine's two Republican senators, considered swing votes on those bills, both oppose offshore drilling.

Each week on the City Room blog, editors select a New Yorker to answer readers' questions. Here are excerpts from last week's Q. and A. with Tibor Fuchs, president of the Metropolitan New York Chapter of the Indoor Gardening Society of America. This week, Jorge Pabon, a performer and choreographer who is known as Pop Master Fabel, will respond to questions about the history and culture of hip-hop.Q. What are your recommendations about the frequency and amount of watering indoor plants? William R. Bauer A. The only foolproof method of proper watering is the finger test. Insert a finger an inch or two into the soil. If it's moist, do nothing. If it's damp and a tropical, water it. If it's a succulent, wait until it's completely dry. When watering, water thoroughly. Make sure at least some water has come out the drainage hole.

With e-readers like Apple's new iPad and Amazon's Kindle touting their vast libraries of digital titles, some bookworms are bound to wonder if tomes-on-paper will one day become quaint relics. But the question also arises, which is more environmentally friendly: an e-reader or an old-fashioned book? To find the answer, we turned to life-cycle assessment, which evaluates the ecological impact of any product, at every stage of its existence, from the first tree cut down for paper to the day that hardcover decomposes in the dump. With this method, we can determine the greenest way to read.

HALSEY--Richard Sweeney, died peacefully March 28, 2010, in Dallas, TX. Born April 8, 1929, in North Hollywood, CA, to John Calvin Sweeney and Grace Thorne Crossman, direct descendant of Captain John Underhill and Jean Coutant. Graduate, New England Conservatory, Simmons College, and Case Western. Dean of the School of Information Science and Policy, SUNYA, 1981-1993. Publications include "Classical Music Recordings for Home and Library," 1976; "Best Rated CDs (Classical)," 1992; "The Citizen Action Encyclopedia: Groups and Movements That Changed America," 2002; "Lobbying for Public and School Libraries: A History and Political Playbook," 2003. At the time of his death, he was engaged in documenting women activists who changed America. Known for his passionate advocacy of citizen action, he believed in the power of each individual to make a difference for the greater good. Survived by his beloved wife, Gillian Maclauchlan Clive McCombs of Dallas, daughters Rachel Gratia Halsey of Los Angeles., Gabriela Libra Halsey of Schenectady, NY; stepdaughters Heather Clive McCombs of Appleton, WI, Willow Lovelace McCombs Newman (Kevin) of Milan, MI, Margaret Butterfield McCombs of New York, NY; grandchildren Soja and Bijan Moore, James Dean Philip and Georgia Gillian Parnau and Skyler Adelaide Newman. Richard's life will be celebrated April 16, 2010 at 4pm, at the Perkins Chapel, Southern Methodist University, Dallas. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New England Conservatory Scholarship Fund or the League of Women Voters.

HUGHES--Dr Patrick H.,75 born and raised in Latrobe, PA, recent resident of Maple Leaf Estates, Port Charlotte, FL, passed away Saturday, March 27 in Fort Myers, FL. He was tenacious, hard-working, discerning, fearless, pioneering, modest, athletic, handsome, and a great adventurer. His seminal work in the field of drug addiction and treatment in the late 60's helped to transform our understanding of substance abuse from a moral affliction into the modern concept of a treatable disease. As a professor at the University of Chicago, he went into the Chicago ghetto to understand heroine addiction and discovered "copping areas." He won the trust of radical groups, such as the Black Panthers, which helped him gain a revolutionary perspective within his field. His findings were published in his book "Behind the Wall of Respect." He then went on to the international stage, traveling to Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Afghanistan, Iran, India, Burma and more in an effort to understand and develop effective treatment strategies for the varied drug problems around the world in his role as Principal Investigator for the World Health Organization (WHO) in Geneva, Switzerland. He finished out his career with 20 years of clinical service at the Tampa Bay Pines V.A. During this period, he also led important research at the University of South Florida looking at physician drug abuse. His accomplishments were not limited to his career. A self-taught sailor on the stormy seas of Lake Michigan during his Chicago years, he took a break from research after WHO and lived on his Formosa 41 sailboat in the Mediterranean Sea for four years, braving the vicious Mistral storms and ultimately sailing across the Atlantic Ocean back to the States, navigating by the stars with an old-fashioned sextant and encountering a storm so powerful it broke the boom. Medical Degree, University of Pittsburgh (second in class); Medical Internship, Stanford University; Psychiatric Residency, Columbia University; Masters in Public Health, Columbia University. Featured doctor in People Magazine, May 1978. He is survived by a daughter, Kristina, and four siblings Richard Hughes, Rosemary Slate, Kevin Hughes and Kathy Molina. He was preceded in death by his parents Michael F. and Sarah Frances Hughes. The family held a private service. Memorial donations may be made to: Adams Memorial Library, 1112 Ligonier St., Latrobe, PA 15650 www.adamslib.org. Funeral services under the direction of Gendron Funeral & Cremation Services Inc., 4224 Cleveland Ave., Suite 1, Fort Myers, FL 33901, 239-274-0088. gendronfuneralhome.com

But Stamkos is still a big part of the hockey conversation this spring as an unforeseen contender for the Maurice Richard Trophy, awarded to the N.H.L.'s top goal scorer. Stamkos's competition comes from two of the more glamorous players and the sport's most publicized rivals, the Pittsburgh Penguins' Sidney Crosby and the Washington Capitals' Alex Ovechkin. Going into Saturday's games, Stamkos was tied with Ovechkin at 46 goals, one behind Crosby.

QUINTON--Dolores. It is with great sadness and fond memories, we mourn the loss of our dear friend, Dolores Quinton who passed away March 31st at the age of 83. Dolores touched so many lives with her knowledge, charm and wit. Her passion for the arts eventually led her to the acting profession and the words of William Shakespeare guided her through her long career. Mrs. Quinton appeared on stage and television and her vast collection of books defined her love for literature, politics and the cinema. She attended Horace Mann school, and also had a Master's in Early Childhood Development. She held marketing position for the introduction of new products. She became a board member of the Center for Living, which is an adolescent outpatient substance abuse facility in New York City. She made her mark at the center with the same energy she always used in the past. Her simple questions always sparked discussions. With the heart of a lion and the soul of a child, Dolores had a zest for life and we were lucky that she stopped by us along the way. Mrs. Quinton was a devoted wife and mother and was predeceased by her husband, Albert Quinton and daughter, Patricia Quinton. She is survived by sister, Donna DeAngelis, who lives in Italy as well as a niece and great niece who also reside in Italy. On Tuesday, April 6 at 10am, a funeral mass will be held for Dolores at St. Stephens of Hungary Parish, located at 414 East 82nd Street in New York City. With love from Elizabeth and Liz and your loving New York friends.

This week in Critics' Picks, A. O. Scott looks at Ingmar Bergman's classic meditation on life and death, "The Seventh Seal." The film tells the story of a knight who returns from the Crusades to find his homeland ravaged by the Bubonic Plague. "In spite of its reputation as a bit of a downer," Mr. Scott says, "'The Seventh Seal' is actually kinda fun." "I think they're confused," says the blogger Hong Sukwoo as he slowly drinks his strawberry juice with a straw in the ornate Las Vegas-meets-grandma marble lobby of Seoul's Imperial Palace Hotel. Sukwoo is talking about Korea's younger generation, the K-pop kids now in their late teens and early 20s who have plenty of disposable cash and a burning desire to be unique, but who barely have a clue who they are. Sukwoo, at the ripe age of 28, already considers himself part of an earlier "not so beautiful, but perhaps more thoughtful" generation. For the past four years, he has been filling his Your Boyhood blog (yourboyhood.com) with the photos he takes of Seoul's jeunesse dorée and essays that read like sad, disjointed poems (at least when you try to decipher them with your computer's instant translator). For him the blog is still in the early stages of a project he imagines will take him about 10 more years: to record the passing youth of one of Asia's - and the world's - speediest fast-track cultures. "Young Koreans haven't found their own style yet, so they're copying images they find on the Internet," he says. "It's a form of stylish cosplay."

His take on fashion shows and customized garments, as well as his emo-style self-portraits, have won him a local cult following.

Glenn Greenwald and others have objected to a passage in today's column in which I suggest that conservatives only show up on Rachel Maddow's show when they have something nasty to say about the Republican Party. Greenwald has a point: I intended a touch of hyperbole about MSNBC's biases, but, taken literally, the line reads as an anti-Maddow exaggeration, which I did not intend. She does, in fact, have conservatives on her show as conservatives, and it's possible (as Greenwald suggests) that any seeming imbalance in her guest list is mainly the result of Republicans turning her invitations down.

I've invited the clinical psychologist Cynthia Green, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York and the author of several books on memory (including "Through the Seasons: An Activities Book for Memory Challenged Adults and Caregivers"), to join the conversation today. I've been hearing laments about the difficulties of visiting relatives with dementia; people yearn to make that time together enjoyable and meaningful, but they can't always figure out how to connect. Despite the number of very thoughtful tributes to Alexander McQueen that ran after his death on Feb. 11, the reality is very few people really understood him. A private man who also had difficulty switching off the creativity and finding balance in his life, he may have preferred it that way. His friends were the same, small close-bound group that went back 20 years, and of course, as we know, two of women who were integral to his life, his mother, Joyce, and his friend and mentor, Isabella Blow, had died.
