A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

If you could never quite picture Philippe Starck's machine-gun lamp in your own home, try picturing it in the architect Piero Portaluppi's 1935 rationalist masterpiece, the Villa Necchi Campiglio; it has just taken up a seven-week residence in the house's entry, alongside Konstantin Grcic's Kanu chair, with Portaluppi's elaborate ceiling tableaus overhead. The villa, which reopened to the public in 2008, is one of four house museums that will host more than 200 pieces of 21st-century design for ''Unexpected Guests,'' one of the headline exhibitions of Milan's design week. Among other interventions are a Nacho Carbonell chair and Steven Holl credenza in the Museo Bagatti Valsecchi; ceramics by the upstart Tomás Alonso in the Casa Museo Boschi Di Stefano's Lucio Fontana gallery; and at the Museo Poldi Pezzoli, Gaetano Pesce's La Michetta modular sofa for Meritalia (above) and Front's horse-shaped lamp for Moooi, which displaced an armored steed. The Italians may have invented design, but they still have a sense of humor about it. Go to casemuseomilano.it.

BOSTON - The first game I covered for The Times was on Aug. 2, 2005. That night at Shea Stadium, Victor Zambrano allowed four homers to the Brewers in a five-batter span. The Mets went on to overcome a four-run deficit, give up the go-ahead run in the ninth inning, tie the score in the bottom half and then win in the 11th on Mike Piazza's bases-loaded walk. The game lasted 4 hours 28 minutes, and it was a thrilling night.

Is there anyone alive not conflicted about getting and spending? Even at the height of the bubble, when Americans wallowed in an orgy of things, there were always people like Kate Bingaman-Burt, for whom the daily acquisition of stuff resulted in a pang or two. ''Obsessive Consumption'' (Princeton Architectural Press) is her sweet act of contrition. A graphic design professor from Portland, Ore., Bingaman-Burt drew three years of everyday commerce, from pizza to toothpaste, ballet slippers, zippers, tweezers, DVDs, moving boxes, airline tickets, fly swatters, diet soda, etc. She annotates where necessary - ''Serta Mattress, Queen $500 No More Futon for Us!'' - and we're also treated to credit card bills, recreated in her own innocent hand, which somehow (maybe not for her) takes the sting out of owing MasterCard $5,522.62. Read from beginning to end, ''Obsessive Consumption'' reveals a happy (if somewhat guilty) grasshopper who likes a good bargain as much as she likes a good burrito. Bingaman-Burt engages in the same name-brand culture as the rest of us, but in her life, at least, it's art.

New Rates Could Slow Adoption of Solar | The proposed rate structure announced last week by Pacific Gas and Electric would replace the current five tiers with three. Most customers' bills would rise, but those using the most electricity would see significant reductions, to about 30 cents per kilowatt hour from the current level of nearly 50 cents. The existing rates have been a boon to California's residential solar industry, but these incentives would be reduced under the new plan. P.G.&E. has asked state regulators to rule on the proposal by year's end. If approved, the rates would go into effect in May 2011. David Hochschild, a vice president for external relations at Solaria, a solar manufacturer in Fremont, said, "You can't have one foot on the gas and one foot on the brake at the same time." [The San Jose Mercury News]

D'LUGOFF--Avital Achai, passed away March 29, 2010, Passover eve. Preceded in death by her loving husband Art D'Lugoff four months prior. Beloved mother of son Raphael and daughters Sharon, Dahlia and Rachel. Grandmother of Nathan, Samuel, Charlotte, Alice and Ace. Brother-in-law Dr. Burt D'Lugoff of Maryland. Avital left two brothers and a sister surviving in Israel and many nieces, nephews and cousins. She was born in British mandated Palestine in Kibutz Givaat Brenner. Her father Joseph Achai was a noted biblical scholar and Hebrew poet. She was a decorated veteran of the Israeli Naval Forces having served seven years. Arriving in the US, she worked as a music teacher, and was an avid and skilled photographer. She lived a full and bountiful life. She will be sorely missed and lovingly remembered.

ORESMAN--Roger B.,died peacefully at home on April 2 surrounded by his wife of 35 years, Janice, and children Sam Fortenbaugh and Cristina Carlson. He was 89 years old. A dignified lawyer with a commanding presence, he was dedicated to his profession as a partner in the firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, where he practiced law for more than fifty years. He was respected for his loyalty, integrity, fairness, and strong sense of ethics. Roger was an avid bicyclist who rode almost daily in Central Park until he was 86. He and Janice often took their bikes to France and toured the countryside, enjoying the wonderful food and wine that inspired him in his own kitchen where he was the master chef. French cuisine in New York also meant La Grenouille where special celebrations were always held. A thoughtful conversationalist, a superb listener, and a valued friend, he delighted in art, The Century Association, and dancing to his favorite selections from The American Songbook. His signature snappy red bow ties reflected his jaunty spirit. A lifelong New Yorker, born on October 26,1920, he only lived outside his beloved city to attend college and to serve in the Navy during World War II. He was a devoted alumnus of The Fieldston School, Harvard College, Harvard Business School, and Columbia Law School, as well as an active supporter of his wife's alma mater, Smith College. He is also survived by his brothers, Donald and Stephen, and their families. A gathering of family and friends will be held at a later date. Contributions may be sent to The Roger B. Oresman 1941 Fund, Harvard Art Museum, 32 Quincy Street, Cambridge, MA 02138.

YUDAIN--Bernard, former Corporate Affairs Director of Time Inc., and a journalist whose vision and editing transformed Greenwich Time into one of the best community newspapers in America, died April 3, 2010, after a short illness in Greenwich, CT. He was 91 and a proud 73-year resident of Greenwich, the town he loved. Survivors include his wife, Jean Yudain, son David Yudain, brother Sidney Yudain, nephew Ted Yudain Jr. and five other nieces and nephews. Memorial service April 8, 11am, at Christ Church, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Family Centers of Greenwich.

ST. JOHN--Fordyce Barker, Jr.,age 88, died in Redding CT, on March 31, 2010. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Lisa Polhemus St. John, three children, two grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Known as John St. John, he served with the 84th Infantry in World War II and graduated from Princeton University in 1945, then worked in the natural resources and banking industries before retiring from the Bank of New York. The St. Johns were long-time residents of New Canaan, CT and Sagaponack, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Connecticut Humane Society, 455 Post Road, Westport, CT 06880.

REISER--Robert F.,78, of Sag Harbor, NY, died suddenly on April 3, 2010. Beloved husband of Mary (Lawless). Devoted father of Mark, John, (Linda), Robert, (Bernadette), Mary O'Donnell, (Walter), Martin and Peter. Loving grandfather of Erin, Timothy, Daniel, Michael, Brendan, Bridget, Kathleen, Thomas, Walter, Mary Claire, and Robert. He graduated from St. Peter's College, Jersey City in 1954 and received an M.B.A. from The Harvard Business School in 1958. He was a lieutenant in the Intelligence Service in the Unites States Army from 1954-1956. He worked for Moran Towing Corporation until he joined Xerox in 1964. At Xerox he held various management positions retiring as Senior Vice-president and President of Xerox International. After retiring in 1988, he joined the faculty at Babson College in Wellesley, MA where he taught for five and a half years, retiring as Chairman of the Marketing Department. He was Mayor of North Haven, NY from 1998-2002. Reposing at Yardley and Pino Funeral Home, 91 Hampton St., Sag Harbor, Tuesday April 6, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass Wednesday 10am, St Andrews R.C. Church. Interment St. Andrews Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations to The Cormaria Retreat House, P.O. Box 1993, Sag Harbor, NY 11963 or St. Andrew's R.C. Church, 122 Division St., Sag Harbor, NY 11963.

Butler The biggest factor is health. Center Matt Howard has a mild concussion, and guard Shelvin Mack cramped up Saturday from food poisoning. Mack said he was fine, but without Howard, Butler will be hard pressed to neutralize Duke's offensive rebounding. Butler again needs a huge game from Gordon Hayward, left, the best N.B.A. prospect on the court. Butler held Kansas State and Syracuse to season lows in points, so don't expect as many open 3s for Duke as it had against West Virginia. Butler needs to keep the score below 60.

LUNEY--William Ross, of Tarrytown, NY, 80, on April 3, 2010. Graduate of Northwestern University and University of Michigan School of Law. Served in the U.S. Navy from 1953-1956. Bill married Mary Connelly on June 4, 1960 in Camden, Maine. Bill began his legal career at Sullivan and Cromwell in New York City. He went on to serve as legal counsel, Vice President and Secretary for Bristol-Myers Squibb. Trustee of the Interlochen Center of the Arts in Interlochen, MI and he was a member of the visiting committee of Northwestern University. Member and former Chairman of the Zoning Board of Appeals in Tarrytown. Member and former President of Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough. Member of the New York Athletic Club. Loving father of Margaret L. Walker and husband David of Scarborough, NY and Michael D. Luney of Camden, ME and grandfather of William, Ryan and Patrick Walker. Predeceased by his wife Mary and son William R. Luney, Jr. Visitation at Coffey Funeral Home, Tarrytown on Monday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Tuesday at 10:00 at the Church of the Transfiguration.

KUALA LUMPUR -- Through most of their 17-year marriage, M. Indira Gandhi says she and her husband observed rituals that she considered integral to their Hindu faith. Each morning they would pray before a shrine and on Fridays they would fast. During festivals they donned brightly colored, traditional outfits to attend their local temple. Those were traditions Ms. Gandhi assumed they would be passing on to their three young children.

PILLSBURY--Edmund P. We mourn the death of Edmund P. Pillsbury, who served as Director of the Yale Center for British Art from 19761980. Ted oversaw the opening of the Center as a public institution in April 1977 and played an important role in the life of the Center in its formative years. His untimely death is a great loss for the art world, and we extend our deep condolences to his family, friends, and colleagues. Amy Meyers, Director and the staff of the Yale Center for British Art

MORIARTY--Daniel John, born September 1, 1941 in New York City, died at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles after a brave battle with AML. A graduate of The Dwight School and Georgetown University, Dan began Groovies Movies while in college and was a publicist for The Shadows nightclub in Washington, DC. He returned to New York to represent, among others, The Lovin' Spoonful, Richie Havens and Buffy St. Marie. Dan went on to a distinguished career in senior executive positions at Norton Simon, Inc., Revlon, Max Factor, Christian Dior, LVMH, Large Scale Biology Corp. among others, and most recently, until his retirement, at APLA. Unfailingly generous and loving with his time, wisdom, humor and friendship to family, friends, and colleagues, Dan served on the boards of educational, charitable and business not-for-profit organizations and was an avid world traveler. After the death of his parents Jane G. and Mortimer D., Dan became the beloved patriarch of his family. He is survived by his brothers and sisters Mortimer, Kevin, Margaret, Michael, John and Jane and their spouses, nine nieces and nephews, three great-nephews and his dearest friend Thomas McCauley. The family will be receiving April 7 from 6-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street on April 8 at 10am. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations be made to: Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Ave., Hawthorne, NY 10532.

Ever since he ran Bill Clinton's ''It's the Economy, Stupid'' presidential campaign in 1992, James Carville has held a reputation for common-sense Democratic strategy. In recent years, Mr. Carville has seized on the transformation of America's energy system, which simultaneously touches voter concerns about the economy, national security and the environment. But he acknowledges that ''energy independence'' has lately lost political altitude.

ROSE--Daphne, 79, passed away peacefully on March 31, 2010; Loving mother to Jamie and Jennifer, Step Mother to Peter and adoring Grandmother to Shelby, Drew, Eliza, Faith and Amy. A woman of grace and unparalleled style, she will be missed, yet never forgotten. In lieu of flowers, plant a rose!

THAU--Diane Rita. The beautiful and beloved Diane Rita Thau, 68, of Pacific Palisades, California, died at home surrounded by her family after a four year battle with Ovarian Cancer. Diane was one-of-a kind. Her beauty, humor and class could light up a room, ignite a conversation and even make a stranger feel like a lifelong friend. She always had a twinkle in her eye, adventure in her soul and boundless love in her heart. She graduated from NYU and went on to earn a Masters degrees in Arts and Sciences from Columbia University and from The College of New Rochelle. Diane's love of children and passion for education lead her to a career specializing in Early Childhood Development and learning disabilities. Her distinguished career spanned over 30 years, practicing in both New York and Los Angeles. Diane was a beautiful woman, a devoted wife, a loving mother and grandmother, a treasured friend and a respected teacher. Her grace, generosity, kindness, and friendship will be missed by all who knew her.

GARBER--Morris W. in Manalapan, NJ, on April 1st, 2010. Survived by his wife Phyllis, son Joshua, daughter Miriam Finkelstein, son-in-law Greg, sister Loretta Newman and husband Jack, grandchildren Sara and Matthew.

SNYDER--Marc. On April 1, 2010 Marc Snyder, beloved husband of Sharon L. Snyder (nee Clatterbuck); devoted father of Emma Rose and Madison Grace Snyder. A celebration of life will be held at the family home on Saturday, May 22 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Gilchrist Hospice, 11311 McCormick Rd., Suite 350, Hunt Valley, MD, 21031

DRUCK--Judith, a beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother died on April 3rd, after a life of almost 97 years. She was a woman of great courage, love, determination, and independence. She is survived by her children, Susan Salzhauer and Stephen Druck, her seven grandchildren, and her many great-grandchildren. She loved them all, as well as her husband Maurice who she continued to love every day of her life. GG, as she was fondly named by great grandchildren, was an inspiration for generations of her family, and for many blessed to know her. May her memory continue to be a source of blessing, courage, and inspiration. Funeral will be graveside for family on Wednesday. For Shiva information call: 212-334-8710.

As a reporter with The Sunday Times of London in the 1970s, Elaine Potter worked the paper's exposure of the scandal over thalidomide, which was promoted as a cure for morning sickness but caused birth defects in thousands of children. Ms. Potter laments that investigative reporting is hard to find today as papers fill their pages with celebrity photos and articles generated by news releases.

RUDMAN--Frances, 97, of Great Neck, New York, died on April 3, 2010, in Highland Park, Illinois. She is survived by her children, Jerry Rudman of Highland Park, Illinois, Stephanie Joseph and her husband William of New York City, Michael Rudman of Sands Point, N.Y., eight grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. An accomplished pianist, she was an arranger and copyist with the big bands during the '40's and worked with Ella Fitzgerald, the Paul Whiteman Orchestra and Vincent Lopez Band. She and her late husband, Jack, founded National Learning Corporation in the 1950's, the first publishers of books to help applicants pass civil service licensing examinations, MCAT's, LSAT's, GRE's and thousands of other tests. She continued to work at National Learning nearly everyday day until her 95th birthday. A private funeral will be held on April 6 at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Chicago Botanic Garden or to UJA-Federation of New York.

TENDLER--Sylvia, passed away peacefully on March 30, 2010 surrounded by family. Loving wife of Meyer for 64 inseparable years. Devoted mother of Shelli(Arthur) Carol (Vincent), and Craig (Sheri). Cherished and adored grandmother of Seth, Ian, Talia, David, Sam, Helena, Amanda and great-grandmother of Danielle and Josh. Her acts of kindness benefited the lives of countless people and for that we are blessed. Shiva will be observed on Wednesday and Thursday at 2 Peter Cooper Rd. Apt 14C. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Sylvia's memory to: Henry Street Senior Center- Meals on Wheels or the Alzheimer's Association.

The Mets worked out under a clear sky at Citi Field on Sunday morning, the day before their season opener against the Florida Marlins, and Manager Jerry Manuel used the occasion to deal with some lingering questions about his lineup. Manuel's main revelation was that Gary Matthews Jr. would start in center field Monday instead of Angel Pagan and bat sixth. The two players were competing to fill in for Carlos Beltran, who will start the season on the disabled list, and Pagan appeared at times to be the front-runner.

Fans of men's college basketball could watch their team on March Madness on Demand, the N.C.A.A. Web site that streamed the games, and may do so Monday night for the final between Duke and Butler. Duke, which defeated West Virginia on Saturday, above, is in the final for the 10th time. The prevalence of viewers from Kentucky reflects the run of the Kentucky Wildcats, who were knocked out by West Virginia in the round of eight. March Madness on Demand, which is free, offers classic games, an iPhone app and, naturally, a link to the N.C.A.A. store. SHELLY FREIERMAN

ROSENBERG--Stephen Nicholas, M.D.,passed away peacefully on April 4, 2010. Beloved and devoted husband and source of great strength to Barbara. Loving, generous and unfailing father of Jordana and Amanda. Amazing, wonderful father-in-law of Kevin Hall. Wondrous grandfather of Rainer Harley and Leo Edward. Cherished son of the late Ruth and Edward. Caring brother of Barbara Guter. A man of unusual qualities with a gifted mind and caring determination to improve the quality of healthcare. Teacher, novelist, researcher, conversationalist extraordinaire. He will be deeply missed. Services Wednesday April 7, 2010 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

MENAPACE--Ralph C. III, died March 29, 2010 in Philadelphia, PA of heart failure at age 42. A graduate of the University of Rochester and of Suffolk University, Ralph is survived by his mother and stepfather, Nathalie and Marshall Cox, by his brother, Jamie Menapace, and by his sister, brother-in-law and Nephew, Nancy, Jamey and Benjamin Wilson. He lived and worked in Boston, MA, and was a newly elected member of the Board of Governors of the Union Club of Boston. Family will receive friends on Monday, April 5, from 6-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral Service will be held on Tuesday, 10am at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 65 East 89th Street. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Ralph's memory may be made to The Seven and Eight Park Street Foundation, Inc., 8 Park St., Boston, MA.

FRANKEL--Irene of Easthampton, MA.,83, died April 3, 2010. She was predeceased by her husband Dr. Jack Frankel in 2009. Irene leaves her five children; Barbara (Michael Gecewicz) Frankel, Judy (Robert) Wild, Richard (Regan Szczepanowska) Frankel, Carolyn (Mark) Boyes-Watson, and Joan (Marty) Walder, her twelve grandchildren, and her two great-grandchildren. The funeral will be Wednesday, April 7th at 12:00 Noon at Cong. B'nai Israel, Northampton, MA. with burial in B'nai Israel Cemetery. Shiva will be Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday at 131 North Maple St. in Florence, MA. Memorial contributions can be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. The Ascher-Zimmerman Funeral Home is assisting the family.

The garden outside my window is home to an enormous and beautiful tree. I gave it a hug the other day, but the trunk is so huge I could barely get my arms round a quarter of its girth. For now, the branches are bare of leaves, so you can see its form in all its majesty, a triumph of natural architecture. And if you half-close your eyes and dream a little, you can also see its roots, stretching deep beneath the grass, much as its branches and twigs stretch outwards towards the buildings and upwards towards the sky.

When the health bill was being debated in Congress, there was no stronger opponent to it than Senator Tom Coburn, the physician and  Republican from Oklahoma who is known in some circles as Dr. No. In December he said that seniors would die faster because of cuts in Medicare in the version of the health care measure then being considered.

Today's priestly sex abuse story features a South Asian cleric accused of assaulting a teenage girl (and robbing his diocese into the bargain) while serving temporarily in Minnesota. He had already returned to India by the time the allegations surfaced, at which point the Minnesotan bishop wrote to the Vatican suggesting that the priest might need to be removed from ministry. The priest's bishop in India, however, ordered him to undertake a year of prayer in a monastery, rather than seeking to have him defrocked, even as further accusations surfaced in Minnesota, and the county attorney began pursuing extradition. A Vatican spokesman says that the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith recommended laicization, but (per canon law) deferred to the Indian bishop on the matter. However, the documents suggest that at least initially, the C.D.F. only recommended that the priest be monitored and kept away from minors.

"Many pundits have complained about the iPad's inability to support multitasking, and while I can see how that makes it impractical as a tool for work, it's actually an asset for someone who just wants to focus. You can only do one thing at a time on the iPad, and while I'm well aware that e-mail and LOLcats and all kinds of social networking treats are not much further away than a few extra clicks, switching from one app to another feels so definitive - qualitatively different from having multiple windows open on a single screen ... We are often urged to frown on devices that don't prompt us to collaborate on and create - or at the very least comment on - all the amazing old and new things, from news reports to scientific studies, Web comics to video mash-ups, that proliferate online. It's so undemocratic, so anti-DIY. So old paradigm. But here's the thing: Sometimes I don't want to talk. Sometimes what I want is to listen, really listen, to what someone else has to say."

It's in my blood: all the men in my family are dressed-up rowdy Texas boys at heart - my brother, our father and his father are all just a little bit taller than shotguns, and wear suits as tight as barbed wire, sharp edged as bullet holes. The fact that I shattered the family height record doesn't stand for much: I'm 5-foot-9-ish on a really good day. I'm not one for the Napoleon complex, and anyway, there are perks to being, let's say, compact. But there is one big difference between my forebears and me: those bastards had crazy cash, and I'm a broke scribe struggling in this sick city. So how's a bred-for-bespoke fella supposed to pay for fancy garb without two dimes to rub together?

As far as symbols of '80s excess go, it's hard to beat Cindy Crawford (she of big hair and voluptuous - by model standards, anyway - body) and MCM (Mode Creation Munich), the Euro leather goods brand, whose flashy logoed caramel-colored bags gave even Gucci and Louis Vuitton a run for their money. (Did we mention this was the '80s?) The MCM ads were equally flashy, featuring Crawford perched on a pile of suitcases or posing wearing nothing except a giant MCM logo. (If that weren't enough, they were signed "I want my MCM" and "The beginning of a beautiful friendship." Awwww.) And while you might think that such naked consumption went the way of the world economy, you would think wrong. Not only has the brand been on a store opening spree with 15 new Saks Fifth Avenue boutiques and a Beverly Hills Rodeo Drive boutique scheduled for later this year, but it has signed on as a sponsor for New York fashion week. MCM is even recreating its Cindy Crawford campaign, this time around with the model Coco Rocha. Under the circumstances, the images are a bit more modest - Rocha's mane is tamed down, and she's wearing a bustier dress - but the message is not lost.

After more than 160 years in its Berlin home, the Staatsoper Unter den Linden will move to a smaller space for three years while its longtime theater undergoes renovations, The Associated Press reported. At a news conference on Tuesday, the opera company said it was preparing to move west to Berlin's Schiller Theater as the Staatsoper building, which opened on the Unter den Linden boulevard in 1844, begins a $321 million restoration project. Rehearsals in the Schiller Theater, which is contending with its own renovations, are to begin Aug. 19, and the Staatsoper's 2010-2011 season will open there on Oct. 3 with the world premiere of Jens Joneleit's "Metanoia," directed by Christoph Schlingensief. Other conductors who are scheduled to lead the Staatsoper during the season include James Levine and Pierre Boulez. At the news conference, Daniel Barenboim, the music director for the Staatsoper, said, "Moving for three years can be seen as a calamity or as a challenge, and we have decided to see it as the latter." Its artistic director, Jürgen Flimm, said it would be difficult for operagoers to follow the company to its new home, adding: "I hope there will be sufficient curiosity. That's why we are doing so much."

A working environment where colleagues are perpetually stabbing each other in the back and occasionally inflict bodily harm on one another would seem to be de rigeur at "Desperate Housewives," at least when the cameras are rolling. But it is those same conditions that Nicollette Sheridan, a former star of that ABC prime-time serial, says went on behind the scenes at the show, whose producers she is suing for assault and wrongful termination, The Associated Press reported. In her lawsuit, Ms. Sheridan, who played Edie Britt on the first five seasons of "Desperate Housewives," says that the show's creator, Marc Cherry, hit her during an incident in September 2008. When Ms. Sheridan asked Mr. Cherry about a line in the script, he "took her aside and forcefully hit her with his hand across her face and head," the suit said, according to The A.P. When Ms. Sheridan complained to ABC, she says she was ignored and her character was later killed off in retaliation. ABC and Cherry Alley Productions, Mr. Cherry's company, have not yet responded to the suit, which was filed on Monday in Los Angeles County Superior Court.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Monologue | Monday night on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" on NBC: You know, 30,000 people showed up for the annual Easter Egg Roll at the White House today. Or as Fox News calls it, a "socialist free food giveaway."

12:47 p.m. | Updated Yes, everything is starting to bloom (achoo!), which means it is time to start thinking about gardening. South Orange, with Maplewood, will be offering a series of organic vegetable gardening courses to coincide with the launch on April 17 of the South Orange Community Garden, South Orange Village President Doug Newman wrote in an e-mail to The Local. The garden planting season begins May 1. Classes cost $100 for 10 two-hour classes.

Monologue | Monday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Today, President Obama threw out the first pitch at the Washington Nationals' game. Obama took a short windup and threw a high-arcing pitch. Of course, Democrats saw the pitch as moderately close to the middle, while Republicans are calling it "way to the left and possibly socialist."

Monologue | Monday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: President and Mrs. Obama hosted the annual White House Easter Egg Roll today. Dozens of children gathered on the White House lawn to roll eggs toward a finish line while the president cheered them on and Republicans tried to block them.

Newsweek has an Easter-time excerpt from Lisa Miller's forthcoming book "Heaven," which looks at the apparent decline of a belief in the physical resurrection of the dead among contemporary religious believers. The number of Americans who believe in the literal resurrection of Jesus Christ has dropped 10 points in the last decade; only 26 percent of Christians believe that they will have bodies in the next life; and almost a third of Americans (including one in five self-identified Christians) now believe in reincarnation. Pondering these trends, Miller argues that some kind of immortality of the soul is simply "easier to swallow" than a physical resurrection; the latter, she suggests, presents all sorts of "credibility problems" that the "more reasonable" belief in purely spiritual afterlife lacks.

Prepared for the Big One? Not Exactly | As residents on both sides of the Mexican border cleaned up after Sunday's earthquake, the authorities warned that many Californians remained unprepared for a serious quake, and emergency officials said that budget cuts have strained their ability to handle a disaster. The budget challenges faced by firefighters and other first responders have probably affected preparedness, fire officials say, particularly in remote or lightly populated areas that often depend on larger cities or agencies for help in emergencies. Sunday's quake registered 7.2 and centered in a largely unpopulated area of northern Mexico. But a recent study by the California Emergency Management Agency found a majority of the state's households failing to meet recommendations for many basic emergency needs, like stockpiling water (a minimum of three gallons per person), reinforcing their homes and making disaster plans. "We know that there's going to be an earthquake, and we know it's going to be a major natural disaster," said Lou Paulson, president of the California Professional Firefighters and a captain in the Contra Costa County fire protection district. "And I don't want to be one of the people who stands in front of the state of California and says, 'We told you so.' " [The New York Times]

7:26 p.m. | Updated There is more upheaval at the offices of the Republican National Committee as it struggles to recover from fallout from the disclosure that it had paid a $1,946 tab for staffers and contributors to go to a West Hollywood bondage and strip club. Michael Steele, the committee's national chairman, said Monday he had replaced the committee's chief of staff, Ken McKay, with a deputy, Michael Leavitt, as part of an effort to regain control of expenditures of the committee. Mr. Steele has said that he was unaware of the outing, and did not know his committee had reimbursed a Republican consultant who put in for the expense. ''I want to do everything in my power to ensure that the committee uses all its resources in the best possible fashion and for this reason I have appointed Mike Leavitt Chief of Staff,'' Mr. Steele said after Mr. McKay's departure was reported by the Politico Web site.

MacBAIN--Margaret Johanna, Margaret Johanna MacBain, fondly known as Margee, passed away Sunday evening March 28. 2010. Mrs. MacBain, the daughter of Dietrich and Johanna Gristede, was born on October 12, 1912. Her father Dietrich, with his brother Charles, founded Gristede Brothers in 1891. Margaret grew up in New York and graduated from Barnard College. She married her childhood sweetheart Gavin MacBain who later became CEO of Bristol Myers. Mr. MacBain died on March 31, 1978. The MacBains had one daughter Margaret Alison Fay, who passed away on May 12, 2003. Mrs. MacBain was involved in many volunteer organizations, including Trickle Up, the United Nations Hospitality Committee and most particularly UNIFEM, the United Nations Development Fund for Women. She is survived by her grandchildren, Lisa Ann Fay and Keith Saltonstall Fay, her son-in-law, Richard Saltonstall Fay, her nieces, Margaret Mischner and Laura Hansen Sturm, and her nephew, Robert Hansen Sturm. The service will be held on Thursday, April 8, 2010 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name to UNIFEM at 304 East 45th Street, New York, New York 10017 (212 906 6400) would be greatly appreciated.

ORESMAN--Roger B.,died peacefully at home on April 2 surrounded by his wife of 35 years, Janice, and children Sam Fortenbaugh and Cristina Carlson. He was 89 years old. A dignified lawyer with a commanding presence, he was dedicated to his profession as a partner in the firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, where he practiced law for more than fifty years. He was respected for his loyalty, integrity, fairness, and strong sense of ethics. Roger was an avid bicyclist who rode almost daily in Central Park until he was 86. He and Janice often took their bikes to France and toured the countryside, enjoying the wonderful food and wine that inspired him in his own kitchen where he was the master chef. French cuisine in New York also meant La Grenouille where special celebrations were always held. A thoughtful conversationalist, a superb listener, and a valued friend, he delighted in art, The Century Association, and dancing to his favorite selections from The American Songbook. His signature snappy red bow ties reflected his jaunty spirit. A lifelong New Yorker, born on October 26,1920, he only lived outside his beloved city to attend college and to serve in the Navy during World War II. He was a devoted alumnus of The Fieldston School, Harvard College, Harvard Business School, and Columbia Law School, as well as an active supporter of his wife's alma mater, Smith College. He is also survived by his brothers, Donald and Stephen, and their families. A gathering of family and friends will be held at a later date. Contributions may be sent to The Roger B. Oresman 1941 Fund, Harvard Art Museum, 32 Quincy Street, Cambridge, MA 02138.

They were once gleaming, efficient dispensers of comfort food, shiny chrome and beveled milky glass. They were the heralded automat vending machines. Now they lie heaped ingloriously in a dank basement at 131st Street and Broadway. They are among the salvaged items from New York City that Steve Stollman has collected for the past 24 years and has kept in the commercial building at 600 West 131st Street, which is now owned by Columbia University. Columbia is developing the area as part of its Manhattanville campus expansion, and Mr. Stollman has to vacate this month, he said.

He graduated from St. Peter's College, Jersey City in 1954 and received an M.B.A. from The Harvard Business School in 1958. Last week the Lollapalooza festival teased fans by slowly revealing this summer's lineup ''Wheel of Fortune''-style, filling in the name of each band, one letter at a time. First, on Wednesday, came O, followed by R, I and S. By Monday morning the festival's Web page, lollapalooza.com, was filled with clues like SO--I------ --IS--OR--IO-- and S--OO--. It only took a day or two for the online hive to piece it all together and come up with plausible guesses for most of the names, like Social Distortion and Spoon. Now Lollapalooza, which will be held at Grant Park in Chicago from Aug. 6 to 8, has announced the official list of bands, and for the most part the guesswork was correct. The big headliners are Lady Gaga, Green Dayand the reunited Soundgarden, along with the Strokes, Phoenix, MGMT, Hot Chip, Yeasayer, the XX, the New Pornographers and, of course, Social Distortion and Spoon, along with more than 100 others, includingJimmy Cliff, far left, and Gogol Bordello (Eugene Hutz of the band is near left). One notable name not hinted at in the Web game: Erykah Badu, left top, who was just confirmed.

Working parents perpetually agonize that they don't see enough of their children. But a surprising new study finds that mothers and fathers alike are doing a better job than they think, spending far more time with their families than did parents of earlier generations. The study, by two economists at the University of California, San Diego, analyzes a dozen surveys of how Americans say they use their time, taken at different periods from 1965 to 2007. It reports that the amount of child care time spent by parents at all income levels - and especially those with a college education - has risen ''dramatically'' since the mid-1990s. (The findings by the husband-and-wife economist team of Garey Ramey and Valerie A. Ramey appear in a discussion paper presented in March at a Brookings Institution conference in Washington.)

HERSEY--Irwin. Born Irwin Herskowitz, editor and nationally known authority on tribal art died in Manhattan April 2 at age 89. Born September 15, 1920, Mr. Hersey was a graduate of City College and received his masters degree from Columbia University. In World War II he was commissioned and trained as a Japanese linguist and served in Tokyo on General MacArthur's staff. He was recalled to active duty in Korea. He left the army a captain and worked as a business editor for Fairchild and Hearst Publications. In 1957 he became editor of the Journal of the Society of Aeronautics and Astronautics and director of publications of the American Rocket Society. Later he became a consultant to cities wanting to expand business meetings and conventions, worldwide. His knowledge and expertise of African tribal art led to his work as an appraiser and was among the first to try to provide professional standards to the field. From 1978 to 1983 he founded and edited the Primitive Art Newsletter. Objects from his collection are represented in major U.S. museums. He is survived by his wife Marcia.

Laura Marling is the most prominent member of a loose community of young London-based performers, including Johnny Flynn and Mumford and Sons, playing acoustic music inspired by British and American folk traditions. Her debut album, "Alas I Cannot Swim," was recorded when she was 17 and nominated for the 2008 Mercury Prize. This week her follow-up, "I Speak Because I Can"(Astralwerks), was released in the United States. The album has been greeted by a sweep of five-star reviews in British newspapers, earning comparisons to Joni Mitchell's "Court and Spark." In a warm, dusty voice and accompanied by her intuitive guitar playing, Marling sings of being perched between adolescence and womanhood, between the rural England where she was raised and the anxious metropolis she has made her home, between despair and freedom. Marling spoke with The Moment during her recent American tour.

As much as in the general public, military blogs have reacted with passion to the released Wikileaks video of a 2007 Apache attack in Iraq. With more expertise than most viewers -- as well as more empathy, even among those who felt the pilots acted improperly -- they explored a range of issues: Were the people in the video carrying weapons? Is Wikileaks a security risk? Did the military fail in not explaining the video more fully to the media? Should journalists operate so closely to insurgents?

Everybody on the right seems convinced that a value-added tax is on its way. Sometimes this conviction is framed in alarmist, "look what the Democrats are going to do next" terms: See, for instance, this Allahpundit post today, following up on this Charles Krauthammer column from last month. Sometimes it's couched as advice to President Obama, delivered more in sorrow than in anger, explaining what he'll have to do if he wants to pay for the new entitlement he's created: See Glenn Hubbard in The Wall Street Journal, for instance, or Greg Mankiw in the Times. And sometimes it's presented as an idea that the right-of-center should learn to live with, provided that it's part of a grand bargain of some sort: See James Pethokoukis's ideal scenario, or Mankiw's thoughts on the fiscal commission, or Tyler Cowen's provocative "case for a V.A.T."

The photographer Pieter Hugo is no stranger to shocking and peculiar sights. His horrifying, arresting 2007 portrait series "The Hyena & Other Men" showcased Nigerian street performers posing alongside their exotic prey. In "Nollywood," his latest body of work, currently on view at the Yossi Milo Gallery, Hugo once again focuses his camera on performers, only this time his subjects are actors from Nigeria's surprisingly robust film industry, which is apparently the third largest in the world. The photographs don't allude to any films in particular, but rather explore some of the industry's more popular themes, like mysticism, war and the supernatural. The results are often menacing if not grotesque, and they blur the line between documentary and fiction. In one photo, a trio of zombielike children await their next cue, and, in another a well-dressed man proudly stands, camera ready, holding the entrails of a slain ox.

"Raymond vs. Raymond" sold 329,000 copies in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Bieber's album "My World 2.0" (Island), which was No. 1 on last week's chart, fell one spot in its second week out, with 290,000 sales. Is the threat of physical violence required? Or are sniggering and teasing more than enough? How young is too young to be considered a bully? Is excluding a child from a social circle bullying? The Wednesday matinee of the Broadway musical "Jersey Boys" at the August Wilson Theater has been canceled, a spokesman for the show said, in the aftermath of an electrical fire that took place on West 52nd Street on Tuesday. A buildup of carbon monoxide caused the underground fire and a manhole explosion, prompting the evacuation of several buildings in the area and causing Tuesday night's performance of "Jersey Boys" to be canceled. According to a statement from the spokesman, the "Jersey Boys" producers were notified by authorities that it would not be possible to have a performance on Wednesday afternoon. "The problem should be solved this afternoon to make sure there is a performance tonight," the statement said. Exchanges for the  matinee performance can be arranged at the point of purchase.

If you divide the time I spend on YouTube into a pie chart, the two largest slices would represent Formula One videos and videos of guitar theatrics. At long last, the twain have met. In the above video (via 0-60mag.com), a man replicates a Ferrari F10 engine with his Gibson Explorer guitar. And he doesn't just bust out a few "revs." He actually performs a lap -- matching the gear changes with a video of Fernando Alonso doing a lap in his Ferrari. It might not be as impressive as the Renault team playing "God Save the Queen" or "We Are the Champions" on its Formula One engine, but it's pretty close.

The early chapters of Brian Lutz's ''Knoll: A Modernist Universe'' (Rizzoli) read like a portrait of the Greatest Generation, only with really cool furniture. Hans Knoll, an entrepreneur from a well-known German furniture-manufacturing family, and Florence Schust, an architect whose education brought her in contact with greats like Eliel Saarinen and Mies van der Rohe, married in 1946 and quickly turned Hans's small company into a design powerhouse. They recruited people like Harry Bertoia and Eero Saarinen to design groundbreaking furniture, reintroduced classics like Mies's Barcelona chair and started the Knoll Planning Unit, which under Florence's direction revolutionized office interiors. Hans died in a car accident in 1955, but Florence stayed for another 10 years. Knoll after the Knolls became a more corporate place, concentrating heavily on office systems but still caring enough about furniture to commission pieces from a who's who of design and architecture.

Super groups: They worked for Blind Faith, the Avengers, Them Crooked Vultures and the 1992 men's United States Olympic basketball team, so why not Tom Clancy? On Wednesday, Penguin Group said it would publish a new thriller by Mr. Clancy that would bring together many of his best-known characters from his last-quarter century of literary output. The new novel, called "Dead Or Alive" and written with his frequent collaborator Grant Blackwood, will feature the characters Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst-turned-American president; his son and fellow analyst, Jack Ryan Jr.; the C.I.A. operative John Clark; his apprentice, Ding Chavez; and the agency executive Mary Pat Foley. In a statement, Penguin said the novel will pit them against "The Emir, a sadistic killer who has masterminded the most vicious terrorist attacks on the West" and who "has eluded capture by the world's armed forces and law enforcement agencies." "Dead Or Alive" will be released by the G. P. Putnam's Sons imprint of Penguin on Dec. 7.

A building in Hunts Point in the Bronx that houses four public schools and 1,500 students was evacuated around 8:20 Wednesday morning after elevated levels of carbon monoxide were detected, fire officials said. The building, at 730 Bryant Avenue, is home to Public School 168, the Hyde Leadership Charter School, the Vida Bogart School for All Children and Hunts Point School. No injuries were reported.

Overview | What do you know about psychiatric disorders that cause people to obsess over a physical feature? How can a community of parents, peers, teachers, doctors and psychiatric professionals best help and support someone with one of these disorders? In this lesson, students reflect on stories of teenagers with body dysmorphic disorder, or B.D.D., and eating disorders. By drawing and discussing support webs around each story, groups investigate the disorders from the perspectives of the individual affected and the people in their lives.

For the past 25 years, Bob Garfield has written the AdReview column for Advertising Age, but on Monday he filed for the last time. AdReview was a witty and sometimes withering deconstruction of all manner of advertising campaigns that had many fans. Half-Trillion-Dollar Shortfall in State Pension Funds | An independent analysis of California's three big pension funds has found a hidden shortfall of more than half a trillion dollars, several times the amount reported by the funds and more than six times the value of the state's outstanding bonds. The analysis was commissioned by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who has been pressing the State Legislature to focus on the rising cost of public pensions. Graduate students identified the shortfall in the three funds serving more than 2.6 million people - the state-run employees' pension fund, known as Calpers; a second large fund for teachers, known as Calstrs; and the University of California Retirement System. The researchers offered recommendations for closing the gap, including revamping the benefit structure. [The New York Times]

This spring at the Prado Museum (museodelprado.es), an exhibition pays homage to that institution's - and perhaps Spain's - most treasured painting, "Las Meninas" (1656) by Velázquez. In what is likely to be a true once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has lent John Singer Sargent's famous painting "The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit" (1882), which many art historians call the "American Meninas" to be displayed next to the Velázquez painting. The loan is part of the Prado's series of "Invited Work" exhibitions, which bring individual works of special importance or resonance to the museum, to be seen in proximity to the Prado's collection.

On a recent Monday afternoon in the East Village, the 32-year-old upstart photographer Todd Selby - more commonly known as the Selby - was entertaining a guest in his modest ground-floor studio. One of the two monitors on which he creates his teeming online gallery, The Selby Is in Your Place, was tuned to a Web site called Unhappy Hipsters. The idea behind the site - which that week was reaching something of a viral mass - is pretty straightforward: cut and paste a selection of those placid, sparsely populated house shots from magazines like Dwell and run the snarkiest captions imaginable beneath them. "He'd become a caricature of what it meant to be a young, monied follower" is a typical entry. "Oh, my God," Selby said, scrolling through the site with what appeared to be a mixture of astonishment and appreciation, as if meeting a fellow traveler. After all, Selby's vérité approach to photographing personal spaces is precisely in tune with the urge to skewer those magazines that celebrate sleek minimalism while scorning clutter like the long-suffering mother of a teenage son.

MOSCOW -- The second female suicide bomber in the attacks on the Moscow subway system last week was a 28-year-old teacher from a predominantly Muslim region of southern Russia who was married to an extremist leader, officials said on Tuesday. The woman, Maryam Sharipova, was first identified by her father, and genetic tests confirmed that she carried out the attack during the morning rush on March 29. Ms. Sharipova was from the Dagestan region, in the Caucasus Mountains of southern Russia, as was the other suicide bomber,Dzhanet Abdullayeva, a 17-year-old woman whose name was released last Friday.

SIBARIUM--John M.,89, died March 30, 2010. He led a colorful career as an engineer, educator, editor and consultant, and was a leading advocate of educational programs for the heating and cooling industry, serving as Chairman of the National Old Timers Association of the Energy Industry. As technical editor for Fuel Oil News, Master Plumber & Heating Contractor, The Heating Merchandiser and publisher of Oil Heating & Air Conditioning Age magazines, his industry editorials and technical articles set patterns leading the industry into new directions. A long time resident of Long Island, Mr. Sibarium served as a member of the State University of New York Advisory Council and Chairman of the Heating & Cooling Industry Commission. In addition, he held the positions of Chairman of the Advisory Council of the Vocational Education & Extension Board of Nassau County (VEEB), Vocational Education and Fire Service and was a member of the Advisory Engineering Conferences of Hofstra University's Plant Management Conferences. He is survived by his wife Margaret, sons Alan and Michael, daughters Karen James and Janet Sibarium, step-son Michael Kiernan, sister Antoinette Herold, and several grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Calling hours: Friday, April 9 from 5-8pm with a Masonic service at 7:30pm; funeral Saturday, April 10 at 10am. Thomas A. Glynn & Son Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Ave., Rockville Center, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: The National Shrine HQS, Children's Burn Program, 2900 Rocky Point Drive, Tampa, FL 33607.

MAGUIRE--Maureen Reidy, age 76, died peacefully on April 6th after a long battle with cancer. Beloved wife of Frank J. Maguire. Assistant Professor of English at Western Connecticut State University. Devoted mother to Shevaun, Barrett, Bevin, and Leslie, grandmother of nine, sister to Sheila and Colleen. BA from Albertus Magnus College; MA and Doctorate from New York University, she was a teacher and curriculum developer with the NYC schools for 25 years. Memorial contributions: The Wilton Woman's Club. Calling hours: Wednesday, April 7 from 3-5pm and from 7-9pm at Bouton Funeral Home, Georgetown, CT. Christian burial: Thursday, April 8th at 10:30am in Our Lady of Fatima, Wilton, CT.

OESTREICHER--Ann. Died April 4th at the age of 83. She was born and spent her formative years in Chicago, Illinois. Later, she moved to California, where she made the acquaintance of President Nixon and his family. Quickly forming a close bond, she remained a steadfast and supportive friend. Throughout her life, Ann devoted both her time and resources to philanthropical endeavors. Her foundation enabled her to support many humanitarian causes. A visitation will take place at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 6-9pm. Funeral services will be held at Mary Manning Walsh, 1339 York Avenue, on Thursday at 11am.

MacBAIN--Margaret Johanna, Margaret Johanna MacBain, fondly known as Margee, passed away Sunday evening March 28. 2010. Mrs. MacBain, the daughter of Dietrich and Johanna Gristede, was born on October 12, 1912. Her father Dietrich, with his brother Charles, founded Gristede Brothers in 1891. Margaret grew up in New York and graduated from Barnard College. She married her childhood sweetheart Gavin MacBain who later became CEO of Bristol Myers. Mr. MacBain died on March 31, 1978. The MacBains had one daughter Margaret Alison Fay, who passed away on May 12, 2003. Mrs. MacBain was involved in many volunteer organizations, including Trickle Up, the United Nations Hospitality Committee and most particularly UNIFEM, the United Nations Development Fund for Women. She is survived by her grandchildren, Lisa Ann Fay and Keith Saltonstall Fay, her son-in-law, Richard Saltonstall Fay, her nieces, Margaret Mischner and Linda Hansen Sturm, and her nephew, Robert Hansen Sturm. Because of a $45 million budget gap, the New York City Housing Authority may have to revoke rental-assistance vouchers from more than 10,000 low-income tenants, a drastic move that could cause families to lose their apartments. The federal government gave the housing authority less money for the voucher program, known as Section 8, than the authority expected. But the authority made matters worse by continuing to issue new vouchers until December, eight months after the government warned it to stop doing so because the program was likely to run a deficit.

RAIFORD--Louis G. 82, of Las Vegas, passed away April 1, 2010. He was born March 16, 1928, in New York City, and retired in 1990 as the chief of police for the City of New York. He was a member of N.O.B.L.E. (National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives), NYPD Guardians Association, Knights of the Round Table, The Honor Legion and a Lifetime member of the NAACP. Louis was a Palmer Memorial Institute Alumni and John Jay College of Criminal Justice Alumni. He will be forever loved and remembered by wife, Elois B. Raiford; his children, grandchildren and great-granchild. Services will be 11:45am Thursday, April 8, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York.

In the rush this January to finish New York State's application in a competition for federal education grants, much of the spotlight fell on the Legislature, as lawmakers wrangled over a bill that would increase the number of charter schools permitted in the state. New York did not win the first round of the competition, called Race to the Top, but the failure to increase the number of charter schools was not the only reason. A close review of the state's application, and of the judges' comments, reveals a number of ill-fated moves.

Copake Country Club six time golf club champ. Long resident of New Hyde Park, NY, Lenox, MA, and Fountains of Lake Worth, FL. DRUCK--Judith, a beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother died on April 3rd, after a life of almost 97 years. She was a woman of great courage, love, determination, and independence. She is survived by her children, Susan Salzhauer and Stephen Druck, her eight grandchildren, and her many great-grandchildren. She loved them all, as well as her husband Maurice who she continued to love every day of her life. GG, as she was fondly named by great-grandchildren, was an inspiration for generations of her family, and for many blessed to know her. May her memory continue to be a source of blessing, courage, and inspiration. Funeral will be graveside for family on Wednesday. For Shiva information call: 212-334-8710.

SCHNEIDER--Richard Harlan "Rick", passed peacefully on April 2, 2010, at the young age of 54 from complications of brain cancer. Beloved husband of Tami, nee Barcoff; loving father of Brady, Casey and Bumpy; proud son of Dolores and the late Harold N. Schneider; dear brother of Gregg and wife Kristy, dear brother of Linda and husband Brian Singer; loving uncle to Dustin, Andy, Margo, Brooks, Gabbi, Brett, Will and Bobby; cherished son-in-law to Helene Barcoff, Jeff Arno and the late Bert Barcoff; giving brother-in-law to Stacey, nee Barcoff, and Chuck Butler. Rick graduated with honors from the University of Illinois and Harvard Law School. Beginning his law career at Kirkland & Ellis in Chicago and Rosenfeld, Meyer & Sussman in Los Angeles, Rick later moved to New York to launch his financial career starting off at Paine Webber. Rick retired in December 2008 as a Managing Director at Highbridge Capital. As a noted philanthropist, Rick was on the board of the Alzheimer's Association NYC Chapter, the Riverside Park Fund and supported numerous other charities that were close to his heart. Rick lived his life to the fullest. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in memory of Rick to the MSKCC Brain Tumor Center, c/o Katie Kotkins, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, NYC 10017.

BANGKOK -- Convoys of anti-government protesters coursed through Bangkok on Tuesday afternoon while thousands more demonstrators remained in the commercial heart of the city, where they continued to defy government orders to disperse. Crowds of protesters steadily pushed back lines of unarmed soldiers in an attempt to make their way into the important commercial and tourist district of Sukhumvit in central Bangkok. It was nearly a festive atmosphere, with the protesters, known as red shirts, hugging and shaking hands with smiling soldiers.

10 P.M. (13, 49) UNMISTAKEN CHILD (2009) In 2001 Geshe Lama Konchog, a revered Tibetan master, died at 84 after decades of isolated meditation in a mountain cave. Not long after, the Dalai Lama instructed Tenzin Zopa, a disciple of Konchog since the age of 7, to search for his reincarnation in the form of a young boy. For four years Mr. Zopa -- traveling the high country by foot, mule and helicopter, and guided by astrology, dreams and the direction of the smoke from the pyre at Lama Konchog's cremation -- looked for small children with special characteristics and performed ritualistic tests. He then made his determination, above, and awaited the Dalai Lama's decision. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this documentary from Nati Baratz ''inevitably leads you to consider the material world and to contemplate the balance in your own life between physical gratification and spirituality.'' He continued: ''The rugged landscape, in which mist filters through craggy cliffs, and wild flowers seem to dance in the mountain meadows, suggests that religion and geography are profoundly intertwined.'' The film, presented by ''Independent Lens,'' is in English, Tibetan, Nepalese and Hindi, with English subtitles. 8 P.M. (Fox) HUMAN TARGET Chance (Mark Valley) guards a British princess (Christina Cole) whose love for a commoner has made her the target of an assassination plot.

PACKARD--Mary Ellen Winship Githler born June 12, 1923 to Walter Boit and Priscilla (Doane) Winship in Wakefield, MA. Died April 5th, 2010. Services will be held at The Christ Episcopal Church, 4030 Manatee Avenue West in Bradenton on Friday at 2pm. She was first married to the late Frederick Joseph Githler of Corning, NY (1944) then widowed by the recent passing of Richard Packard. "Mimi" is survived by three children: Frederick J. Githler of Denver, Priscilla W. Githler, and Charles Edward Githler, daughter-in-law Kim Githler of Sarasota, her sister Stephanie Balcke of Orleans MA, her sister-in-law Joan Winship and nephew Walter Winship both of Sarasota and four grandchildren: Charles Githler of Sarasota, Joe Githler of Oregon, Cassie McDonald of Arlington, MA and Taylor Yunis of New York City. She graduated from Rogers Hall and then Smith College in 1944 when she married Frederick and moved to Princeton, NJ where she resided for 35 years; spending her summers in Cape Cod (where she will be interred). In Longboat Key and Bradenton, since 1975, she enjoyed travel, oil painting, bridge, the theater-- was active in The Smith Club of Sarasota-- and had a wide circle of friends. Mimi briefly taught Latin, was known for her sense of humor and as a witty raconteur. Jennings Funeral Home of Sarasota is handling services.

The Yankees paid around $150 million last season in luxury taxes and revenue sharing, the majority of it on the latter. When other teams complain about the Yankees' high payroll, it can strike a nerve with club officials. The Milwaukee Brewers' owner, Mark Attanasio, told USA Today on Monday that while he is struggling to re-sign the slugger Prince Fielder, the Yankees' infield makes more than the entire Brewers team. It prompted the Yankees' president, Randy Levine, to tell ESPN New York that Attanasio, his friend, should stop whining.

The Supreme Court's ruling recently that lawyers have a duty to warn their noncitizen clients about the potentially disastrous immigration consequences of pleading guilty to a criminal charge seemed so sensible that it left me wondering why a question with such an obvious answer needed to be debated by the Supreme Court in the first place. Surely if the Sixth Amendment's guarantee of effective assistance of counsel means anything, it means that lawyers must advise their clients that admitting to even a minor offense can earn a noncitizen a quick one-way ticket into what immigration law delicately calls "removal proceedings."

The exhibit, Henri Cartier-Bresson: The Modern Century, opening on Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, is the first major American retrospective of his work in 30 years. While many city neighborhoods have been turned into sanitized and silenced versions of themselves, East Harlem is boisterous and pulses with energy. Street art is everywhere: on the sides of buildings, on trash in abandoned lots, among transformed town houses and around new restaurants. On April 6, two professors from Seton Hall University, Dr. Peggy Brady-Amoon and Dr. Eunyoung Kim, Catherine Epstein and I, met to talk about Jeffrey Jensen Arnett's portrait of "emerging adulthood", in his book "Emerging Adulthood: The Winding Road from Late Teens through the Twenties." The four of us came from different experiences and professional backgrounds. It was particularly fascinating to hear the perspectives from two SHU experts in the college adjustment process: Peggy's extensive experience before teaching at Seton Hall University as an on-campus college counselor and Eunyoung's interest and research in the challenges and opportunities facing immigrant populations. The production  will also star Boyd Gaines and Brenda Wehle. Mr. Steggert, who is coming off the recent production of "Yank!" at York Theater Company and was featured in the Broadway revival of "Ragtime," will play Pete, a boarding school student who travels to New York and meets the actress Katharine Cornell (Ms. Burton, of "The Constant Wife" and "The Elephant Man"). Mr. Gaines ("Gypsy," "Journey's End") will play Cornell's husband, the director Guthrie McClintic, and Ms. Wehle ("Pygmalion," "Come Back, Little Sheba") will play her manager, Gert Macy. The play, which stems from Mr. Gurney's real-life encounter with Cornell at a 1948 production of "Antony and Cleopatra," will be directed by Mark Lamos. Previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater are scheduled to begin on June 1, with an opening night of June 24.

The closest thing I've found is the Commission to Inquire Into Child Abuse's report on Ireland's religious-run reform schools, which solicited claims of abuse from Irish-born adults educated in those schools between 1914 and 1999. It's a sweltering August morning in Midtown Manhattan, and the loading dock foreman is cursing me for my terrible truck-parking skills. Yesterday I was here meeting my client, wearing a suit and tie and looking slick. Today I got up at 4 a.m. to drive the truck and deliver the job. Yesterday I went in the front door; today I take the freight elevator. Did I get demoted overnight? No, I'm the boss. I need this delivery to go smoothly, and the recession has thinned my work force, so here I am -- parking the truck.

By age 12, I had a rote reply for grown-ups' quizzical looks when they heard I went to a Waldorf school: "It's based on the ideas of Rudolf Steiner." Blank stare. "He was an Austrian philosopher who believed in teaching the whole student - mind, body and soul." Luckily no one ever asked me to elaborate, because I'd have been at a loss for words - except to say that we students got to do lots of drawing and painting, which I loved, but we couldn't skip eurythmy class (yuck). any serious discussions of pedagogic method and what Steiner called his "spiritual science," anthroposophy, took place out of earshot in the teachers' room. My only mental picture of Steiner (1861-1925) came from a dim black and white photo showing a stern mouth and X-ray eyes that made me glad this guy wasn't our headmaster. Oh, well, I reasoned, as soon as I enter the real world after graduation, it's Goodbye, Dr. Steiner.

KARLOVY VARY, CZECH REPUBLIC -- As President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and President Barack Obama prepare to arrive in Prague on Thursday to sign a landmark arms control treaty, Marcela Balounova, like many Czechs, remains haunted by her memories of 1968, when nearly one million Warsaw Pact troops invaded Czechoslovakia, ushering in a period of political repression. ''The Russians invaded us before and they are invading us again,'' Ms. Balounova, 50, said from her art gallery in this picturesque spa town, where Peter the Great first came for a treatment in 1711 and which has since become so popular with Russians that most signs offering luxury products and services -- from million-euro villas to colonic irrigation -- are in Russian. ''I still remember crying when the Russians came here. And now here we are more than 40 years later and this place has become a Little Moscow.''

If you thought you saw a familiar, nattily attired Englishman poking around Lincoln Center in recent days, you might well have spotted Sting, right, inspecting the Metropolitan Opera as he prepares to perform there as part of an orchestra tour this summer. On July 13 and 14, Sting, the Police man and solo pop star, will perform at the Met with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra of London, it was announced on Wednesday. While Sting said, in a telephone interview, that he was ''stoked'' for the full orchestra tour, which begins June 2 in Vancouver, British Columbia, his dates at the Met have him feeling ''both excited and anxious.'' ''I think one needs to take this seriously,'' Sting said. ''It's quite something to be sitting in front of the Royal Philharmonic on the Met stage. I think I'm suitably anxious.'' Sting played orchestral concerts with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in May 2009 and the Philadelphia Orchestra in January.

As it was getting started in 2008, the New Orleans nonprofit 504ward wanted to make a big splash while advancing its primary goal: to retain or draw talented young professionals and their businesses to New Orleans, a city still recovering from Hurricane Katrina. ''Moving to New Orleans is an adventure for people,'' explained the nonprofit's founder, Jessica White. ''It is not a standard move like going to D.C. or San Francisco. It is a wild card in that sense. The people we attract are by their nature entrepreneurial. Fifty-five percent of the 23- to 35-year-olds we surveyed here said they considered themselves somewhat to very entrepreneurial. But to keep the talent here, we need to make sure they have a great experience.''

Richard Jenrette, a retired Wall Street financier, bought Millford Plantation in Pinewood, S.C. -- an antebellum house he calls the ''Taj Mahal of my dreams'' -- in 1992. He already owned five other grand old homes, but Millford, he said, was ''the finest example of pre-Civil War Greek Revival architecture in America.'' A National Historic Landmark, it was built in 1841 by Susan and John Laurence Manning as a smaller version of the Charleston Hotel (demolished in 1960). It retains much of its original interior: 16-foot ceilings, floor-to-ceiling windows, a cylindrical chambered circular stairway, elaborate woodwork and plasterwork with classical Greek and Roman motifs and Duncan Phyfe furniture.

Out of the blue a couple of weeks ago, I got a call from a headhunter on my mobile phone. I happened to be walking across a parking lot at the time. I glanced over my shoulder -- like a refugee in the witness-protection program -- and wondered, ''How did they find me?'' The truth is, my professional background includes more than one successful stint in corporate America. I am a loyal, hard-working, high-achiever type who plays well with others. I'm the kind of employee who is continually awarded both recognition and additional responsibilities. My M.B.A. usually counts for something, as do a list of references who are willing to sing my praises. My husband admits that he hated working with me when we were in wireless telecommunications together. He claims I was the quintessential teacher's pet. I'm not a corporate wonk, but I can play that role when I have to.

The Jets courted the free agent defensive end Jason Taylor, who played for Miami last season, showing off their new stadium and offering a tempting role Wednesday. The Jets, who ranked first in the N.F.L. in total defense last season but registered a mediocre 32 sacks, would use Taylor, 35, strictly in a pass-rushing role, an attractive bargaining chip. This off-season, the Jets have added cornerback Antonio Cromartie, replaced safety Kerry Rhodes with Brodney Pool and made Taylor their top free-agent priority. Should he land in New York, the Jets could trade linebacker Bryan Thomas and further reduce linebacker Vernon Gholston's role. The Jets also hosted Mark Brunell, the backup quarterback in New Orleans last season. For more, go tonytimes.com/fifthdown.

9 P.M. (TV One) LISARAYE: THE REAL McCOY In 2006 LisaRaye McCoy (above right, with her daughter, Kai), went from American actress (she portrayed Neessee James on the CW sitcom ''All of Us'') to first lady when she married Michael Misick, the premier of the Turks and Caicos Islands. Suddenly her life was filled with mansions, private jets, servants and curtsies before the queen of England. And then -- after accusations that her husband was unfaithful, followed by a divorce -- it wasn't. This new reality series follows Ms. McCoy as she tries to re-establish her acting career and get her life back on track with assistance from 19-year-old Kai; her assistant, Quincy; and celebrities like Jamie Foxx, the Rev. Al Sharpton, Laila Ali, Tony Rock and Lil Jon. The reinvention begins as Ms. McCoy prepares to attend a fashion show and continues at 9:30 as she gets ready to walk the runway. In between, she sleuths for information on Kai's new boyfriend. 8 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSELJohn Stossel explores libertarian beliefs about welfare, war, abortion, gay marriage and other issues. The political satirist P. J. O'Rourke; the Harvard economist Jeffrey Miron; and the feminist Wendy McElroy weigh in.

WASHINGTON -- Federal air marshals confronted a passenger who had apparently lighted a cigarette in an airline lavatory on Wednesday night, leading Norad to scramble two fighter jets and a phalanx of law enforcement officials to meet the plane, United Flight 663, when it landed at Denver International Airport. But there was no immediate indication of terrorism. A federal official speaking on condition that he not be identified by name said that the passenger had gone to the bathroom to smoke a cigarette, claimed he had diplomatic immunity and made sarcastic comments that the marshals took as a threat.

COOK--William D.,"Cookie", 78, of Woodstock and Brooklyn, died April 5. For more than three decades he served New York Schools as teacher and conflict-mediator. Paraphrasing Ted Kennedy, Bill was a decent man who saw wrong and tried to right it, saw suffering and tried to heal it-sending forth ripples of hope. During his life he sent out lots of ripples. My sons join me and sending love and sympathy to his wife, Shelly, daughters, Sara and Jenny, grandchildren, Isabel and Jesse-and to John, Bob, family and friends. May he rest with the dignity and peace he brought to so many. Erwin Frankel gfiltefish@aol.com

April 15 is drawing closer, and somehow it doesn't seem as scary as usual -- at least not to those of us who weren't very profitable last year. But if you're planning to make money this year, you might want to think ahead. As a small business recuperates, it sucks up money -- to finance new hires, training, receivables, inventory, equipment, real estate and other things that support growth. And then you have to pay taxes. It is very easy for a business to end up with no cash left in the pot on April 15 to pay those taxes.

Southfork. That was the first name I had in mind way back when I was searching for space. I was surprised that no restaurant had gobbled up that easy play on words since the Hamptons are located on the South Fork of Long Island and the name lends itself naturally to various logos. Southfork. Sweet and simple. Then I consulted my two newest and dearest friends, Google and Go Daddy. What's a restaurant without a discrete identity and a findable Web site? Google spit out South Forks as if it were an unhinged dishwasher. In Texas, Minnesota, Indiana, Colorado, and Long Island. From South Fork Boats in Arizona to Southfork Angus in Australia. Nike, which stood by Tiger Woods when AT&T and Accenture dropped him, began running a new 30-second commercial Wednesday that uses the recorded voice of his father, Earl, who died in 2006. In the commercial, Woods looks at the camera with a dour, unchanging expression as his father's resurrected voice says: ''Tiger, I am more prone to be inquisitive, to promote discussion. I want to find out what your thinking was. I want to find out what your feelings are. And did you learn anything?''

AROUND the time she began working as special projects editor for House & Garden in 2003, Susanna Salk noticed that children's rooms were being featured in shelter magazines, something that would have been almost unthinkable a decade earlier. ''Before, the priority was always a living room, a bedroom, a kitchen space, a garden and a portrait of the family,'' Ms. Salk said, explaining that she believes the shift took place in part because more adults with children had ''lots of disposable income.''

AMINOFF--Jeffrey H.,60, on April 5, 2010 after a long and valiant struggle with MS. A man of resolute principle, steadfast loyalty, and exceptional generosity, who persevered through adversity with great courage and a gentle wit. The son of the late Michael and Luba Aminoff, he is survived by his wife, Kathleen M. Faccini, his brothers, Melvin and Cary, his sisters-in-law Loretta, Ruth, and Linda, his nieces and nephew, and his special friend, Murphy. A graduate of Tulane Law School and the Masters Program in Tax at New York University Law School, he was a partner of the law firm of McCarter & English until illness interfered. Yet throughout it all he never complained about his fate and he continued to live his life to the fullest. We shall all miss him.

Some of you may remember "The Story of Fashion," a three-part series that was first shown in 1987 on the A&E channel and was narrated by Karl Lagerfeld. The films have been reissued as a DVD set, and they are still pretty interesting and informative, if dated in places. Of course, the designers look astonishingly young. Mr. Lagerfeld, without his many rings, discusses everything from French court clothes to Mary Quant, and there are some fascinating bits with people such as the late illustrator Antonio Lopez. A culinary group in Italy called Home Food seeks out exceptional home cooks, puts them through a training course and dubs them Cesarinas -- little Caesars, emperors of the kitchen.  Then a few times a month, the Cesarinas open their homes to paying guests.  Matt Gross, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, grabs a fork and dives in.
Come Monday, Microsoft will need to apply some of its most sophisticated public relations and marketing maneuvers.

Early this week the Aspen Music Festival and School released its schedule of programs for the summer. It should have included a blue pencil. The festival announced on Friday that David Zinman, its music director since 1997 and the director of the American Academy of Conducting at Aspen, which he founded in 2000, had resigned effective immediately.
A giant marketer is again sponsoring a campaign for one of its mainstream food brands that is aimed at gay and lesbian consumers.

Underneath the 40-block strip of land between Queens and Manhattan known as Roosevelt Island is a complex system of pneumatic tubes that connects the island's 12,000 or so residents. But it's not mail that's hurtling through them at at 30 miles an hour. It's garbage. Vacuum cleaners, Christmas trees and last night's unfinished dinner have all passed through the intestines of the Automated Vacuum Assisted Collections facility, a pneumatic trash system built in 1975 that seems forever ahead of its time.

ESPN's heavily promoted live airing of Tiger Woods's first tee shot at the Masters Thursday at 1:42 p.m. Eastern generated a substantially higher rating for "SportsCenter" than it usually gets in that part of the afternoon.
