GOLDBERG--Arthur. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Arthur Goldberg. Our heartfelt condolences to Judy Goldberg and family. Alan Lucas, Rabbi Louis Naviasky, President

Philadelphia Eagles fans had a love-hate relationship with quarterback Donovan McNabb since the day he was drafted. Yes, there was a little love mixed with the hate. Here is a look back at the highs and lows of McNabb's career and his stormy relationship with Philly's fickle fans. APRIL 17, 1999 The Eagles draft McNabb. A horde of Eagles fans known as the Dirty 30 boo and act obnoxiously when the pick is announced. Future historians will confuse this with the start of the Tea Party movement.

GOLDBERG--Arthur Irwin, 77 years, died April 9, 2010. Beloved husband of Judith, to whom he proposed marriage one afternoon by the sea in 1962. Beloved father of Jacob, Daniel and Adam, father-in-law of Chari, Christine and Monica, grandfather of Louis, Hannah, Emma, Lucy, Josiah and Sadie. Devoted son of the late Jacob and Sadie Goldberg. Cherished brother of Lila Eisner. Adored uncle and great-uncle. Arthur grew up in Richmond Hill, NY and studied at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy before entering the Navy and serving as an officer on the USS New Jersey; he would continue to serve in the Navy Reserve for many years. After the Navy, Arthur attended New York University School of Law, and enjoyed a long and distinguished career at the bar. He was a founding partner of the firm Jacobson, Goldberg & Kulb of Garden City, NY. He served as the elected Justice of the Village of East Hills, NY for 38 years, and was a former President of the county Magistrates Association. Arthur served Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn, NY in many roles over many years, including President. Arthur was a long-time member and a former Chairman of the Council of Overseers of his undergraduate alma mater, and served as a member of the Board of Trustees of Long Island University. He was awarded an honorary doctorate in appreciation of his sustained commitment and wise counsel. Above all this, Arthur loved his family. His life was one of intelligence, integrity, compassion and beneficence. His memory shall be a blessing for his wife, his sons, his sister and their families. Services will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, April 11 at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, NY.

There is perhaps no better symbol of the Southern California lifestyle than the heat lamp, that industrial, propane-fueled pillar that magically appears on every restaurant terrace the moment the mercury dips below 70. As ubiquitous as cellphone towers -- and as grimly utilitarian -- the lamps are a not so subtle reminder that even L.A. is prone to the change of seasons. Sort of, anyway. Kindle Living aims to give the heat lamp an image makeover by reimagining it as an actual lamp. The three models currently in production come complete with pleated shades, curvaceous bases (to hide unsightly propane tanks) and an array of colors, like black -- perfect for that post-Oscar bash -- or pale pink for a poolside sweet 16. And true to form, the Kindle Glow, with its translucent shell, offers not just warmth but mood lighting. Now if only it provided cellphone reception. ALIX BROWNE

Is there anyone alive not conflicted about getting and spending? Even at the height of the bubble, when Americans wallowed in an orgy of things, there were always people like Kate Bingaman-Burt, for whom the daily acquisition of stuff resulted in a pang or two. ''Obsessive Consumption'' (Princeton Architectural Press) is her sweet act of ontrition. A graphic design professor from Portland, Ore., Bingaman-Burt drew three years of everyday commerce, from pizza to toothpaste, ballet slippers, zippers, tweezers, DVDs, moving boxes, airline tickets, fly swatters, diet soda, etc. She annotates where necessary -- ''Serta Mattress, Queen $500 No More Futon for Us!'' -- and we're also treated to credit card bills, recreated in her own innocent hand, which somehow (maybe not for her) takes the sting out of owing MasterCard $5,522.62. Read from beginning to end, ''Obsessive Consumption'' reveals a happy (if somewhat guilty) grasshopper who likes a good bargain as much as she likes a good burrito. Bingaman-Burt engages in the same name-brand culture as the rest of us, but in her life, at least, it's art. ANDY PORT

RIBAKOFF--Eugene J. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the tremendous loss of our esteemed friend and former President and Board Chairman, Eugene J. Ribakoff. An unparalleled leader in the JDC family, Gene's generosity, invaluable wisdom, and boundless dedication was an inspiration to both the lay and professional leadership of JDC. A true ambassador for the organization, he traveled the world visiting JDC programs and was passionately involved in the full scope of JDC services in more than 70 countries. He served with vigor as Chair of the JDC's Israel Committee, Central and Eastern Europe Committee, and the Transmigrant Committee, where he personally oversaw with great devotion the emigration of hundreds of thousands of Jews from the former Soviet Union and elsewhere. A philanthropist of the first order, Gene's unquenchable desire to help others was evident in his leadership roles at other organizations, including World ORT, the United Way of Palm Beach County, the Jewish Federations of both Palm Beach and Worcester, the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Greater Boston, the Boston Museum of Science, Massachusetts General, and Brandeis University. A towering figure in the business community, he built Automotive Management, Inc. and HARR Motor Companies, among others. Funeral services will be held on Sunday April 11th at 4pm at Temple Emanu-El, 190 North County Rd., Palm Beach, FL. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Stephanie; his son and JDC Board Member Charles and his wife, Patty; his daughter and JDC Board Member Betsy and her husband, Richard; and to his seven grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Irving A. Smokler President Judge Ellen M. Heller Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager Chief Executive Officer

CONNOR--Robert E.,age 76, died on Thursday, April 8, 2010 at Calvary Hospital in New York. Born in Manchester NH, Mr. Connor was the son of the late US District Judge Aloysius J. Connor and Beatrice Connor. He graduated from Georgetown University in 1956. His career in New York spanned three decades including several years as a Sr. Vice President of Advertising and Public Relations at Smith Barney. After retirement in 1996 he became a Trustee/Director for Allianz/Pimco Mutual Funds. He leaves his wife Tyrrell Cohalan Connor of Vero Beach, FL, and three children; Robert Jr. of NYC, Daniel of Shelton CT and Katherine of Stamford CT; a brother, James A. Connor of Hampton NH, two sisters, Hannah Tyson of Santa Fe NM, and Ellen Connor-Stahl of Hollis NH. A memorial mass will be held at 10:30 am, Wednesday April 14th, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th and Lexington, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to St. Vincent Ferrer or the New York Society Library. Burial will be at St. Joseph's Cemetery in Manchester NH at 11am, Thursday April 15th.

Since 1966, police officers have been required by law to remind each person they arrest and question of the right to remain silent. The standard statement of those rights includes a warning: ''Anything you say can and will be used against you in a court of law.'' Most career criminals (as well as most career watchers of television shows like ''Law & Order'') know that talking to detectives without a lawyer rarely works out well for the guilty. But the less-experienced often do speak to police officers immediately after being arrested or detained.

BATEY--Gregory L.,died unexpectedly March 28 in Michigan at age 58. Surviving Greg are his wife Patricia, his daughters Piper and Sissel and siblings Martha Batey, David Batey and Jean Linsin. Greg was Managing Director & Chief Investment Officer, Fixed Income, at Munder Capital Management, Birmingham, MI. He was born in Detroit, graduated from the University of Michigan and earned a PhD at Stanford University in Engineering Economic Systems. Prior to joining Munder Capital, Greg led strategy and research groups at JP Morgan, Chase, and Lehman Brothers in London, Hong Kong and New York. Greg was passionate about life and traveled the world in the spirit of discovery. An avid mathematician, he cultivated sunflowers not only for their splendor but to teach his children the beauty of the Fibonacci sequence. Greg was a most honorable, loyal and loving man and his was a life well lived. A Memorial Service will be held at Kirk in the Hills Presbyterian Church, 1340 W. Long Lake Rd., Bloomfield Hills, MI on April 24 at 11am. View a complete obituary and share memories at: DesmondFuneralHome.com. Greg was enthralled with the power of education and he continued to learn throughout his life. To honor his joy of learning, in lieu of flowers, donations in Greg's memory may be sent to Horizons-Upward Bound (HUB), Development Office, P.O. Box 801, Bloomfield Hills, MI 48303. HUB's mission is to prepare motivated students with limited opportunity to enter into and succeed in post-secondary education.

NICOLA DE THOMASIS, a round-bellied, bearded, bespectacled man from the rough-hewn hills of Abruzzo, stood near the head of his dinner table, holding a pair of tongs -- and my fate -- in his hand. He had already placed on my plate an almost lethally large portion of spaghetti alla chitarra, dressed with the region's traditional tomato-and-lamb ragù, and his tong-bearing hand kept inching closer and closer to the communal pasta platter until, at last, he dove in with the instrument, scooped up a final, fatal tangle of noodles and added them to my dish. I was done for. But if I was going to die, this was absolutely the way to go. I had already sampled the family's wild-boar sausage, chunky prosciutto whose craggy appearance belied juicy depths, and sharp pecorino from the sheep that outnumber the humans in Abbateggio, this village (population 420) at the edge of Majella National Park. The spaghetti was thick and toothsome, made by the expert hands of Nicola's wife, Nicoletta, who'd sliced it on a chitarra, a guitarlike box of wires that gives the pasta flat, almost crisp edges. After that would come more: lamb chops, breaded and fried and drizzled with lemon, their rib bones arcing elegantly away from the meat; simple roasted potatoes; Savoy cabbage sautéed into the warm, vegetal equivalent of a grandmother's hug.
Variations on a dinnerware theme.

This spring at the Prado Museum (museodelprado.es), an exhibition pays homage to that institution's - and perhaps Spain's - most treasured painting, ''Las Meninas'' (1656) by Velazquez. In what is likely to be a true once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has lent John Singer Sargent's famous painting ''The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit'' (1882), which many art historians call the ''American Meninas'' to be displayed next to the Velazquez painting. The loan is part of the Prado's series of ''Invited Work'' exhibitions, which bring individual works of special importance or resonance to the museum, to be seen in proximity to the Prado's collection. Boit was an American painter and art collector who lived an expatriate life in Paris with his wife and eight children. Sargent's enigmatic painting of his four daughters has become as much an emblem of the American Gilded Age as Velazquez's picture is of the 17th-century Spanish court. Both painters used the candid and confident gaze of a young girl of privilege - Infanta Margarita was just 5 years old when Velazquez immortalized her on canvas, and Julia Boit was 4 when Sargent painted her - to engage the viewer. And both pieces go beyond traditional portraiture to offer compositions of complexity.

THE library of my youth, in Ocean Township, N.J., was a tomb of peace, where the only sounds were shuffles, whispers and the occasional shush -- delivered with an index finger crossing the lips of a bespectacled, cardigan-wearing librarian. These days, at my local branch in Washington Township, N.J., I have to play an MP3 file in a loop -- a sound bite of a hair dryer blasting between my ears -- because without the white noise, I wouldn't be able to think straight.

Depending on how you look at it, the venerable Centre Georges Pompidou, designed by Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano, will get either a new sibling or a new rival next month, when a branch opens to the public in Metz, France. The Centre Pompidou-Metz's inaugural exhibition has blockbuster written all over it; the coyly titled ''Masterpieces?'' will feature some 800 of the world's most prized modern works, from Alexander Calder's ''Josephine Baker IV'' to Yves Klein's ''Grande anthropophagie bleue (ANT 76).'' A TGV rail link makes the museum an easy 80-minute trip from Paris. And then there is the building itself. Conceived by Shigeru Ban and Jean de Gastines as a series of modules around a central spire, it is flamboyantly capped by an undulating lattice roof structure (made from 11 miles of glue-laminated timber beams) and sheathed in a fiberglass and Teflon membrane that gives the place an otherworldly glow when lit up at night. All the better for stealing the spotlight. ALIX BROWNE

According to Ver Bien Para Aprender Mejor (''See Well to Learn Better''), a program sponsored by the Mexican government, about one-tenth of the country's children do poorly in school simply because they can't see well. That's not just because glasses are expensive, but also because in Mexico they're often perceived as evidence of a handicap. In an attempt to address both problems, Ver Bien turned to the industrial designer Yves Béhar, who, as the creator of the One Laptop Per Child XO (the original $100 computer), has earned a reputation as a maker of inexpensive, attractive products for kids in the developing world. Béhar designed a set of split frames, which makes the glasses less costly to assemble in the field and lets kids customize them using a smorgasbord of color options. ''They're at the intersection of practicality and personal expression,'' Béhar says. With the help of Augen, the manufacturer, Ver Bien can keep the total cost -- including an eye exam and shipping -- at just $10. This year alone, it will give away 400,000 pairs. ''This is about using the very best not to make the most expensive product,'' Béhar says, ''but to make the most valuable product -- and to make it efficiently.'' JESSE ASHLOCK

A new baseball season is an expression of possibility. And so it was on April 9, 45 years ago, when the Yankees traveled to Houston for a game at the new Astrodome. The Times was there: ''It will mark the first time that baseball, like pheasant, ever has been served under glass. It will be offered in a monstrous indoor playpen under a domed roof and in an air-conditioned arena. It stuns the eye with such dazzling splendor that even the natives, experts at the use of superlatives, find themselves groping for words in trying to describe this Eighth Wonder. ... But if the Astrodome is a baseball paradise, a serpent already has been detected in this diamond version of the Garden of Eden. ... Outfielders have trouble judging fly balls.''

FOR motorists who believe they have a right to know when they are under electronic surveillance, or simply don't want to get a traffic ticket, there is a new device that alerts drivers when they are approaching a speed or red-light camera. The $129 V4e warning system, made by GPS Angel of San Francisco, uses GPS to map a vehicle's location and alerts drivers when they approach a camera. The alerts are visual, with flashing lights, and audible, with beeps that increase in intensity the closer the car gets to the camera. It is a stand-alone alternative to smartphone apps like Trapster, which have been available for some time.

GREENE--Edythe F. (nee Friedman), 95. A beautiful lady, died on April 6, 2010. Predeceased by husband Martin John Greene and her lovely granddaughter Leslie Robin Kobell and Edythe's parents Fannie and David Friedman, her brothers Jack Friedman and Leonard Brooks Freeman and her sister Loretta Shaw. Survived by son Robert Kobell. Services will be private.

MYERS--Raymond G.,81, died in Atlanta on February 13th from complications of Parkinson's. Born 1928 in Mount Vernon, NY, he graduated Dartmouth College in 1950 and was a Second lieutenant in the Army Signal Corps. Head copywriter of the Sales Promotion department at Scali, McCabe, Sloves from 1967-1986, he created smart, award-winning material for every account in the agency, including. Volvo, Perdue, and Nikon. He was a relentless champion of the magnificence and mischief of the English language. Words, inflections, rhythms, dual meanings, and interpretations were the toys in Ray's "sandbox." He put a high price on grammar and insisted on full sentences. He was a consummate teacher and inspiration to young talent, mentoring many and leading by example, encouragement, and commitment. His fierce scowl was legendary and frequently frightening, but it masked a great sense of fun. Like Snoopy with his Walter Mitty lives, Ray found joy and excitement in pursuing the "what if." He was a famous jazz clarinetist on winter nights in Westchester, sitting by the fire for hours playing along to Teddy Wilson 78s. He was a prolific farmer, tending his ever-growing garden on the Hudson, which he called Riverview Farms. He was an Olympic skater, donning his cap and long scarf to spend lunch hours at Rockefeller Center's rink. He was a landscape architect, putting in long hours on the plantscape at Zoo Atlanta. He was a copywriter to the end, hard at work on a campaign for an imagined product, "Gritz" sandpaper. He is missed by his wife, Nancy, four daughters, and four grandchildren. "You did good, kid."

SPIRO--Herbert J.,died in San Antonio after a long illness on April 6. Born September 7, 1924, in Hamburg, Germany, his family fled to Texas in 1938. He served as an interrogator with the Army's 11th Armored Division in the European theater, receiving a Purple Heart and the Bronze Star Medal. He graduated from Harvard University, from which he was also awarded a PhD in government. He later held teaching positions at Amherst, the University of Pennsylvania, and the Free University of Berlin, and was among the first American scholars to study African politics. From 1970-75, he served on the Policy Planning Staff, U.S. Department of State, and from 1975-77 as U.S. ambassador to Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea. He was the author of eleven books and numerous articles. He is survived by sons Peter, of Philadelphia, and Alexander, of New York; his former wife, Elizabeth Spiro Clark, of Washington; and grandchildren Liana, Henry, Julian, and Lila. He will be buried in San Antonio on Monday, April 12, 2010, 9:00 a.m. at Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery. You are invited to sign the guestbook at www.porterloring.com. Services with Porter Loring, 1101 McCullough, 210-227-8221 San Antonio, Texas.

LEFCOURT--Ellen Navin Ellen Lefcourt, M.Ed.,extraordinary mother and friend, died on March 25, 2010 in Chapel Hill, North Carolina, surrounded by her family. She was 68 years old. Ellen grew up in Indiana, Manhattan and Chicago. She met her first husband, Roger Kellison, in Chicago in 1960. They moved to New York where they had son Daniel and daughter, Laura. Ellen and Roger divorced, but remained friends. In 1971, Ellen and her children moved to Brattleboro, Vermont, where she married Eric Anderson, with whom she had her third and fourth children, Molly and Rob. In 1981, the family, minus Mr. Anderson, left Vermont for Northampton, Massachusetts, where Ellen earned her undergraduate degree at Smith College, and a Master of Education at Harvard University. Ellen spent the last decade of her life living in Chapel Hill, NC, close to her daughter and son-in-law, Laura and Daniel Wallace. She enjoyed a rich life with deep and true friends and devoted family, and remained involved with writing, editing and appreciating the arts until her death. Ellen believed the greatest achievement of her life was raising four productive, happy and loving children, all of whom inherited her unfailing irreverence and her unfettered compassion. She loved them, their spouses and her grandchildren ferociously. What an amazing woman she was, whose real genius was the art of living: as much as she was loved, she loved more.

MATLACK--Jamie, of Newtown died at her residence on Saturday, March 13, 2010 surrounded by her family. She was 53. She was the beloved wife of Lars K. Tofastrud. Born in Syracuse, NY, Jamie was the daughter of the late John A. and Anne M. Matlack (Verdone). Friends and colleagues are invited to a celebration of her life at the Trenton Country Club, 201 Sullivan Way, Ewing, NJ 08628 on April 24, 2010 at 1pm to 4pm. Please refer to www.fluehr.com for further information.

GOODMAN--David S.,88, on April 4, 2010 at LIJ Hospital. Beloved husband for 69 years of Bernice Wedeen Goodman (Bunny). Devoted father of Tom S. Goodman, Manchester, VT. Predeceased by his daughter Sally F. Amar. Proud and loving grandfather of Tristan X. Goodman, Manchester, VT, his sister Nellie Charney and nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. His mother died when he was very young. He was valedictorian in elementary school. Attended Townsend Harris High School, CCNY and graduated NYU Dental School at the top of his class. He was a Captain in the US Army Dental Corps and served in England, France and Belgium during the Battle of the Bulge. He was a life long inventor, builder, artist and teacher. He is a past president of New York Chapter of The National Clock Association and his book "This Old Clock" is used internationally. His interests in clocks and the diversity of clockwork brought him to the New York Public Library at 42nd and 5th Avenue where he spent years educating himself in the history of mechanical clocks, and their technological changes over the centuries. He taught clock history and repair at Roslyn High School, Long Island for over 20 years and loved every minute with his students. He made time to travel with his wife and children through England and Europe. He valued his time on earth and made the most of it-No Regrets.
Classical Allan Kozinn

CHAIRY/ (cher e) / adj. / The quality of ''thing-ness,'' personified by the moving, talking upholstered chair from ''Pee-wee's Playhouse.'' Used to indicate authenticity, e.g., 'Alessandro Mendini added a bold new pattern to his Proust chair, but even with the makeover, its little curved legs and voluptuous arms still make it look very chairy. TOUSLED/ (tou zeld) / adj. / Studied interior dishabille; the antidote to the perfectly styled rooms that have long been the aspirational norm in design magazines. The decorating equivalent of meticulously using hair gel to achieve bed head, as in, You might wonder why the subjects of Todd Selby's photos don't bother to straighten up a bit, but in fact the tousled aesthetic of their living rooms is totally intentional.

THE NEWS The president of Kyrgyzstan, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, fled the capital as demonstrations against rising utility costs and his repressive rule erupted into violence. Protestors seized ministries and TV stations and set up an interim government. BEHIND THE NEWS Kyrgyzstan is the only nation with both Russian and (to Moscow's irritation) American military bases. Mr. Bakiyev tried to pit the two against each other to get more aid from both, but Russia lost patience and began squeezing the country with high energy prices. America needs its leased airbase to support operations in Afghanistan.

Every now and then a good book completely passes us by: we don’t get a copy, for whatever reason, and we don’t request one because the book’s not on our radar. That’s what happened with Paul Harding’s first novel, “Tinkers,” which was published at the beginning of 2009 by the Bellevue Literary Press, a small publisher that had only been in business for a couple of years. Now “Tinkers” has gone and won the Pulitzer Prize — the first novel from a small press to win that award since “A Confederacy of Dunces” did it for Louisiana State University Press in 1981.
Conan O’Brien’s manager, Gavin Polone, said that a whirlwind negotiation of only about 10 days led the late-night star to leave network television and jump to the cable network, TBS.

The German philosopher Jürgen Habermas has long been recognized as the most persistent and influential defender of an Enlightenment rationality that has been attacked both by postmodernism, which derides formal reason's claims of internal coherence and neutrality, and by various fundamentalisms, which subordinate reason to religious imperatives that sweep everything before them, often not stopping at violence.

The average salary of a full-time faculty member rose 1.2 percent over the last year. That is the smallest increase professors have received in at least 50 years, according to the latest annual study from the American Association of University Professors.

In conjunction with a human coach who studies your uploaded data, the device is supposed to encourage you to be more active and become healthier.

Last week, the current ownership of the newspapers in Philadelphia won an improbable series of legal victories at the Third Circuit in an effort to keep the properties out of the hands of the lenders, and then today, The Philadelphia Daily News, the underdog newspaper owned by an underdog owner in an underdog market, won a Pulitzer for investigative reporting. The back end of Augusta National's challenging Amen Corner proved to be a propitious place for the Masters champion Phil Mickelson last weekend. His eagle on No. 13 on Saturday was the first of consecutive eagles that vaulted him into contention. And on Sunday, after driving into the pine needles to the right of the fairway on the par-5 510-yard hole, he opted not to lay up, but instead gambled on threading the needle between the trees. The ball landing a few feet from the hole. Though he missed the eagle, his subsequent birdie set him firmly on the path to his third Masters title.

Oh, what a headache: the producers of "Jersey Boys" have filed suit against the producers of a touring show called "The Boys in Concert," saying that it is trying to confuse audiences into thinking the two musicals are related, Reuters reported. "Jersey Boys," which tells the story of Frankie Valli and his rock group, the Four Seasons, has remained a popular and lucrative show since it opened on Broadway in 2005 (and won the Tony Award for best musical), spawning several regional productions and a national tour. "The Boys in Concert," whose cast and creators include the "Jersey Boys" alumni Christian Hoff, Michael Longoria and Daniel Reichard, features the music of several pop acts of the 1960s and 70s, including the Four Seasons. The lawsuit, which The New York Post reported was filed by Mr. Valli, as well as his band mate Bob Gaudio and the playwrights Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, says that "The Boys in Concert" copies many elements of "Jersey Boys" and that its promotional materials represent "a deliberate and willful attempt to create public confusion and foster the misimpression" that the shows are "associated or connected." The "Jersey Boys" producers are seeking damages and an injunction against performances of "The Boys in Concert" that use copyrighted or similar materials. Representatives for "The Boys in Concert" did not immediately respond to Reuters or The Post.
The Federal Reserve Board on Monday named William B. English as director of its division of monetary affairs, one of the most powerful staff positions at the central bank.

A wealthy client of the Swiss bank UBS pleaded guilty on Monday to tax fraud, the ninth American caught up in an investigation of the bank's offshore private banking services, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reports.

My Sunday column was about an amazing set of kids living in a Zimbabwe hut together after their four parents died of AIDS. The kid in charge, a high school student, wants a bicycle to reduce his three-hour commute to school each way -- and now it looks as if he'll get it. Several readers are trying to send him money for that bike (I didn't want to post his contact information for fear of getting him in trouble with the Zimbabwean government, and aid organizations were wary of being intermediaries for similar reasons).

"There's never been a better time to be a dog in New York City," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proclaimed Monday morning. As usual, he had statistical proof. The percentage of dogs and cats put to death at the city's shelters hit an all-time low last year - 33 percent, down from 69 percent in 2003.

One thing that keeps coming up in comments, both here and on my column, is the widespread belief that all we need to do on the banking front is (a) break up the big banks, so that none of them are too big to fail (b) promise not to bail out any banks in the future. That way, the claim goes, bankers will know that they will face dire consequences if they misbehave, and market discipline will do the rest.

It may not seem to matter much now in a post-Conan-O'Brien-goes-to-TBS world, but a winner has been declared in the box-office showdown between "Clash of the Titans" and "Date Night." It tells you something about the remarkable power our system has vested in 5-to-4 Supreme Court decisions that the most interesting piece I've read about the post-John Paul Stevens court involves the swing-voting Anthony Kennedy, rather than any of Stevens' prospective liberal replacements. On Scotusblog, Lyle Denniston argues that Stevens' retirement will only increase Kennedy's already-enormous influence on American jurisprudence. For one thing, Kennedy will be moving up in seniority, meaning that he's more likely to be the "assigning justice" on a case that divides the Court.  Denniston explains what this means:

"Two recent scholars have read the obituary for historical Jesus studies. James D. G. Dunn ... argues that the furthest we can get behind the Gospels is to the underlying strata of Jesus as his earliest followers remembered him. That is as far as we can go. That is the Jesus who gave rise to the Christian faith, and that is the only Jesus worth pursuing ... Dale Allison, whom I consider the most knowledgeable New Testament scholar in the United States, is less sanguine and more cynical than Dunn ... After three decades of work in and around the historical Jesus, Allison sketches the variety of views about the historical Jesus and the supposed modern theory that if we put our heads together we will arrive at firm conclusions. Allison offers this depressing conclusion: "Progress has not touched all subjects equally, and whatever consensus may exist, it remains mostly boring." Allison admits this about one of his own books on Jesus: "I opened my eyes to the obvious: I had created a Jesus in my own image, after my own likeness." He's not done: "Professional historians are not bloodless templates passively registering the facts: we actively and imaginatively project. Our rationality cannot be extricated from our sentiments and feelings, our hopes and fears, our hunches and ambitions." So, he ponders, "Maybe we have unthinkingly reduced biography [of Jesus] to autobiography."

After more than two decades of making us eat our meat, Roger Waters is finally giving us the pudding: on Monday Mr. Waters, the onetime Pink Floyd singer, songwriter and bassist, gave in to the demands of ornery students everywhere and announced a concert tour version of "The Wall," his former band's classic album about post-World War II disillusionment, rock stardom and the anguish of being pursued by groupies. Billboard reported that Mr. Waters will begin the 36-date tour on Sept. 15 in Toronto and conclude it on Dec. 13 in Anaheim, Calif. Concerts, which will, of course, feature a 35-foot-tall, 240-foot-wide wall on stage, are also scheduled for Madison Square Garden (Oct. 5) and the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J. (Nov. 3). Billboard said that "The Wall" has been performed live only 31 times by Pink Floyd or Mr. Waters, who left the group in the mid-1980s: in a series of concerts the band played in 1980 and 1981, and by Mr. Waters in 1990 to mark the fall of the Berlin Wall.

More on Father Kiesle | Melinda Costello was a 7-year-old parishioner in the late 1960s in Fremont, Calif., when the Rev. Stephen Kiesle first playfully invited her to sit on his lap. Ms. Costello, now 48, recalled that as the tickling and touching quickly progressed to fondling her chest and genitals, Mr. Kiesle justified his behavior as exorcism and "told me the devil was inside me," she said in an interview with The New York Times. Emerging accounts like Ms. Costello's in California churches have intensified pressure on the pope. As Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, then a top Vatican official overseeing clergy, he sent a letter in 1985 to Bishop John S. Cummins of Oakland, who had repeatedly voiced concerns about Father Kiesle, saying that the case needed more time and that the "good of the universal church" should be considered before moving to discipline the priest.

At first glance, Vincent Olinet's mixed-media sculptures of pretty, frilly things like pastel layer cakes, four-poster fairy beds and glossy lipsticks are seductive, but upon closer inspection they reveal a subversive side. The cakes have collapsed in a gooey mess on their plates, the beds have been left outside to rot in the rain, and the lipsticks have rough edges and are sloppily varnished. ''I like to make shiny, colorful art pieces that appeal to our dreams and urges but actually deal with decay or disillusion,'' says the Brussels-based Olinet. Apply with caution. An exhibit of his work is at Galerie Laurent Godin in Paris through May 15. Go to laurentgodin.com.

Since Sunday, a new Twitter user who goes by the screen name @julietcap16 has been excitedly firing off posts about her typical teenage life, her frustrations with school and the birthday party she hopes her family will throw for her. But she's not just any social-media savvy teen: she's the online avatar for Juliet Capulet in a 21st-century update of "Romeo and Juliet" that the Royal Shakespeare Company has started online. BBC News reported that during the project, which is called "Such Tweet Sorrow" and will run for five weeks, actors playing Shakespeare's star-crossed lovers (who had their disagreements about the chirping of birds) and other characters from that tragedy will play out the story on Twitter and react to real-life events. Charlotte Wakefield, a actor in the Royal Shakespeare Company who is playing Juliet, has already tweeted about her new bed and her beloved deceased mother -- not to mention the Robert Pattinson cutout she keeps in her bedroom.

LUSTER--Esta, G. 94 years old, passed away on April 10, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Hyman I. Luster. Survived by her children Phyliis Gaier Posner (Stephen) Marty Luster (Barbara). Grandchildren Matthew, Todd and Melanie Gaier, Brian Luster, Ann Appavoo. Great-grandchildren Cody, Cassady, Shea, Priva, Yitzchak, Shanti, Leo and Raj. All of whom will greatly miss her. Graveside service Monday 11:15am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Services entrusted to Star of David Memorial Chapels 631-454-9600.

HAYNES--Carroll E. Anthony L. Watson, Chairman and CEO; Frank J. Branchini, President and COO; and the Board of Directors and staff of EmblemHealth are deeply saddened by the passing of our dedicated Board member and friend, Carroll (Carl) E. Haynes. Carl had been a member of the Emblem- Health Board of Directors since the Board was formed in 2007. Prior to that, he served as a long-term member of the Boards of Directors of both HIP Health Plan of New York and the HIP Foundation beginning in 1994. Carl devoted his life to working for the betterment of the members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, where he held the positions of International Vice President and Director of Public Services Division. Carl was born and raised in Hinton, West Virginia. He moved to New York City to work for the New York City Housing Authority, and joined Local 237 in 1960. He rose through the ranks to become President of Local 237, the largest Teamsters local in the country with 24,000 public service employee members. He served as Local 237 President from 1993 to 2007. He also served on the executive boards of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O., the New York Central Labor Council, and the Municipal Labor Committee, a coalition of 51 New York City employee unions. Carl is survived by his wife of 53 years, Janice, his daughter Liane Haynes Smith, his son Jay Christopher Haynes, three grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A viewing will be held on Tuesday, April 13, from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Pelham Funeral Home, 4 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY. There will be a Funeral mass on Wed., April 14 at 10am at St. Catherine's Church, 25 2nd Avenue, Pelham, NY. Anthony L. Watson, Chairman and CEO Frank J. Branchini, President and COO EmblemHealth, Inc.

RIBAKOFF--Eugene J. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the tremendous loss of our esteemed friend and former President and Board Chairman, Eugene J. Ribakoff. An unparalleled leader in the JDC family, Gene's generosity, invaluable wisdom, and boundless dedication was an inspiration to both the lay and professional leadership of JDC. A true ambassador for the organization, he traveled the world visiting JDC programs and was passionately involved in the full scope of JDC services in more than 70 countries. He served with vigor as Chair of the JDC's Israel Committee, Central and Eastern Europe Committee, and the Transmigrant Committee, where he personally oversaw with great devotion the emigration of hundreds of thousands of Jews from the former Soviet Union and elsewhere. A philanthropist of the first order, Gene's unquenchable desire to help others was evident in his leadership roles at other organizations, including World ORT, the United Way of Palm Beach County, the Jewish Federations of both Palm Beach and Worcester, the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Greater Boston, the Boston Museum of Science, Massachusetts General, and Brandeis University. A towering figure in the business community, he built Automotive Management, Inc. and HARR Motor Companies, among others. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Stephanie; his son and JDC Board Member Charles and his wife, Patty; his daughter and JDC Board Member Betsy and her husband, Richard; and to his seven grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Irving A. Smokler President Judge Ellen M. Heller Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager Chief Executive Officer

The competition for online shoppers -- excluding eBay and Amazon, which are more like online malls -- tends to pit brick-and-mortar retailers against one another on the Web. So Office Depot outperformed Staples in February, and Wal-Mart did better than J. C. Penney, Target (which was No. 17), Kohl's (No. 23) and Macy's (No. 24). Specialty sites included Ticketmaster, Avon (No. 15) and Netflix (No. 16). BUDAPEST -- Hungary's center-right opposition party won first-round parliamentary elections here on Sunday, while a far-right party, whose black-clad paramilitary extremists evoke the Nazi era, made significant gains. With 99 percent of votes counted, the ruling Socialist Party conceded to the Fidesz party of a former prime minister, Viktor Orban. Fidesz won 52.8 per cent of the vote, followed by 19.3 per cent for the Socialists and 16.7 per cent for the far-right party Jobbik -- a better showing than any other far-right party in Hungary since the fall of Communism in 1989.

HACKETT--Gay died on April 9th, 2010 of lung cancer. Daughter of the late Virginia and Thayer Cumings. Devoted wife of Randall W. Hackett. Loving mother of Samantha McLean Spruance and Stuart Locke McLean. Adoring grandmother of William Halsey Spruance III and James McLean Spruance. Gay attended The Chapin School and graduated from Miss Porter's School in 1959. A graduate of The NY School of Interior Design in 1960, she was a successful Interior Decorator first with Katherine Cowdin, Inc. and then her own firm Gay Hackett, Inc. which she started in 1982. An active member of The Board of Governors of The River Club, she was also a member of The Colony Club. Gay loved to travel and she and her husband spent happy times exploring the world. Gay created many miniature rooms and wrote the book "Gay Hackett's Miniature Rooms" last year for her close friends. Her kindness, sense of humor, talent and love of life will be missed by her many friends and family. Memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York at 4pm, April 16th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to NY Presbyterian-Columbia Oncology, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, New York, NY 10032.

KATCHER--Edward, 91, died peacefully at home on April 11 with his loving family by his side. His wife Naomi Zieph Katcher of 60 years survives him as does his daughter Lee, son Saul, sister Gladys Bletter, sister and brother-in-law Jeanne and Richard Kandel and loving cousins, nieces and nephews. He was a proud solider and patriot serving as a Captain in the CBI during World War II and was awarded the Bronze Star. He was an award winning political reporter, editor and columnist for many years.

BAHRT--Norma, artist, wife of the late Irv Bahrt, passed away March 27, 2010 at the age of 84. Her love and creative spirit live on in her daughters Amy and Jenni and her grandchildren Evan and Liam.

LLEWELLYN--J. Bruce, died peacefully at home on April 7 after a long illness. Edward Lewis, Donald McHenry, and Maurice Sonnenberg deeply regret the passing of their dear friend of many decades. He was a man of exceptional knowledge, principle, and generosity. He persevered where others failed and yet while attaining great feats, never forgot his roots. We will sorely miss our extraordinary friend. May he rest in peace.
LLEWELLYN--J. Bruce. Dear friend and colleague, you will be in our hearts forever. Sue and Burt Rubin

KALINSKY--Morris, 86, of Charleston, SC, on April 10. Son of Jake and Minnie. He opened Bob Ellis Shoe Store in February, 1950 in Charleston. Morris received numerous industry awards including The Fashion Footwear Association's Best U.S. Retailer in 1992 and induction into the Footwear News Hall of Fame. He became one of the most recognized names in retail footwear. He is survived by wife of 50 years Sybil, sons Jeffrey of New York and Barry (Mona) of Charleston, and three grandchildren.

SUSMAN--Florence Carol Levin, was born May 21, 1914 in New York City. She attended NYU and graduated from the Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania (now Drexel University College of Medicine) in 1937. She married Benjamin R. Susman. M.D. in 1946 and for 40 years they had a joint practice in Manhattan and later in Mt. Vernon, NY. She is survived by her children Maxine Susman and her husband Jay Harris, Rita Wolpert and her husband Michael Lobel, and William Susman and his wife Virginia, by her grandchildren Suzanne, Owen, Julianne, Margaret, and Katherine and by her niece Myra Graubard her husband John and her children Naomi and Michael. The interment was at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Donations may be made to the Compassionate Care Hospice Foundation.

RIBAKOFF--Eugene J. The Officers, Board, and staff of World ORT mourn the tremendous loss of Eugene J. Ribakoff, Deputy President of World ORT. Our dear friend, Gene, has provided invaluable wisdom, and boundless dedication to two of the world's largest Jewish organizations, impacting the lives of Jews in close to 100 countries. As the Deputy President of World ORT and as a past president and a leader of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, he traveled the world visiting programs and projects and was passionately involved in the full scope of the work of the two organizations meeting critical human needs across the globe. On behalf of World ORT he dedicated himself to ensuring that Jewish students and adults received the best possible general and Jewish education to prepare themselves for a future of self sufficiency. In the short time he served as Deputy President he proved to be an invaluable resource for the professional and volunteer leadership of World ORT. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Stephanie; his son, Charles and his wife, Patty; his daughter Betsy and her husband, Richard; and to his seven grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Jean de Gunzburg, World ORT President Mauricio Merikanskas, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Judy Menikoff, Treasurer Martin Behr, Secretary Robert Singer, Director General and CEO World ORT

This year, a gain that large would return the House to Republican control. President Obama's most recent Gallup Poll rating: 45 percent.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- In the past two weeks, Anthony Kim has shown why he remains one of the most explosive young golfers in the world. His playoff victory against Vaughn Taylor at the Shell Houston Open last week might not have been popular here in Augusta -- it prevented Taylor, an Augusta native, from getting the last spot in the Masters -- but it did much to rekindle the fire in Kim. And when he moved to within a stroke of Phil Mickelson's lead for a short time during a torrid run Sunday in the Masters, Kim also re-emerged as a threat to win a major championship.

MEYERS--Dr. Helen, a brilliant psychoanalyst, inspiring teacher and leader in her field, passed away Thursday morning, April 8. She was 85. An exceptional intellect, scholar and doctor, Helen Meyers was a powerful, influential presence in the psychoanalytic world at large and at Columbia University Psychoanalytic Center; a master teacher, theoretician, and a mentor to generations of psychiatrists and psychoanalysts. She was an accomplished therapist, with one of the best reputations, not only in New York City, but the world. She was a sought after speaker at professional conferences, a powerful role model for women in the field, an influential and well-respected writer and thinker. Beyond her professional achievements, she was a loving, indeed doting, wife, mother and mother-in-law, aunt and grandmother, and a beloved, loyal friend. She is survived by her husband Dr. Donald Meyers, son Andrew, daughter-in-law Beth, brother Willi, granddaughters Rennie and Maddie, and nieces and nephews Erica, Lizzie, Jonathan and Peter. The funeral service will be at the Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. on Tuesday, April 13, at 11:30am

MYERS--Raymond G.,81, died in Atlanta on February 13th from complications of Parkinson's. Born 1928 in Mount Vernon, NY, he graduated Dartmouth College in 1950 and was a Second lieutenant in the Army Signal Corps. Head copywriter of the Sales Promotion department at Scali, McCabe, Sloves from 1967-1986, he created smart, award-winning material for every account in the agency, including. Volvo, Perdue, and Nikon. He was a relentless champion of the magnificence and mischief of the English language. Words, inflections, rhythms, dual meanings, and interpretations were the toys in Ray's "sandbox." He put a high price on grammar and insisted on full sentences. He was a consummate teacher and inspiration to young talent, mentoring many and leading by example, encouragement, and commitment. His fierce scowl was legendary and frequently frightening, but it masked a great sense of fun. Like Snoopy with his Walter Mitty lives, Ray found joy and excitement in pursuing the "what if." He was a famous jazz clarinetist on winter nights in Westchester, sitting by the fire for hours playing along to Teddy Wilson 78s. He was a prolific farmer, tending his ever-growing garden on the Hudson, which he called Riverview Farms. He was an Olympic skater, donning his cap and long scarf to spend lunch hours at Rockefeller Center's rink. He was a landscape architect, putting in long hours on the plantscape at Zoo Atlanta. He was a copywriter to the end, hard at work on a campaign for an imagined product, "Gritz" sandpaper. He is missed by his wife, Nancy, four daughters, and four grandchildren. "You did good, kid."

Voluptuousness may be back in fashion for the fall, but as usual, the architectural designer Greg Lynn is ahead of the curve. "With everything that I design, from a church to a plate to skyscraper to a spoon," he says, "I am always thinking about voluptuous volumes and spaces." Add to that list Lynn's soft-serve riff on the T logo, which he created for the spring design issue. It's as intriguing coming as it is going. Lynn was inspired by the T's combination of hard lines and curvilinear flourishes and scrolls. "This is something I have a great affinity for," he says. "The combination of the hard-edged and the curvaceous." View interactive >>

"There is a way to beat obesity. But it is radical and expensive. No other diet or weight-loss approach is remotely as effective as bariatric surgery. Most people who seek it out have tried everything else. Many of them can pinpoint the moment they concluded that they had no other choice. Mine came late in the afternoon on June 13, 2008, when I learned that Tim Russert, the Meet the Press host, had died of a sudden heart attack at NBC's Washington bureau. I didn't know Russert well, but as I sat at my desk, my tolerance for the status quo ended. I'm 30 years old, I remember thinking. I can't spend another decade like this. I Googled bariatric surgery Washington D.C. Nine months later, on a morning in March 2009, Dr. Joseph Afram, the director of the bariatric-surgery program at George Washington University Hospital, picked up his scalpel and went to work, carefully separating my stomach from my digestive pouch and leaving a walnut-size cavity, which he then attached directly to my small intestine. When he was done, my stomach was no longer."

In the hands of the illustrator Jean Philippe Delhomme, the unbearable lightness of being hip, rich and polished has never seemed so disarmingly down-to-earth. For more than 25 years, the artist has chronicled the in-crowd by quizzical strokes through advertisements and editorials for the likes of Barneys, Interview and Glamour. His signature is a rainfall of lifelike impressions that glitter until they prickle. "Know thyself," he seems to say to a beau monde unwittingly silly in its distractions. Words to heed in frugal times? Recognize yourself in his world and you may feel better about being so terribly "with it."

For years, only a simple sign indicated the location of what was once the Nazi secret police headquarters in Berlin. On May 7, the exhibition is scheduled to get a new home: a glass and concrete museum and documentation center built on same site.

Paprika a power ingredient? That tasteless powder that your great-aunt sprinkled over potato salad to give it some color? Well, no. But in a fertile valley in the Spanish equivalent of the Wild West, they make a paprika with a sneaky heat and deep smokiness that takes the spice to a whole different place. Called pimentón, it's a nearly effortless way to add complex flavor to all kinds of dishes, like barbecued brisket, or barbecue sauce, or a Spanish lamb stew, or this quick and easy kale recipe.

The first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, which starts on Wednesday, can be a danger zone for favorites. Scotty Bowman, who coached more Stanley Cup championships than anyone, told listeners of Toronto radio FAN 590 this morning (audio) that he was very aware of the possibility of first round upsets and there are no sure things. "I look at all the different TV shows and everyone's always picking the favorites, it's the easy thing to do. You wonder how a team that's 20 or 30 points behind another can even have a competition."

It's the start of design week here in Milan, and our first event was an off-site exhibit at one of our favorite galleries: Nilufar. Run by Nina Yashar, the gallery-cum-high-end-design-boutique specializes in antique design masterpieces as well as newly commissioned works by young designers. The standout at this year's exhibition, however, was a bit old and a bit new. The designer Barnaba Fornasetti, son of the legendary Piero Fornasetti, has made newly commissioned pieces out of some of his father's classic collaborations with the famed designer Gio Ponti. Instead of making these pieces in the high-gloss lacquer that is a Fornasetti trademark, these new works are covered in the original zinc lithographic plates that papa Fornasetti used to print his famous designs. The matte gray zinc is embellished in a black etched patchwork of flowers, trompe l'oeil books, faux bois and more. The zinc plates are attached to the wooden construction of the furniture by way of utilitarian yet decorative nail heads. The collection consists of two desks, a tall secretary desk, a chair, a chandelier and a wardrobe (in which Barnaba has even placed some of his own idiosyncratic Fornasetti printed suits, vests and shirts). All of the pieces are unique and are destined to become instant, if remixed, classics.

Labor Leader Steps Down | Andrew Stern, the leader of the Service Employees International Union, signaled Monday that he would step down at the end of this week, Politico reported. He has been locked in a fierce struggle with a splinter S.E.I.U. health care workers' local in the Bay Area. He has also been fighting the hotel and restaurant workers' union Unite Here, whose leader in San Francisco, Mike Casey, is a prominent national labor figure. [Politico, The New York Times]

The waste-to-energy plants I visited in Denmark this year for an article look like, well, power plants. Each has a prosaic smokestack dating from the days when all they had were old-fashioned incinerators. Twenty years ago, an important form of "pollution control" was to build a very, very tall smokestack so that dirty emissions dispersed far and wide.

It's not often that a politician makes it known in advance when he'll be attending a theater event, but in this case, Representative Barney Frank not only wants you to know he'll be at a performance of "The Temperamentals," he hopes you'll stick around afterward and ask him questions. Mr. Frank, the outspoken Democrat of Massachusetts, will participate in a postperformance discussion on May 3 at New World Stages, the play's press representatives said on Tuesday. The congressman will appear with Jon Marans, the author of "The Temperamentals," a play about forerunners of the gay rights movement in the early 1950s. Other guests planned for the talk series in future weeks include the playwrights Charles Busch and Terrence McNally, and James E. McGreevey, the former governor of New Jersey.

Weeks after the demise of the "Lips Together, Teeth Apart" revival that would have marked his Broadway debut, Mr. Oswalt, the comedian and actor ("Big Fan," "Ratatouille," "The King of Queens") has been cast in a new television pilot that puts him opposite the Broadway veteran Matthew Broderick. Publicists for Mr. Oswalt said in a statement that he would star in a comedy pilot called "Beach Lane," created by Paul Simms ("NewsRadio"), in which he will play a well-to-do if not well-educated man who is put in charge of a local newspaper in fictional Dockhampton, N.Y. Mr. Broderick will play an established journalist whom Mr. Oswalt's character hires to help him keep the presses rolling. On the morning of June 22, 2009, all 78 associates of SRC Power Systems, which makes custom-engineered power units and is based in Springfield, Mo., filed onto the shop floor to hear an hour-long presentation about the company's latest sales-and-marketing plan. People grabbed folding chairs where available while others sat on wire containers or floor baskets near their tools and workstations. There was a dark mood in the air. One guy leaned up against an engine crate, his arms folded across his chest and his jaw set. It was as if he already didn't like what he was about to hear.

Will there be annual limits of coverage for the new high-risk pool? I am 56 years old, facing unemployment at the end of the year, will not be eligible for Cobra and have a pre-existing condition, so I am unlikely to get health insurance on the private market. California's major risk insurance pool caps annual benefits at $75,000, with a lifetime of $750,000. It also has a three-month waiting period for pre-existing conditions. And it is enormously expensive ($1,064/month for one person for PPO.) Will the new reform law supersede rules about annual caps and waiting periods? Will the annual out of pocket $6,950 payment cap be in addition to premiums? - Judy

What we're reading this morning:

Nearly seven hours of previously unreleased interviews with Jacqueline Kennedy, recorded just months after the death of President John F. Kennedy and intended for deposit in a future presidential library, will be released as a book, the publisher Hyperion said on Tuesday. The original interviews with Mrs. Kennedy were conducted in the spring of 1964 with the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. as part of an oral history project intended to preserve memories of Kennedy and his administration. In the seven interviews, Hyperion said, Mrs. Kennedy discusses various subjects including her husband's election campaigns, his handling of challenges like the Cuban Missile Crisis, her role as a wife, mother, and first lady; and what her husband would have done in a second term as president.

Arroz de Verduras, or vegetable rice, is an intensely flavored dish of many colors. It is rice cooked in a sofrito, a base of garlic, onions, sweet paprika, fresh tomato and saffron, and then studded with corn, edamame, peas and olives and baked until the edges are crisp and golden. It is a dish with Portuguese roots that George Mendes, the 37- year-old chef and a co-owner of Aldea, in Manhattan, introduced at his restaurant. As a first-generation American, he grew up in Danbury, Conn., surrounded by 30 relatives, all of whom had emigrated from Portugal. "My mom, and my aunts, all cooked," he said.

Chemistry students and teachers might want to check out the new Chem4Word add-on for Microsoft Word. The free software, which was developed by Microsoft Research and the Unilever Center for Molecular Science Informatics at the University of Cambridge, allows Word users to insert chemical symbols, formulas and even 2-D models of molecules into documents. Chem4Word works with Word 2007 and the current beta version of Word 2010, and is listed as a beta version itself. More information and a demonstration video are also available for scientists, aspiring scientists and those who have chemistry papers due soon.

''There's never been a better time to be a dog in New York City,'' Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proclaimed Monday morning. As usual, he had statistical proof. The percentage of dogs and cats put to death at the city's shelters hit an all-time low last year - 33 percent, down from 69 percent in 2003. During that same period, the adoption rate for shelter pets increased to 66 percent, up from 26 percent, officials from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said at a news conference with the mayor and four adoptable dogs at City Hall.

EPSTEIN--Nancy F. July 9, 1920--April 10, 2010, 89, of Los Angeles died peacefully on April 10, 2010 at St. John's Health Center in Los Angeles. Born in Chicago, she was the daughter of Sol and Miriam Franklin, and was married to the late Julius Epstein, a Chicago real estate financier who passed away in 1968. She is survived by her daughter, Kay Unger Pitman of New York City, and Dan Epstein of Chicago, Illinois, and her grandchildren Sam Pitman (Erica) and Max Pitman (Day), Julie Epstein and Nick Epstein. She is the aunt of Nancy and Jim Epstein, originally of St. Louis, the daughter and son of her sister, Sally Epstein. Ms. Epstein grew up in Chicago and moved to Los Angeles after the death of her late husband. She lost her oldest son, seven year old Stephen, in a tragic drowning accident in 1949. In his memory, she and Julius started the Stephen David Epstein Foundation, which provided financing to hundreds of underprivileged children in the fine arts, including concert pianist Emanuel Ax and Earl Carlyss of the Juilliard String Quartet. There will be a private memorial service for family only. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in her memory to City of Hope (www.cityofhope.org) or the Family Institute (www.family-institute.org), or another charity in her honor.

MALIN--Herbert, 80, died at his home in Great Neck, NY on April 11, 2010 after a lengthy illness. Herb's huge heart, non-stop warmth and fantastic story-telling will be forever cherished by his surviving family, his wife and best friend Hope, his adoring children Robyn, Stacy and Glen, daughter-in-law, Cathy Malin and son-in-law Jason Rubinstein. Poppy Herb will be missed terribly by his biggest fans, his treasured grandchildren, Jesse, Zoe, Jonas, Noah and Kyle. In addition to being a beloved patriarch, Herb was Founder and President of Allied Bolt, Inc., a talented sculptor, lawyer, sports fanatic and confidante, mentor and best friend to many. Funeral services Tuesday, April 13, 1pm, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

The musician, poet, artist and dreamer Patti Smith brings all facets of her persona to ''Land 250,'' her solo exhibition at the Fondation Cartier in Paris, through June 22. Using drawings, Polaroids, films and favorite objects, Smith chronicles her relationships in one way or another. ''The idea of friendship is really valuable to Patti,'' says Grazia Quaroni, the foundation's curator, ''whether it's real people she's shared her life with,'' like Robert Mapplethorpe, ''or the references she has in her literature and other things,'' such as Arthur Rimbaud. Smith's world is also captured in the documentary ''Patti Smith: Dream of Life,'' currently making the film-festival circuit. The photographer Steven Sebring spent 11 years traveling with Smith to create a collage-like tribute. For information, go to dreamoflifethemovie.com. CHRISTINE MUHLKE
COLPITTS--Clifton, died April 3. Survived by friends at Brooks Brothers. Service at St. Agnes, 143 East 43rd, April 14, 6:30pm.

SCHEIN--David. Devoted husband of Roz, father of Lisa, brother of Harold. Died peacefully at home April 11, 2010 after a brief illness and a long, spectacular life. A passionate tennis player, avid golfer, smooth dancer and jazz connoisseur, he will be remembered fondly by all who knew him for his charming smile and love of life. The family will receive visitors at his home Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday from 2-5 and 7-9pm.
GLADSTONE--Bernard. Lovingly remembered today and every day. Ruth

ORINGER--Estelle Parnas. A gifted pianist and exceptional woman, who inspired and engaged people till 97 1/2 when she became seriously ill for the first time, died on April 2. Graduate of the Manhattan School of Music, music director of the New Dance Group, accompanist for Martha Graham dancers. An outstanding teacher in public schools and Hebrew schools who communicated her passion for music and living. Returning to concertizing in her 60s, she performed at NYU's Maison Francaise, synagogues, churches and halls, with a well-received "debut" at Carnegie Recital Hall followed by concert tours in Haiti. Specialties: Baroque, romantic, French and Spanish composers. At recent concerts through JASA to captive audiences she said: "I love watching people do a double take when I slide over from the wheelchair onto the piano bench and seem 50 years younger when I play". A bright star, who left a deep impression everywhere, has left us. She is survived by her loving daughter, Judith.
LLEWELLYN--J. Bruce. Dear friend and colleague, you will be in our hearts forever. Sue and Burt Rubin

One rainy day last month, Roberta Flack, the smooth voice of 1970s soul ballads, stepped out of a recording studio in Chelsea, hailed a yellow taxi and threw a suitcase of CDs into the back seat. Arriving at the Dakota, where she has long had an apartment, Ms. Flack got out and hurried past the wrought-iron gate, seeking cover from the downpour. Then: ''Panic! Panic! Panic!'' Ms. Flack recalled on the telephone the other day. ''I left the suitcase in the cab!''

LONDON -- Political leaders in Northern Ireland said Monday that an overnight bombing near Belfast outside a headquarters of Britain's MI5 security service, resulting in minor injuries to one pedestrian, would not impede the peace process in the province. An Irish Republican Army splinter group, the Real I.R.A., claimed responsibility for the bomb in a phone call to the local offices of the BBC. The police said the bomb, placed inside an abandoned taxi, exploded outside the Palace Barracks in Holywood, six miles northeast of Belfast, at 12:24 a.m., as more than 60 homes in the area were being evacuated after a warning that the explosion was imminent.

In this week's Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein finds out why Twitter app developers are worried. She speaks with Claire Cain Miller, The Times technology reporter who covers Twitter, about the company's moves toward building its own tools for the microblogging service, and the concerns among developers who fear that Twitter might turn into a competitor. Independent developers have created some 70,000 apps that let users do things like track messages on cellphones, monitor multiple Twitter accounts, shorten link addresses and post photos on the service.Dean Kamen, inventor of the Segway, is also a strong advocate of promoting science and technology education. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Mr. Kamen about his own early inspirations and about the nonprofit group he founded to encourage interest in these fields among the young. The organization, called First (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology), holds its 19th annual championship, with competitions in robotics, gaming and Lego construction, April 15-17 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta.You might expect your brand new computer to have a clean hard drive, only to find programs installed on it that you didn't ask for, or trial versions of software that pester you to buy the full version or sign up for a service. There is a name for that, as Pedro Rafael Rosado explains in his regularly featured audio essay on tech terms.Also on the show, Ms. Biersdorfer rounds up tech news of the week, including updates for the Google Docs service, a new fleet of MacBook Pro laptops from Apple; Neflix streaming movies via Wii game consoles; and prepackaged movies on portable Seagate drives. And if you can't wait for baseball season to start, her tech tip of the week can help you get set: MySportsCal lets you download your favorite team's schedule right into your Outlook, iCal or Google calendar.

Not only did the diva of the $800 haircut lose her star colorist Marie Robinson, who famously took Scarlett Johansson from blond to brunet for the "Nanny Diaries," but Robinson also put a dent in the staff and hired seven of her colleagues for her eponymous new salon in the Flatiron district. Included in her sweep are Tommy Buckett, Allison Woodruff and Ryan Trygstad, all favorites of the magazine world. And the celebrity stylist Danilo will also work out of the light-filled 5,000-square-foot space when he's in town. Master Cleanse lemonade is on tap; the paint, floor stain and cooling system are all eco-friendly, and the music runs along the lines of Hot Chip and Kylie Minogue. And so far, there aren't any $800 services on the menu. 155 Fifth Avenue; (212) 358-7780.

You've had calorie, fat and sodium counts appended to your fast food choices. A new twist is knowing your food's carbon footprint, that is, its environmental impact. That's what Radhika Oswal offers Otarian, a vegetarian fast food chain with the planet on its mind. Recycling, composting, sustainable building materials and no ingredients that are shipped by air are the rules here. The carbon footprints were calculated according to standards set by the World Resources Institute, an environmental organization based in Washington.

Wayne Clough, the secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, detailed a plan on Monday to transform the 1881 Arts and Industries building into an education center, with programming that would emphasize the four themes outlined in the Smithsonian's new strategic plan: biodiversity and sustainability, the American experience, exploring the universe and valuing world cultures. The Arts and Industries building, which in the past housed temporary exhibits and has been empty since 2004, needs $65 million in structural renovations, according to Linda St. Thomas, the Smithsonian's spokeswoman. On Monday, the Smithsonian's Board of Regents reviewed a concept design for the building by the Los Angeles-based architecture firm Morphosis; its potential cost has not been determined, Ms. St. Thomas said. The Arts and Industries building has also been discussed as a possible site for a future national Latino museum. A presidential commission is studying the potential for such a museum.

The National Endowment for the Arts has named Jason Schupbach as its new director of design. Mr. Schupbach will oversee the distribution of the N.E.A.'s design grants (which totaled about $1.1 million in the 2009 fiscal year), the Mayors' Institute on City Design and a new $5 million program, Our Town, focused on creating local arts districts. "Design has an intrinsic value to community building, to economic development, and to really revitalizing communities and creating jobs," said Mr. Schupbach, who currently holds the position of creative economy industry director for the Massachusetts Office of Business Development.

Last week Usher bumped his young protégé Justin Bieber from the top spot on the Billboard album chart, and this week Mr. Bieber returns the favor. "My World 2.0" (Island) by the 16-year-old Mr. Bieber -- seen on "Saturday Night Live" with Tina Fey as host last week -- returned to No. 1 with 102,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Usher's "Raymond v Raymond" (Jive) fell one spot to No. 2, with 92,000. Slash, the guitarist once of Guns N' Roses, is at No. 3 with his new, self-titled album, released by EMI, which sold just more than 60,000 copies in its first week out. The country band Lady Antebellum rose one spot to No. 4 with its album "Need You Now" (Capitol Nashville), which sold just fewer than 60,000 copies. (SoundScan's publicly released numbers are rounded; its subscribers get exact figures.)

On March 17, 1974, the architect Louis I. Kahn died of a heart attack as he was walking through Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. He was 73. In his briefcase were the final drawings, which he had just completed, for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial to be built on the southern tip of Roosevelt Island.

A musical based on a George Bernard Shaw play? It's worked in the past. To a 2010-2011 schedule that already includes a musical adaptation of "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," the transfer of the life-size puppet play "War Horse" and John Guare's long-awaited "Free Man of Color," Lincoln Center Theater has added a new musical based on Shaw's "Candida," the theater company said on Wednesday. The musical, called "A Minister's Wife," tells the story of a minister and his wife, Candida, whose marriage is upended by a young poet; the adaptation is by Austin Pendelton ("Orson's Shadow"), with music by Josh Schmidt ("Adding Machine") and lyrics by Jan Tranen ("Night in Sarajevo"). It will be directed by Michael Halberstam, the artistic director and a co-founder of the Writers' Theater in Glencoe, Ill., where the musical had its debut last year. The Lincoln Center Theater production will begin previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse theater on April 7 with an opening night planned for May 5. A cast has not yet been announced.

As we left winter behind and started feeling the sweaty hands of summer, I, like many others, caught the annoying head cold that often accompanies seasonal transitions. It was relatively benign, but it kept me inside while others were out enjoying the warm, sunny weather. When I ventured back into the world, a friend noticed that I was using a handkerchief rather than Kleenex, and produced a striped cotton one. We talked about how, as children, our fathers had carried them and instilled the habit in us. I've carried a handkerchief ever since, preferring it to the fragile Kleenex that inevitably winds up in the dryer, ground up into dust.

After years of practice, NBC is finally addressing the abrupt departure of one of its signature late-night personalities with a plan for a smooth transition. (It may be only the bandleader for "The Tonight Show," but hey, it's a start.) On Tuesday, the network announced that Rickey Minor, the music director of "American Idol," would succeed Kevin Eubanks in that role. Mr. Eubanks announced on Monday's broadcast that he was stepping down after 18 years of chuckling amiably at Jay Leno's gags. Mr. Minor, who was nominated for an Emmy Award as the music director of the 2008 Grammy Awards, will make his "Tonight Show" debut on June 7 and continue to work with the "American Idol" creator Simon Fuller on other projects, NBC said. Mr. Eubanks became the band leader of "The Tonight Show" in 1995, when he replaced Branford Marsalis, and followed Mr. Leno to his short-lived NBC prime-time series, "The Jay Leno Show."

Can there be a 3-D movie about a work of art that predates the discovery of perspective? If anyone can make such a film, surely Werner Herzog can. The Guardian reported that Mr. Herzog, the director of "Grizzly Man" and "Fitzcarraldo," is working on a movie that will take audiences inside a French cave containing drawings that are more than 30,000 years old. In a video interview on the blog of Roger Ebert, the film critic of The Chicago Sun-Times, Mr. Herzog said that he had been given permission to film inside the Chauvet cave in the southeastern Ardèche region of France, whose walls are decorated with more than 300 images of rhinoceroses, bison and other animals. (Due to the risk of damage to the drawings, the site is usually restricted to visitors.)

Earthquake Kills Hundreds in Western China | An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.1 struck Qinghai Province in western China on Wednesday morning, leaving at least 400 dead and 10,000 injured, Chinese state media reported. Chinese officials said the quake struck in a poor and sparsely populated area near the mountainous border with Tibet. The circumstances echo the devastating earthquake that rocked neighboring Sichuan Province almost two years ago, killing 87,000 people. [The New York Times]

Readers responded with their own take on the musical's success, with some dismissing the role of critics and others suggesting audiences are just looking for an escape. The first sculpture that greets you upon entering Carol Bove's solo exhibition at Kimmerich Gallery is a frondlike piece of rusty metal mounted on an armature and set atop a brass pedestal. There is nothing inherently important about any of its elements. A long-gestating musical from the "South Park" creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone, and Robert Lopez, a co-creator of "Avenue Q," is bound for the Great White Way in March 2011, its producers announced on Wednesday. Continuing Mr. Parker and Mr. Stone's tradition of satirizing every organized religion from Catholicism to Scientology, the musical, called "The Book of Mormon," will juxtapose a tale of two young Mormon missionaries with the story of Joseph Smith, who founded Mormonism in the 19th century (a topic that the "South Park" guys have covered previously on the show). Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker wrote the book, music and lyrics with Mr. Lopez, a Tony Award winner for "Avenue Q," and Mr. Parker will direct with Jason Moore ("Avenue Q," "Shrek the Musical"). Scott Rudin and Anne Garefino will produce "The Book of Mormon"; no cast or theater has been announced.

FOWLER--Bob. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Bob Fowler, a Life Member of our National Board of Governors. Bob's service to Boys & Girls Clubs spanned more than 50 years. In 1965, he helped found the Club in Jacksonville, FL, an experience that established a lifelong commitment to Boys & Girls Clubs and young people. Bob served as chairman of BGCA's Southeast Region for more than two decades, overseeing an era of unprecedented growth. He joined the Board of Governors in 1978, and was named a Life Member in 2002. Over the years, Bob Fowler received numerous accolades for his dedication, including the highest honors BGCA can bestow on volunteers, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian and Distinguished Benefactor Awards. Our hearts go out to his wife Corey who was always by his side and shared her husband's passion for philanthropy. Bob Fowler was an extremely generous and compassionate human being who will be greatly missed by everyone in the Boys & Girls Club family.

STEIGMAN--Jonas. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of Jonas Steigman, beloved father and father-in-law of our dear friends Karen and Robert Spitalnick. The Steigman and Spitalnick families have helped advance biomedical research at Einstein focusing on children's genetic and neurological disorders. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson, Board of Overseers

HONG KONG -- Even though China's leaders appear to have reached a consensus that the nation's currency policy must change, the timing of any shift has been complicated by surging nationalism, a media frenzy in China over the issue and visits by top officials in recent days. China has spent several trillion renminbi in the last 21 months to prevent its currency from rising against the dollar. American lawmakers have become increasingly critical of the policy, complaining that it keeps Chinese exports artificially cheap.
