COHEN--Rosalie Palter, 99, of New Orleans and Cincinnati, died peacefully on April 7. Predeceased by husband Joseph Cohen M.D., and sister Mildred Brown. Mother of Carmel J. Cohen (Babette) and Sharon Leviton (Jim); grandmother of Lisa Cohen Liman (Lewis); Jonathan Cohen (Mariza); and David Leviton. Great-grandmother of five. Inspired by her mentor, the eminent poet and scholar Ephraim Lisitsky, Rosalie became a scholar of Jewish learning and philosophy. She embraced the concept of Tikkun Olam, and created programs and institutions that became the bedrock of the New Orleans Jewish Community. She was the first female president of the Jewish Federation of New Orleans from 1959 to 1961; a cofounder in 1960 of the New Orleans Lemann Stern Young Leadership Group, which educates young Jewish women and men in leadership skills and philanthropy; and, in 1962, of the Home for the Jewish Aged, now Woldenberg Village. She developed educational programs for New Orleans's Jewish women: the New Orleans Enduring Heritage Institute, 19651972; a forum for presidents of Jewish women's organizations, 1980s; and a Torah study group, 19851993. At the national level, she was the first elected female vice president of the American Council of Jewish Federations, 19631965, and she was in the leadership of Hadassah. She was a founding member of the National Foundation for Jewish Culture (NFJC) in 1960. Possessing physical beauty, charm, idealism, and determination, she was just 19 when she and husband Joe honeymooned at the 1929 World Zionist Congress in Zurich, at which the Jewish Agency was born. They were soon (erroneously) reported killed in Arab-Jewish skirmishes in Palestine. 75 years later she became a refugee of Hurricane Katrina. In the years between, she built a family and was a cherished friend and mentor. New Orleans was her home, but the institutions that she inspired extend nationally and internationally. She once said, simply, "I have had a vision of what a Jewish community ought to be, and I felt I had a responsibility." Funeral services were held in New Orleans on Sunday, April 11 at Congregation Shir Chadash.

The field for the 136th running of the Kentucky Derby is finally taking shape, and the most obvious conclusion so far is that it is going to be a rich bunch. Spots in the starting gate are determined by graded stakes earnings, and right now, Homeboy Kris holds the 20th spot with $250,500 in eligible purse money -- the highest total ever for the last spot in the field. Last year, it took only $55,500 for Nowhere to Hide to be the last horse in the Derby field.

Claire Daly travels the country as a jazz saxophonist and teacher. At home in New York, she holes up in a ''whisper room'' in a studio at the old Horatio Seymour Tammany Club building in Chelsea to practice. ''If you close the door behind you,'' she said, ''you cut out about 75 percent of the sound. So it's a great tool for a practicing musician in Manhattan.'' She also rehearses and gives lessons in the building. ''I really don't have neighbors to complain about the noise, so I have been able to have a lot of sessions and music happening here over the years.'' HOWARTH--Dushka, Gurdjieff's Daughter Dies. 1924-2010. Dushka Howarth died on March 28th at the age of 85. The daughter of George Ivanovich Gurdjieff and Jessmin Howarth, Dushka was a multifaceted and highly creative woman: in early life, a publicist for such renown entertainers in the Harlem jazz scene as Nat King Cole and Dick Hymen; later, a talented popular singer with a huge multicultural repertory; still later, returning to her roots, a dedicated teacher and advisor for the Gurdjieff Sacred Dances. She devoted her last years to preserving the heritage of her father and mother, in part by founding the Gurdjieff Heritage Society. Her archival efforts resulted in the publication of a complete set of Gurdjieff's harmonium music in 2005, and soon after recordings of the original orchestral scores for Gurdjieff's Oriental Suite. In 2009, she published a 500 page memoir and family photo album, "It's Up To Ourselves": A Mother, A Daughter, and Gurdjieff. Dushka was truly unique. She will be remembered. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made at: Gurdjieff-Heritage-Society.org. A Celebration of Dushka Howarth's Life will be held on May 21 at 6:30pm at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave. Visit website and RSVP to: celebration@gurdjieff- heritage-society.org.

8 P.M. (HBO2) MAKING THE CROOKED STRAIGHT Dr. Rick Hodes, above, an observant Jew, believes that he who saves one life saves an entire world. He not only treats the sick and poor of Ethiopia -- especially those with tuberculosis of the spine and complex scoliosis -- he also shares his home with 5 adopted children and more than 20 foster children, Christian and Muslim, providing them with a safe environment, medical treatment and an education. This documentary from Susan Cohn Rockefeller examines Dr. Hodes's 20-year mission and unusual family life, as well as the spirituality that guides his work. The film coincides with the publication of ''This Is a Soul: The Mission of Rick Hodes'' by Marilyn Berger, a former reporter for The New York Times. 7 A.M. DORAZIO--Virginia Margaret Dortch, photographer, writer, and devoted mother passed away on April 11, 2010 at The Beth Israel Medical Center, New York. Born in 1925, Virginia grew up outside Little Rock, Arkansas, daughter of Robert L. Dortch and Katherine Morton, on a large family farm. Drawn to painting, she studied art and art history, receiving a B.A. from Columbia University and an M.F.A. from The University of North Carolina. In 1952, she traveled throughout Europe, where in Rome she met her husband, the Italian artist Piero Dorazio. They married in 1953. She witnessed and participated in Italy's burgeoning post-war art scene and spent two decades traveling between Europe and New York, becoming acquainted with many artists and leading figures in the European and American art world, whom she often photographed. She and Piero divorced in 1983, but remained good friends. She authored two books: Balla: An Album of his Life and Work, an early book in English on the Italian Futurist painter, and later, Peggy Guggenheim and her Friends. Though she never forgot Little Rock, she spent her last decades in the city she loved, New York. Eternally curious, she passed many enjoyable hours doing research for her books at the city's great libraries and museums. She will be forever missed by her friends and family for her beautiful blue eyes, warm smile, generous heart, colorful stories, and tart conversation. She is survived by her adoring son, Justin Dortch Dorazio, Samantha Dunham, and three grandchildren, Katherine, Mark, and James. There will be a farewell gathering on Wednesday, April 14, 6-8pm at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue followed on Thursday at 11am by a brief service. Donations in her memory may be made to: The New York Public Library.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - I love clues like "Company with the stock symbol DPZ." I'm sure there are a few day traders out there who knew that answer immediately but for most of us, it's the kind of clue that seems impossible at first. Hmmm. It probably starts with D. But what is that PZ all about? I bet it only took you a few seconds. Same with the 2006 Rihanna song "___ Been the One." I don't know who Rihanna is but by applying a little standard crossword logic, I was able to fill the blank from just the first letter. How about that novel with the chapter "Farming in Polynesia?" You've never read that book but if you've been doing crosswords for a while, you filled in that four-letter answer immediately. Does this mean crosswords are making us smarter? Or just filling our heads with useless trivia? Either way, it's fun.

Wall Street analysts, commenting on positive retail sales numbers, have lately used the term that they've "beat expectations." This is a little like a mother saying of her new son-in-law, "He's not the handsomest, but he's nice." Yes, most department stores and specialty retailers like H & M saw decent sales gains for March. In Paris, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton reported an 11 percent quarterly increase. But this was after a not-so-pretty 2009. And several luxury companies, including LVMH, continue to express caution about the rest of the year. Many people are still out of work, or finding work that pays less.

As a photographer, I work the night shift - when daylight gives way to moonlight, neon, and street light. In cities, especially New York, the darkness awakens me in a way the light of day never can. Gradually, my insomniac wanderings have taken me to the more ambiguous, transitional zones of the city. And I am seeing these not in black and white, as I used to, but in color - as if the visual noise of daytime were transforming itself into haunting nocturnal tonalities.

The Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook may be most famous these days for affordable Swedish design, but a group of artists is giving the once rough-and-tumble peninsula a softer, more creative edge. Their fondness for turning salvaged objects into objets d'art makes the area feel like "a small town of misfit toys," in one resident's words, which might also serve to describe much of the creative class that now lives there. To reach these somewhat inaccessible streets, take the B61 bus to the Red Hook Ikea; the bus runs between Queens Plaza and Red Hook, stopping in Downtown Brooklyn near the Jay Street-Borough Hall subway stop (A, C, F lines) and near the Borough Hall stop (2, 3, 4, 5, M, R). Or take the water taxi to Ikea from Pier 11 near Wall Street.

How do you succeed on Broadway without really trying? It doesn't hurt when you have a star from one of the most successful film franchises in history in a leading role. Daniel Radcliffe, the "Harry Potter" star -- who, in fairness, works hard in all his endeavors, we're sure -- will play the ambitious window washer J. Pierrepont Finch in a revival of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying" that is planned for Broadway in the spring of 2011, its producers announced on Thursday. The musical revival, with music and lyrics by Frank Loesser and book by Abe Burrows, Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert, will be Mr. Radcliffe's first Broadway role since the revival of "Equus" that ran at the Broadhurst Theater in 2008 and 2009. Rob Ashford, ("Promises, Promises"; "Curtains") will direct "How to Succced," and it will be produced by Broadway Across America (John Gore, Thomas B. McGrath, Beth Williams), Craig Zadan and Neil Meron. The original production (with a cast that included Robert Morse and Charles Nelson Reilly) opened in 1961 and ran for more than 1,400 performances; a film version was released in 1967, and a previous Broadway revival, starring Matthew Broderick and Megan Mullally, was mounted in 1995.

Stella McCartney just opened her first store in Milan, on via Santo Spirito in the heart of the city's fashionable shopping district. Housed in an 18th-century building, the store - which was designed by the architects APA in London and J&R Studio in Milan - has a sustainable oak parquet floor, in McCartney's signature color palette, that was designed by Yael Mer and Shay Alkalay of Raw Edges for Established & Sons (www.establishedandsons.com), the furniture company headed by Alasdhair Willis, McCartney's husband. While the store's ground floor is full of decorative touches, the second floor is a study in white on white with accents of bright color like the organic felt cubes that display shoes, and a painted ceiling that is original to the building. Moreover, the design doesn't just look good; it does good, too - McCartney is aiming for LEED certification.

Rescue efforts continued in western China a day after the 7.1-magnitude quake that devastated a county seat on the Tibetan plateau (Slides 1, 2, and 3). The situation left passengers stranded and mostly resigned (Slides 6 and 7) at some of the world's busiest airports.

Among the clognoscenti, a visit with the Portland, Ore.-based Clogmaster, a k a Cecilia Tidlund, is the stuff of legend. Not only can you custom-design clogs from candy-colored, patent and metallic leathers, you'll also receive a custom fitting - maybe even a customized dressing-down about your appalling footwear habits. (Silly me, I wore flip-flops.) Tidlund, a native of Sweden and the founder, in 1976, of one of America's first bespoke clog companies, is an orthopedic-wellness militant à la the Soup Nazi. Which is why, when I phoned Tidlund to solicit her (withering, I was certain) take on one of spring's big trends - the befeathered, begrommeted, open-toed, high-heeled clog (see Miu Miu, above left; Louis Vuitton, above right; and Chanel) - I was surprised that she wasn't entirely negative. First she reminded me that ''we've seen them before.'' Then she added, ''I'd rather people get into a bad fashion clog than a ballet flat or flip-flop. Flimsy shoes are ruining people's feet. I've seen 12-year-olds with bunions.''

Who says poetry doesn't pay? On April 26 and 27, there will be 53 high school students from around the country reciting verse from memory before a panel of judges, vying for the title of Poetry Out Loud Champion and a total of $50,000 in prize money. The competition, a partnership between the Poetry Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts, began last month with contests in all the states (and the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands). The winners of those competitions will go to Washington for the semifinals on April 26; nine students will advance to the finals on April 27. The national champion will get $20,000, the second- and third-place finalists $10,000 and $5,000. Other finalists and semifinalists will also win cash prizes, and the finalists' schools will each receive $500 to buy poetry books. The judges include Garrison Keillor, the poet and critic Adam Kirsch, and last year's national champion. Both the semifinals and the finals will take place at the Lisner Auditorium at George Washington University and are free and open to the public.

Oregon Town Considers Beacon for Big One | Cannon Beach, Ore., a seaside town of 1,500 tucked in the northern corner of Oregon, has tried harder than most places to prepare for a devastating earthquake and subsequent tsunami. It has upgraded warning signs, sirens, evacuation routes, and seismically reappraised bridges and buildings. Now, the community is trying to become the first to build a $4 million seismically sound evacuation tower that could rise over the crest of even 18-foot tsunami waves. While California is often seen as the epicenter of earthquakes in the country, new studies show that parts of the Pacific Northwest, stretching from Northern California to British Columbia, are at even greater risk of a catastrophic earthquake lasting as long as five minutes. Every so often, it pays not to jump all over a potentially contentious celebrity tweet immediately after it appears. Eminem briefly sent his followers into a tizzy when he posted a message on Twitter Wednesday morning on his Twitter feed that read: "There is no Relapse 2." Most readers took this to mean that the rapper would not release a follow-up to his 2009 album "Relapse," the first he had put out since "Encore" in 2004. But a few hours later, Eminem set his loyal fans straight, posting a second message that said only "RECOVERY," and directed followers to his Web site, eminem.com. There, the rapper said that his new album, "Recovery," will be released on June 22 by Aftermath/Interscope Records, and will feature contributions from producers including DJ Khalil, Just Blaze, Jim Jonsin and Boi-1da.

I'm late turning to Jeffrey Goldberg's mammoth New Yorker story on Mark and Delia Owens, a pair of celebrated conservationists who apparently went vigilante in their struggle against poachers in Zambia's North Luangwa National Park, but I wanted both to recommend the piece (it's the fastest-moving 17,000 words you'll read this month), and to remark on how surprised I was, all things considered, to find myself feeling sympathetic toward its off-the-reservation subjects. The tenor is appropriately prosecutorial: Goldberg builds an extensive, persuasive case that the Owenses' much-lauded environmental activism in the Zambian hinterland led to at least one murder, and maybe more. The victim was a poacher; the killers were probably game scouts who were trained by the Owenses as a kind of private army (and encouraged to take the fight to hunters) - and the fatal gunshots, Goldberg plausibly contends, may have been fired by Mark Owens' own son, Christopher. (Remarkably, the murder was captured on camera by an ABC documentary crew sometime in 1995; even more remarkably, it was then broadcast, on an episode of the newsmagazine show "Turning Point" in 1996.)

"Getting rid of the old punitive morality that surrounded sexuality seemed like it would do no one any harm, and relieve a lot of unnecessary anguish and guilt. But young people have not reacted to it as theorised. They will gladly skip the 'morality' part. But in a world as socially competitive as that of teen dating, the 'punitive' part is simply too useful a tool to do without. So people proclaim themselves free of moral hang-ups, and yet throw around words like 'slut' and 'whore' with an abandon that no previous generation ever did. It is unlikely there was any moral disapproval in the taunts to which [Phoebe] Prince was allegedly exposed. It might have been better if there had been. Moral pretensions might have led her alleged tormenters to look at their own conduct, and reined them in. In place of moralism we have nothing but the will to power and the desire to ostracise - a values system that differs from the old one only in its arbitrariness."

PORTLAND, Ore. -- The regular season came to a bizarre end here Wednesday night, in a game between the league's two most injury-depleted teams. As the playoff-bound Trail Blazers mostly rested their key players in a game that had no consequence for their postseason positioning, the low-run Golden State Warriors brought just eight players. Two of them (Ronny Turiaf and Anthony Morrow) were declared unfit to play by the team's trainer during warmups. Midway through the first quarter, center Chris Hunter aggravated his knee. So Coach Don Nelson, who recently became the career victories leader, used five players for the rest of the game.

John Wyatt says he tried to see his newborn daughter the moment he realized that his 20-year-old girlfriend gave birth, but the Virginia hospital lied to him and told him that neither the mother nor the baby was there. By the time he located them, the newborn had been given up for adoption, and while Virginia courts have recognized his right to custody, the state of Utah, where she has been living for more than a year now with her adoptive parents, say he has no claim on the girl.

A film by Doug Liman ("The Bourne Identity," "Mr. & Mrs. Smith") adapted from the memoir of Valerie Plame Wilson, a formerly covert C.I.A. employee, whose identity was unmasked amid the dispute over the Iraq war, will be among the 16 movies shown in competition at the Cannes Film Festival in May, and among the 46 features chosen for the festival, The Hollywood Reporter said. Mr. Liman's film, called "Fair Game," stars Naomi Watts as Ms. Plame and Sean Penn as her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, the former ambassador. Other directors with films showing in competition include Mike Leigh ("Another Year") and Alejandro González Iñárritu ("Biutiful"). The features making their Cannes debut out of competition include Ridley Scott's "Robin Hood," starring Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett; Oliver Stone's "Wall Street 2: Money Never Sleeps"; Woody Allen's "You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger"; and Stephen Frears's "Tamara Drewe." The festival, whose jury will be led this year by Tim Burton, runs from May 12 through 23.

Much as we might rag on it, the awful truth must be looked at head-on: Reality TV, that fiction of verisimilitude, is, even for people who read W. G. Sebald and enjoy grim Scottish films with subtitles, supernally addictive. Not always and (let's hope!) not forever, but in the right now of it. Sure, sometimes one is simply not in the mood for all that virtual id, the jawing and bitching, the glaring white teeth and the faux familiarity. And it is possible to envision a day in the not-too-far-off future when one might return to an old-fashioned pastime, like doing one's nails, over the vicarious pleasures of comparing and contrasting the suntans and blown-out blondness that beset the Real Housewives of Orange County. Meanwhile, though, one stays tuned, fascinated by the mindless commotion, caught on the hook of the souped-up dramas that barge into every episode, unsure whether one is watching a version of oneself or a counter-version or perhaps an alternate version. Which brings me to the question: Who might one be if one were to be played by a reality-show star? Who might one want to be?

On March 17, 1974, the architect Louis I. Kahn died of a heart attack in Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. He was 73. In his briefcase were the final drawings, which he had just completed, for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial to be built on the southern tip of Roosevelt Island. A few weeks later, state officials approved Mr. Kahn's design. They said construction would begin before the end of the year. Even if Mr. Kahn had not died, he almost certainly would never have lived long enough to see any evidence of his design bearing fruit.
van GOETHEM--Loredana, 86, (Zeina) (Tapparelli d'Azeglio, Pavone) died on 12 April 2010. Her husband Pierre survives her.

GINGOLD--Evelyn Block, passed away at the age of 90 on April 14, 2010. She was born in 1920 and graduated from Hunter College in 1941. She became the first Western Union messenger girl and later a cryptographer during g the war. She married Sol Gingold, a dentist and a school friend of her brother, in 1942. They raised three daughters, Arleen, Janet Marcus and Laurie Frankel. They lived in Great Neck amid a large family for over 45 years until Sol's death in 2003. Evelyn lived in Florida since 2004, although she returned to Great Neck in the summer for as long as she was able. She was the last one left in the family of her generation. As well as her daughters she leaves behind three grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

About a month after Dr. Elliot Pellman stepped down from the N.F.L.'s controversial committee on concussions, Major League Baseball announced on Tuesday that Pellman had been replaced as its chief medical director. Gary Green, a professor of sports medicine at U.C.L.A. and baseball's adviser on performance-enhancing drugs for the past seven years, will replace Pellman, according to a statement released by the commissioner's office.

FRANKENHOFF--William Pollner, beloved husband of Jill and father of William and Christine, passed away peacefully at his home on Tuesday April 13th. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale University and was a veteran of WWII. Bill began his career as a management consultant, becoming President of W. E. Hill and later co-founding Combined Capital Management. Bill is survived by his wife, children and grandchildren; Allegra and Felix. A service will be held at St. Thomas More on Friday, April 16th at 2pm.

Fat-fingered Android phone fans may be frustrated by the crowded keyboard of the Motorola Droid, but there is an alternative, the Droid's little brother, the Motorola Devour. The phone is neither small nor lightweight but has one of the most nicely spaced out keyboards on a sliding phone. The weight may be partially due to the chassis, which is extruded aluminum, not silver plastic. Screen navigation is done through an optical navigation pad, reputed to be more reliable than a trackball.

ROOSEVELT--Emily. The extended Roosevelt and Foehl families mourn the death of our dear Emily who passed away suddenly and unexpectedly on April 11, 2010, at home in Park City, Utah. Born in White Plains, New York on August 13, 1969, Emily demonstrated to all who knew and loved her that she would live life to the fullest with no regrets. Empathy, inquisitiveness, courage, and determination defined her daily life. Emily graduated from Whitby School, The Millbrook School, the University of Virginia, and the University of Maine School of Law. She served with distinction as a law clerk for The Honorable Judge Monroe McKay of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Salt Lake City from 1997 to 2000. In 2000, until her death, she worked in the Regional Solicitor's office of the United States Department of the Interior in Salt Lake City, Utah where she worked tirelessly on behalf of public land issues. In June 2008, Emily received the greatest gift of all a new heart. We want to thank the team at University of Utah Hospital for giving her the best care possible. We also extend our profound thanks to Emily's donor and family for giving her a new lease on life. Since receiving her new heart, Emily became an outspoken advocate for organ donation and patient care, helping to raise funds and awareness, supporting others going through the transplant process, and serving as the master of ceremonies for the ribbon cutting of the Patient Care Pavilion at the University of Utah Hospital in July 2009. Emily will be forever missed and celebrated by all her "stars and angels" including her husband, Peter Foehl; her sons Mason and Liam; her parents Chris and Roddy Roosevelt; her sister Kate and her partner Caroline; her brother Chris, his wife Christina, and their sons Noah and Wylie; her in-laws Allen and Sally Foehl; Pete's brother Chas, his wife Sara, and their children Walker and Reed; Pete's brother Dave and his wife Carol; her beloved grandmother Rosalind E. Havemeyer; many uncles, aunts, and cousins; and a huge community of friends and colleagues across the country. Emily would have wanted everyone to become an organ donor (organdonor.gov), rather than sending flowers. You may also honor her life by donating to Intermountain Donor Services (c/o Debbie Snider, IDS, 230 S. 500 E., Ste. 290, Salt Lake City, UT 84102) or the charity of your choice. A celebration of Emily's life will be held on Saturday, April 17 at 4pm at Park City Community Church, 4501 N. Highway 224, Park City, Utah. The family will be providing further information about a memorial service to be held in New England this summer.

CHUTE--Mortimer. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and the employees of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) note with sorrow the death of our friend and colleague Mortimer Chute. Mort served as the Vice President of Development at MSKCC from 1983 to 1999. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family.

MASTERS--Cary Jed, died on Sunday April 11, 2010 in Knoxville, TN. Survived by his parents Joan and Richard, brother William, sister Amy and dear friend Vicki. Cary was a graduate of Berklee College of Music in Boston. He will be missed for the love in his heart and music in his soul. "It's Time To Come Home."

MILLER--Duncan, 85, of Ocean Reef, FL and Black Butte, OR, died at his Florida home on April 1, 2010. He was born in Scarsdale, NY to Clifton Miller and Emily Thompson Miller. He served in the US Army stationed in Puerto Rico. He met his bride 41 years ago and married her in 1976. They have been winter residents of Ocean Reef for the past 40 years, and enjoyed spending the summers in Black Butte, OR. He was an investment advisor on Wall Street and in Connecticut. He was an outdoorsman and an avid fisherman and golfer but his passion was bonefishing. Duncan was predeceased by his parents and a step brother E. Carroll "Stony" Stollenwerck. Duncan is survived by his loving wife Margaret "Peg" and a brother Clifton (Carole) Miller, Jr. of Florida and several nieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed. A private service was held. Beyer Funeral Home was entrusted with the funeral services.
CZUKOR--John. 12/31/16-4/15/05. Lovingly remembered today and every day. Lester

SIEGEL--Richard D.,57, lost his battle with his disease after ten years of a fierce and spirited struggle. He was a great example of hope and perseverance. Beloved husband, father, son, brother, uncle, friend. Funeral Services at Sutton Place Synagogue, Friday, 10am. Burial at Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

MEJIA--Alberto "Tito," passed away on Friday, April 9 due to an accidental drowning while vacationing with friends in Antigua. Tito Mejia grew up in New York City and Locust Valley, NY. He was 25 years old at the time of his death. He attended and graduated from The Buckley School, Deerfield Academy, and Trinity College. He worked as an Investment Associate in the Private Wealth Management Division at UBS in New York. He is survived by his parents, Alberto and Peggy Mejia of New York City and Palm Beach, his brother Alexander Mejia of New York City, his paternal grandmother Julia Hernandez de Mejia of Bogota, Colombia, his aunt and godmother Suzanne Ainslie of Palm Beach, his aunts Julia Elvira Mejia de Pizano, and Olga Mejia de Samper, and his uncle Eduardo Mejia all of Bogota, Colombia. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to the "Tito Mejia Memorial Fund" at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA, 01342. Tito Mejia was a remarkable young man. He will be missed greatly by his family and legions of friends. A Funeral Mass will be held at 1pm on Friday, April 16, 2010 at St. Ann Catholic Church, 310 North Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401. A memorial service is planned in New York City at a later date.

HAMILTON--Robert, on April 14th. Beloved husband of Stella. Loving brother of Norman, Melvin, Joyce and her husband Paul. Devoted son-in-law of Julie, brother-in-law of James and Edward. Will be missed by beloved kitty, Dallulah. Family will receive friends on Thursday 5-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

GRIBETZ--Dr. Donald. The Jewish Community Relations Council of NY mourns the passing of Dr. Donald Gribetz, brother of our esteemed Past President, Judah Gribetz. May the entire Gribetz family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Janice W. Shorenstein President Alan S. Jaffe President-Elect Michael S. Miller Executive Vice Pres. & CEO

SUTPHEN--Martha Rusk, 79, died peacefully of cancer in Sag Harbor, NY, on April 12, 2010. A New York City public school teacher, she leaves her husband, Dr. Richard Stock, her daughters Susan Slowinski, Lucy, Molly, and Ann Sutphen and grandchildren Sam, Simon, Ellie, Nina, and Kara. She was the daughter of the late Dr. Howard and Gladys Rusk. Her first husband, Preston Sutphen, died in 1986. Her family is humbled by the love of her many friends. A Memorial Service will be held at the Century Association (7 West 43rd) on April 19th at 3pm. Memorial contributions can be sent to Doctors Without Borders USA, P.O. Box 5030 Hagerstown, MD 21741 or Peconic Land Trust, PO Box 1776, Southampton NY 11969.

YANKELEWITZ--Rebbetzin Bluma. The entire Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of the devoted loving wife of the revered Rabbi Gershon Yankelewitz, an esteemed senior Rosh Yeshiva of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, who together with him, nurtured a rare generation of children and students, who have distinguished themselves as marvelous teachers of students devoted to Jewish studies. She reared a veritable Dor Yesharim - a generation of upright children. May Rabbi Yankelewitz and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Chancellor Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

Mike Zwerin, a jazz trombonist and bass trumpeter who became a prominent jazz critic and author, died on April 2 in Paris, where he lived, after a long illness. He was 79. The cause was a blood disease, his son, Ben, said.

Seeking solitude? You could do worse than to head to these far corners of the globe. AUSTRALIA Yes, there are less populated places -- the South Pole is perhaps the most extreme option. But for secluded locations you might actually want to live in, Australia is full possibilities. Consider, for starters, the State of the Northern Territory: With a land mass of around 550,000 square miles, it is more than three times the size of California, but has a population of 227,000 (about the same as Birmingham, Ala.). It gets better: More than half of the state's residents live in the capital, Darwin. That leaves the other 549,960 square miles to around 100,000 people. Average it out, and each Outback loner gets 3,520 acres all to him or herself.

LONDON -- UBS's shareholders, frustrated over huge bank bonuses, voted in droves on Wednesday against last year's compensation decisions. Almost 40 percent of UBS shareholders, voting at the company's annual shareholders meeting, rejected the bank's 2009 compensation report, while 55 percent approved it. In previous years, UBS shareholders approved the remuneration policies with a clear majority of more than 80 percent. The vote is nonbinding but a way for investors to express their opinions.

HERSHENHORN--Libby, April 13, 2010. Brooklyn native by way of Havana. Loving mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister and aunt. A woman who lived for her children. She will be remembered forever for her courage and dignity and the values she instilled in us. Sam, Howard and Steven Hershenhorn and family

Flip pocket camcorders have always made it a snap to share video through online social networking and e-mail. The new Flip SlideHD makes it easier to share face t0 face with a pop-out 3-inch widescreen LCD for sharing videos with friends and family. The LCD, which has a resolution of 400-by-240 pixels, is an improvement over the 2-inch LCD on the Flip MinoHD. While the new screen isn't exactly panoramic, it's suitable for quick viewing of videos. The benefit is that you can whip the device out of your pocket and share videos without having to download to a computer or connect via H.D.M.I. cable to a TV. It's meant to wow Grandma, and it probably will.

If you're losing weight, why keep it to yourself? Now the whole world can know, automatically. With the Wi-Fi Connected Body Scale from Withings, a French company, everyone can know your body weight, lean and fat mass, and your B.M.I., or body mass index.

HELLER--Marvin, 85, of Cliffside Park, NJ. A Bronx native, Marvin attended Stuyvesant High School and served in the Army Air Corps during World War II. He attended City College on the GI Bill, graduating with a degree in chemistry. In 1954, he married Ida Melnitsky, a cancer researcher at Sloan Kettering. They later relocated to Teaneck, NJ, where the couple raised three daughters. Marvin founded wall covering adhesives manufacturer Roman Adhesives and served on the board of the Teaneck Public Library. Marvin and Ida moved to Cliffside Park after she suffered a stroke in the early 1990s; she died in 2003. Marvin is survived by his daughters, Amy Heller, Susan Halfon and Karen Key; sons-in-law, Dennis Doros, Neil Halfon and Mark Hoelter; grandchildren, Adam Doros and Rachel and Alyssa Halfon; sister, Eleanor Neulinger; and partner, Larrier Giovine. Marvin was loved by friends, colleagues and family for his charm, generosity, storytelling, joie de vivre and endless supply of puns. The funeral will be held at Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ at 10am on Friday, 16 April, 2010. In lieu of flowers, the family of Marvin Heller asks that mourners contribute to a charity of their choice.

O'NEILL--Cynthia Sumner, September 29, 1949 to April 12, 2010. We love you beyond compare: your wife Elly Thomas, your children Heather and Lorrin O'Neill, your mother Florence Hale, your large family, Lily Bean, and so many others. Service at All Souls Unitarian, 80th and Lexington, New York, Friday, April 16, 2010 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, Institute of Contemporary Psychotherapy, 1841 Broadway, New York, NY 10023.

Hard on the heels of iPad-mania and a new update for the iPhone operating system, Apple continues to ride the product wave this month (and it's only half gone) with the introduction of upgraded MacBook Pro notebook computers that the company says will run at faster speeds and with longer battery lives. The revamped line ranges in size from 13 to 17 inches, with the 15- and 17-inch models running Intel's speedy Core i5 processing chips and a new switching technology that allows the computer to toggle between a pair of graphics chips inside the machine. One is tuned for energy efficiency -- for Web surfing or reading e-mail messages -- and the other is for high-performance, graphics-intensive applications like editing video or playing games.

(Fox Business Network) STOSSELJohn Stossel examines federal income tax codes and tax forms, which have become complicated and costly to file. The guest panel includes the director Christopher Marshall and the screenwriter Vincent Vittorio of ''An Inconvenient Tax''; Mike Tomberlin of Tomberlin Electric Vehicles, whose golf carts qualify for ''green'' tax credits; Gary Milkwick, the vice president for accounting at the Tax Club; and Neal Boortz, a radio host and the author of ''The Fair Tax Book.''

INDIO, Calif. - The afternoon theme du jour is that rap goes with everything -- no surprise, perhaps, when the night's headliner is Jay-Z, who has become the man for all festivals. But the more improbable corollary is that rap-rock, the widely derided late-1990s fusion that dominated FM rock radio for a few tedious years, is recovering some of its early promise. The day's first blast of it was by P.O.S., a Minnesota rapper who details setbacks, struggles, contradictions and small, hard-won successes: "I can never be what I want to be/Nothing but a man," he rapped. His rhymes are fast, with jagged rhythms; his band pounds without steamrollering him, and he keeps his shoutalongs simple enough to keep the crowd with him: "Yeah right!" went one, "Yeah," went another.

The market wasted little time in rushing to a particularly harsh judgment against Goldman Sachs on Friday, slicing some $12.4 billion off the company's market value after the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a blockbuster civil suit against the firm and a vice president who works there. The commission says Goldman failed to disclose to investors how a complicated mortgage-backed security was made and the conflicts that resulted from it.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - You're right, that's a purposely salacious blog post title. Let me atone by tackling the bible clues first because they're both terrific. "Biblical spot" ought to be EDEN but that's not enough letters. There's a lot of complex geography in those testaments but fortunately we don't need to know any of it here as long as we're reading the right translation. Spot is a verb. Thou SEEST? What about "Fall cuisine?" Yes, that's biblical too but APPLE is wrong. I laughed when the answer finally came to me like MANNA from heaven.
